Recommendation for higher risk Alaskans to stay at home as much as possible. Higher risk is defined as (quote) People who are over 60, and anyone who has serious chronic health conditions such as heart and lung disease, and diabetes (quote)

Public Health Disaster Emergency emergency declared. Extended on 20201116 until 20201216: https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/Disaster-Declaration-11.6.2020.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/12.15.2020-COVID-Disaster-Declaration.pdf. Extended to 20210214: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/01.15.21-Disaster-Declaration.pdf. On 20210214, the Public Health Disaster Emergency has been allowed to expire and will not be extended. An order issued by the Governor will serve as a temporary extension to measures still in place until individual policies begin to be phased out by the Legislature and Executive, ordering (quote) 1. All Commissioners and state employees must continue to operate in a manner that prioritizes the health and safety of the citizens of Alaska. 2. All State departments, agencies, or instrumentalities must continue to operate with the same guidance and direction that has previously been provided in order to respond to the effects of COVID-19. 3. All mitigation efforts for the health and safety of State employees remain in effect. 4. By the close of business on Tuesday, February 16, 2021, please provide the Chief of Staff with a summary that evaluates each element of the January 15, 2021 Disaster Declaration that affects your department so that we can prepare to address them in an orderly fashion and conduct a methodical return to normal state operations in a manner that prioritizes the health and safety of Alaskans. (quote). https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/02.14.21-Memo-to-Commissioners-re-Health-and-Safety.pdf

First issuance is schools staying closed until March 30 (i.e., extending spring break), issued 20200313 https://www.alaskapublic.org/2020/03/13/governor-says-all-k-12-students-in-alaska-to-attend-no-contact-school-until-march-30/ ...all public and private schools closed on 20200320 https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/03202020-SOA-COVID-19-Health-Mandate-008.pdf, extended to end of the school year. Alaska Smart Start 2020 framework released on 20200520 and updated document on 20200727. Framework details how school districts can choose to reopen and provides guidance for those determined as low, medium and high risk environments https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf. Grants local districts the authority to determine whether to operate in-person, online, or a hybrid contingent on the school districts assessment of the risk level, ending the SchoolClose: https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf

All state-operated libraries, archives, and museums are to be closed from March 17 through March 31. Expiry date to be coded as 20200401, and then incorporated into the non-essential business closure. Eased on 20200508, permitting reopening at 25 pct capacity: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Mandates that all persons who travel from CDC Level 3 countries or areas with ongoing community spread, such as Europe, stay home and avoid contact with others. (quote) Contact your employer and do not go to work or school for a 14-day period after you return (quote). No expiration date provided. Not listing any locations under AppliesTo at present. Mandates 14 day quarantine for all people arriving in Alaska from anywhere else. A 20200424 health order extends this without any expiry https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf Eased on 20200606: All people arriving in Alaska from outside the state must self-quarantine for 14 days unless the traveler has tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure, or the traveler has a negative test from 5 days before and obtains another negative test upon arrival in Alaska, or the traveler gets tested upon arrival and self-quarantines until results, or the traveler is an Alaskan resident returning from trips of five days or less, or the traveler is a critical infrastructure employee. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/06012020-COVID-MANDATE-010.pdf. The order is expanded on 20200811: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/08062020-COVID-MANDATE-010-REVISED.pdf. Eased on 20201016: The requirement for people flying into Alaska without a negative test is now five days (previously 7-14 days). This means that travelers into the state will no longer have to take a second test to leave quarantine. Also, Alaskans will be able to travel out of state for up to 72 hours without requiring a test, previously 24 hours. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/10152020-COVID-MANDATE-010-REVISED.pdf. Extended on 20201116: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-lnternational-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD3.pdf. Extended to 20210214: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/01.15.21-Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD4.pdf. Ended on 20210214 when Public Health Emergency allowed to expire, replaced with recommendations. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-2-International-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf
Limited operations required: bars and breweries trucks, self-service dining. Easing as part of Phase II on 20200508. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added TakeawayOnly to BusinessRestrictLevel, Removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Business closures are expanded to include all entertainment facilities (including theaters, gyms, bowling alleys, bingo halls). Eased on 20200424, allowing gyms to reopen for outdoor services: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf Last group of businesses permitted to reopen on 20200508, at 25 pct capacity
Limited operations required: restaurants, food trucks, self-service dining. Easing began on 20200424 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added TakeawayOnly to BusinessRestrictLevel, Removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) no gatherings of more than 10 people may take place (quote). Mandated for Fairbanks North Star Borough and Kethikan Gateway Borough only. No expiry provided.

Closure required: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo shops, body piercings, massage therapy, tanning. Mandated for Fairbanks North Star Borough and Kethikan Gateway Borough only.

(quote) No gatherings of more than 10 people may take place (quote), and requires at least 6 ft distancing for gatherings that do occur. No clear exemptions for religious gatherings. Issued 20200323, in effect on 20200324 at 5 pm. Now applies statewide.

Statewide closure required: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo shops, body piercings, massage therapy, tanning. 20200409 update removed expiry of 20200421. Limited operations allowed starting 20200424 conditional on meeting health and safety mandates: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Any family member who is ill with COVID-19 must be immediately isolated in their home or permitted place of residence of isolation (quote). Details how people who exhibit symptoms of COVID-19 must not leave their dwelling within 72 hours of their last fever, and then individuals who have known exposure to indivduals who tested positive for COVID-19 shall self-quarantine for 14 days following the last exposure. Also refers to CDC guidelines https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/03272020-SOA-COVID-19-Health-Mandate-011.pdf. Extended on 20200424 without expiration date https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

(quote) All individuals shall cease participation in public or private gatherings that include non-household members, regardless of the number of people involved. This includes, but is not limited to, weddings, faith gatherings, graduations, and funeral events (quote). Coding as 0 for gathering limits. Extended on 20200421 without an expiration date https://gov.alaska.gov/newsroom/2020/04/21/governor-unveils-path-to-reopening-alaskan-economy/

All non-essential businesses are required to cease activities beyond minimum basic operations. In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. To be reevaluated on 20200411. The 20200424 order allows non-essential businesses to re-open to in-person services conditional on meeting health and safety mandates https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. The 20200424 order indicates the following (quote) Individuals are no longer required to stay home as previously required (quote), effectively ending the order. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry as 20200409 update removed expiry. Added 20200424 as DateEnded as 20200424 order indicates individuals are no longer required to stay at home

PolicyCodingNotes: Travel between communities banned unless for critical personal or infastructure needs. A 20200409 update to health order removed initial expiry. The 20200424 order eased intra-state restrictions, to allow intrastrate travel and outdoor recreation as long as only household members travel together in the same vehicle, groups are limited to 20 people, they adhere to social distancing outside of transport, encouraged to use cloth masks if/when engaging with a third party vendor (eg, stopping for gas or food) https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf On 20200512, policy began substate: https://web.archive.org/web/20200513172554/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05112020-COVID-MANDATE-018-Intrastate-Travel.pdf

Highly recommended for all Alaskans: wear a cloth face covering in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain. On 20200424, strengthened phrasing, (quote) In all gatherings that include multiple households, cloth face coverings should be worn by all participants (quote): https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

Face coverings must be worn by all employees and patrons in businesses. On 20200508, eases business mask requirements, now only requiring masks to be worn at personal care services. Cloth face coverings are now strongly encouraged at other sectors that have re-opened (retail, gyms, restaurants, etc) https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf. On 20200722, expands business mask requirements, now requiring employees at state buildings to wear face coverings (in addition to personal care services): (quote) the following workplace policy is being implemented by the Office of the Governor: All employees, contractors, and visitors to State of Alaska facilities must wear a facemask if social distancing of at least six feet or more between individuals cannot be maintained. This applies to entryways, hallways, stairwells, elevators, enclosed parking areas, and personal offices where a six-foot distance cannot be exercised. (quote) http://doa.alaska.gov/dop/fileadmin/DirectorsOffice/COVID19messages/072220_GovernorMemo_FaceCover.htm

Non-essential businesses (such as professional services) can resume operations if they limit their capacity to 25 pct or 20 customers, meet specified social distancing requirements, hygiene protocols, staffing requirements, cleaning and disinfecting. Retail businesses have same protocols and 25 pct capacity limit, but also are encouraged to do entryway, curbside and home delivery, telephone and online ordering for contactless pickup and delivery, cashless and receiptless transactions. Personal care services are also permitted to reopen with no more than 10 people, required distancing etc., as can loding and overnight camps https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf Further eased on 20200508, allowing for 50 pct capacity: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf

Effective 20200424, gyms, fitness centers, sports, and recreational facilities can open outdoor for workouts with a maxiumum 20 people. Face coverings are required by employees and social distancing of at least ten feet must be maintained while exercising between individuals. Fishing Charters may also resume operations. If patrons are household members, the charter may be for the full legal load/capacity of the boat or vessel. If patrons are non-household members, fishing charters may only take the number of patrons that can maintain social distancing requirements if their vessel is not large enough to allow each patron and crewmember to social distance at legal load/capacity. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf. Both coded to OutdoorOnly for BusinessRestrictLevel

Requires patrons to wear cloth face coverings when at retail businesses, personal care services (except for being able to be removed for a short time during necessary services, otherwise, must be worn at all other times including when entering and exiting the shop). Also includes the following under indoor gatherings: (quote) At gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, when possible. (quote) Coding to a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to very limited settings. Mask mandate is no longer in effect as on 20200522 with Alaska going to Phase 3: https://gov.alaska.gov/newsroom/2020/05/19/governor-announces-phase-three-of-reopen-alaska-responsibly-plan/

Restaurants may resume table-service dining if they meet all health and safety requirements, including limiting capacity to 25 pct indoors and limiting groups to household members only. Outdoors can only have up to 20 tables. In addition to requirements, encouraged to continue entryway, curbside and home delivery, telephone and online ordering, cashless and receiptless transactions, and having customers enter and exit through different doors (one way traffic). Eased on 20200508, allowing for 50 percent capacity indoor and no more than 20 tables outdoor. Bar seating in restaurant areas is limited to 25 pct. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf. Ended on 20200522 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-Alaskas-Plan-Forward-Final.pdf

No gathering larger than 20 people is allowed, which includes the minimum number of necessary personnel to facilitate the event, or 25 percent maximum occupancy (whichever is smaller). Gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, whenver possible. Also applies to religious gatherings.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on bar closures allowing service at 25 percent if health and safety protocols are followed. Groups are limited to household members only and tables must be at least ten feet apart. Ended on 20200522 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-Alaskas-Plan-Forward-Final.pdf

Part II of recovery phase includes prohibition on gatherings of 50 or more. Ended 20200522, as as gathering limits became a recommendation https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-Alaskas-Plan-Forward-Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEased and added DateEnded of 20200522, updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on gyms, fitness centers, sports, and recreational facilities, which can now have up to 25 pct capacity indoor. Outdoor activity is limited to 50 people. Workout equipment should be spaced 10 feet apart, encourages mask wearing.

Eases restrictions on libraries, museums and archives, venues of amusement (eg, bowling alleys, theaters), allowing 25 pct capacity indoor. Also permits swimming pools to re-open at up to 50 pct capacity.

Prohibits intra-state travel to communities that are not located on the Road System (i.e., any community connected by a road to the Seward, Parks, Klondike, Richardson, Sterling, Glenn or Top of the World Highways), Alaska Marine Highway System or the Inter-Island Ferry System. Ended on 20200605: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05112020-COVID-MANDATE-018-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
Any proposed large public gatherings such as festivals and concerts need to consult first with public health before scheduling.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Alaskans are now encouraged to wear a face mask whenever in public

(quote) the following workplace policy is being implemented by the Office of the Governor: All employees, contractors, and visitors to State of Alaska facilities must wear a facemask if social distancing of at least six feet or more between individuals cannot be maintained. This applies to entryways, hallways, stairwells, elevators, enclosed parking areas, and personal offices where a six-foot distance cannot be exercised. (quote) Coding to a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to very limited settings.

(quote) Any person currently positive with COVID-19 cannot travel to Alaska until they have been released from isolation or cleared for travel by a medical provider or public health agency. (quote) Extended on 20201116: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-lnternational-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD3.pdf. Extended to 20210214: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/01.15.21-Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD4.pdf. Although the Public Health Emergency has been allowed to expire, this travel restriction has been temporarily extended until the Legislature or Executive orders them ended. Coded with no DateExpiry. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-2-International-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf

(quote) Wearing a cloth face covering is strongly recommended for all Alaskans 2 years of age and older, other than those with breathing problems and those who cannot remove the covering without assistance. (quote) Coding separately from public mask mandate. No expiration date.

The following testing or quaratine protocols are recommended for international and interstate travelers: travelers should submit negative test results into the Alaska Travel Portal or upon arrival to airport screeners, take a second test between five and fourteen days after arrival, take a test at the airport if no test taken prior arrival, practice social distancing until results are obtained, and self-monitor for symptoms for fourteen days after arrival. Test no longer required for residents traveling out of state for more than 72 hours. Includes exemptions for fully-vaccinated travelers who (quote) should follow pre-travel testing protocols, but do not need to follow strict social distancing while they are awaiting test results. b. Fully-vaccinated is defined as more than two weeks following receipt of the second dose in a two-dose series, or more than two weeks following receipt of one dose of a single-dose vaccine. (quote) As EmergDec has been allowed to expire, this order serves as a temporary mitigation measure, with no DateExpiry provided. Lists US states and the District of Columbia under AppliesTo

A series of recommendations are provided for intrastate travel, including obtaining a test three days prior to travel on the Road System and Alaska Marine Highway System and following strict social distancing until negative results are received or for fourteen days if no test is available. Prohibits anyone who is currently infected from traveling until (quote) cleared from isolation by a medical professional (quote), while (quote) asymptomatic people who have recovered from a documented SARS-CoV-2 infection within the past 90 days are exempt from travel testing. (quote) Also provides intrastate travel protocol for fully-vaccinated travelers who (quote) should follow pre-travel testing protocols, but do not need to follow strict social distancing while they are awaiting test results. i. Fully vaccinated is defined as more than two weeks following receipt of the second dose in a two-dose series, or more than two weeks following receipt of one dose of a single-dose vaccine. (quote) No DateExpiry provided. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf On 20210426 Slightly eases recommendations for intrastate travel, including obtaining a test pre-travel on the Road System and Alaska Marine Highway System and following strict social distancing until negative results are received or for ten days (from 14) if no test is available. No longer prohibits anyone who is currently infected from traveling until (quote) cleared from isolation by a medical professional (quote). (quote) Asymptomatic people who have recovered from a documented SARS-CoV-2 infection within the past 90 days are not recommended to pre-travel test nor test upon arrival. (quote) Also provides intrastate travel protocol for fully-vaccinated travelers who (quote)do not need to get tested before or after travel and do not need to self-quarantine after travel. i. Fully vaccinated is defined as more than two weeks following receipt of the second dose in a two-dose series, or more than two weeks following receipt of one dose of a single-dose vaccine. (quote) https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/04.26.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added VaccineExempt, Updated PolicyCodingNotes, Added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Public Health Emergency declaration. No formal expiry provided, (quote) will be eligible for termination upon the resolution of the outbreak as determined by the Arizona Department of Health Services (quote)

Public school closure. Statewide closure of all schools as of 20200320. Extended to the end of the academic year on 20200330 https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/03/governor-ducey-superintendent-hoffman-announce-extension-school-closures Extended through 20200817 https://azgovernor.gov/file/35148/download?token=jFLDklga Open for Learning plan announced on 20200723 which eases school closures on public and charters, but does not eliminate them completely (quote) all districts shall begin distance learning beginning August 17 (quote) https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/07/arizona-open-learning
Limited operations required (take-away, delivery, etc. only if the proper licenses were provided): bars (for places in counties with COVID19), to be enacted on 20200320.
Closure required: movie theaters, indoor gyms, fitness clubs, bars. In effect at close of business on 20200320. Only applicable to counties with confirmed COVID-19
Limited operations required (take-away, delivery, etc only): restaurants (for places in counties with COVID19), to be enacted on 20200320.

Via stay-at-home order, bar operations limited to delivery, takeout etc (conditional on proper licensing) for all counties. Mandate ended on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

First gathering restriction activated with stay-at-home order. Extended to 20200516 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34712/download?token=aWa7Jw6L. Ended on 20200516 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf (shall maximize physical distance has now become should) Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited from 20200629 Extended gathering restrictions to limit gatherings to 50 people on 20200723 https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2020-52_continuation_of_eo_2020-43.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateReexpanded1 based on new gathering row.

PolicyCodingNotes: Via stay-at-home order, earlier business closures became applicable to all counties and additional ones occurred (i.e., in-person retail, close contact personal services). Easing began on 20200504, allowing retailers to have curbside pick up https://azgovernor.gov/file/34712/download?token=aWa7Jw6L . Ended mandated business restrictions on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf
Via stay-at-home order, restaurant operations became limited to delivery, takeout etc for all counties. Easing began on 20200511 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34745/download?token=kz_fRE5B
(quote) All indiviudals in the State of Arizona shall limit their time away from their place of residence (quote). Mandate ends on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Quarantine on any individuals entering Arizona from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut as points of travel origin. Quarantine is 14 days long with exceptions for essential service providers. Ends on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo-2020-24.pdf

Allows retailers not classified as essential to operate and offer goods through delivery, window, walk-up, drive-through, drive-up, or appointment if establish and implement protocols to address COVID19. Eases to allow for indoor services on 20200508: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Further eases restrictions on non-essential retail to permit in-person services at stores provided they establish and implement protocols to address COVID-19. Also requires the continuance of limited operations (i.e., delivery and curbside) for indoor malls. Also permits barbers and cosmetologists to reopen at this time. Ends all mandated restrictions starting on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Requires protocols for resuming in-person operations for barbers and cosmetologists, including using face coverings for employees and customers. Starting in 20200810, requires more businesses to have masks mandated for bars, restaurants, gyms, etc: https://www.azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/community/bars-nightclubs-dine-in.pdf Ended on 20210325 https://azgovernor.gov/file/37347/download?token=VU8JnhRg

Allows for dine-in services provided dining establishments enact physical distancing policies, limit the number of diners, and follow protocols as directed by CDC and the Arizona Department of Health Services. Ended on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

(quote) All individuals, when in public areas, should maximize physical distance from others. Social settings where appropriate physical distancing is not practical should be avoided unless precautionary measures are observed and CDC guidelines are followed (quote)

(quote) All vulnerable individuals, including the elderly and individuals with underlying health conditions, are advised to take reasonable steps to continue limiting their time away from their place of residence or property (quote)

Indicates that any jurisdiction (county, city, town) may adopt policies regarding face coverings in public for the purpose of mitigating the spread of COVID-19. Considered a recommendation at present based on the EO and accompanying press release about increasing awareness about face-covering https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/06/governor-ducey-announces-enhanced-covid-19-action-plan

Bars are required to close for on-premises consumption, but permits them to operate for pick-up, delivery, and drive-thru operations if they have the proper license. Eased on 20200827, as counties start moving beyond red transmission status: https://directorsblog.health.azdhs.gov/positive-news-for-az-counties-in-the-moderate-transmission-level-moving-into-next-phase-of-safely-reopening/

Re-introduces gatherings restrictions and specifies a limit of 50 people, exempting religious gatherings. Extended to 20200810: https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2020-52_continuation_of_eo_2020-43.pdf Extended beyond 20200810: https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/08/arizona-department-health-services-phased-reopening-plan-paused-industries Slightly eased on 20201203.Public events of more than 50 remain prohibited unless the city, town or county has determined that adequate safety precautions are document as part of the request.    https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/executive_order_2020-59.pdf Ended on 20210325 https://azgovernor.gov/file/37347/download?token=VU8JnhRg

Indoor gyms, fitness clubs, indoor movie theaters, nightclubs, water parks shall cease their activities. Licenses for festivals, fairs, special events are suspended. Began easing on 20200827: https://directorsblog.health.azdhs.gov/positive-news-for-az-counties-in-the-moderate-transmission-level-moving-into-next-phase-of-safely-reopening/

All school districts and charter schools shall develop and implement a policy to require face coverings, such as face masks or face shields, for all staff and students over the age of 5. Rescinded on 20210419: https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-10.pdf.

As counties move to yellow and green transmission status, bars can re-open for in-person services at 50 capacity. Further, counties at moderate transmission level (yellow) cannot have bars open for onsite services unless they operate as a restaurant (i.e., have a formal food license). As such, counties in yellow and red transmission levels are considered having bars broadly closed for onsite services (takeaway only).

Counties classified as yellow and green transmission levels allowing indoor gyms and like venues to re-open (25 pct for yellow, 50 pct for green), and movie theaters, water parks, tubing may re-open at 50 pct capacity with additional mitigation requirements. On 20210305, all capacity limits are removed for all transmission levels. https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-05.pdf

Six counties remain at the substantial transmission level (red), continuing the following restrictions: licenses for festivals, fairs, special events are suspended. Indoor gyms, fitness clubs, indoor movie theaters, water parks shall cease their activities.These counties are: Gila, Graham, Mohave, Pinal, Santa Cruz, and Yuma. Nightclubs also remain closed in both yellow and red levels.

Greenlee moves back to moderate transmission level (yellow), bringing these restrictions statewide: bars cannot operate have onsite premises unless they operate as restaurants, and thus statewide, bars are limited to takeaway, drive-through, delivery, etc. On 20201218, Department of Health announces change to benchmarks, where the substantial transmission level (red) is the same as the moderate transmission level (yellow). Because all counties are currently at substantial (red) risk levels, this means bars cannot reopen for onsit services unless they operate as restaurants: https://media.kjzz.org/s3fs-public/covid-19-in-az-week-of-dec-14.pdf. On 20210305, capacity restrictions for all transmission levels are ended. Bars at moderate (orange) and substantial (red) risk levels still cannot reopen for onsite services unless they operate as restaurants. However, for bars that continue to operate as a bar, they can now open indoors and operate with no capacity limits if they reach minimal (green) transmission level. Currently all counties are at either moderate or substantial level. Physical distancing and mask measures remain in place. https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-05.pdf Ended on 20210325 https://azgovernor.gov/file/37347/download?token=VU8JnhRg

Greenlee moves back to moderate transmission level (yellow), closing nightclubs. Joins other counties with these restrictions and makes this a statewide policy. Ended on 20210325 https://azgovernor.gov/file/37347/download?token=VU8JnhRg

Department of Health announces change to benchmarks, where the substantial transmission level (red) is the same as the moderate transmission level (yellow). Because all counties fall into these levels, these restrictions are statewide. Gyms and like venues can re-open at 25 pct capacity with additional mitigation requirements, and movie theaters, water parks, tubing may re-open at 50 pct capacity with additional mitigation requirements. Ended on 20210305 https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-05.pdf

The business guidance has transitioned from requirements to recommendations. Businesses are encouraged to continue to take actions recommended by the CDC, US Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration and ADHS to limit and mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Businesses have the ability to continue requiring masks and social distancing. ADHS encourages both customers and employees to wear masks.

State of emergency declared, with a duration of no more than 30 days. Declares a disaster area emergency on 20200326, which extends emergency declarations and powers for an additional 45 days. Is then extended for 60 days on 20200618: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-37.pdf Extended for 20 days on 20201211: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-51.pdf Extended to 20210227: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-53.pdf. Extended to 20210401: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_21-03.pdf. Extended to 20210531 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_21-07_Emergency_Extension.pdf. Ended on 20210531 https://governor.arkansas.gov/news-media/press-releases/governor-hutchinsons-weekly-address-getting-across-the-covid-finish-line

(quote) the Arkansas Department of Health, in coordination with the Arkansas Department of Education, is closing all public schools in Grant, Jefferson, Pulaski, and Saline Counties. ...only schools in these four counties are being closed because of COVID-19. (quote). Extracurricular activities are also postponed.

Statewide closure of Arkansas K-12 public schools. In effect for two weeks. Students can return after their spring break on 20200330. Extended to 20200417: https://web.archive.org/web/20200324155352/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Directive_03.19.2020_final.pdf Extended to the end of the academic year: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-13._.pdf Eased on 20200601, permitting school-based sporting activites to resume: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528084038/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive__team_sports__.pdf

Limited operations required (allowed to remain open for carry-out, drive through, and delivery): bars. Expiry is linked to the powers given to the Department of Health during the emergency, so the same expiry dates apply to directives. Eased on 20200526, permitting bars to re-open at 33 pct: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528084032/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_bars_and_clubs.pdf

The following businesses must close: gyms, indoor entertainment venues (eg, bowling alleys, trampoline parks, indoor amusement centers, clubs). Expiry is linked to the powers given to the Department of Health during the emergency, so the same expiry dates apply to directives.

Limited operations required (allowed to remain open for carry-out, drive through, and delivery): restaurants. Expiry is linked to the powers given to the Department of Health during the emergency, so the same expiry dates apply to directives. Eased on 20200511 to permit onsite services: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Resume_Restaurant_Dine_In_May_11_directive_FINAL.pdf

The following businesses must close: personal care services (barbers, body art establishments, cosmetology establishments and massage therapy clinics/spas, and medical spas). Expiry is linked to the powers given to the Department of Health during the emergency, so the same expiry dates apply to directives.

Prohibits gatherings of 10 indoors and outdoors, but expressly exempts places of worship (which are advised to maintain at least 6 ft distancing). Eased to permit larger outdoor gatherings on 20200504: https://web.archive.org/web/20200612201628/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_large_outdoor_venues.pdf

(quote) ADH is now recommending self home quarantine for 14 days for all travelers from New York State and all international locations. This is due to high rates of COVID-19 in New York as well as in a growing number of international locations. In the interest of the public health, all travelers who return from one of these locations are advised to quarantine at home for 14 days, starting from the date they left that location (quote) Added Connecticut and New Jersey on 20200330: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/NY-NJ-CT-NO-Intl_Self_Home_Quarantine.final.3.30.20.pdf

(quote) casinos shall remain closed (quote), which is now considered a formal mandate for casino closure as the prior health directives were framed in terms of recommendations (quote) casinos should close (quote)
(quote) Everyone should wear a face covering, or mask, in public (quote)
Recommends staff of gyms and fitness centers to wear a mask at all times. Recommends that patrons do as well except when actively exercising.

Effective 20200504, gyms and fitness centers can reopen but with extensive guidelines, maintaining at least 6 ft distancing, having at least 12 ft distancing in group fitness classes. Prohibits use of spas, saunas. Further eases under Phase 2, allowing pools, spas, saunas to reopen: https://web.archive.org/web/20200616230431/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_gym_phase_II.pdf

Expands busines mask requirement to a mandate for for staff who come in contact with patrons and then patrons must wear face coverings upon entrance and while in the restaurant until food or drink is served. Continues to recommend the use of masks at gyms and like venues. As more sectors reopen, more require mask use by employees and patrons. With the statewide mask mandate on 20200720, broadly applies to indoor settings and outdoor settings when 6 ft distancing cannot be maintained: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-43.pdf. Extended to 20210401: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_21-03.pdf. Ended on 20210401 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Face_Covering_GuidanceFINAL3.31.21.pdf

Starting 20200511, dine-in services can resume under Phase 1 restrictions and guidelines: seating limited to up to 33 percent total of capacity, maintaing at least 10 ft distancing between tables, all staff that come in contact with patrons must wear masks, all staff must wear gloves, patrons have to wear face coverings upon entry and while in the restaurant until the food or drink, all tables and chairs etc must be cleaned and disinfected after each customer, and more. Expiry is linked to the powers given to the Department of Health during the emergency, so the same expiry dates apply to directives. Eased on 20200615 to permit up to 66 pct capacity: https://web.archive.org/web/20200616230431/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive__restaurant_dine-in.pdf On 20201120, requires restaurants that sell alcohol to close by 11 pm: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Alcoholic_Beverage_Control_on-premise_permitted_locations.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions, permitting up to 50 people to gather outdoors: (quote) directive covers outdoor venues for commercial, community, or civic events and activities where an audience, spectators, or a gathering of people are present (quote). Indoor gatherings remain limited to no more than 10, exempts religious gatherings. Eased on 20200518, permitting up to 50 people indoors: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518220537/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_large_indoor_venues.pdf

Large outdoor venues, such as theatres, arenas, sports venues, race tracks, stadiums, auction houses, amusement centers, and fair grounds may reopen for events with up to 50 people in attendence. Seating must be arranged to ensure 6 feet between members of audience. Eased on 20200518, permitting both indoor and outdoor services to resume: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518220537/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_large_indoor_venues.pdf

Eases restrictions on in-person operations for barbers, body art establishments, cosmetology establishments, massage therapy. In smaller facilities, the 6 ft physical distancing condition may require that fewer than 10 persons are present at any given time. Larger facilities (able to accommodate more than 10 persons while maintaining appropriate physical distancing) shall operate no more than 30 pct of their stations. Further eased on 20200615, allowing more than 10 persons at a time in smaller facilities and up to 66 pct for larger facilities: https://web.archive.org/web/20200621173255/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_barbers_and_cosmo.pdf

(quote) A 14-day self-quarantine is required for travelers entering Arkansas who have visited an international location or an area of high community transmission in the United States in the previous 14 days. (quote), which are considered Connecticut, New Jersey, New York. Expands to a mandate. Ends on 20200615: https://web.archive.org/web/20200616230431/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_business_limitations_phase_II.pdf

Further eases gathering restrictions, permitting up to 50 people indoors and outdoors, per the directive applying to (quote) venues for commercial, community, or civic events and activities where an audience, spectators, or a gathering of people are present (quote). Exempts religious gatherings. Eased on 20200615, permitting up to 100 people indoors and outdoors: https://web.archive.org/web/20200624055534/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Large_Indoor_Venues.pdf

Eases restrictions on indoor only entertainment venues, allowing them to re-open to in-person services if they follow the directive guidelines (e.g., 33 percent capacity maximum, social distancing, face coverings for all attendees, hand sanitizer stations at entries). Applies to venues including: bowling alleys, trampoline parks, indoor amusement centers. Further eased on 20200615 with Phase 2, allowing up to 66 pct capacity: https://web.archive.org/web/20200624055534/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Large_Indoor_Venues.pdf Re-expanded these restrictions on 20210102, requiring locations to have no more than 10 people in a single room unless they apply for and get approval: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_indoor_venues_amended_1.2.21.pdf. Eases these restrictions on 20210215, requiring locations to have no more than 100 people in a single room unless they apply for and get approval: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_large_indoor_venue_amended_21521.pdf

Eases restrictions on casinos, allowing them to re-open to in-person services if they follow directive guidelines (eg, reopening at not more than 33 percent capacity, ensure 6 ft distancing for everyone) and submitting a formal plan to the Secretary of Health. Further eased on 20200615, permitting them to operate up to 66 pct capacity: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618154440/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_casinos_phase_II.pdf

Further eases restrictions on large venues, allowing both indoor and outdoor venues to reopen at 33 percent capacity for the facility with a plan approved by the Secretary of Health. Fifty (50) people or fewer in attendance is allowed without a requirement to submit a plan. Applies to theatres, arenas, sports venues, race tracks, stadiums, auction houses, amusement centers, etc. Further eased on 20200615, permitting up 66 pct capacity or up to 100 people: https://web.archive.org/web/20200624055534/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Large_Indoor_Venues.pdf Re-expanded these restrictions on 20210102, requiring locations to have no more than 10 people in a single room unless they apply for and get approval: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_indoor_venues_amended_1.2.21.pdf. Eases these restrictions on 20210215, requiring locations to have no more than 100 people in a single room unless they apply for and get approval: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_large_indoor_venue_amended_21521.pdf

Requires face coverings for all persons (exempting children under 10) at indoor venues including (quote) auditoriums, lecture halls, movie theatres, other theatres, museums, arenas, sports venues, race tracks, stadiums, gymnasiums, auction houses, amusement centers, barns, exhibit halls, conventions centers, and funeral homes. Examples also include recreational facilities, such as bowling alleys and trampoline parks. Prior directives also require face coverings by patrons at restaurants and large outdoor venues. Coded as Mandate1 as these directives apply to specific types of venues rather than a broad mandate across settings.

Eases restrictions to allow onsite services at bars, with seating up to 33 pct of total capacity in indoor and outdoor areas. Must have physical distancing between tables (10 ft), staff must wear masks, etc. Further eases restrictions on 20200615, permitting up to 66 pct capacity: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618065144/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_bars_phase_II.pdf

Eases restrictions on nightclubs, permitting them to reopen to 33 pct of total capacity (indoors and outdoors), seating only, tables at least 10 ft apart, required masking, etc. Further eased to permit up to 66 pct capacity: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618065144/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_bars_phase_II.pdf

Eases school restrictions, permitting school-based sporting events can happen and laying out specific guidelines based on indoor/outdoor sports, kind of contact, etc. (quote) Onsite instruction still prohibited. Ended on 20200824, with Governor Hutchinson announces 2020-2021 school year will begin week of August 24, ending the school closure. Policy source reflects media coverage of original presser.     https://arktimes.com/arkansas-blog/2020/07/21/coronavirus-today-schools-will-open-as-currently-scheduled

Further eases gathering restrictions, permitting up to 100 people indoors and outdoors for (quote) venues for commercial, community, or civic events and activities where an audience, spectators, or a gathering of people are present (quote). Exempts religious gatherings

(quote) All students age 10 and over are strongly recommended to wear a face covering at all times while on the bus. It is recommended that students under the age 10 wear a face covering where practical, due to the bus being a confined area where physical distancing is not feasible. (quote) Further, under the when schools are open and operating section, school staff are recommended to wear 3-ply masks

Requires (quote) every person in Arkansas to wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing. (quote) Exemptions are for children younger than 10, individuals whose medical condition or disability prevent them from wearing a face covering, exercisng, at worship or religious services. Technically does not apply to counties where no newly identified cases for 28 straight days, but without further details on these counties, we are currently coding as statewide. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor environments and outdoor settings unless physical distancing is practiced. Extended to 20201015 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-45.pdf. Extended another 60 days through 20201213 so coded as 20201214: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-48.pdf. Extended to 20201231: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-51.pdf. Extended to 20210227: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-53.pdf. Extended to 20210401: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_21-03.pdf. Ended on 20210401 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Face_Covering_GuidanceFINAL3.31.21.pdf

In conjuction with the broader mask mandate, requires every person 10 years of age and older to wear a face covering completely over the mouth and nose in both indoor environments and outdoor settings when distancing of six feet or more cannot be assured. Drivers must wear a face covering. Extended to 20210401: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_21-03.pdf. Ended on 20210401 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Face_Covering_GuidanceFINAL3.31.21.pdf

Amends bar restrictions, requiring that they close by 1100 pm. Otherwise extends eased restrictions on bars, permitting them to reopen at 66 pct capacity of total seating capacity (indoor and outdoor). Still requires at least 6 ft between tables, seated services only, required use of masks for patrons and staff, etc.

Expands gathering restrictions, requiring indoor venues to have no more than 10 people in a single room or gathering unless they successfully submit and are approved for formal plans. Continues permission to have up to 100 people outdoors for formal planning.

Eases gathering restrictions, requiring indoor venues to have no more than 100 people in a single room or gathering unless they successfully submit and are approved for formal plans. Continues permission to have up to 100 people outdoors for formal planning.
Gathering directives have been converted into guidelines. Indoor guidelines state that event capacity should be based on ability to maintain 6ft social distancing.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and Deleted DateExpiry and DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Mask mandate is replaced with a recommendation. Every person in Arkansas SHOULD wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing.

Business mask mandate (implied by statewide public mask mandate) is replaced with a recommendation. Every person in Arkansas SHOULD wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing.

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who do not need to wear masks in any settings. Every unvaccinated person in Arkansas should wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing.

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who do not need to wear masks in any settings. Every unvaccinated person in Arkansas SHOULD wear a face covering completely over the mouth and nose in both indoor environments and outdoor settings when distancing of six feet or more cannot be assured.
Declares new state of disaster emergency related to public health, to expire in 60 days unless ended earlier or renewed by the Arkansas Legislative Council.
State of Emergency proclamation. No clear expiry provided.
California Department of Public Health issed guidance recommending the cancellation of gatherings of 250 or more. http://www.tcoe.org/GatheringGuidance.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Local school closures only (according to NGA). From KFF (quote) While the CA governor has not officially mandated the statewide closure of schools, the states mandatory quarantine order effectively closes all schools. (quote) Not currently coding as school closure mandate since a separate mandate did not occur. On 20200331, superintendent announces that students will not be able to return for the rest of the academic year - distance learning will continue.
(quote) All gatherings should be postponed or cancelled (quote). Coded as recommendation from CDPH
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Bars, wineries, breweries, and pubs must be closed unless authoritized for take-away sales. Began easing on 20200612, allowing counties that completed advanced Phase 2 attestation to re-open bars, wineries, and tasting rooms.

Gathering restriction without numerical limits instituted with the enactment of the stay-at-home order. Governor does not set numerical limits at the state-level, defers to counties to do this. Houses of worship are required to close for all indoor services, so coding as 0 under InGathLimReligious

Identifies 16 critical sectors to remain open, otherwise all businesses must close. No clear expiry provided. Easing of certain businesses under Stage 2 Reopening: retail (curbside and pick-up), manufacturing, offices, select services (carwash, pet grooming, landscape gardening), outdoor museums and open gallery places. https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf

Limited operations required (take-out, delivery) for restaurants and like establishments. No in-person services. Easing began with Phase 2 attestation processes: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx.

Issued/enacted immediatedly. Note shelter-in-place and stay-at-home are being treated as equivalent at present. Considered an eased mandate starting 20200508: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf Coded as ending on 20200831, since the most restrictive tier still permits many types of non-essential activities and visitation of non-essential businesses as part of the Blueprint for a Safer Economy: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/8-28-20_Order-Plan-Reducing-COVID19-Adjusting-Permitted-Sectors-Signed.pdf

Provides guidance around using face coverings - defaults to county policies, some of which are mandates (documentation of this may occur in the future) - but indicates that individuals should wear coverings if they feel comfortable doing so if counties do not have formal recommendations or mandates. Treating as a statewide recommendation

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing resumption of limited in-person services conditional on health and safety requirements: manufacturing, offices, select services (carwash, pet grooming). Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing limited outdoor services to resume conditional on health and safety requirements: landscape gardening, outdoor museums and open gallery places. Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing limited services via takeaway conditional on health and safety requirements: retail (curbside and pick-up). Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

The following counties have completed attestation as of 20200518, and thus could move more eased restrictions on more types of businesses (in-person retail services and malls): Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Glenn, Humbolt, Inyo, Lassen, Mariposa, Modoc, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, San Benito, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yuba-Sutter. Note that each county has a separate attestation plan and thus could have eased earlier, and thus further reivew is needed to decipher exact timing - this is ongoing work.

The following counties have completed attestation as of 20200518, and thus could move to ease restrictions on restaurants (i.e., dine-in services are permitted): Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Glenn, Humbolt, Inyo, Lassen, Mariposa, Modoc, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, San Benito, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yuba-Sutter. Note that each county has a separate attestation plan and thus could have eased earlier, and thus further reivew is needed to decipher exact timing - this is ongoing work.

Eases restrictions on indoor religious gatherings, permitting houses of worship to re-open to 25 pct or up to 100 attendees, whichever is lower. Public and social gathering restrictions remain without explicit numeric limits, counties set these themselves.

Requires mask use for employees at hair salons and barbershops as they reopen. On 20200618, mandating that people in California must wear a face covering when (quote) engaged in work, whether at the workplace or performing work off-site, when interacting in-person with any member of the public, working in any space visited by members of the public, regardless of whether anyone from the public is present at the time, working in any space where food is prepared or packaged for sale or distribution to others...in any room or enclosed area where other people (except for members of the persons own household or residence) are present when unable to physically distance (quote). Also requires employees to wear masks when driving or operating any public transportation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/Guidance-for-Face-Coverings_06-18-2020.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, wineries, tasting rooms, and like venues, allowing them to re-open for counties that have completed advanced Phase 2 attestation: Alpine, Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Contra Costa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, Humboldt, Inyo, Kern, Kings, Lake, Lassen, Los Angeles, Madera, Mariposa, Mendocino, Merced, Modoc, Mono, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Plumas, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Tehama, Trinity, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo, Yuba-Sutter

(quote) People in California must wear face coverings when they are in high-risk situations listed below (quote), inside of, or in line to enter, any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding in public transportation or in a tax, private vehicle, or ride-sharing vehicle, workplace, operating transportation where others are present, and in outdoor public spaces where maintaining 6 ft or more distance is not feasible. Expands previous recommendation to a mandate. Starting on 2020113, the mandate is as follows (quote) People in California must wear face coverings when they are outside of the home, unless one of the exemptions below applies.(quote): https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx. Modified on 20210503 such that vaccinated individuals need only wear a mask outdoors when attending a crowded event: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close wineries and tasting rooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Bars must close all operations, even if they operate outdoors. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx Since July 1, more counties have been added to the County Monitoring List and thus their restrictions have increased

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close movie theaters, family entertainment centers (e.g., bowling alleys, miniature golf, batting cages and arcades), zoos, museums, cardrooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx On 20200713, gyms/fitness centers and personal care services are also required to close unless modified to oudoor only. More counties are added and removed from the County Monitoring List until 20200831.

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close restaurants, wineries, and tasting rooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx More counties are added and removed from the County Monitoring List to 20200831, which is when the Tier system is introduced and Tier 1 has to have outdoor only
All counties that completed attestation must close bars, brewpubs, pubs, and breweries for all operations (indoor and outdoor). Now statewide bar closure, takeaway only

Counties on the County Monitoring List must close houses of worship for indoor gatherings, so coding as 0 for InGathLimReligious. Also includes Imperial, which has not been approved for Phase 2 attestation. Counties are added and removed from County Monitoring list to 20200828 with the introduction to the Tier system

California Department of Health provides re-opening critieria for K-12, allowing schools to re-open for in-person instruction if they are not on the County Monitoring List and have not been on the County Monitoring List for the last 14 days. Requires school health and safety protocols to be approved by local health authority. Waivers can be applied for only via local health authorities. Applicable to these 26 counties: Alpine, Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Del Norte, El Dorado, Humboldt, Inyo, Kern, Lake, Lassen, Long Beach, Mariposa, Mendocino, Modoc, Mono, Nevada, Plumas, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yolo, Yuba-Sutter. Starting on 20200831, California starts its Tier system and thus counties at Tiers 3-4 can re-open for in-person instruction and those at Tier 2 for at least 2 weeks.

Counties that have been on the County Monitoring List must have distance learning only, and cannot re-open for in-person instruction until the county has been off the County Monitoring List for at least 14 days. These 31 counties are as follows: Alameda, Colusa, Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Marin, Merced, Monterey, Napa, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tulare, Yolo, Yuba, Ventura. Also includes Imperial, for a total of 32 counties, but Imperial has not completed advanced Phase 2 attestation. Starting on 20200831, California starts its Tier system and thus counties at Tier 1 cannot re-open for in-person instruction and Tier 2 counties cannot re-open until they have been at that level for at least 2 weeks.

(quote) Face coverings must be used in accordance with CDPH guidelines unless a person is exempt as explained in the guidelines, particularly in indoor environments, on school buses, and areas where physical distancing alone is not sufficient to prevent disease transmission. (quote) Also details face covering requirements by age/grade. Applies to public and private K-12 schools.

Tier 3 (Moderate) counties can have bars reopen for outdoor services only. Tier 3 (Moderate), 9 counties: Del Norte, Humboldt, Mariposa, Mono, Plumas, Shasta, Siskiyou, Trinity, Tuolumne. Since 20200831, counties have moved from Tier to Tier on what is permitted.

Tier 4 (Minimal) counties can have bars reopen for outdoor services and 50 pct capacity indoors. Tier 4 (Minimal), 2 counties: Alpine, Modoc. Since 20200831, counties have moved from Tier to Tier on what is permitted. Starting 20201124, no counties are at this level
Tier 2 (Substantial) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 100 people or 25 pct (whichever is lower)
Tier 3 (Moderate) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 200 people or 50 pct (whichever is lower)
Tier 4 (Minimal) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 50 pct

With the switch the Tier system, all counties can have retail and malls open to some degree (varying levels of capacity limits) across tiers: Tiers 3 and 4 can have indoors with some modifications and physical distancing, Tier 2 is at up to 50 pct capacity, and Tier 1 is up to 25 pct capacity. The statewide easing of restrictions for indoor services also applies to hair salons and barbershops at this date.

Tier 1 counties can only have the following businesses operate outdoors: gyms/fitness centers, movie theaters, museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariums, additional personal care services (esthetician, skin care, and cosmetology services, electrology, nail salons, body art professonals and tattoo parlors, piercing shops, and massage therapy outside of healthcare settings). Tier 1 (Widespread) and Tier 2 (Substantial) businesses can only be open for outdoor services: family entertainment centers (e.g., kart racing, mini golf, batting cages), cardrooms and satellite wagering. Somewhat eased on 20201020, as the additional personal care services could then operate indoors for Tier 1 counties

Tier 2-4 counties can have the following businesses operate indoors (but at varying levels of capacity by Tier): gyms/fitness centers, movie theaters, museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariumsadditional personal care services (esthetician, skin care, and cosmetology services, electrology, nail salons, body art professonals and tattoo parlors, piercing shops, and massage therapy outside of healthcare settings).

Tehama moves back to Tier 1 (Widespread) from Tier 2 (Substantial). If schools had re-opened already, they may remain open conditional on following health and safety protocols. If not, they are not permitted to re-open until Tehema moves to Tier 2 for at least 2 weeks. Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel. By 20201124, the following counties are at this level: Alameda, Butte, Colusa, Contra Costa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, , Humboldt, Kern, Kings, Lassen, Mendocino, Merced, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Stanislaus, Sutter, Trinity, Tehama, Tuolumne, Yolo, Yuba

For private gatherings, no more than 3 households per gathering and (quote) all gatherings must be held outside (quote). Gatherings may be held outside up to 75 pct capacity if there are structures enclosing the outdoor area, but the no more than 3 households gathering in the public place or outdoor space requirement continues. Coding as a 0 for indoor social social gatherings and applying indoor religious gathering limits. Based on average household size in California (2.94 in 2019 per Statistica: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242265/average-size-of-us-households-by-state/), we are coding the limit on outside private gatherings to no more than 9 people across 3 households.

Gatherings may be held outside up to 75 pct capacity if there are structures enclosing the outdoor area, but the no more than 3 households gathering in the public place or outdoor space requirement continues. Coding as a 0 for indoor social social gatherings and applying indoor religious gathering limits.
