Somewhat eases gathering restrictions for Tier 4 (Minimal), (quote) indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged in Red, Orange and Yellow Tiers (quote). Prohibits personal gatherings that include more than 3 households. Continues houses of worship restrictions: counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 50 pct. Based on average household size in California (2.94 in 2019 per Statistica: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242265/average-size-of-us-households-by-state/), we are coding the limit on private gatherings to no more than 9 people across 3 households.

Somewhat eases gathering restrictions for Tier 3 (Moderate), (quote) indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged in Red, Orange and Yellow Tiers (quote). Prohibits personal gatherings that include more than 3 households. Continues houses of worship restrictions: houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 200 people or 50 pct (whichever is lower). Based on average household size in California (2.94 in 2019 per Statistica: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242265/average-size-of-us-households-by-state/), we are coding the limit on private gatherings to no more than 9 people across 3 households.

Somewhat eases gathering restrictions for Tier 2 (Substantial), (quote) indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged in Red, Orange and Yellow Tiers (quote). Prohibits personal gatherings that include more than 3 households. Continues houses of worship restrictions: houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 100 people or 25 pct (whichever is lower). Based on average household size in California (2.94 in 2019 per Statistica: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242265/average-size-of-us-households-by-state/), we are coding the limit on private gatherings to no more than 9 people across 3 households.

(quote) Persons arriving in California from other states or countries, including returning California residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. (quote) Listing the 50 states plus DC under AppliesTo. On 20210106, eases quarantine recommendation. Persons arriving in California from other states or countries, including returning California residents, should practice self-quarantine for 10 days (down from 14 days) after arrival. https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Travel-Advisory.aspx#

For counties in Tier 1 (Widespread), individuals are required stay at home between the hours of 10 pm to 5 am. For counties that move to Tier 1 after the effective date of the order, the time-based stay-at-home order comes into effect on the second day of Tier 1 status. Initially applies to: Alameda, Butte, Contra Costa, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, Imperial, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Mendocino, Merced, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, Trinity, Tehama, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo, Yuba. As of 20201222, the Limited Stay At Home Order is extended to end with the Regional Stay-at-home order. On 20201229, Humboldt moves out of the this order, constituting an easing: https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/ On 20210125, limited stay-at-home order ends with the conclusion of regional stay-at-home orders: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-030.aspx
Alpine, Mariposa move back to Tier 3 (Moderate), where counties have bars able to reopen for for outdoor services only. No counties can now have bar services inside (either outdoor or takeaway)

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, prohibiting any number of private social gatherings and closing houses of worship for indoor services. Outdoors religious services can still occur with social distancing. With ending of regional stay-at-home order, these gathering restrictions are eased, now applying corresponding tier levels to each location: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-030.aspx

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, requiring all non-essential businesses to close for in-person services for at least 3 weeks. Applies to the following locations staring 1159 pm on 20201206: Calaveras, Fresno, Imperial, Inyo, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Mariposa, Merced, Mono, Orange, Riverside, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Stanislaus, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura. On 20210125, regional stay at home order ends, easing business restrictions back to the tier system: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-030.aspx

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, closing restaurants for in-person services (takeaway only). With the regional stay-at-home orders ending on 20210125, this policy is eased to permit outdoor dining in locations in tier 1: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-030.aspx

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, requiring counties in these regions to exist under a full stay-at-home order. On 20201211, Greater Sacramento region (Alpine, Amador, Butte, Colusa, El Dorado, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, Sierra, Sutter, Yolo, Yuba) has a regional stay-at-home order go in effect at 1159 pm on 20201210: https://covid19.ca.gov/stay-home-except-for-essential-needs/#regional-stay-home-order On 20201218, Bay Area is put under the regional stay-at-home order. On 20210112, Greater Sacramento is removed from the regional stay-at-home order, constituting an easing the overall policy (and ending for specific counties). On 20210125, regional-stay-at-home order is ended: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-030.aspx

Greater Sacramento region (Alpine, Amador, Butte, Colusa, El Dorado, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, Sierra, Sutter, Yolo, Yuba) goes to regional stay-at-home order, where counties have bars, breweries, and distilleries closed for in-person service. Now a statewide policy. Eased on 20210112, with the Greater Sacramento region no longer under the regional stay-at-home order and Sierra moves to having outdoor services allowed:https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/
Non-essential travelers from other states or countries are strongly discouraged from entering California.
Except in connection with essential travel, Californians should avoid non-essential travel to any part of California more than 120 miles from ones place of residence, or to other states or countries.
Sierra moves from the regional stay-at-home order to Tier 3 (Moderate), permitting bars to open outdoors.

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 1 (Widespread). Religious gatherings can open for indoor services at 25 pct capacity, removing absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. All other gatherings must be held outside. Prohibits non-religious personal gatherings that include more than 3 households. Based on average household size in California (2.94 in 2019 per Statistica: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242265/average-size-of-us-households-by-state/), we are coding the limit on outside private gatherings to no more than 9 people across 3 households. As of 20210206, applies to: Alameda, Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Contra Costa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, Humboldt, Imperial, Inyo, Kern, Kings, Lake, Lassen, Los Angeles, Madera, Marin, Mendocino, Merced, Modoc, Mono, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Plumas, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Francisco, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, San Mateo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo, Yuba

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 2 (Substantial). Religious gatherings can open for indoor services at 25 pct capacity, removing absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. For other gatherings, no more than 3 households can gather together (coded to 9 based on average household size in CA). As of 20210206, applies to: Mariposa

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 3 (Moderate). Religious gatherings can open for indoor services at 50 pct capacity, removing absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. For other gatherings, no more than 3 households can gather together (coded to 9 based on average household size in CA). As of 20210206, applies to: Alpine, Sierra, Trinity

Tiers 2 through 4 can open theme parks. Tier 2 can open at 15 pct capacity indoor and outdoor, Tier 3 can open at 25 pct capacity indoor and outdoor, and Tier 4 can open at 35 pct capacity outdoor and 25 pct capacity indoor.

Tiers 1 through 4 can resume outdoor live entertainment with assigned seating (concerts, sports). Tier 1 events are limited to 100 people or fewer, Tier 2 events are limited to 20 pct capacity, Tier 3 events are limited to 33 pct capacity (max 67 pct capacity if all guests are tested or show proof of full vaccination, and Tier 4 events are limited to 67 pct capacity. On 20210415: Tiers 2 through 4 may resume indoor live entertainment (Tier 1 remains outdoor only, 100 people max). Tier 2 events may open up to 10 pct to 20 pct indoors and 20 pct outdoors, depending no venue size and if all guests show proof of tests or vaccination, Tier 3 events may open up to 10 pct to 35 pct indoors and 33 pct to 67 pct outdoors, depending no venue size and if all guests show proof of tests or vaccination, Tier 4 events may open up to 10 pct to 50 pct indoors and 67 pct outdoors, depending no venue size and if all guests show proof of tests or vaccination. https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-live-performances-indoor--en.pdf

Eases quarantine restrictions. Instead of quarantining for 10 days, travelers can get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before travel, and get tested 3-5 days upon arrival to their destination. They should stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if their test is negative. This does not apply to vaccinated individuals.
Unless they are fully vaccinated, non-essential travelers from other states or countries, are strongly discouraged from entering California, and should adhere to quarantine procedures.
(quote) Californians should avoid non-essential travel outside of California, to other states or countries unless they are fully vaccinated. (quote)

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 1 (Widespread). Outdoor only. Social gatherings are permitted up 3 households outdoors. Private gatherings with defined guest lists may have 25 people outdoors, or 100 outdoors with negative test or vaccination. Religious gatherings have no absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. Gathering guidance is recommended (not mandated) for fully vaccinated persons, so coded VaccineExempt as 1. As of 20210415: Applies to no counties.

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 2 (Substantial). Social gatherings are permitted up to 25% capacity or 10 people indoor, 25 people outdoor (from 3 households). Private gatherings with defined guest lists may have 100 people indoor with proof of negative test or full vaccination, 50 people outdoors, or 200 outdoors with negative test or vaccination. Religious gatherings have no absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. Gathering guidance is recommended (not mandated) for fully vaccinated persons, so coded VaccineExempt as 1. As of 20210415: Applies to Amador, Calaveras, Del Norte, Fresno, Glenn, Inyo, Kings, Madera, Merced, Mono, Nevada, Placer, Sacramento, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Shasta, Solano, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Yuba.

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 3 (Moderate). Social gatherings are permitted up to 25% capacity or 25 people indoor, 50 people outdoor (from 3 households). Private gatherings with defined guest lists may have 150 people indoor with proof of negative test or full vaccination, 100 people outdoors, or 300 outdoors with negative test or vaccination. Religious gatherings have no absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. Gathering guidance is recommended (not mandated) for fully vaccinated persons, so coded VaccineExempt as 1. As of 20210415: Applies to Alameda, Butte, Colusa, Contra Costa, El Dorado, Humboldt, Imperial, Kern, Lake, Los Angeles, Marin, Mariposa, Mendocino, Modoc, Monterey, Napa, Orange, Plumas, Riverside, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Siskiyou, Sonoma, Trinity, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo.

Eases gathering restrictions for Tier 4 (Minimal). Social gatherings are permitted up to 50% capacity or 50 people indoor, 100 people outdoor (from 3 households). Private gatherings with defined guest lists may have 200 people indoor with proof of negative test or full vaccination, 200 people outdoors, or 400 outdoors with negative test or vaccination. Religious gatherings have no absolute limits after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling lifted a ban on indoor services during the coronavirus pandemic. Gathering guidance is recommended (not mandated) for fully vaccinated persons, so coded VaccineExempt as 1. As of 20210415: Applies to Alpine, Lassen, Sierra.
All counties are now eligible for in-person instruction (are in Tiers 3-4 or have been in Tier 2 for at least 2 weeks), making the policy statewide.

Eases business mask requirements such that masks are only required in public places indoors for unvaccinated individuals. Masks are still required for everyone on public transportation, per CDC order, as well as in healthcare settings, schools, shelters, and prisons.  Expanded on 20210728 to require masks for all individuals regardless of vaccination status in senior care facilities. https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx

Eases mask requirement such that masks are only required in public places indoors for unvaccinated individuals.  Masks are still required for everyone on public transportation, per CDC order, as well as in healthcare settings, schools, shelters, and prisons. Exemptions are for individuals under 2 years old, persons who are not medically able to wear a face covering, persons who are working alone in an enclosed space, etc. Coded as Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across indoor settings for unvaccinated people. Coded as VaccineExempt because vaccinated individuals are exempt from the mask policy except in a narrow list of settings.  Expanded on 20210728 to require masks for all individuals regardless of vaccination status in senior care facilities, and to recommend masks for all individuals regardless of vaccination status in indoor public settings.  https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx

Recommendation of canceling or postponing any events with more than 250 people. Issued on 20200313, unclear if any expiry exists

All downhill ski resorts are ordered to close for March 15-22, 2020, so through 20200323. Official expiry of this order is 30 days after 20200314, so 20200413. Extension to 20200523: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20049%20Amending%20and%20Extending%20Ski%20Closures.pdf Ended state-level restrictions on 20200526, permitting re-opening based on compliance with local health authorities https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ieLfhoFx6RU_7tkGElC2QA_88VSfFYHj/view

Limited operations required: bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, wineries, tasting rooms, and other places of public accommodation offering alcholic beverages for on-premises consumption (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise consumption only). Effective 8 am on 20200317 through 20200430 (so expiry coded to 20200501). Easing began on 20200618: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BdMbwLeI0sY5xmvWk555jCewPvgTJb9e/view

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: gymnasiums, movie and performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls and music halls, cigar bars, and casinos. Effective 8 am on 20200317 and remains in effect for 30 days, so 20200416

Limited operations required: restaurants, cafes, and like venues (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise eating only). Effective 8 am on 20200317 through 20200430 (so expiry coded to 20200501). Easing began on 20200527 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ieLfhoFx6RU_7tkGElC2QA_88VSfFYHj/view
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, added TakeawayOnly to BusinessRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: In effect at 1201 am on 20200319. (quote) all mass gatherings shall be limited to no more than ten (10) people. Remains in effect for 30 days, so to 20200418. Expands gathering recommendation to formal restriction. Also explicitly includes faith-based events. Technically issued on 20200320, but in effect on 20200319

All P-12 schools to suspend in-person operations March 23 to April 17, so through 20200417. Expressly includes charter schools, and public and private schools. Official expiry of this is order is 30 days after the 20200318 issuance, so it would be 20200417. Extended in-person closure through the end of the academic year: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20041%20P-12%20Closure%20Extension%20End%20of%20Year.pdf

(quote) I direct all businesses other than those qualified as Critical Businesses to close temporarily (quote). Initial easing of NEBusinessClose began on 20200427 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20044%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

(quote) I direct all Coloradans to stay at home, subject to limited exceptions such as obtaining food and other household necessities, going to and from work at critical businesses, seeking medical care, caring for dependents or pets, or caring for a vulnerable person in another location (quote) In effect at 600 am on 20200326 through 20200411, so coded to expire on 20200412.

(quote) All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a Residence are prohibited, except for the limited purposes expressly permitted in this PHO which include Essential Activities. (quote) Eases on 20200427 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PWuZ-bhXERZNQ-5RpUZqpsg-0_KNu0La/view

PHO Second Updated Public Health Order 20-24 closes public and private colleges and universities except to facilitate distance learning. They can perform essential functions if social distancing is followed, such as food services, medical and mental health services, security, critical research and housing.

People with symptoms of COVID-19 must self isolate until they recieve a negative test or at least 72 hours after symptoms resolve. (quote) Normal in-person instruction at all P-12 schools in Colorado will be suspended until the scheduled end of the 2019-2020 regular school year. P-12 schools and school districts may use school buildings for providing services to students, educators, and families, including but not limited to: in-person small group instruction, staff professional development, food service, access to internet, devices, or instructional materials, special education services, or mental health supports. P-12 schools and school districts intending to provide these services must work in coordination with their local public health agency and must observe Social Distancing Requirements pursuant to applicable public health orders (quote). Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel as individuals are being allowed back into school buildings for limited in-person instruction and services. On 20200720, Guidance on reopening schools from Public Health department devolved authority on school closures to local districts, thus ending the formal School Closure at state level. (quote) Local public health agencies (LPHAs) may declare the phase for their county/area using the Stay, Safer, and Protect Complete Framework metrics. (quote): https://www.cde.state.co.us/communications/20200720reopeningguidance

Eases restrictions on public and private postsecondary institutions: (quote) Programs and courses at postsecondary institutions that cannot be conducted remotely, generally due to equipment requirements, may be conducted through limited in-person instruction. Institutions that wish to resume providing in-person instruction must inform the Colorado Department of Higher Education and ensure that Social Distancing Requirements are strictly followed. (quote) On 20200618, (quote) Programs and courses at postsecondary institutions may resume in-person classes at 50 pct of the occupancy limit not to exceed 50 people per room. If the room is extra large, the institution may allow up to 100 people indoors within their usable space calculated using the Social Distancing Space Calculator. (quote) Coding as ending the state-level closing of postsecondary institutions, as now institutions are now instructed to work with the Colorado Department of Education for guidelines on in-person instruction: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1DtXFRETS7kAVYYHhVmo9IcfciW5j1BMc/view

(quote) All individuals currently living within the State of Colorado are encouraged to stay at home and avoid unnecessary interactions whenever possible in order to reduce the spread of disease. (quote) Strongly recommends that vulnerable individuals, as defined as individuals 65 years or older, pregnant women, or individuals who have health conditions (chronic lung disease or severe asthma, serious heart conditions, immunocompromised), to stay-at-home: (quote) People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are urged to stay in their residence at all times except as necessary to seek medical care. Permits non-critical retail to allow customers onto premises up to 50 pct capacity and in a manner allowing for strict compliance with mandatory social distancing requirements. These include requiring maintaining at least 6 ft separation between individuals. Starting on 20201020, as counties move to Safer at Home Level 3 (Orange Level), capacity is reduced to 25 pct in some counties: https://www.julesburgadvocate.com/2020/10/20/state-raises-logan-county-to-high-risk-on-covid-19-dial-slaps-on-new-restrictions/ Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf. On 20210324, capacity for retail in Green counties ends, eases to 75 pct in Blue counties, and extends at 50 pct capacity in Yellow counties https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NNGzlC_fzTo6lU1WK3YcexMk4ZYnCTCq/view Ends restrictions on 20210416 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view

Eases restaurant restrictions, now allowing for outside dining and limited indoor dining (i.e., no more than 50 pct occupancy or no more than 50 people, whichever is less), no more than 8 people to a table, and 6 ft physical distancing    https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ieLfhoFx6RU_7tkGElC2QA_88VSfFYHj/view On 20200618, extra large restaurants can have up to 100 people for occupancy. Starting on 20200915, with COVID19 dial, all levels permit indoor services but at varying levels (and these get updated regularly): https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard

Drive-in movie theaters are permitted to re-open, while indoor movie and performance theaters must remain closed. On 20200618, eased as indoor movie and performance theaters are permitted to re-open for indoor services at up to 50 pct capacity, adhering to social distancing, etc. For large indoor performance venues, capacity limits are based on the (quote) Social Distancing Space Calculator (quote) wherein up to 175 can be at outdoor venues and up to 100 people at indoor venues.

Starting June 4, houses of worship can have up to 50 pct capacity or 50 people indoors (whichever is less), and only 6 ft distancing required for outdoor religious gatherings. Gathering limits of no more than 10 continue for non-religious gatherings. Requires mask use by staff, volunteers, and congregants. Starting on 20200915, substate gathering restrictions begin with the COVID19 Dial: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view

Eases restrictions on bars and like venues, allowing them to re-open under restricted oocupancy, health and safety protocols, etc. (quote) Effective June 18, 2020, bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, microbreweries, distillery pubs, wineries, tasting rooms, special licensees, clubs, and other places of public accommodation offering alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, referred to as Bars, may operate with the lesser of 25 pct of the posted occupancy limit or 50 patrons, whichever is less (quote).

Movie and performance theaters and like venues are permitted to re-open at 50 pct capacity, distancing requirements, etc. With COVID19 dial implementation, these limits remain at 50 pct but total number of people permitted varies by level: 100 for indoor and 175 for outdoor for Safer at Home Level 2, 175 for indoor and 250 for outdoor for Safer at Home Level 1, and 500 for Protect Our Neighbors. Eases to some degree as more counties move to less restrictive levels, but counties are move to stricter ones as well. Eased on 20210307, where indoor movie and performance theaters can re-open for indoor services. Capacity limits are 50 pct across Green, Blue, and Yellow levels. but different levels for absolute numeric levels (150 (up from 100) for indoor if event is seated and 175 for outdoor for Yellow, 225 (up from 175) for indoor if event is seated and 250 for outdoor for Yellow). https://drive.google.com/file/d/1KPNMKVzWx2KbAqAjja-lGfO6v4CqFOZ7/view. On 20210324, eased for Blue and Green counties, which no longer have restrictions for outdoor events https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NNGzlC_fzTo6lU1WK3YcexMk4ZYnCTCq/view On 20210416 ends restrictions on outdoor events, eases restrictions on indoor events https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view Extended to 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/137UVAaWEVIQ4AIzTtOaOXrvLMRfjhZ1P/view Ended on 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fIYXM08Ck2zHPSxhHusybGfwJ_f8ROjR/view

Mandates that, at Goverment Offices and Facilities, all employees that interact in close proximity to with other employees or the public and all members of the public must wear medical or non-medical face coverings that cover the nose and mouth, as a condition of ingress or movement within such location. Considered a Mandate1 on PublicMaskLevel coding since it applies to the public in limited settings (government offices and facilities).

Effective July 1, on-premise consumption is no longer allowed and restricted operations are required for bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, wineries, tasting rooms, and other places of public accommodation offering alcholic beverages (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise consumption only). Bars that offer food from a licensed retail food establishment are permitted to operate akin to restaurants. Otherwise, bars and like venues have to close to take-away only. On 20200915, with some counties under the Protect Our Neighbors phase with the COVID19 Dial, those locations are permitted to have bars without food licenses to reopen at 50 pct capacity: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view Extended to 20201129 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view

Issues statewide mask order, requiring people in Colorado who are 11 years and older to wear a covering over their noses and mouths when entering or moving within any public indoor space, or while using or waiting to use public (buses, light-rail) or non-personal (taxis, car services, ride-shares) transportation services. Exemptions for individuals who cannot wear masks or face coverings due to medical conditions or disabilities, and does not require masks in outdoor spaces (though encourages such use). Includes worship services. In effect at midnight on 20200716, so coded to 20200717. Coded as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it covers broadly covers indoor settings and explicitly does not require mask use in outdoor settings. Amends bar restrictions by ceasing sale of alcohol after 10 pm daily. Extends closure for onsite consumption and restricted operations are required for bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, wineries, tasting rooms, and other places of public accommodation offering alcholic beverages (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise consumption only). This category of businesses may remain open for on-premise cconsumption if it is a licensed food establishment, wherein food is served and tables are set with at least 6 ft physical distancing between tables. Note that Colorado moves to Protect Our Neighbors phase, which involves both state-level mandates and devolution to county variance. Because county variance status is not easily trackable at from the state level at this time, we are not currently tracking these variances. On 20200723, amended EO take away curfew: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20144%20Amending%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf

On 20200821, amends restrictions to allow alcohol for deliverys with no curfew: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20170%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf. Counties in Protect Our Neighbors phase continue to have gathering limits of 500, and up to 500 people for indoor religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings do not have numeric capacity limits, but 6 ft distancing must occur. As of 20200915, this applies to 5 counties: Gilpin, Gunnison, Mesa, Moffat, Rio Blanco. These designations are based on the new COVID19 Dial, which is regularly updated but counties cannot fully move to a new phase until they have been in the same one for at least 2 weeks. https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

Counties in Safer at Home Level 2 are permitted to have up to 10 people personal gatherings, and up to 50 people indoors (or 50 pct capacity, whichever is lower) for religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings have no numeric limit but must have 6 ft social distancing. As of 20200915, this applies to 34 counties: Adams, Alamosa, Archuleta, Boulder, Broomfield, Chaffee, Conejos, Costilla, Custer, Denver, Eagle, Garfield, Grand, Jackson, Jefferson, Lake, La Plata, Logan, Montezuma, Montrose, Morgan, Phillips, Pitkin, Prowers, Pueblo, Rio Grande, Routt, Saguache, San Juan, San Miguel, Sedgwick, Summit, Washington, Weld. Easing began on 20200929, with Archuleta, La Plata, Montrose, and Prowers moving to Safer at Home Level 1: https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

Counties in Safer at Home Level 1 are permitted to have up to 25 people personal gatherings, and up to 175 people indoors (or 50 pct capacity, whichever is lower) for religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings have no numeric limit but must have 6 ft social distancing. As of 20200915, this applies to 25 counties: Arapahoe, Baca, Bent, Cheyenne, Clear Creek, Crowley, Delta, Dolores, Douglas, Elbert, El Paso, Fremont, Hinsdale, Huerfano, Kiowa, Kit Carson, Larimer, Las Animas, Lincoln, Mineral, Otero, Ouray, Park, Teller, Yuma. Extends gathering restriction of up to 10 people from no more than 2 households for remaining counties, permits up to 50 people indoors for religious gatherings, no explicit limit for outdoor religious gatherings beyond 6 ft distancing. Applicable to Levels Green to Orange.

Levels Orange to Green counties can have restaurants and like venues open for indoor services but at varying levels of capacity (25 pct for Orange, 50 pct for Yellow, Blue, and Green, but different absolute numbers). Extended to 20210106 https://drive.google.com/file/d/14El-qBmb1QTLZb2lBuGdocZrJMJlx3wy/view. Extended to 20210203 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ZeHik4-YQxDJqIdgFvc5yqheqIZpdVTU/view. Eases absolute capacity restrictions for restaurants in Yellow and Blue counties. In Blue and Yellow counties restaurants can operate at up to 50 pct capacity limit indoors, but also a maximum number of people (whichever is lower): 225 people for Level Blue and 150 people for Level Yellow. All parties are required to have at least 6 ft social distancing, and no on-premise alcohol consumption or sales between 2 am and 7 am for Blue counties, and 1 am to 7am for Yellow counties. Coding together at present given their similar overall capacity levels. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1KPNMKVzWx2KbAqAjja-lGfO6v4CqFOZ7/view. Extended to 20210406 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1KPNMKVzWx2KbAqAjja-lGfO6v4CqFOZ7/view. On 20210324, ends restrictions for restaurants in Green counties, where there are no capacity limits. Local authorities may implement restrictions. Eases restrictions for restaurants in Blue counties, which may operate up to 100 pct but individuals must maintain 6 feet of distance. Prohibits alcohol sales between 2 am and 7 am. Extends restrictions for restaurants in Yellow counties, which may operate up to 50 pct or 150 people, whichever is lower. No alcohol sales between 1am and 7 am. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NNGzlC_fzTo6lU1WK3YcexMk4ZYnCTCq/view Ended restrictions on 20210416 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view

Eases gathering restrictions for the following: for Level Red counties, gatherings outside of ones immediate household are prohibited, so coding as 0. This means that they must do their best to follow public health recommendations but may exceed recommended capacity caps if they cannot conduct their essential activity within those restrictions. Extends stay-at-home recommendation for all populations, but exempts vaccinated individuals. Individuals (quote) who have not yet been vaccinated with a COVID-19 vaccine are urged to stay in their residence at all times (quote). Emphasizes vulnerable populations in particular.

Extends business mask requirements in all counties in Red, Orange, Blue, and Yellow counties. Face coverings are required to be worn by individuals age eleven (11) and older when entering or within Public Indoor Spaces. (quote) To protect workers, customers, and the community, owners, operators, and managers of the businesses, services, and locations listed in Sections II.A and II.B of this Executive Order and those authorized on their behalf, shall deny admittance or service and require the removal of any individual who fails to wear a medical or non-medical face covering as required by this Executive Order. (quote) Also, eases business mask requirement for Green counties, where businesses must continue to require customers and employees to wear masks in congregate care facilities, emergency health care facilities, and personal services businesses. Extended to 20210516 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view Introduces exemptions for vaccinated individuals on 20210502: Allows Restaurant employees to not wear masks if 85 pct of a Restaurants employees are fully vaccinated. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m6j4VRs6klkNXLsA5HODb9Pln9NXl1I6/view

Extends mask mandate in Red, Orange, Yellow and Blue counties, requiring people in Colorado who are 11 years and older to wear a covering over their noses and mouths when entering or moving within any public indoor space. Exemptions for individuals who cannot wear masks or face coverings due to medical conditions or disabilities, and does not require masks in outdoor spaces (though encourages such use). Exemption for indoor spaces with fewer than ten individuals who are unvaccinated or of unknown vaccination status. Includes worship services. Coded as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it covers broadly covers indoor settings and explicitly does not require mask use in outdoor settings.  Extended to 20210516 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view Introduces exemptions for vaccinated individuals on 20210502: Allows no masking in Public Indoor Spaces if 80 pct or more of the individuals in a Public Indoor Space have provided proof of vaccination. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m6j4VRs6klkNXLsA5HODb9Pln9NXl1I6/view  Eased to a statewide Mandate1 on 20210515 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202021%20103%20Face%20Covering%20Order.pdf

Eases mask mandate for Green counties, where face coverings are only required in public areas of state government facilities, areas in state government facilities where members of the public come into contact with state government employees and in congregate care facilities, prisons and jails, emergency health care facilities, and personal services businesses. Coded as a Mandate1 due because it explicit does not broadly include all public indoor spaces. Extended to 20210516 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dNbRJfjyHoPrUbNNALtTPgvG93FPY_NZ/view

Eases restrictions on bars statewide, allowing bars to re-open. When more than 100 people are gathered in a room in a Public Indoor Space, the setting may operate at 100pct capacity not to exceed 500 people, with 6 feet distancing required between parties of unvaccinated people or when vaccination status is unknown. Extended to 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/137UVAaWEVIQ4AIzTtOaOXrvLMRfjhZ1P/view Ended on 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fIYXM08Ck2zHPSxhHusybGfwJ_f8ROjR/view

Makes gathering restrictions statewide. When more than 100 people are gathered in a room in a Public Indoor Space, the setting may operate at 100pct capacity not to exceed 500 people, with 6 feet distancing required between parties of unvaccinated people or when vaccination status is unknown.  No limits for outdoor gatherings. Religious gatherings are classified as essential and thus exempt.  Extended to 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/137UVAaWEVIQ4AIzTtOaOXrvLMRfjhZ1P/view Ended on 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fIYXM08Ck2zHPSxhHusybGfwJ_f8ROjR/view

Makes restrictions for casinos, bounce houses and ball pits statewide, where these businesses may re-open at 100 pct capacity. However, when more than 100 people are gathered in a room in a Public Indoor Space, the setting may operate at 100pct capacity not to exceed 500 people, with 6 feet distancing required between parties of unvaccinated people or when vaccination status is unknown. Extended to 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/137UVAaWEVIQ4AIzTtOaOXrvLMRfjhZ1P/view Ended on 20210601 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fIYXM08Ck2zHPSxhHusybGfwJ_f8ROjR/view

Makes statewide the business mask mandate that originally only applied to counties with a one-week disease incidence rate below 35 per 100,000 and adds exemption for fully vaccinated individuals. Businesses must continue to require unvaccinated customers and employees to wear masks in congregate care facilities, child care centers and services, prisons, jails, and emergency health care facilities. PolicyCodingNotes: Extends school mask requirements but adds exemption for fully vaccinated individuals: masks are required of unvaccinated school employees and students aged 11 years and older during in-person instruction and indoors.  Extended to 20210701 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fIYXM08Ck2zHPSxhHusybGfwJ_f8ROjR/view. Ended on 20210701 https://drive.google.com/file/d/17dvoWVtBcvAT4qX5MJWyio7SFkJfh45d/view

The state recommends local public health agencies and school districts consider adopting mask mandates for either unvaccinated individuals or all individuals in schools. 
 (quote) The state recommends local public health agencies and school districts consider either mask requirements for all unvaccinated individuals or all individuals in schools, particularly in higher-risk environments. (quote). Higher-risk environments are defined as those that meet any of these criteria: (quote) The community has a vaccination rate under 70% among individuals age 12 and older. (quote) or (quote)  The school has a vaccination rate under 70 percent among staff and students age 12 and older.  (quote) or (quote) The communitys transmission rate is above 35 cases per 100,000 people over a seven-day period. (quote)

PolicyCodingNotes: Any person in a public place in Connecticut who is unable to or does not maintain a safe social distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face-covering. Also must use mask or face covering in transportation services. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as this applies to all public places, and does not distinguish between indoor or outdoor settings (and thus is applicable in all public places). Extended for 6 months on 20200814, so coding to 20210212 (182 days later) - this extension also includes a small expansion, requiring documentation for medical exemptions: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7NNN.pdf. Extended to 20210209 on 20201109: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9L.pdf. Extended to 20210420: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10A.pdf. Extended to 20210521 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-11A.pdf Eased to Mandate2 on 20210518  https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-12.pdf

Eased gathering restriction of 5 to 10 people for indoor settings. (quote) indoor social and recreational gatherings as described in Executive Order No. 7D, Section 1 are permitted for up to and including ten (10) people (quote). . However, religious gatherings are exempt quote) effective immediately, the 49-person limit on religious, spiritual and worship gatherings is raised for indoor gatherings to 25 percent of capacity of the indoor space or a maximum of 100 people, whichever is smaller, and to 150 people for outdoor gatherings (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions for both indoor and outdoor gatherings. Restrictions are (quote) amended to permit social and recreational gatherings pursuant to DECD Rules for Gatherings and Venues and Sector Rules for Outdoor Events (quote), and thus permit up to 25 people for indoor private gatherings and 100 for outdoor private gatherings (e.g., weddings, reunions, parties). Religious gatherings indoors are capped at 25 pct capacity or 100 people, and then up to 150 people outdoors. Easing begins on 20201008 with Phase 3: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Phase-3-reopen

Travelers entering Connecticut from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10 pct test positivity rate over a seven-day rolling average, shall self-quarantine for a period of 14 days. On 20200630, Expands states included in the travel quarantine requirement, adding eight states to the list. The total list is as follows: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah: https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/06-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-June-30 On 20200707, Expands states included in the travel quarantine requirement, adding Delaware, Kansas, and Oklahoma: https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/06-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-June-30 As of 20200714, removes Delaware and adds Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, and Wisconsin now on the travel quarantine list: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Travel-In-or-Out-of-CT On 20200724, the policy removed Minnesota and then also eased the policy permitting a negative test in lieu of quarantine https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7III.pdf On 20200728, Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Puerto Rico, and District of Columbia are added to the quarantine list: https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/07-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-July-28 On 20200804 District of Columbia and Delaware were removed from the list and Indiana and Rhode Island were added: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/travel On 20200811, Alaska, New Mexico, Ohio, and Rhode Island are removed from the list, and Hawaii, South Dakota, and the Virgin Islands are added: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/travel On 20200818 Washington was removed from the list and Alaska and Delaware were added Eases gathering restrictions, such that indoor gatherings can be up to 100 people (or 50 pct capacity) in commercial establishment or places of business (only up to 25 for private residences) and 150 for outdoor gatherings. Indoor religious gatherings are limited up to 200 people (or 50 pct capacity), while outdoor religious gatherings have no absolute numeric limit (50 pct capacity and 6 ft spacing). Masks and social distancing required in all gatherings. https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9F.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions as the state returns to Phase II restrictions for gatherings. Indoor gatherings now have a cap of 25 people in commercial establishment or places of business (only up to 10 for private residences) and 50 for outdoor gatherings (10 people for private residences). Religious indoor gatherings are limited to 100 people (or 50 pct capacity) while outdoor religious gatherings have no absolute numeric limit (50 pct capacity and 6 ft spacing). Masks and social distancing required in all gatherings.

Extends restrictions for indoor recreation and performing arts venues as the state moves from Phase 3 to Phase 2.1. Indoor performing arts venues are able to operate at 50 pct capacity, conditional on mask use and social distancing. Movie theaters and similar indoor recreation venues are capped at 100 people. Venues must close at 10pm.

Expands restrictions on restaurants, transitioning from Phase 3 to Phase 2.1. Restaurants are allowed up to 50 pct capacity indoors with 6 ft spacing with a maximum of 8 people per table. Now mandates that restaurants must stop service at 930pm and must close in-person service at 10pm but may continue takeout orders after 10pm.

Advisory for all Connecticut residents to stay home between the hours of 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. in order to reduce the risk of further viral transmission. High-risk individuals should take extra precautions. Extended to 20210420: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10A.pdf.

Eases gathering restrictions. Eliminates the numerical cap for religious gatherings and instead restricts indoor religious gatherings to 50 pct capacity. Outdoor religious gatherings are limited to allow 6 ft of distance between people not of the same household. Face coverings are still required. Continues previous social gathering limits of 25 people indoors and 50 people outdoors. Gathering restrictions to remain in effect for the duration of the public health emergency, so DateExpiry coded as 20210420.

Extends restrictions for indoor recreation and performing arts venues as the state remains in Phase 2.1. Indoor performing arts venues are able to operate at 50 pct capacity, conditional on mask use and social distancing. Movie theaters and similar indoor recreation venues are capped at 100 people. Eases mandatory closure to 11pm. Eased on 20210319. Venues are no longer subject to 100 person limits. Continues restricting capacity at 50 pct, requiring 6 ft spacing between parties, and mandatory nighttime closure at 11pm: https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen. Extended to 20210521 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-11A.pdf

Extends restrictions on restaurants as the state remains in Phase 2.1. Restaurants are allowed up to 50 pct capacity indoors with 6 ft spacing with a maximum of 8 people per table. Now allows restaurants to have in-person service to 11pm. Eased on 20210319. Restaurants no longer have capacity limits. Continues requiring tables are spaced 6ft apart, 8 people per table, and mandatory nighttime closure at 11pm: https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen. Extended to 20210521 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-11A.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions. Indoor social gatherings at commercial venues may continue at 50 pct capacity, up 100 people. Outdoor social gatherings at commercial venues may have 200 people. Social gatherings at private venues may have up to 25 people indoors and 100 people outdoors. Indoor and outdoor religious gatherings have no listed restrictions, other than limiting capacity (quote) to a number that can be accommodated safely by location with masks and social distancing required (quote). No DateIssued listed for sector guidance rules, so DateIssued coded as 20210304 in accordance with governor press release. DateEnded coded as the end of the current emergency declaration. Extended to 20210521 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-11A.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210519 https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen
According to governors press release, effective 20210319 Connecticuts travel advisory is modified from a requirement to recommended guidance. No DateExpiry provided.

(quote) The Department of Economic and Community may issue for each of various business and activity sectors (individually and collectively, the Sector Rules), which Sector Rules shall constitute legally binding guidance (quote). Extends eased restrictions on performing arts venues and movie theaters. Venues are no longer subject to 100 person limits. Continues restricting capacity at 50 pct, requiring 6 ft spacing between parties, and mandatory nighttime closure at 12am (from 11pm).  Ends restrictions on 20210519 https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen

(quote) The Department of Economic and Community may issue for each of various business and activity sectors (individually and collectively, the Sector Rules), which Sector Rules shall constitute legally binding guidance (quote). Eases restaurant restrictions, as the 8-person per table limit will be lifted for outdoors only, while his limit will remain in effect for indoor service. No capacity limits. Continues requiring tables are spaced 6ft apart and mandatory nighttime closure is now at 12am (from 11pm).  Ends restrictions on 20210519 https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen

Eases bar restrictions, allowing bars that do not serve food to reopen outdoors only. (quote) The Department of Economic and Community may issue for each of various business and activity sectors (individually and collectively, the Sector Rules), which Sector Rules shall constitute legally binding guidance (quote). Standing bar service is allowed outdoors. There will no longer be an 8-person table limit outdoors. Requires mandatory nighttime closure at 12:00am.  Ends restrictions on 20210519 https://portal.ct.gov/DECD/Content/Coronavirus-Business-Recovery/Sector-Rules-for-Reopen

Eases public mask mandate and introduces exemptions for vaccinated individuals. Now only requires unvaccinated individuals in indoor settings to wear face coverings. Fully vaccinated individuals do not have to wear masks. Masks are also explicitly required when using a taxi, shared car or ride-sharing service, means of mass public transit, or any semi-enclosed transit area. Exemptions that continue are children under 2, individuals whose health or safety would be comprised due to a medical condition. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it is applies broadly to indoor settings. Allowed to expire on 20210721.

Mandatory face coverings, (quote) All individuals must wear a face covering, except where doing so would inhibit that individuals health or where the individual is under two years of age (quote). Applies to riding public transportation or in other types of vehicles (taxis, private car service, ride sharing), customer of any businesses (including, but not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, supermarkets, laundromats, and restaurants, both inside the business and when waiting in line outside), when obstaining services from a healthcare provider, when they are in an outdoor public area if maintaining social distancing is not possible, and when they are in any public area and are feeling sick, coughing, or sneezing. Coded as a PublicMaskLevel Mandate3 as it requires mask wearing in any business and outdoor public spaces. (quote) Students in Kindergarten and above shall wear face coverings while inside child care homes and centers and at schools at all times except for meals, naps, or when doing so would inhibit the child’s health. If outside at a child care home or center or at a school, face coverings shall be worn by students (Kindergarten and above) if social distancing cannot be maintained (quote). Does not explicitly require teachers or school staff to wear face coverings in this order. Expands gathering restriction for indoor and outdoor gatherings, prohibiting more than 50 people. (quote) Houses of Worship may continue to offer in-person worship services, provided, however, that the total number of guests permitted in a House of Worship at any one time shall not exceed the lesser of 30 pct of that House of Worship’s stated fire occupancy or 100 guests. (quote). Extended to 20201225 https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/11/Ninth-Extension-of-State-of-Emergency-11252020.pdf

Expands restrictions on breweries, taprooms and taverns. Food courts are now allowed to operate at 20 percent capacity (indoors and outdoors) or 100 individuals, whichever is less. All other food and drink establishments follow the new general capacity limits for retail and business: retail establishments of 5000 sq ft. or less may reopen at 40 percent capacity, businesses with less than 100,000 sq. ft. and retail with less than 100,000 sq. ft. and more than 5,001 sq. ft. shall not exceed 30 pct capacity, while businesses or retail of more than 100,001 sq. ft. shall not exceed 20 pct capacity. Food and Drink establishments must close indoor and outdoor dining between 10pm and 5am. Only members of the same household may share a table and tables are limited to parties of 6, consisting of no more than 4 adults. (quote) Any common areas where people would typically stand or engage in other activities must be off limits if not otherwise occupied by tables with seated patrons. This includes dance floors, arcade/bar game areas, pool tables, and similar spaces. (quote). Additional requirements for Food and Drink Establishments are listed in the twenty-seventh modification. https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/12/Fourth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-12.10.20.pdf. Extended to 20210123: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/tenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/.

Expands restrictions for indoor gatherings, prohibiting more than 10 people in both public and private gatherings. Outdoor gatherings remain limited to 50 people. Eases restrictions for religious gatherings, which now have no stated numerical limit, only a capacity limit. (quote) Notwithstanding the indoor gathering occupancy limits set forth in Paragraph N.2, Houses of Worship may continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of guests permitted in a House of Worship at any one time shall not exceed forty percent (40pct) of that House of Worship’s stated fire occupancy. (quote). Extended to 20210123: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/tenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/. Extended to 20210224: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/eleventh-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/. https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Sixth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02042021.pdf. On 20210214 eases religious gathering restrictions, now allowing for 50 pct capacity: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Sixth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02042021.pdf. Extended to 20210321: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Twelfth-Extension-State-of-Emergency-02192021.pdf.

Expands restrictions on restaurants and like businesses. Food courts are now allowed to operate at 20 percent capacity (indoors and outdoors) or 100 individuals, whichever is less. All other food and drink establishments follow the new general capacity limits for retail and business: retail establishments of 5000 sq ft. or less may reopen at 40 percent capacity, businesses with less than 100,000 sq. ft. and retail with less than 100,000 sq. ft. and more than 5,001 sq. ft. shall not exceed 30 pct capacity, while businesses or retail of more than 100,001 sq. ft. shall not exceed 20 pct capacity. Food and Drink establishments must close indoor and outdoor dining between 10pm and 5am. Only members of the same household may share a table and tables are limited to parties of 6, consisting of no more than 4 adults. (quote) Any common areas where people would typically stand or engage in other activities must be off limits if not otherwise occupied by tables with seated patrons (quote). Additional requirements for Food and Drink Establishments are listed in the twenty-seventh modification. https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/12/Fourth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-12.10.20.pdf. Extended to 20210123: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/tenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/.

Expands recommendation to stay home to all Delawareans, not just vulnerable individuals. (quote) Beginning on Monday, December 14, 2020 and ending on January 11, 2021 unless expressly extended, Delaware residents are advised and strongly encouraged to stay home as often as possible and to only leave home to go to work or school, or for necessary needs such as seeking medical care, going to the grocery store or pharmacy, or picking up food. (quote). Extended to 20210123: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/tenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/. Ended on 20210212 for all Delaware residents and vulnerable individuals: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Sixth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02042021.pdf.

Eases gathering restrictions. Indoor public gatherings can now be held at the lesser of 25 people or 50 pct capacity. Organizers may ​submit a plan to the DPH to host larger events up to 150 people. Outdoor gatherings continue to be limited to 50 people, or up to 250 with an approved plan from DPH. Indoor private gatherings remains at 10 people. Continues restrictions for religious gatherings, which may now operate at 50 pct capacity. Eases gathering restrictions. Indoor public gatherings can be held at the lesser of 25 people or 50 pct capacity. Organizers may ​submit a plan to the DPH to host larger events up to 150 people. Outdoor gatherings are now limited to 150 people (from 50) in places without fire occupancy restrictions. This includes, but is not limited to, outdoor weddings, funerals, concerts, parades, festivals, conventions, fundraisers, sporting events and fairs. Outdoor venues with fire occupancy restrictions and with more than 100,000 square feet of public space must limit occupancy to 50 percent of stated fire capacity. Outdoor venues with fire occupancy restrictions and with less than 100,000 square feet of public space must limit occupancy to 75 percent of stated fire capacity. Any outdoor venue hosting more than 150 people must still have a plan approved by DPH to mitigate spread of COVID-19. Indoor private gatherings remains at 10 people. Continues restrictions for religious gatherings, which may now operate at 50 pct capacity.  Extended to 20210516 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/fourteenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/ Extended to 20210613 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/fifteenth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions. Gatherings or events at any business or space open to the public of up to 250 (from 25 indoors and 150 outdoors) people (e.g. weddings and receptions, graduations, birthday parties, funeral receptions, etc.) are permitted under the listed conditions. Gatherings or events at private residences with less than 250 people (e.g. dinner parties, house parties, birthday parties) people should follow CDC guidance for face coverings. Individuals who are not part of the same household are expected to remain at least three (3) feet apart to the greatest extent possible and are encouraged to maintain greater physical distance whenever possible. Organizers may ​submit a plan to the DPH to host larger events up to 250 people. Removes restrictions for religious gatherings, which may now operate at 100 pct capacity but maintaining social distancing.  Removes social distancing requirements on 20210521  https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/05/29th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-051821.pdf Extended to 20210713 https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/06/Sixteenth-Extension-State-of-Emergency-06132021.pdf Ended through ending of state of emergency: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/termination/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/eleventh-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/

Eases mask or facial covering requirements requiring Delawareans to wear a cloth face covering anytime they are indoors with anyone outside their immediate household, regardless of whether social distancing is possible or not, but not outdoors anymore. (quote) All individuals must wear a face covering, except where doing so would inhibit that individuals health or where the individual is under two years of age (quote). Applies to riding public transportation or in other types of vehicles (taxis, private car service, ride sharing), customer of any businesses (including, but not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, supermarkets, laundromats, and restaurants), when obstaining services from a healthcare provider. Coded as a PublicMaskLevel Mandate2 as it requires mask wearing in indoor public spaces broadly. Eased on 20210521  https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/05/29th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-051821.pdf

Eases mask requirements requiring Delawareans to wear a cloth face covering in very limited settings. The order requires mask-wearing on public transit, planes, in schools, health care facilities and congregate settings like prisons and homeless shelters, in State-owned buildings and facilities, including Division of Motor Vehicles (DMV) facilities, Delaware State Service Centers, and the Carvel State Office Building. (quote) All individuals must wear a face covering, except where doing so would inhibit that individuals health or where the individual is under two years of age (quote).  Coded as a PublicMaskLevel Mandate1 as it requires mask wearing in very limited indoor public spaces. Extended to 20210713 https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/06/Sixteenth-Extension-State-of-Emergency-06132021.pdf. Slightly eased on 20210615 such to narrow the requirement for masks in state building to apply only to executive buildings and facilities under the authority of the governor https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/06/First-Modification-of-the-29th-State-of-Emergency-06152021.pdf Ended through ending of state of emergency: https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/termination/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/eleventh-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/

Extended to 20210401: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%20127%2012-18-2020.pdf. On 20210322, eased restrictions for some businesses and extended to 20210521: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%E2%80%99s%20Order%202021-038%20%20Extension%20of%20the%20Public%20Emergency%20and%20Public%20Health%20Emergency%20and%20Modified%20Measures%20in%20Phase%20Two%20of%20Washington%2C%20DC%20Reopening%20%203-17-2021_0.pdf. (quote) All individuals living in Washington, DC, are order to stay at their place of residence, except as specified in this order (quote)

People using ride share programs, taxis, or other private transportation vehicles are required to wear masks or face coverings. Also recommends wearing masks on public transportation. Coded as Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is a mandate one specific arena for the public (i.e., ride-share, taxis, and private transportation). On 20200513, expands mandate to cover all types of transportation, but still coded to Mandate1 for only applying to a specific sector: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayors-Order-2020-066-Extensions-of-Public-Emergency-and-Public-Health.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200609, removed DateEased, added Mandate1 to PublicMaskLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) DOH guidance relating to masks must be followed (quote), thus making the following guidelines for mask use mandatory: masks and face coverings for the general public, indicating that the general public should wear a cloth face covering when taking care of people with suspected or confirmed COVID-19, entering a healthcare providers office, entering a public setting where social distancing is difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery store pharmacy), or if you are having respiratory symptoms. Also expands the mask mandate for wearing face coverings on transportation. Coded as Mandate2. because it does not expressly require masks or facial coverings across all public settings (indoor and outdoor), and due to its less than direct mandate approach (i.e., must follow guidance from DOH) versus expressly mandating masks. On 20200622, eased to a recommendation with Phase 2: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

Establishes eased gathering rule for religious groups. (quote) Places of worship may operate with expanded capacity limits. In no event shall attendance at any service exceed fifty percent (50%) of the capacity of the facility or one hundred (100) persons, whichever is fewer (quote). Also eases the overall restriction for nonreligious gatherings from 10 to 50 - both indoor and outdoor. (quote) The prohibition on large gatherings of more than ten (10) individuals, in force since March 24, 2020 (Mayors Order 2020-053), is repealed and replaced by a prohibition on mass gatherings of over fifty (50) persons (quote) Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf

Eases mask policy to a recommendation for the broader public, while still requiring masks to be worn by customers upon entering or waiting in line to enter essential businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to limited settings.
During Phase 2 of reopening starting on 20200622 school buildings can open under certain guidelines

Mask requirement applies whether in an indoor space, such as the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives, or businesses or other establishments open to the public, or public transportation, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. Exemptions include for individuals under the age of 2 yeras old, due to medical conditions or disabilities, etc. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf. Extended to 20210401: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%20127%2012-18-2020.pdf. Extended to 20210521: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%E2%80%99s%20Order%202021-038%20%20Extension%20of%20the%20Public%20Emergency%20and%20Public%20Health%20Emergency%20and%20Modified%20Measures%20in%20Phase%20Two%20of%20Washington%2C%20DC%20Reopening%20%203-17-2021_0.pdf.

Quarantine order for entry into DC (quote) All residents and persons traveling to or from high-risk areas within the prior fourteen (14) days for non-essential travel must self-quarantine for fourteen (14) days following their return or arrival to the District (quote). Maryland and Virginia are exempt from high risk area label. As of 20200727, these states are as follows (and will be updated on 20200810): Arkansas, Arizona, Alabama, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-list-high-risk-states As of 20200810 the list of states is as follows: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states On 20200824 states that were added to the updated list include: Delaware, Hawaii, and South Dakota and states that were removed include Montana and New Mexico https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-8-24-2020. Delaware is removed from the list on 20200827: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-updates-list-high-risk-states On 20200908 Montana and Ohio are added to the list and Alaska and Arizona are removed https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-sept8 On 20200921 Alaska, Arizona, Delaware, West Virginia, and Wyoming are added to the list. California, Hawaii, and Ohio are removed. https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-september-21-2020. On 20201002, Arizona is removed and New Mexico is added to the list. https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-oct-5-2020 Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf. On 20201019, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island are added to the list: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-october-19-2020. On 20201102, California, New Jersey, and Oregon are added to the list: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-november-2-2020. On 20201109, eases quarantine restrictions. Instead of self-quarantining for 14 days, travelers from states not considered low-risk can choose to limit daily activities until they obtain a test for COVID-19 within three to five (5) days after their arrival and have received a negative COVID-19 PCR test result. https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/MO-2020-110.pdf. Extended on 20201123 and adds North Dakota as a low-risk state with Hawaii. Maryland and Virginia are exempt https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo. Extended to 20210401: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%20127%2012-18-2020.pdf. On 20210322, creates exemption for vaccinated individuals. Extended to 2020521 https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%E2%80%99s%20Order%202021-038%20%20Extension%20of%20the%20Public%20Emergency%20and%20Public%20Health%20Emergency%20and%20Modified%20Measures%20in%20Phase%20Two%20of%20Washington%2C%20DC%20Reopening%20%203-17-2021_0.pdf On 20210322 adds  Arizona, Arkansas, California, Guam, Kansas, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico, Northern Mariana Islands, Oregon, Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands and Washington to low-risk states and removes North Dakota https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

DC mandates remote education until at least 20201106 on 20200730: https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/School-Year-20-21-Presentation_07-30-20.pdf  On 20201005 the mayor announces that elementary schools will reopen for Term 2 starting 20201109. Other schools remain closed. https://dcpsreopenstrong.com/ Schools will not reopen for in person instruction on 20201109 https://dcpsreopenstrong.com/updates/changes-to-school-reopening-plans/

Expands gathering restrictions. Indoor gatherings cannot exceed 10 people (from 50), and outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 25 people (from 50). Expands indoor gathering limits for places of worship, which may now operate at the lesser of 50 people (from 100) or 50 pct capacity. Does not specify changes to outdoor gathering limits for places of worship, so remains at 100 people. Eased on 20201217: https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-126.pdf.

Eases gathering restrictions for houses of worship. Houses of worship may allow the lesser of 25 pct occupancy or 250 people (including worshippers, clergy, and staff) indoors. Continues social gathering limits. Indoor gatherings cannot exceed 10 people, and outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 25 people. Houses of worship not subject to numeric caps outdoors. Extended to 20210401: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%20127%2012-18-2020.pdf. Extended to 20210521: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayor%E2%80%99s%20Order%202021-038%20%20Extension%20of%20the%20Public%20Emergency%20and%20Public%20Health%20Emergency%20and%20Modified%20Measures%20in%20Phase%20Two%20of%20Washington%2C%20DC%20Reopening%20%203-17-2021_0.pdf.
