PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions. Outdoor gathering limit increases to 50 people. Indoor gatherings continue to be limited at 10 people. Indoor religious gatherings continue to be limited to the lesser of 25 pct capacity or 250 people (including worshippers, clergy, and staff). Outdoor religious gatherings continue to have no numeric cap.  Eased on 20210501 https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/M.O.%202021-060%20Modified%20Measures%20in%20Phase%20Two%20of%20Washington%20DC%20Reopening.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210521 https://coronavirus.dc.gov/page/mayors-order-mayor%E2%80%99s-order-2021-069-modified-measures-springsummer-2021-washington-dc-reopening

Exempts vaccinated individuals from quarantine requirements. Continues allowing travelers from states not considered low-risk to limit daily activities until they obtain a test for COVID-19 within three to five (5) days after their arrival and have received a negative COVID-19 PCR test result. Low-risk states North Dakota and Hawaii. Maryland and Virginia are exempt. Quarantine list as of 20210322: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin, and Wyoming. On 20210405 removes Puerto Rico and Washington and adds Louisiana and Mississippi to low-risk states https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo. On 20210506 Removes Arizona, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico and Oregon from low Risk States and adds Alabama to low Risk States https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo Ends restrictions on 20210521 https://coronavirus.dc.gov/page/mayors-order-mayor%E2%80%99s-order-2021-069-modified-measures-springsummer-2021-washington-dc-reopening

Continues public mask requirement but introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Fully vaccinated individuals (2 weeks after 2-dose vaccines or 2 weeks after single-dose vaccines) may gather indoors without masks under certain circumnstances (such as being around other vaccinated individuals, or in the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives for short periods of time, or in businesses or other establishments open to the public) and may gather outdoors without wearing masks. Even fully vaccinated individuals must continue wearing masks on public transportation. The mask requirement continues to apply for unvaccinated individuals whether in an indoor space, such as the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives, or businesses or other establishments open to the public, or public transportation, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. Exemptions include for individuals under the age of 2 yeras old, due to medical conditions or disabilities, etc. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings.

Continues public mask requirement but removes some exemptions previously introduced for fully vaccinated individuals. Fully vaccinated individuals (2 weeks after 2-dose vaccines or 2 weeks after single-dose vaccines) may gather outdoors without wearing masks and may gather indoors without masks only with small groups of fully vaccinated people but will still have to wear a mask when indoor common areas or inside businesses, or on public transportation. The mask requirement continues to apply for unvaccinated individuals whether in an indoor space, such as the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives, or businesses or other establishments open to the public, or public transportation, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. Exemptions include for individuals under the age of 2 years old, due to medical conditions or disabilities, etc. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings.  Ended on 20210518, when it becomes a recommendation https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Masks_and_Cloth_Face_Coverings_DCHealth_COVID-19_Guidance_2021.5.18.pdf

Introduces public mask recommendation with exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Persons who are fully vaccinated do not need to wear masks, except when on public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States, at homeless shelters, at correctional facilities, in childcare facilities, or in healthcare facilities. Unvaccinated individuals should wear a cloth face covering or mask at any indoor or outdoor public setting, including but not limited to office buildings, gyms, apartment common areas, public transportation, or other establishments

(quote) All persons must wear masks indoors as prescribed by DC health guidance and regulations (quote): any business or establishment open to members of the public (including but not limited to: grocery stores, restaurants and bars (when not eating or drinking), places of worship, gyms, office buildings, libraries, indoor entertainment venues, and common areas of apartment or condominium complexes), on public transportation or shared modes of transportation such as taxis, airplanes, trains, etc. Exemptions are children under the ages of 2, individuals for whom wearing a mask may harm their health, while eating or drinking, etc. This applies to both fully vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals. Coded as Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor settings.

Public Health Emergency declared. Extended to 20200905: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-166.pdf. Extended to 20201104: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-213.pdf. Extended to 20201222 https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Public-Health-Emergency-Extension-Filed-10.23.2020.pdf On 20201103 it extends state of emergency for 60 days https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-276.pdf Extended to 20210303 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-316.pdf. Extended to 20210427 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf. Extended to 20210626 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-94.pdf. Allowed to expiry on 20210626.

Bars, pubs, and any licensee authorized to sell alcholic beverages on premises that derive more than 50 pct of gross revenue from sale of alcoholic beverage must suspend the sale of alcoholic beverages for 30 days, effective 20200317. Such vendors may continue to sell alcoholic beverages in sealed containers for consumption off-premises. Easing began for all Phase 2 counties (all counties except for Miami-Date, Broward, and Palm Beach) on 20200605: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf
Closure required: nightclubs. Extended through Phase 1 and Phase 2, but ended restrictions on 20200925 with Phase 3: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Requires public beaches to limit gatherings to no more than 10 persons, requires at least 6 ft distancing. Also supports local beach closures. Ends on 20200605, when gathering restrictions are no longer mandated at the state-level: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf

Announcement from Florida Dept of Education, all public and private K-12 schools and technical center campuses are closed through 20200415, so coded to 20200416. Extended to 20200502: http://www.fldoe.org/core/fileparse.php/7590/urlt/SchoolCampusClosuresExt.pdf Extended for the rest of the academic year: http://www.fldoe.org/newsroom/latest-news/florida-extends-distance-learning-through-remainder-of-academic-year.stml Requires schools to open in August, so coding as an ending on 20200801: http://www.fldoe.org/core/fileparse.php/19861/urlt/DOE-2020-EO-06.pdf
Requires closure of gyms and fitness centers statewide. Eased on 20200518, allowing them to re-open at 50 pct: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-123.pdf
Requires the following to close in Broward and Palm Counties: movie theatres, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades, gymnasiums, fitness studios (and gyms), beaches

For Broward and Palm Beach counties, restaurants and like venues with seating for more than 10 people must close for on-premises services, and only permits delivery, takeaway, etc. Coding as TakeawayOnly for BusinessRestrictLevel since the base policy is to close restaurats for on-premises services. Elsewhere, restaurants are only permitted to operate at up to 50 pct capacity, no more than 10 people at a table (of which is not considered a strong enough initial policy to trigger its inclusion: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-68.pdf)

Statewide closure of on-premises services at restaurants (takeaway, curbside, drive-thru, etc only). Eased on 20200504, with most counties going to Phase 1: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf

Mandates 14 day quarantine on people from New York, New Jersey, and Conneticut, expiry date when emergency order no longer in effect. On 20200327, expanded to include Mandates 14 day quarantine on people from Louisania, enforced by license plate checks, expiry date when emergency order no longer in effect. On 20200508, extended to 20200702 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-114.pdf Eased on 20200605 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf Ended on 20200925: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Per EO 20-83, State Health Officer issues recommendation that (quote) all individuals should cease participation in social or recreational gatherings of more than 10 people (quote). Expiry of 20200508 per EO 20-83

Per EO 20-83, State Health Officer issues recommendation that (quote) all individuals over the age of 65 and all individuals of any age with high-risk conditions should remain in their residence (quote). Expiry of 20200508 per EO 20-83

Closes short-term vacation rental properties, excludes hotels, motels, etc. (quote) I hereby order all parties engaged in rental of vacation rental properties, as defined in section 509.242(l)(c), Florida Statutes, to suspend vacation rental operations. (quote) Eased on 20200518, allowing counties to seek approval to reopen vacation rentals: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-123.pdf

(quote) I hereby order Miami-Dade County, Broward County, Palm Beach County, and Monroe County to restrict public access to businesses and facilities deemed non-essential pursuant to the guidelines established by Miami-Dade County pursuant to its March 19, 2020 Emergency Order 07-20 (quote). These business closures involve non-essential retail and commercial entities.

Requires that groups of people greater than 10 are not permitted to congregate in any public space. Exempts religious gatherings. Ended on 20200605, with recommendation to limit gatherings to 50 or fewer https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf

Applies the closures of non-essential retail and commercial venues statewide, as well as the closure of movie theatres, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades. First eased on 20200504, allowing most counties reopen in person: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf

(quote) all persons in Florida shall limit their movements and personal interactions outside of their home to only those necessary to obtain or provide essential services or conduct essential activities (quote). Specifically emphasizes the requirement that senior citizens and individuals. Extended to 20200504: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-111.pdf Ended mandate on 20200504: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf

Eases restrictions on in-person retail (conditional on maximum 25 pct capacity and must abided by safety guidelines from CDC) and museums and libraries (conditional on 25 pct capacity maximum and interactive functions or exhibits remain closed) in counties that are not Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties. These counties move to Phase 1 over time

Eases restrictions on restaurants (on-premises consumption allowed if no more than 25 pct capacity indoors, follow social distancing measures, keep bar counters closed). Applicable to counties that are not Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach

Stay-at-home recommendation across populations broadly, and strongly encourages senior citizens and individuals with significant underlying medical conditions to stay at home. Starting on 20200605, focuses only on senior citizens and at risk individuals, ending the overall stay-at-home recommendation: https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/20200622-SOF-DOH-Public-Health-Advisory.pdf

Broward and Miami-Dade counties are moved to Phase 1, which eases their restrictions on in-person retail (conditional on maximum 25 pct capacity and must abided by safety guidelines from CDC) and museums and libraries (conditional on 25 pct capacity maximum and interactive functions or exhibits remain closed). These policies are now statewide. On 20200518, eased to permit up to 50 pct capacity: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-123.pdf When counties start moving to Phase 2 on 20200605, remains only a recommendation: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf

Eases restrictions on vacation rentals, allowing counties to seek approval with a written requests for safety plan. Considered easing, and not ending, of state-coordinated restrictions on vacation rentals they still require approval and oversight from the state-level. Ended on 20200925: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Eases restrictions on gyms and fitness centers, allowing them to operate at 50 percent of building occupancy so as long as they follow social distancing for classes and sufficient cleaning. Also allows for professional sports venues to host training, competitions, events and games. Further easing began on 20200605, with gym restrictions becoming recommendations for Phase 2 counties (but continued the professional sports eased restrictions statewide): https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf Ended on 20200925 with Phase 3: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Broward and Miami-Dade counties are moved to Phase 1, which eases their restrictions on restaurants and like establishments (on-premise consumption allowed if no more than 25 pct capacity, follow social distancing measures, keep bar counters closed). On-premise consumption allowed if no more than 25 pct capacity, follow social distancing measures, keep bar counters closed. Further easing occurs immedately, permitting up to 50 pct capacity on 20200518. For Phase 2 counties, starting on 20200605, bar areas can reopen: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf All counties are at Phase 2 by 20200914: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-223.pdf On 20200925, Phase 3 ends restrictions on restaurants, allowing them operate at full capacity. Note that there are clauses in the EO to permit limited occupancy between 50 and 99 pct if local governments justify their need: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars and like venues in all counties except but Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach (as they remain in Phase 1), allowing them to operate up to 50 pct of indoor capacity. Outdoor seating is permissible with appropriate social distancing.
(quote) All persons in Florida are encouraged to avoid congregating in groups larger than 50 persons. (quote) Extended to 20200905: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-166.pdf

For Phase 1 counties, contiues eased restrictions on in-person retail, museums and libraries, now allowing them all to operate at 50 percent capacity as long as they follow safety measures. Ended on 20200914, when all counties went to Phase 2: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf

For Phase 1 counties, continues eased restrictions on gyms and fitness centers, allowing them to operate at 50 percent of building occupancy so as long as they follow social distancing for classes and sufficient cleaning. Ended on 20200914 when all counties went to Phase 2: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-214.pdf

For all counties except for Miami-Date, Broward, and Palm Beach (as they remain in Phase 1), the following businesses are permitted to reopen under Phase 2: (quote) entertainment businesses, including but not limited to movie theaters, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, and arcades may operate at fifty (50) percent of their building capacity, with appropriate social distancing between groups and appropriate sanitation (quote), as well as a subset of personal care services that had not previously opened (quote) personal services, including but not limited to tattooing, body piercing, acupuncture, tanning and massage, may operate with appropriate safety guidelines as outlined by the Department of Health (quote). Also permits amusement parks to reopen as part of Phase 2. Other counties move into Phase 2 gradually, until it is statewide on 20200914: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-223.pdf

All individuals in Florida should wear masks in any setting where social distancing is not possible, with exemptions for children under the age of 2, individuals with a condition for which wearing a face covering would cause medical concern, etc.

(quote) All individuals over the age of 65 and all individuals of any age with high-risk health conditions should limit personal interactions outside of the home and take all measures to limit the risk of exposure to COVID-19 (quote). Ended on 20200925: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Suspends on-premise consumption of alcoholic beverages at venues where alcoholic beverage sales comprise more than 50 pct gross venue. This effectively closes bars for in-person and on-premise consumption, but permits take-away. This bar restriction is now statewide, as this restriction had been in place for Phase 1 counties (Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties). Due to the reference of Phase 2 and the state of public health emergency, we are coding this as linked to the onward emergency extensions. Ended on 20200925 with Phase 3: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

(quote) All individuals should refrain from participation in social or recreational gatherings of more than 10 people (quote). Remains a recommendation. Phase 3 ends recommendation for gathering restrictions, now only includes recommendations of minimizing time in crowds by non-vulnerable populations https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/covid19/Taskforce%20Report.pdf

Miami-Dade and Broward move to Phase 2, where the following businesses are permitted to reopen under Phase 2: (quote) entertainment businesses, including but not limited to movie theaters, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, and arcades may operate at fifty (50) percent of their building capacity, with appropriate social distancing between groups and appropriate sanitation (quote), as well as a subset of personal care services that had not previously opened (quote) personal services, including but not limited to tattooing, body piercing, acupuncture, tanning and massage, may operate with appropriate safety guidelines as outlined by the Department of Health (quote). Also permits amusement parks to reopen as part of Phase 2. Ended on 20200925, as state moves to Phase 3: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all public elementary, secondary, and post-secondary schools on 20200318. Will remain closed through 2020031, so expiry is 20200401. Extened  to 20200425: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/03262002/download Extended for the rest of the academic year on 20200401: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/04012001/download Eases on 20200601: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05282002/download
Closure required: bars. Closure appears to be in full, not permitting takeaway at this time. Began easing on 20200601: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05282002/download

(quote) no business, establishment, corporation, nonprofit corporation, or organization shall allow more than ten (10) persons to be gathered at a single location if such gatherings requires persons to stand or be seated within six (6) feet of other person (quote). Does not appear to exempt religious gatherings at this juncture. Eased on 20200601: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05282002/download
Closure required: nightclubs. Eased on 20200601: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05282002/download

Issues a stay-at-home order for specific populations only. (quote) who have serious underlying conditions likely to cause an increased spread of COVID-19, if such persons were to become infected (quote), persons living in nursing homes or long term care, people with chronic lung disease, people undergoing cancer treatment.

Requires the following to close: gyms, fitness centers, bowling alleys, theaters, live performance venues, and amusement parks, body art studios, hair designers, massage therapy, barber shops. First eased on 20200423, permitting  gyms, fitness centers, bowling alleys, body art studios, hair designers, massage therapy to resume in-person services. Sector-by-sector, easing occured through 20200701, at which live performance venues could reopen: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download

Limited operations (takeout, curbside pick-up, and delivery) required: restaurants and social clubs with dine-in services. Eases on 20200427, permitting indoor services to resume: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/04232002/download

(quote) all residents and visitors of the State of Georgia are required to shelter in place, within their homes or places of residence, meaning remaining in their place of residence and taking every possible precaution to limit social interaction to prevent the spread or infection of COVID-19 to themselves or any other person (quote) Eased on 20200501, only applying to sub-populations: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/04232002/download

Persons (quote) testing positive for COVID-19 shall immediately isolate himself or herself at home or another location approved by the Department (quote). Individuals with suspected COVID-19 shall also isolate or have COVID-19 exposure shall self-quarantine for 14 days. (quote) This Administrative Order shall remain in effect for thirty days following the end of the Public Health State of Emergency declared (quote).  Extended with 20200831 emergency declaration to 20201110. his Administrative Order shall remain in effect for thirty days following the end of the Public Health State of Emergency declared (quote). Eased on 20201204, now allowing indiviuals with COVID-19 exposure to leave quarantine earlier than 14 days if they follow the quarantine protocol: https://dph.georgia.gov/document/administrative-order/administrative-order-10-current/download. Policy extended on 20210211, 20210310, 20210408, 20210510 and 20210629.  The 20210629 extension does not have an expiration date.

(quote) If possible, wear face masks or cloth coverings when you are in public to slow the spread of coronavirus. (quote) Then on 20200423, (quote) All residents and visitors of the State of Georgia are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings as practical while outside their homes or residence, except when eating, drinking, or exercising outdoors (quote). Following businesses may begin in-person services: gyms, fitness centers, bowling alleys, body art studios, hair designers, massage therapy. Requires at least 6 ft distancing, following gathering restrictions (no more than 10 people together), practicing sanitation and hyigene protocols, etc. In the follow-up EO on 20200423, gyms and fitness centers must follow current gathering limitations (ie, no more than 10 people at a time in a single room, 6 ft distancing, no group classes, not opening pools, basketball courts, and other group sporting areas), personal care services can only have 1 patron per service provider at a time, staggering work stations at least 10 ft apart, staggering work schedules so no more than 50 pct of usual employees are present. Bowling alleys can only have up to 6 patrons per lane, lane use is staggered, no congregate setting. While the original 20200420 order said these easings were in effect on 20200424, an EO issued on 20200423 indicated that these eased restrictions were to occur immediately. Eased gyms on 20200514, permitting group classes: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05122002/download Further eases restrictions on gyms, allowing up to 25 people in a single room: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/05282002/download Futher eases on 20200616, allowing up to 50 people (per gathering restrictions): https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Further eases on 20200408, now only requiring 6 ft distancing between at gyms and like venues, personal care services, and bowling alleys: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download   Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

All employees at restaurants are required to wear face coverings at all times. Personal care service providers (eg, barbers, hair stylists, etc) are required to wear personal protective equipment as available and appropriate to their role. Adds more sectors over time as more reopen for in-person services (bars, nightclubs, live performance venues, etc.)  Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Eases restrictions on indoor movie theaters and cinemas, allowing them to reopen as long as they maintain at least 6 ft distancing between patrons and congregating areas are closed (eg, party rooms, playgrounds, arcade rooms). Eases on 20200616, allowing all congregating areas to reopen: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Further eases on 20200408, now only requiring 3.5 ft distancing between parties: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Eases restaurant restrictions by allowing in-person dining services if they maintain no more than 10 patrons per 500 square ft of space per dining location. Also requires at least 6 ft of separation between tables, limit table sizes to no more than 6, prohibit congregation at waiting or bar areas, all restaurant and dining room play areas remain closed. Eases on 20200616, removing occupancy limits and limits to the number of people per table/party, and permitting venues to open congregate settings/playgrounds. Still requires at least 6 ft distancing between seating arrangements/tables, so to some degree occupancy is still limited: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Further eases on 20210408,  now only requiring 42 inches of separation between seating arrangements/tables (i.e., 3.5 feet) instead of 6 ft social distancing: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Eases statewide stay-at-home order to only apply to individuals considered at higher risk for severe illness: persons 65 years and older, those who live in nursing homes, with specific diseases (eg, chronic lung disease, moderate to severe asthma, severe heart disease, immunocompromised, with severe obesity, diabetes, liver disase, and chronic kidney disease on dialysis). Eased on 20200616, now omitting populations older than 65. Now only applies to those who live in nursing homes or with specific diseases (eg, chronic lung disease, moderate to severe asthma, severe heart disease, immunocompromised, with severe obesity, diabetes, liver disase, and chronic kidney disease on dialysis): https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Ends on 20210408: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download

Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to reopen for in-person services conditional on adhering to the following: no more than 25 people or 35 pct capacity of the entire bar, requiring seated service and at least 6 ft distancing between tables, limiting party size to 6 ft. Further eased on 20200616, permitting no more than 50 people or 35 pct capacity of the entire bar: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Further eased on 20210316, requiring only at least 6 ft distancing between seating arrangements/tables: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03122101/download Further eased on 20210408, now only requiring 42 inches of separation between seating arrangements/tables (i.e., 3.5 feet) instead of 6 ft social distancing: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download  Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Eases gathering restrictions, permitting up to 25 people in an indoor or outdoors in a single location if individuals cannot maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Still does not seem to exempt religious gatherings. Eased on 20200616: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download

Eases restrictions on nightclubs, permitting them to reopen conditional on adhering to the following (same restrictions as bars): no more than 25 people or 35 pct capacity of the entire bar, requiring seated service and at least 6 ft distancing between tables, limiting party size to 6 ft. Eased on 20200616, permitting up to 50 people or 35 pct capacity: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Further eases on 20210316, now only requiring at least 6 ft distancing between seating/tables: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03122101/download Further eases on 20200408, now only requiring 3.5 ft distancing between seating/tables: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Eases school restrictions to permit summer school and like programs conditional on following gathering restrictions (ie no more than 25 people) and social distancing between staff, students, etc. Further eases restrictions on 20200616, exempting summer schools from ban on gatherings outside of instruction: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06112001/download Ends state-coordinated restrictions on 20200701, explicitly devolving requirements and guidelines for public elementary and secondary schools to local boards of education: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/06292002/download

Eases restrictions on amusement parks (and like temporary venues, such as carnivals, circuses, etc), permitting them to resume services conditional on adhering to the following: limiting occupancy to adhere to current gathering restrictions (no more than 25 people), enforcing social distancing (ie, at least 6 ft distancing between groups), requiring spacing on rides (eg, open air rides need to having spacing every other row, closed rides can only have people in the same household), not opening rides that promote congregation (eg, wave pools). Ends on 20210408, by omitting continued restrictions in the order: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download

Eases gathering restrictions, permitting up to 50 people in an indoor or outdoors in a single location if individuals cannot maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Still does not seem to exempt religious gatherings. Extended to 20201001: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2020-executive-order/09152001/download. Eases restrictions on live performance venues, permitting them to re-open conditional on the following: venues can reopen with different requirements depending on their tier level (Tier 1 with less than 1000 people, Tier II for 1000 to less than 5000, and Tier III with 5000 or more people). Specific capacity limits are not provided at this juncture, but physical distancing of at least 6 ft between groups is required. Extended to 20210501: https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/03312103/download Ended on 20210501 https://gov.georgia.gov/document/2021-executive-order/04302101/download

Persons with COVID-19 exposure likely to result in infection must quarantine for 14 days from last known exposure. Exposed persons may be able to leave quarantine prior to the expiration of 14 days under certain conditions set out in the Quarantine Protocol. Persons may leave quarantine after 10 days have passed without symptoms, or 7 days have passed and they experience all three criteria: received a negative test result, do not experience symptoms, and have received a test at least 5 days after quarantine and discontinue isolation 48 hours after. Now also stipulates that persons who have been fully vaccinated for COVID-19 (more than 2 weeks following receipt of the second dose in a 2-dose series, or more than 2 weeks following receipt of one dose of a single-dose vaccine) and remain asymptomatic after COVID-19 exposure do not need to quarantine following at COVID-19 exposure. PolicyCodingNotes: Requires customers to wear a face covering while waiting to enter and while at an essential business or operation (e.g., grocery stores, pharmacies). Coded as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is applicable to very limited settings. Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this order on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Advises everyone to wear a mask or face covering when in public. Recommendation extended to 20200601 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2005024-ATG_Seventh-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed-1.pdf Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this recommendation on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

(quote) Elderly and others at high risk for COVID-19 are urged to stay in their residences to the extent possible, except as necessary to seek medical care. (quote) Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this recommendation on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Interisland travel quarantine will remain in place through Aug 31 (at least), so coded accordingly. Mandated self-quarantine requirement takes effect on Aug 11. (quote) all persons traveling to the Islands of Kauai, Hawaii, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao, in the State of Hawaii shall be subject to mandatory self quarantine. The period of self-quarantine shall begin from the date of entry onto the Island and shall last 14 days or the duration of the person’s presence on the Island, whichever is shorter (quote) Extended to 20210101: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/2011051-ATG_Fifteenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Reeased on 20201217 to reduce isolation period from 14 days to 10 days and extended to 20210215: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/2012088-ATG_Seventeenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Extended to 20210414: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2102078-ATG_Eighteenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Extended to 20210609 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

(quote) All individuals shall wear face coverings over their noses and mouths when in public settings (quote). Exemptions are for children under the age of 5, individuals who are medically unable to wear a face covering, when eating, or drinking, or when outdoors when at least 6 ft distancing can be mantained. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across settings. Note that individual Hawaiian islands/counties have had mask mandates at this level at various points in time since May 2020 but this is the first statewide mask mandate at Mandate3. Extended to 20210215: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/2012088-ATG_Seventeenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Extended to 20210414: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2102078-ATG_Eighteenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Extended to 20210609 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf Eased to Mandate2 on 20210525 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/2105107-ATG_Amendment-to-Nineteenth-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Extends interisland travel quarantine but introduces exemptions for vaccinated individuals. All persons traveling to the Islands of Kauai, Hawaii, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao shall be subject to mandatory self quarantine for 10 days or the duration of the visit if shorter. A county may adopt a negative test exception to the Interisland Travel Quarantine and an exception for fully vaccinated individuals. An exception to the Quarantine for Travel Between Counties is authorized (quote) for persons who, prior to departure complete a DOH-approved vaccine regimen in the State of Hawaii and provide validation as well as consent and authorization to access vaccination information as set forth in the States Safe Travels program and in accordance with the Vaccination Information Rules and Penalties attached hereto as Exhibit A. (quote). Extended to and ended on 20210614 at 1159 pm, so coded to 20210615 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/2106080-ATG_21st-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Eases mask mandate under Exhibit I. The amendment lifts the mask mandate for all individuals outdoors, effective immediately. All individuals shall continue to wear face coverings over their noses and mouths when in indoor public settings. Exemptions are for children under the age of 5, individuals who are medically unable to wear a face covering, when eating, or drinking. Coded as a Mandate2under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across indoor settings. Note that individual Hawaiian islands/counties have had mask mandates at this level at various points in time since May 2020.  Extended to 20210807 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/2106080-ATG_21st-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Exempts fully vaccinated individuals from pre-travel testing and quarantine requirements effective 20210708. Otherwise, prior requirements remain in effect for not fully vaccinated individuals: all persons entering the State of Hawaii to be subject to mandatory self-quarantine for 10 days or the duration of the visit if shorter. Continues requiring evidence of a negative test upon arrival and (quote) administered within 72 hours from the final leg of departure and whose negative test results for the COVID-19 disease are either uploaded into the States Safe Travels program prior to departure to the State or provided in written hard copy upon arrival in the State (quote). Makes an exemption for individuals who have been on a boat for at least 10 consecutive days before entering State waters and no one on board has been ill or is exhibiting symptoms of COVID19.

Requires masks to be worn by all staff and all students over the age of 2 when indoors, regardless of vaccination status, when not eating and drinking.  Masks are not required outdoors but are recommended outdoors when social distancing is not possible.
