Through the end of March, Idahoans are encouraged to avoid social gatherings of more than 10 people.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateEnacted to 20200318 (was 20200401) and added DateExpiry of 20200401, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict

PolicyCodingNotes: Blaine County put under shelter in place on 20200319
Bars must close in Blaine County per the non-essential business closure
(quote) Gatherings of individuals outside the home are prohibited (quote). Applicable to Blaine County only.

(quote) All businesses with a facility in Blaine County, except Essential Businesses as defined below in Section 8, are required to cease all activities at facilities located in the County except Minimum Basic Operations (quote). Also explicitly closes nightclubs, as well as indoor gyms and recreation facilities, Blaine County.
Limited operations required (takeout and delivery only): restaurants and cafes. Applicable to Blaine County only. In effect at 1159 pm on 2020320 (coded to 20200321)

On 20200323, all public schools are directed to have a (quote) soft closure (quote)(changed 20200331). The soft closure is because school districts are mantaining food services for needy students for pickup and enacting distance learning. The EO does not have an enact date so is assumed to go into effect immediately. Soft closure extended to end of academic year by Department of Education . Board of DOE approves framework that provides local districts with critera to make localized decisions about reopened on 20200709: https://boardofed.idaho.gov/resources/board-approves-school-reopening-framework/
Closes bars statewide. Eased as part of Stage 3 on 20200530 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325, until 1159 pm 20200415 (coded to 20200416). (quote) Limit all non-essential gatherings of any number of individuals outside the household (quote). Includes faith-based activity, with the exception of funerals as long as they comply with social distancing requirements. On 20200501, mandate became a recommendation, ending the formal gathering restriction: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325, until 1159 pm 20200415 (coded to 20200416). All businesses with a facility in the State of Idaho except Essential Businesses are required to cease all activities. Also explicitly closes nightclubs, also closes all indoor gyms and recreation facilities. On 20200501, eases restrictions on the operations of in-person businesses in their physical locations unless they were exempted: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf On 20200516, eases restrictions on indoor gyms and fitness centers, as well as personal care services: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf On 20200530, indoor movie theaters can reopen: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf On 20200611, ends all mandated restrictions: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations (drive-thru, carry-out,delivery still permitted) as of non-essential business closure. Continues to have restrictions under Stay Healthy Order https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325. Expiry is currently 1159 pm on 20200415, extended to 20200430 on 20200415. Ended on 20200501 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf

Department of Public Health recommendation on the use of cloth face coverings. Additional extensions are issued alongside shifts to new stages. Extended on 20201230 https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage-2-modified-order_r.pdf. Extended on 20210202 as part of the Phase 3 stage of reopening, the recommendation that individuals wear face coverings while in public, especially when 6 ft distancing is not always possible (i.e., inside businesses), continues. Masks continue to be mandatory in long-term care facilities. https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage3-stay-healthy-guidelines-020221.pdf Extended on 20210511: As part of the Phase 4 stage of reopening, individuals should wear a face covering over their nose and mouth as per guidance from CDC for vaccinated and unvaccinated people. Masks continue to be mandatory in long-term care facilities. https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-stay-healthy-guidelines-051121.pdf

The amendment the stay-at-home order to include this travel restriction (Section 7) was included on 20200415. (Quote) Persons entering the state of Idaho are required to self-quarantine for 14 days. (Quote). Quarantine continued on 20200501 without expiry https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf. Ended the mandate, went to a recommendation on 20200516: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

(quote) Persons who have tested positive for COVID-19, are presumptively diagnosed with COVID-19, or are exhibiting symptoms identified in the CDC screening guidance shall not enter the state of Idaho unless doing so under medical orders for the purposes of medical care, are being transported by emergency personnel, are being driven directly to a medical provider for purposes of medical care, or are a resident of the state of Idaho. (quote) Ends on 20200516, replaces with recommendation: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

(quote) Intrastate travel is prohibited, including but not limited to, travel on scooter, motorcycle, automobile, or public transit, except for those purposes defined in Section 8. People must use public transit only for purposes of performing Essential Activities or to travel to and from work to operate Essential Businesses or maintain Essential Governmental Functions (quote)

(quote) gatherings, both public and private, should be avoided (quote) as part of stage 1. Eased on 20200516 with introduction of gathering recommendation of 10: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Recommends that vulnerable individuals (per CDC definitions) continue to self-isolate via staying at home. Ended on 20200530: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf

Recommendation that gathering or more than 10 people, both private and public, should be avoided. Eased on 20200530 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) individuals arriving in Idaho from another country or from an area outside of Idaho with substantial community spread are strongly encouraged to self-quarantine (quote). Ended as part of transition to Stage 4 on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Restaurants are permitted to re-open upon their plans being approved by local public health districts. No explicit capacity limits are provided so leaving those variables blank. Per Stage 2 order, All businesses resuming in-person services must adhere to sanitation and distancing requirements (at least 6 feet between individuals) and businesses are required to development and implement measures to ensure this kind of physical distancing. Reopening guidance: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/Protocols_RestaurantsD1026-01.pdf Ends on 20200611 when it goes to recommended guidelines: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-protocols-restaurants.pdf

(quote) persons who have tested positive for COVID-19, are presumptively diagnosed...should not enter Idaho (quote). Ended travel recommendation on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to reopen as part of Stage 3. No explicit capacity limits are provided so leaving those variables blank. All patrons must be seated. Per Stage 3 order, All businesses resuming in-person services must adhere to sanitation and distancing requirements (at least 6 feet between individuals) and businesses are required to development and implement measures to ensure this kind of physical distancing. Specific guidelines for bar and like venue reopening are here: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/Protocols_BarsBreweriesD1026-03.pdf Ended on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Eases gathering recommendation to up to 50, Idaho remains in stage 3. Not mandated (quote) Gatherings of more than 50 people, both public and private, should be avoided. People participating in gatherings of 50 or fewer people, while permitted, should adhere to the Social Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 7. (quote) Ended state movement to Stage 4 on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Idaho moves back to Stage 3 and implements gathering restrictions. Indoor limit is 50 individuals and outdoor capacity limit is 25 pct of max occupancy. Gatherings for political expression and religious activities are exempt.

(quote) Gatherings of more than 10 people, both public and private, are prohibited. (quote) This is applies both indoors and outdoors. Exemptions include religious gatherings, political expression, gatherings of individuals in the same household. Extended on 20201230 https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage-2-modified-order_r.pdf. On 20210202, as part of the Phase 3 stage of reopening, gathering limits are no longer mandated, but rather Idahoans are advised to limit gatherings to (quote) 50 or fewer people and adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements (quote). Exemptions include religious gatherings, gathrings of political expression, extracurricular activity participation or attendance, and educational activities. Large events, such as weddings, trade events, or sporting events, that exceed size and capacity limits (quote) may receive an exemption if the organizer submits a plan for the gathering to the local health district having authority where the gathering is to occur and signs an attestation agreeing to comply with the provisions of the plan submitted to the local health district. (quote) https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage3-stay-healthy-guidelines-020221.pdf

(quote) People at increased risk for severe illness should self-isolate. Because of the risk of the rapid spread of the virus, and the need to protect all citizens of the State ofldaho, this Order strongly encourages individuals at increased risk anywhere in Idaho to stay at home (quote). Extended on 20201230 https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage-2-modified-order_r.pdf. As part of the Phase 3 stage of reopening, Idaho rescinds Stay At Healthy Order dated 20201230, ending recommendation Stay At Home recommendation for vulnerable populations and instead encourages physical distancing in social settings. https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage3-stay-healthy-guidelines-020221.pdf

As part of the Phase 3 stage of reopening, gathering limits are no longer mandated, but rather Idahoans are advised to limit gatherings to (quote) 50 or fewer people and adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements (quote). Exemptions include religious gatherings, gathrings of political expression, extracurricular activity participation or attendance, and educational activities. Large events, such as weddings, trade events, or sporting events, that exceed size and capacity limits (quote) may receive an exemption if the organizer submits a plan for the gathering to the local health district having authority where the gathering is to occur and signs an attestation agreeing to comply with the provisions of the plan submitted to the local health district. (quote) https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage3-stay-healthy-guidelines-020221.pdf Eased on 20210511 https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-stay-healthy-guidelines-051121.pdf

As part of the Phase 4 stage of reopening, gatherings of any size are permitted, and they should adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements (including providing for six (6) feet of spacing between guests to the extent possible). Organizers of gatherings and events should
consider local COVID-19 case rates when planning gatherings and events and contact their local public health district for consultation or questions.

Proclamation of disaster issued. Extended every 30 days. Last extension was to 20210207: https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/CoronavirusDisasterProc-01-08-2021.pdf. Extended to 20210307: https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/CoronavirusDisasterProc-2-5-2021.pdf. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/CoronavirusDisasterProc-3-5-2021.pdf. Extended to 20210502: https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/CoronavirusDisasterProc-4-2-2021.pdf. Extended to 20210530 https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/CoronavirusDisasterProc-4-30-2021.pdf Extended to 20210627 https://www2.illinois.gov/sites/gov/Documents/Coronavirus-Disaster-Proc-05-28-2021.pdf Extended to 20210725 https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-14.html. Extended to 20210822: https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-15.html
Prohibits public and private gatherings over 1,000 people for the duration of the disaster proclamation

All public and private schools closed for educational purposes. Eases closure to limited in-person instruction starting on 20200604 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-40.aspx.

Limited operations required (delivery, carry-out, drive-through only): bars. On-site consumption is not permitted. Eased on 20200529, allowing outdoor services: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-38.aspx

Limited operations required (delivery, carry-out, drive-through only): restaurants. Easing began on 20200529, permitting outdoor on-premises food and beverage consumption with DCEO guidance and when permitted by local ordinances and guidelines: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-38.aspx

Prohibits public and private gatherings over 50. (quote) A public or private gathering includes community, civic, public leisure, faith-based events, sporting events with spectators, concerts, conventions, and any similar event or activity that brings together 50 or more people in a single room or a single space at the same time. This includes venues such as fitness centers/health clubs, bowling alleys, private clubs, and theatres (quote). Note that the the gathering limits for businesses are do not meet the threshold for an initial business restriction (i.e., 25 pct maximum capacity, no more than 10 people in a single room at a time).
Gathering restriction of 10 or more. Eased on 20200626, permitting gatherings of no more than 50 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-43.aspx

(quote) All businesses and operations in the State, except Essential Businesses and Operations as defined below, are required to cease all activities (quote). Also explicitly lists the following as being closed to the public: (quote) All places of public amusement, whether indoors or outdoors, including but not limited to, locations with amusement rides, carnivals, amusement parks, water parks, aquariums, zoos, museums, arcades, fairs, childrens play centers, playgrounds, funplexes, theme parks, bowling alleys, movie and other theaters, concert and music halls, and country clubs or social clubs shall be closed to the public (quote). Easing began on 20200501, permitting non-essential retail to re-open to takeaway services: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-32.aspx Continues to ease different types of sectors over time, but continues to keep at least fairs and other large venues closed during Phase 4

Stay at home mandated, effective at 5 pm on 20200320, originally expires 20200407, extended to 20200430 via EO 2020-18: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-18.aspx. Ended 20200529 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-38.aspx

Employees must wear a face covering when they may come within 6 ft of another employee or customer. Essential retail stores and manufacturers are required to provide face coverings to all employees who are not able to maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Extended to 20210207: Employees must wear a face covering when they may come within 6 ft of another employee or customer. Essential retail stores and manufacturers are required to provide face coverings to all employees who are not able to maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Extended to 20210502: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-06.aspx Extended to 20210530 and Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated people, who no longer need to wear a mask outdoors, except in crowded settings and venues where there is a decreased ability to maintain physical distance https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-09.aspx
Eases restrictions, permitting non-essential retail to re-open to permit the fulfilment of telephone and online orders, and curbside/pick-up services are permitted.

(quote) Any individual who is over age two and able to medically tolerate a face-covering (a mask or cloth face-covering) shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a face-covering when in a public place and unable to maintain a six-foot social distance. Face-coverings are required in public indoor spaces such as stores. (quote) Coded to Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use in all public settings where social distancing cannot be maintained, which implies indoor and outdoor settings. On 20200529, clarified that this mandate applies to outdoor settings, (quote) This requirement applies whether in an indoor space, such as a store, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. (quote): https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-38.aspx Policy was extended on 20200724 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-48.aspx. Extended to 20201018 on 20200918: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-55.aspx. Extended to 20201115 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-59.aspx. Extended to 20201213 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-71.aspx. Extended to 20210110: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-74.aspx. Extended to 20210207: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-01.aspx. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Extended to 20210502: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-06.aspx Extended to 20210530 and Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated people, who no longer need to wear a mask outdoors, except in crowded settings and venues where there is a decreased ability to maintain physical distance https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-09.aspx
Eases restrictions on bars to permit outdoor services conditional on DCEO guidance (i.e., table at least 6 ft apart from each other, no more than 6 people per party)

(quote) Any gathering of more than ten people is prohibited unless exempted by this Executive Order (quote), which then applies to religious gatherings and houses of worship, now no longer requring gathering limits and only recommending them: (quote) To protect the health and safety of faith leaders, staff, congregants and visitors, religious organizations and houses of worship are encouraged to consult and follow the recommended practices and guidelines from the Illinois Department of Public Health...(quote). Indoor services up to 10 people is recommended, or outdoors with social distancing.

Further eases restrictions on retail businesses, allowing them to re-open to in-person services at a maxmimum of 50 pct occupancy (if in Tier 1 or 2), provide face coverings to employees, phsyical distancing, etc. During Tier 3 mitigation measures, capacity was reduced to 25 pct capacity (except for drug and grocery stores, which were allowed to operate at 50 percent). DateEased reflects the shift to a 50 percent capacity rule statewide. Extended 20210122: https://www2.illinois.gov/IISNews/22677-Region_4_Moves_to_Tier_2_%E2%80%93_All_Regions_out_of_Tier_3_Mitigations.pdf. Extended 20210205: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended 20210305: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx.

Eases restrictions on the following businesses as part of Phase 3, permitting them to re-open to in-person services conditional on following DCEO guidance: non-essential manufacturing and professional offices (i.e., requires at least 6 ft distancing, employee monitoring, mask use, etc), personal care services (i.e., requires 6 ft distancing between stations, use face coverings for both patrons and employees), gyms and fitness centers (i.e., only permitting one-on-one training, outdoor fitness classes up to 10 people, no contact acticities), and outdoor recreational facilities (i.e., driving ranges, outdoor shooting ranges, paintball courses, outdoor adventure parks). The latter are included in this group of eased business restrictions because at least some indoor services (e.g., locker-rooms) and common areas as long as fewer than 10 people congregate with 6 ft distancing and masks are permitted. Eased during Phase 4, allowing higher ocucpancy levels (up to 50 pct at gyms and larger groups), and allowing higher occupancy of indoor and outdoor recreational activities: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-43.aspx Starting on 20201118, Tier 3 mitigation measures reduced capacity to 25 pct at gyms and personal care services, and only permitting outdoor recreational facilities to operate. Began easing on 20210115: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-02.aspx

Eases restrictions on restaurants to permit outdoor services conditional on DCEO guidance (i.e., table at least 6 ft apart from each other, no more than 6 people per party). Eased on 20200626, allowing indoor services: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-43.aspx

(quote) People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19, including elderly people and those with a health condition that may make them vulnerable, are urged to stay in their residence and minimize in-person contact with others to the extent possible. (quote) Extended to 20210207: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-01.aspx. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Extended to 20210502: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-06.aspx Extended to 20210530 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-09.aspx

All public and non-public K-12 schools may reopen for limited in-person educational purposes (e.g, summer school) after the completion of 2019-2020 term. Requires limiting the number of individuals in one space at 10 or fewer. On 20200626, Permits up to 50 indiviudals in a single space (per Phase 4 guidelines), a level at which we view the schools no longer being closed for in-person instruction. (quote) All public and nonpublic schools in Illinois serving pre-kindergarten through 12th grade students may open for in-person educational purposes, such as summer school, following the completion of the regular 2019-2020 school term. (quote) Note that on 20200724, Illinois issued an additional order clarifying the re-opening of schools for in-person instruction under the same restrictions: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-47.aspx

All public and non-public K-12 schools must require the (quote) use of appropriate personal protective equipment, including the use of face coverings by students, staff, and visitors who are over age two and able to medically tolerate a face covering. Schools must provide face coverings to all employees who are not able to maintain a minimum six-foot social distance at all times and, to the extent possible, make disposable face coverings available for all students. (quote) Extended to 20210207: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-01.aspx. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Extended to 20210502: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-06.aspx Extended to 20210530 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-09.aspx Extended to 20210627 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-11.asp On 20210611, Governor states that (quote) Individuals in schools, day care settings, and educational institutions should continue to follow separate guidance issued by the Illinois State Board of Education, Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, and the Illinois Department of Public Health (quote). According to updated guidance from the Illinois Department of Public Health, all staff and students must wear a face covering, provided the following excepted circumstances: when eating or drinking, when children are napping, when playing an instrument and 6 ft of distance between students is maintained, for staff when alone in their classrooms, among fully vaccinated staff in meetings, and outdoors, for both students and staff (except for those who are unvaccinated, in a high transmission area, and in a crowded setting). Coded as easing, as this guidance includes new exceptions to face covering requirements, such as outdoor exceptions. https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-12.html. Extended to 20210725 https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-14.html/. Extended to 20210822: https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-15.html
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry, added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Further eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to reopen for indoor services conditional on DCEO guidance (i.e., 25 pct standing area capacity, seating capacity limited based on at least 6 ft distancing between tables, 10 person party limit)

(quote) Any gathering of more than fifty people is prohibited unless exempted by this Executive Order (quote), which then applies to religious gatherings and houses of worship, now no longer requring gathering limits and only recommending them: (quote) To protect the health and safety of faith leaders, staff, congregants and visitors, religious organizations and houses of worship are encouraged to consult and follow the recommended practices and guidelines from the Illinois Department of Public Health...(quote). Indoor services up to 10 people is recommended, or outdoors with social distancing. Extended to 20201115, though more regions had additional mitigation measures added over time
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on previously closed busineses, (quote) places of public amusement may resume services consistent with DCEO guidance for indoor recreation (including but not limited to arcades, bowling alleys, and driving ranges), museums and aquariums, zoos and botanical gardens, theaters and performing arts, and outdoor seated spectator events. (quote). Capacity limits are less than 50 people or up to 50 pct capacity (whichever is lower) for most venues (e.g., bowling alleys, skating rinks, indoor theaters, cinemas, performing arts centers), while museums, aquariums, and zoos are 25 pct capacity. Outdoor seated spectator seats are at 20 pct of capacity.

Further eases restrictions on restaurants, permitting them to reopen for indoor services conditional on DCEO guidance (i.e., 25 pct standing area capacity, seating capacity limited based on at least 6 ft distancing between tables, 10 person party limit)

The following public health restrictions and mitigations are instituted for the Metro East region, comprised of Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, and Washington Counties. Expands eased restrictions on bars which, in addition to Phase 4 guidance (eg 25 pct capacity), must close at 11 pm, customers must be seated at tables spaced 6 ft apart, indoor groups of no more than 10, no congregating at the bar area, each party must have a reservation so to have contact information. Indoor services are still permitted as part of Tier 1 mitigation, but now no more than than 25 people per room constitutes an expansion

The following public health restrictions and mitigations are instituted for the Metro East region, comprised of Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, and Washington Counties: gatherings are limited to the lesser of 25 people or 25 pct of overall room capacity. Religious gatherings are exempted from mandated requirements per prior orders. More regions are added to these restrictions over time
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: The following business restrictions are expanded for Metro East region, per Tier 1 mitigation measures: gaming venues and casinos are limited to 25 pct capacity and must close by 1100 pm. Additional Phase 4 guidance continues: indoor food services can occur in alignment with restaurant guidelines, required masking and physical distancing between terminals, etc. Extended to 20200920: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-52.aspx

The following public health restrictions and mitigations are instituted for the Metro East region, comprised of Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, and Washington Counties. Expands eased restrictions on restaurants which, in addition to Phase 4 guidance (eg 25 pct capacity), must close at 11 pm, customers must be seated at tables spaced 6 ft apart, indoor groups of no more than 10, no congregating at the bar area, each party must have a reservation so to have contact information. Indoor services are still permitted as part of Tier 1 mitigation, but now no more than than 25 people per room constitutes an expansion

Region 7 (Will and Kankakee counties) must close indoor on-premises consumption for bars, permitting outdoor services only (physical distancing of at least 6 ft required between tables, no more than 10 people per table), reservations required. Also requires bars to close between 1100 pm and 600 am. More and more locations are moved to this level of restriction over time

Region 7 (Will and Kankakee counties) have expanded restrictions on the following: gaming venues and casinos are limited to 25 pct capacity and must close by 1100 pm and remain closed through 600 am. Additional Phase 4 guidance continues: indoor food services can occur in alignment with restaurant guidelines, required masking and physical distancing between terminals, etc. More and more counties are added to these restrictions over time (until it becomes a statewide policy)

Region 7 (Will and Kankakee counties) must close indoor on-premises consumption for restaurants, permitting outdoor services only (physical distancing of at least 6 ft required between tables, no more than 10 people per table), reservations required. Also requires restaurants to close between 1100 pm and 600 am. More and more locations are moved to this level of restriction over time

Expands restrictions for Region 1 (Boone, Carroll, DeKalb, Jo Daviess, Lee, Ogle, Stephenson, Whiteside, and Winnebago counties): gatherings are limited to no more than 10 people. Religious gatherings are exempted from mandated requirements per prior orders. More locations are added to this level of restriction over time
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands bar restrictions for Region 2 (Rock Island, Henry, Bureau, Putnam, Kendall, Grundy, Mercer, Knox, Henderson, Warren, McDonough, Fulton, Stark, Marshall, Peoria, Tazwell, McLean, Woodford, Livingston, Lasalle): bars must close indoor on-premises consumption, permitting outdoor services only (physical distancing of at least 6 ft required between tables, no more than 10 people per table), reservations required. Also requires bars to close between 1100 pm and 600 am. Note that counties under Tier 2 mitigation measures have a limit of 6 people per table rather than 10, but we are not currently coding this separately. On 20201113, all locations are put under Tier 3 mitigations, which then limit tables to no more than 6 people. Eased starting on 20210119: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-03.aspx.

Expands restrictions for Region 2 (Rock Island, Henry, Bureau, Putnam, Kendall, Grundy, Mercer, Knox, Henderson, Warren, McDonough, Fulton, Stark, Marshall, Peoria, Tazwell, McLean, Woodford, Livingston, Lasalle): gaming venues and casinos are limited to 25 pct capacity and must close by 1100 pm and remain closed through 600 am. Additional Phase 4 guidance continues: indoor food services can occur in alignment with restaurant guidelines, required masking and physical distancing between terminals, etc. Now a statewide policy

Expands restaurant restrictions for Region 2 (Rock Island, Henry, Bureau, Putnam, Kendall, Grundy, Mercer, Knox, Henderson, Warren, McDonough, Fulton, Stark, Marshall, Peoria, Tazwell, McLean, Woodford, Livingston, Lasalle): restaurants must close indoor on-premises consumption, permitting outdoor services only (physical distancing of at least 6 ft required between tables, no more than 10 people per table), reservations required. Also requires restaurants to close between 1100 pm and 600 am. Note that counties under Tier 2 mitigation measures have a limit of 6 people per table rather than 10, but we are not currently coding this separately. On 20201113, all locations are put under Tier 3 mitigations, which then limit tables to no more than 6 people. Eased starting on 20210119: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-03.aspx

(quote) Indoor gatherings of more than one household are prohibited by this Executive Order, unless exempted by this Executive Order. Outdoor gatherings are limited to no more than ten people. Nothing in this Executive Order prohibits the gathering of members of a household or residence (quote). Coding as 0 for indoor gathering restrictions (gatherings permitted for a single household, and thus those living within the same household). Extended to 20210207: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-01.aspx Eased on 20210115, allowing some regions to move to Tier 2: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-02.aspx
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes, added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands restrictions on casinos and gaming, requiring them to cease operations as part of Tier 3 mitigation measures statewide. Eased beginning on 20210115: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-02.aspx

As part of statewide Tier 3 mitigation measures, all recreational facilities and places of amusement have to close indoor operations, only permitting outdoor services up to 25 pct with groups of no more than 10 people. Applies to the following: driving ranges, shooting ranges, paintball courses, adventure parks, arcades, bowling alleys, theaters and performing arts, and outdoor seated spectator events, bowling alleys, skating rinks, indoor theaters, cinemas, performing arts centers, museums, aquariums, and zoos. Eased beginning on 20210115: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-02.aspx

Regions 1, 2, and 5 are designated under Tier 2 mitigation measures, limiting gatherings to no more than 10 people indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings from these requirements. More regions move to this level of restriction over time

Regions 1, 2, and 5 are designated under Tier 2 mitigation measures, thus allowing casinos and camping venues to reopen at no more than 25 pct capacity, physical distancing between machines, etc. Venues must close between 1100 pm and 600 am each day. Further eased on 20210119, with regions returning to Phase 4 and permitting up to 50 capacity: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-03.aspx

Regions 1, 2, and 5 are designated under Tier 2 mitigation measures, allowing for all indoor public amusement and indoor recreation facilities can now resume indoor services up to 25 pct capacity or no more than 25 people, with up to 10 people groups. Further eased on 20210119 when Phase 4 regions could go to 50 pct capacity for these types of facilities: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-03.aspx

Regions under Tier 1 mitigation are permitted to have up to indoor services limited to no more than 25 pct capacity or 25 persons per room, no more than 4 people at a table indoors. Also limits hours of operation (must close between 1100 pm and 600 am for on premises services). More locations move under Tier 1 mitigation over time

Regions under Phase 4 are permitted to have up to 25 pct standing area capacity indoors, with seating capacity limited based on at least 6 ft distancing between tables, 10 person party limit. More locations move under Phase 4 restrictions over time
Regions under Phase 4 guidelines are restricted to gatherings of no more than 50 people, indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings. More regions move to this level over time.

Regions under Tier 1 mitigation are restricted to gatherings of no more than 25 people or 25 pct capacity (whichever is lower) for both indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings. More regions move to this level over time.

Regions under Tier 1 mitigation are permitted to have up to indoor services limited to no more than 25 pct capacity or 25 persons per room, no more than 4 people at a table indoors. Also limits hours of operation (must close between 1100 pm and 600 am for on premises services). More locations move under Tier 1 mitigation over time

Regions under Phase 4 are permitted to have up to 25 pct standing area capacity indoors, with seating capacity limited based on at least 6 ft distancing between tables, 10 person party limit. More locations move under Phase 4 restrictions over time

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St Clair, Washington) moves to Tier 2, bringing all regions statewide to have some level of indoor services at public amusement and recreation facilities (25 pct capacity for Tier 2 and 50 pct capacity for Tier 1 and Phase 4 regions, with varying absolute levels).

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, where bars are permitted to have up to 25 pct standing area capacity indoors, with seating capacity limited based on at least 6 ft distancing between tables, 10 person party limit. All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 such that those with a negative test within the last three days are exempt from capacity limits. Also, vaccinated individuals no longer count against capacity limits: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22961.

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, where gatherings are restricted to no more than 50 people, indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings. All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 to allow gatherings up to 100 people outdoors and to exempt those with a negative test from capacity restrictions. New policy also exempts vaccinated individuals from gathering restrictions.

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, where casinos and gaming venues operate at up to 50 pct capacity, indoor food services can occur in alignment with restaurant guidelines, required masking and physical distancing between terminals, etc. All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 such that those with a negative test within the last three days are exempt from capacity limits. Also, vaccinated individuals no longer count against capacity limits: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22961.

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, joining other Phase 4 regions with the following restrictions: gyms and fitness centers are limited to 50 pct capacity, and personal care services have to adhere to at least 6 ft distancing between stations. Continues prior eased restrictions on non-essential manufacturing and professional services (i.e., requires at least 6 ft distancing, employee monitoring, mask use, etc). All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 such that those with a negative test within the last three days are exempt from capacity limits. Also, vaccinated individuals no longer count against capacity limits: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22961.

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, joining other Phase 4 regions with the following restrictions: allowing indoor and outdoor recreational facilities (i.e., driving ranges, shooting ranges, paintball courses, adventure parks) to operate at up to 50 pct capacity and no more than 50 people in a room (in addition to at least 6 ft distancing, masking). All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 such that those with a negative test within the last three days are exempt from capacity limits. Also, vaccinated individuals no longer count against capacity limits: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22961.

Region 4 (Bond, Clinton, Madison, Monroe, Randolph, St. Clair, Washington) moves to Phase 4, joining other Phase 4 regions with the following restrictions: (quote) places of public amusement may resume services consistent with DCEO guidance for indoor recreation (including but not limited to arcades, bowling alleys, and driving ranges), museums and aquariums, zoos and botanical gardens, theaters and performing arts, and outdoor seated spectator events. (quote). Capacity limits are less than 50 people or up to 50 pct capacity (whichever is lower) for most venues (e.g., bowling alleys, skating rinks, indoor theaters, cinemas, performing arts centers), while museums, aquariums, and zoos are 25 pct capacity. Outdoor seated spectator seats are at 20 pct of capacity. All regions are now in Phase 4, making the policy statewide. Extended to 20210307:https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-04.aspx. Extended to 20210404: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx. Eased on 20210318 such that those with a negative test within the last three days are exempt from capacity limits, outdoor venues are eased to 25 pct capacity, and indoor venues of at least 200-person capacity are eased to 25 pct capacity. Also, vaccinated individuals no longer count against capacity limits: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22961.

Now completely exempts fully vaccinated people from state mask requirements (federal mask requirements on public transportation still apply). Otherwise extends the following: (quote) Any individual who is over age two and able to medically tolerate a face covering (a mask or cloth face covering) shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when in a public place and unable to maintain a six-foot social distance. (quote) Emphasizes (quote) This requirement applies whether in an indoor space, such as a store, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. (quote) Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20210627 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-11.asp. Exempts vaccinated individuals from stay at home recommendation. (quote) Extended to 20210627 https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-11.asp On 20210611 Illinois moves to Phase 5 and no longer recommends that (quote) People who are not fully vaccinated and who are at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19, including elderly people and those with a health condition that may make them vulnerable (quote) stay home. Now, they are simply urged to minimize in-person contact with others to the extent possible. Coded as ending. https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/resources/executive-orders/display.executive-order-2021-12.html

Illinois moves to Phase 5, issuing new recommended guidance for business masks. PolicyCodingNotes: For all counties but Elkhart (which remains in Stage 4), Stage 4.5 allows for the resumption of fairs, festivals, parades and other places of public amusement. For outdoor venues, events must ensure social distancing can be maintained and sanitation measures are in place. For indoor venues, maximum of 50 pct occupancy in addition to social distancing measures. Face coverings strongly recommended. Also youth overnight camps may open conditional on screenings, recommended face coverings

Requires wearing individuals 8 years old and older to wear a mask or other face covering in public indoor spaces (inclusive of commercial entities), public transportation and vehicle services (inclusive of taxis and ride shares), and outdoor public spaces when social distancing from others is not possible.Makes exemptions for private offices, private workspaces, and meetings where 6 ft of social distancing can be achieved, as well as children under the age of 2 years, individuals with with a medical condition or disability preventing the wearing of a face covering, when engaging in sports, attending/engaged in a religious service where social distancing is occuring of at least 6 ft. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal EO was signed on 20200724, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722). PolicyCodingNotes: Eases public mask requirement to only include certain settings. Coded as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to a narrow set of indoor and outdoor settings. PolicyCodingNotes: Extended on 20200326 to 20200416, extended on 20200406 to 11:59 on 20200430, coded accordingly: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.04.06.pdf Extended to 20200516 https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf Eased on 20200501 to exempt religious gatherings: https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf

Closure required: fitness centers, health clubs, gyms, aquatic centers, theaters, performance venues, casinos. In effect at noon on 20200317 to 1159 pm on 20200331, so coded to 20200401. By 20200618, all businesses originally under this closure could open to some degree in person: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf

Limited operations required (only take-out, delivery, drive through): restaurants. Eased for most counties starting on 20200501 https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf. Extended to 20200516 for 22 counties: https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf

Closure required: salons, medical spas, barbershops, tattoo establishments, tanning facilities, massage therapy establishments, and swimming pools. Easing began on 20200508 with tanning facilities no longer required to remain closed and being recommended to follow guidelines. All businesses under this policy could re-open to some degree of in-person services starting on 20200522: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.20.pdf

Expands closures to include a list of non-essential retail establishments (e.g., bookstores, clothing stores, shoe stores, florists, furniture and home furnishing stores, cosmetic stores, florists). Initial easing occurred on 20200501 for most counties: https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf All non-essential retail was permitted to re-open by 20200515: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf

Closes all public and nonpublic schools. Extended to the end of the academic year on 20200427 https://www.homelandsecurity.iowa.gov/documents/disasters/proclamations/2020/PROC_2020_44_COVID-19_April27.pdf Ended on 20200601 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.26%20%281%29.pdf

Expands businesses required to close, including enclosed malls, tobacco and vaping stores, toy and entertainment stories, social and fraternal clubs, amusement venues, museums libraries aquariums and zoos, race tracks, skating rinks, playgrounds, campgrounds, and door-to-door sales. Began easing with eased restrictions on campgrounds, malls, libraries, and other businesses on 20200501. At least some of these businesses remained closed until 20200612: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf
Eases gathering restrictions, now exempting spiritual and religious gatherings from gathering restriction of up to 10 people for other types of gatherings.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateIssued, DateEnacted, PolicyCodingNotes, and PolicySource

PolicyCodingNotes: Allows re-opening of fitness centers, malls, libraries, race tracks, and other retail establishments if they follow requirements laid out in the EO (e.g., 50 percent capacity, adherence to social distancing, and hygiene and public health measures). Effective at 5 am on 20200501 until 20200516. Applicable to all counties except for 22 listed in EO): Adair, Adams, Appanoose, Audubon, Boone, Buchanan, Buena Vista, Butler, Calhoun, Carroll, Cass, Cedar, Cerro Gordo, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Clarke, Clay, Clayton, Clinton, Crawford, Davis, Decatur, Delaware, Dickinson, Emmet, Floyd, Franklin, Fremont, Greene, Grundy, Guthrie, Hamilton, Hancock, Hardin, Harrison, Howard, Humboldt, Ida, Jackson, Jefferson, Jones, Keokuk, Kossuth, Lee, Lucas, Lyon, Madison, Mahaska, Marion, Mills, Mitchell, Monona, Monroe, Montgomery, OBrien, Osceola, Page, Palo Alto, Plymouth, Pocahontas, Pottawattamie, Ringgold, Sac, Shelby, Sioux, Story, Taylor, Union, Van Buren, Wapello, Warren, Wayne, Webster, Winnebago, Winneshiek, Worth, Wright

Allows restaurants to serve food for on-premises consumption if venues comply with the following: limit number of customers to 50 percent capacity, no group of customers can be more than 6 people and have to be at least 6 ft apart, no self-service food, and public health measures by the Iowa DOH. Effective at 5 am on 20200501 until 20200516. Applies to the following counties: Adair, Adams, Appanoose, Audubon, Boone, Buchanan, Buena Vista, Butler, Calhoun, Carroll, Cass, Cedar, Cerro Gordo, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Clarke, Clay, Clayton, Clinton, Crawford, Davis, Decatur, Delaware, Dickinson, Emmet, Floyd, Franklin, Fremont, Greene, Grundy, Guthrie, Hamilton, Hancock, Hardin, Harrison, Howard, Humboldt, Ida, Jackson, Jefferson, Jones, Keokuk, Kossuth, Lee, Lucas, Lyon, Madison, Mahaska, Marion, Mills, Mitchell, Monona, Monroe, Montgomery, OBrien, Osceola, Page, Palo Alto, Plymouth, Pocahontas, Pottawattamie, Ringgold, Sac, Shelby, Sioux, Story, Taylor, Union, Van Buren, Wapello, Warren, Wayne, Webster, Winnebago, Winneshiek, Worth, Wright

Strongly encourages all vulnerable Iowans (ie those with pre-existing medical conditions and those older than 65) to limit activities outside of their home. Eases previous restrictions for remaining 22 counties, joining the statewide eased restrictions on malls and other retail establishments (i.e., up to 50 pct capacity). Note that for the 22 counties, fitness centers and gyms can only re-open for one person at a time and other businesses do not appear to be open yet. Joining this policies at present since retail accounts for the vast majority of these types of businesses - will ease this entry as needed as more restrictions are reduced. From the prior entry: allows re-opening of fitness centers, malls, libraries, race tracks, and other retail establishments if they follow requirements laid out in the EO (e.g., 50 percent capacity, adherence to social distancing, and hygiene and public health measures). Further eased on 20200615, no longer having capacity limits but must maintain physical distancing. Extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.. Extended to 20210109 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.16.pdf. Extended to 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Eases restrictions on close-contact personal care services (eg, salons, barbershops, tattoo establishments, massage therapy) conditional on being at no more than 50 percent capacity, being appointment only, practicing social distancing, other safety protocols recommended by department of public health. Further eased on 20200615, no longer having capacity limits but must maintain physical distancing. Extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf. Extended to 20210109 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.16.pdf. Extended to 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Eases restaurant restrictions for 22 counties, joining the rest of the state with the same eased restaurant restrictions: restaurants to serve food for on-premises consumption if venues comply with the following: limit number of customers to 50 percent capacity, no group of customers can be more than 6 people and have to be at least 6 ft apart, no self-service food, and public health measures by the Iowa DOH. Further eased on 20200612, removing capacity limits but still requiring at least 6 ft distancing between groups, only seated service: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.10.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded and updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on movie theaters, allowing them to resume if at 50 percent capacity, social distancing, no self service of food or beverages. Also eases restrictions on pools for lap siwmming and swimming lessons if they follow social distancing, hygiene practices, and public health measures. Beyond these limited purposes, (quote) all swimming pools and spas, wading pools, ater slides, wave pools, spray pads, and bath houses...shall continue to be closed (quote). On 20200612, further eases restrictions, removing capacity limits but still requiring at least 6 ft of distancing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf Extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.

Eases bar restrictions, permitting them to re-open as long they maintain no more than 50 pct capacity, party size must not exceed 10 per group, social distancing of at least 6 ft between each group, and all patrons must be seated. Further eased on 20200612, only requiring 6 ft distancing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.10.pdf.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded and updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: No longer prohibits large gatherings of any kind, but social distancing must be in place. Clarifies that the following are all permitted: social, community, recreational, leisure, or sporting gathering or event, including but not limited to a parade, festival, farmers market, auction, convention, or fundraiser, Non school sporting and recreational events, Spiritual and religious gatherings. No numerical rule in place.  Extended to 20201116: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.10.16.pdf.

Eases restrictions such that the following businesses can re-open if they follow specified requirements (eg, 50 maximum capacity, proper social distancing, and public health measures): outdoor performance venues, casinos, places of amusements (eg bingo hall, bowling alleys, pool hall, arcade, and amusement parks), skating rinks and skate parks, outdoor playgrounds. Effective 1201 am on 20200601 to 1159 pm on 20200617, so coded to 20200618. On 20200612, further eases restrictions, removing capacity limits but still requiring at least 6 ft of distancing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded and updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes:
Eases restrictions on the following, allowing them to reopen as long as they follow physical distancing requirements (at least 6 ft distancing) and then reasonable health and safety measures: indoor theaters and performance venues with live performances, indoor playgrounds. Extended to 20201211, though indoor playgrounds must close from 10 pm to 6 am: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217 and requires no on-site food or drink service between 10pm and 4am: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf. Extended to 20210109 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.16.pdf. Extended to 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

For salons, barbershops and similar personal care services, requires providers and customers to wear face coverings if they are closer than 6 ft apart. Also indicates casinos can require the use of face coverings to ensure health and safety. On 20201110, new policy somewhat expands the previous requirement: now requiring all patrons and providers of personal care services to wear masks irrespective of 6 ft distancing. Exemption are for services that require moving the face covering of a customer and the customer remains at least 6 ft away from all other customers. Continues to indicate that masks may required by casinos: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.10.pdf Expands to some degree with the expanded mask mandate on 20201117, extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20210109: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf. Extended to 20210207 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Closes bars in Black Hawk, Dallas, Johnson, Linn, Polk and Story Counties only. All bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs, and other establishments that sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on their premises shall be closed to the general public except for carry-out, delivery or drive-through. Starting on 20200916, only Johnson and Story continue to have bar closures, constituting an easing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.09.15.pdf

Strongly encourages Iowans two years and older to wear a mask when in public settings, especially when it is not possible to remain six feet away from others. Extended to 20201116: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.10.16.pdf.

Prohibits gatherings more than 25 people indoors and more than 100 people outdoors unless masks are worn by all people 2 and older and as long as 6 ft distancing is adhered to. Coding as an expansion of the previous gathering restriction, where only 6 ft distancing was required

Requires all people above the age of 2 years old to wear masks in gatherings more than 25 indoors and more than 100 outdoors (including outdoor spectator gatherings). Coded as a Mandate1 as it is limited to very specific settings (certain types of gatherings) and not broadly across indoor settings. Continues to encourage mask use more broadly, but not mandated

Extends previous bar restrictions, allowing them to reopen but only if they follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group or individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Now requires venues to close for on-site consumption between 10 pm and 6 am.
LastUpdatedNotes: Added for onsite consumption to PCNs

PolicyCodingNotes: Indoor gatherings of more than 15 people and outdoor gatherings of more than 30 people are prohibited. Does not apply to individuals who live in the same household and spiritual or religious gatherings. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.

Extends eased restrictions on outdoor performance venues, places of amusements (eg bingo hall, bowling alleys, pool hall, arcade, and amusement parks), skating rinks and skate parks, outdoor playgrounds as long as at least 6 ft distancing occurs and reasonable measures for health and safety are taken. Now notes that casinos may encourage or require face coverings of patrons or employees to reduce risk of transmission. Group sizes may be no larger than 8 unless they are all in the same household. Must close from 10 pm to 6 am to the general public and prohibits private gatherings of more than 15 people indoors and 30 people outdoors.

(quote) all people two or older must wear a mask or other face covering when inside an indoor space that is open to the public and within six feet of individuals who are not members of their household for 15 minutes or longer (quote) Exemptions are for individuals who are medically unable to wear a mask, when eating/drinking, when participating in spiritual and religious services, etc. Also explicitly requires masks inside all Iowa state buildings. Coding as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies across indoor settings. Note that the clause for more than 15 minutes makes this policy very low on the Mandate2 spectrum. Extended to 20210109: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf. Extended to 20210207 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Extends previous restaurant restrictions, allowing them to reopen but only if they follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group or individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Now requires venues to close for on-site consumption between 10 pm and 6 am.
LastUpdatedNotes: Added for onsite consumption to PCNs

PolicyCodingNotes: Extends previous bar restrictions, allowing them to reopen but only if they follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group or individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Now requires that (quote) the establishment not sell or serve food or beverages for consumption on its premises after 10 pm and may not reopen until 4 am the following day.(quote) The bar can still provide carry-out, drive through, or delivery services during these curfew hours.

Extends eased restrictions on outdoor performance venues, casinos, places of amusements (eg bingo hall, bowling alleys, pool hall, arcade, and indoor playgrounds), skating rinks and skate parks, outdoor playgrounds as long as at least 6 ft distancing occurs and reasonable measures for health and safety are taken. Now notes that casinos may encourage or require face coverings of patrons or employees to reduce risk of transmission. Group sizes may be no larger than 8 unless they are all in the same household. For places of amusement (eg bingo hall, bowling alleys, pool hall, arcade, and indoor playgrounds), on-site food or beverage service are not allowed between 10pm and 6am. Not coded as a curfew because is not an explicit cufew on hours of business operation. Extended to 20210109 https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.16.pdf. https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Extends previous restaurant restrictions, allowing them to reopen but only if they follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group or individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Now requires that (quote) the establishment not sell or serve food or beverages for consumption on its premises after 10 pm and may not reopen until 4 am the following day.(quote) The restaurant can still provide carry-out, drive through, or delivery services during these curfew hours.

Extends bar restrictions, allowing them to reopen for normal business hours. Must follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group and individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Masks are required for patrons when not seated. Extended until 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Eases gathering restrictions. Gatherings of more than 10 may be held if the gathering complies with social distancing and other hygiene rules. Does not apply to religious gatherings. Extended to 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Extends restaurant restrictions, allowing them to reopen for normal business hours. Must follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group and individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Masks are required for patrons when not seated. Extended until 20210207: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.01.07.pdf. Not renewed, expired on 20210207: 
https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202021.02.05.pdf.

Gathering organizers are strongly encouraged to ensure the health of participants with social distancing practices, increased hygiene, and other public health measures. Funerals, religious gatherings, governments exemptions. Otherwise, gathering restrictions on no more than 50 people

Closing all public and private K-12 school buildings for student instruction until May 29. However, any school building or facility operating with less than 10 students, instructors or staff may continue normal operations as long as they comply with health and safety requirements. On 20200522 Extends school closures/restrictions under EO 20-07, but allows for in-person groups less than 15 people at a time (with social distancing, ie 6 ft distancing), so treating as easing https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf Ended on 2020526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

Expands restriction on gatherings to no more than 10

With the gathering restriction of no more than 10 in an enclosed space, also applies this restriction to the following businesses, which substantially limits operations: (quote) prohibition includes, but is not limited to, mass gatherings at: auditoriums, theaters, movie theaters, museums, stadiums, arenas, conference rooms, meeting halls, exhibition centers, taverns, health and fitness centers, recreation centers, and licensed pools.
