PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) all individuals within the state of Kansas are directed to stay in their homes or residences unless performing an essential activity (quote). Stay at home ended for all individuals on 20200526, recommendation now occurring for high-risk individuals. https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

Gathering restriction on 10 person gatherings is expanded to include religious gatherings on 20200407 with an enact date of 20200408, legislature struck down, case heard by Supreme Court, which decides in favor of governors order: inclusion of religious gatherings in restriction allowed. (quote) the number of people conducting the service may exceed ten (quote) - see Sec. 1C. Eased on 20200522 with Ad Astra Phase 2: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf

Phase one of reopening plan lists businesses that must remain closed. All businesses not prohibited in given list can open up if they comply with list of requirements (section 5a). Further easing on 20200518 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-31-Implementing-Phase-1.5-of-Ad-Astra-Plan-Executed.pdf. Further easing on 20200522 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf Ended on 20200526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf
Masks are strongly encouraged in public settings.

Eases restrictions on restaurants, which can now open if they can maintain 6 feet distance between customers. Ended on 20200526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

High risk individuals are adivsed to continue to stay at home except when conducting essential functions (high risk being indiviudals with underlying medical conditions or are otherwise immunocompromised). Ended on 20200526 with Ad Astra ending https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

Mass gatherings of no more than 15 individuals allowed. Phase 2 of Ad Astra now formally implemented, but is now different from what had been planned. Ended on 20200526 when Ad Astra became a guideline for counties: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf
Recommends not to have gatherings of over 45 people https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-recommends-communities-move-into-phase-3-of-ad-astra-plan/
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: All businesses or organizations in Kansas must require employees to wear a mask or face covering when employees are working in any space visited by customers or members of the public, space where food is prepared or packaged for sale, working in or walking through common areas, in a room or any enclosed area where 6 ft distancing is not possible. Exceptions involve individuals with medical conditions, mental health conditions, or disabilities that prevent wearing a mask, where wearing a face covering could be a risk to their work per work safety guidelines for the sector.  Ended on 20210401 https://www.kwch.com/2021/04/01/gov-laura-kelly-issues-new-mask-order-for-kansas/

Any person in Kansas shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or other face covering when they are in the following: inside or in line to enter any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding on public transportation or other modes of transportation (taxi, private car service, ride-sharing), outdoors in public spaces and unable to maintain a 6 ft distance between individuals. Exceptions involve individuals with medical conditions, mental health conditions, or disabilities that prevent wearing a mask, children under 5 (especially 2 and younger), people who are deaf or are hard of hearing, when seated at a restaurant, more listed in section 3. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use in across indoor and outdoor settings. Note that due to legislative action in June, counties had an opt-out option of the statewide mandate. As of July 8, about 80 out of 105 counties appeared to have opted out of compliance: https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html#Kansas Effective 20201125, governor aims to close county opt-out option: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-20-68-Face-Coverings-protocol-Executed-1.pdf Ended on 20210401 https://www.kwch.com/2021/04/01/gov-laura-kelly-issues-new-mask-order-for-kansas/

All students, faculty, staff and visitors to public or private K-12 schools must wear face coverings. Exemptions are made for children under the age of 5 years old, while eating, etc. Not re-issued and allowed to expire on 20210401: SB40 now delegates school masks to school districts, removing governor authority in this area http://www.kslegislature.org/li/b2021_22/measures/documents/sb40_enrolled.pdf

Recommends that faculty, staff, and students over 2 wear masks in schools in Kansas regardless of vaccination status: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/Updated-Guidance-for-COVID-19-Prevention-in-K-12-Schools-002.pdf
Declares State of Emergency. No explicit expiry provided.

Requested superintendents to close schools, but did not mandate. Not coded as school closure (i.e., no date ascribed yet), no mandate but gov recommends extension to 20200501 on 20200402. Gov recommends schools to wait to open until Sept 28 2020 https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=301. Devolves to local authorities on 20200928: https://www.kentucky.com/news/local/education/article245731730.html

Advised that all community gatherings be cancelled, via Governor facebook page. On governors website indicates this was on 20200311, but associated link indicates posting of this on 20200313, so using 20200313 as the date. No numerical restriction
Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive thru only): bars. Bars are allowed to resume in-person services under health and safety requirements on 20200629

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive thru only): restaurants. Restaurants are allowed to resume in-person services under health and safety requirements on 20200522 https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/s1l356ZwRf6ZDTmKJBQo_5-22-2020,%20CHFS%20Order%20-%20Restaurants%20and%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf

(quote) all public-facing businesses that encourage public congregation or, that by the nature of the service to the public, cannot comply with CDC guidelines concerning social distancing, shall cease all in-person operations (quote). Includes entertainment, hospitality and recreational facilities, community and recreation centers, gyms and exercise facilities, hair salons, nail salons, spas, concert venues, theaters, and sporting event facilities. Began easing on 20200522: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/RPrsUnlyQzql2yUygXmc_CHFS%20Order%20-%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf

Gov. Beshear suspended all charitable gaming licenses, closing bingo halls temporarily, to protect patrons at those establishments after having previously issued new guidance on closing public-facing businesses.
Bans mass gatherings, does not clearly define mass gathering.

All in-person retail businesses that are not life-sustaining are order to close. Easing began on 20200520: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/g92cg1QISZiIbF4QwHDj_Executive%20Order%20and%20CHFS%20Order_May.pdf

(quote) Only life-sustaining businesses may remain open (quote). No clear expiry. Easing started on 20200511: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/1bt2tc4ATVGSBYI5W2YR_Executive%20Order%202020-323%20-%20Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reopening.pdf
Encourages (quote) all Kentuckians to remain Healthy at Home (quote)
Residents are instructed not to travel outside of state, and must self-quarantine for 14 days upon return. In effect till emergency declaration expires.
Residents are instructed not to travel outside of state except for essential business, and must self-quarantine for 14 days upon return. In effect till emergency declaration expires.
Residents of any other state may not travel into Kentucky except for in specific cases. In effect for duration of emergency

From Governor website on 20200404: ​In an added measure, Gov. Beshear said Kentucky is adopting on a voluntary basis the new guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommending that people wear cloth masks in some situations. Gov. Beshear also stressed that wearing a cloth mask is a measure to be added to social distancing, not to replace it
Persons who have tested positive for COVID19, are presumptively diagnosed, or are exhibiting symptoms shall not enter the Commonwealth of Kentucky.

Eases restrictions on the following non-life sustaining businesses, conditional on their implementation and adherence to the states Healthy at Work guidelines: manufacturing distribution and supply chain businesses, vehicle and vessel dealerships, horse racing tracks (though no spectators), pet care and grooming services, photography businesses, office-based businesses at 50 percent capacity. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=638. Eased on 20210528 to allow 75 pct maximum capacity https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

In-person retail services are permitted to re-open, with a maximum of 33 pct capacity, required 6 ft distancing, etc. Eased on 20201211 to increase to 50 pct capacity, according to Health at Work guidelines. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=638. Eased on 20210528 to allow 75 pct maximum capacity https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf
Gatherings of up to ten people are allowed, religious organizations may have in-person gatherings of more than 10 and no more than 33 pct capacity
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restaurant restrictions to allow for up to 33 percent maximum occupancy, at least 6 ft distancing, and detailed list of recommendations (eg, disposable menus, contactless methods of payment, entry and exit flows) and cleaning requirements. On 20200629, permits capacity up to 50 pct: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/FdYgPMSpRzG2iJHfbOle_6-29-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20-%20June%2029%20Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reopening.pdf On 20200728 must reduce indoor capacity to 25 pct: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/GlXFnrapT8Wp96HaFGBf_2020-7-27%20-%20Healthy%20At%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Restaurants%20-%20Down%20to%2025-%20capacity%20-%20Final%20Version%204.0.pdf On 20200811, permits indoor capacity to increase to 50 pct but must close at 1100 pm: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf.

Requires mask use by specific sectors as they re-open: personal care services (salons, barber shops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, etc). Recommends that customers wear face coverings, but does not explicitly require them. Adds more businesses to mask use requirements at businesses as more reopen, while the public mask mandate explicitly defers to the business guidance documents here: https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-healthy-at-work On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following close-contact personal care services: cosmetology businesses, hair salons and barbershops, massage therapy businesses, nail salons, tanning salons, and tattoo parlors. Requires a maximum of 33 pct capacity, customers are separated by at least 6 ft, etc. Eased on 20200625, allowing up to 50 pct capacity: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/tQ4d7UOzTdKJAJlLkkhh_CHFS%20Order%20-%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity: 
https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=638. Eased on 20210528 to allow 75 pct maximum capacity https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesses, allowing for in-person services if they comply with the minimum requirements set forth by Healthy at Work Kentucky: educational and cultural venues (aquariums, distilleries, libraries, museums, wineries, and limited outdoor programs), horse shows, casinos. For indoor venues, no more than 33 pct capacity is permitted, 6 ft distancing is required, etc. Eased on 20201211 to allow for 50 pct capacity. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=638. Eased on 20210528 to allow 75 pct maximum capacity https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

Eases bar restrictions. Effective June 29 bars are allowed to offer service on-premises for up to 50 percent maximum occupancy, at least 6 ft distancing, and detailed list of recommendations (eg, disposable menus, contactless methods of payment, entry and exit flows) and cleaning requirements

Allows gatherings up to 50 people at a time, easing the previous gathering restrictions.Starting June 10, places of worship were permitted to resume in-person services up to 50 pct of capacity, which excludes them from the 50 person gathering restriction (also the May 9 order clearly exempts places of worship from these gathering restrictions): https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/r00brFxTl2TJkofBUZUh_Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Places%20of%20Worship%20-%20Final%20Version%202.0%20Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits from religious gathering variables

PolicyCodingNotes:
Eases restrictions on venues and event space, permitting the following to reopen at a maximum of 50 pct capacity, requiring at least 6 ft distancing between individuals: convention centers, hotel ballrooms and conference centers, music and concert halls, professional and amateur sporting/athletic stadiums and arenas, wedding venues, fairs, festivals, carnivals, and any other commercially operated events organized for more than 50 persons occurring at indoor and/or outdoor venues and event spaces. On 20201120, expands restrictions, limiting to no more than 25 people: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201118_Executive-Order_2020-968_State-of-Emergency.pdf . Eased on 20201211 to allow 50 pct capacity, according to Healthy at Work guidelines. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity: 
https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=638. Modified on 20210419 such that venues with capacity up to 1000 people may have 60 pct capacity, while venues with capacity over 1000 are limited to 50 pct capacity: https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf  Eased on 20210528 to allow 75 pct maximum capacity https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf On 20210611, Ends all business restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and Healthy at Work guidance. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

(quote) People in Kentucky must cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when they are in the following situations that represent a high risk of COVID-19 transmision (quote). Lists while inside or waiting in line to enter many businesses or indoor public space where it is difficult to physical distance, while waiting for or riding on public transportation or other vehicles (eg taxi, private car service, ride sharing), and in outdoor public spaces where physical distancing of 6 ft is not possible. Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions), among others. In effect for 30 days after 5 pm on 20200710. Coded to Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20201007 https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20200904_Executive-Order_2020-750_Face-Coverings.pdf. Extended to 20201105 https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201006_Executive-Order_2020-856_Reneweal_Face-Coverings.pdf Extended to 20201204: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201104_Executive-Order_2020-931_Face-Coverings.pdf Extended to 20210102: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201203_Executive-Order_2020-996_Face-coverings.pdf. Included in EO on 20201211, no expiration date specified - assumed extended. Extended on 20210130 for 30 days: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210130_Executive-Order_2021-070_Face-Coverings.pdf. Extended to 20210330: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210226_Executive-Order_2021-134_Face-Coverings.pdf. Extended to 20210428 https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210329_Executive-Order_2021-212_face-coverings-renewal.pdf

Imposes restriction on gatherings to no more than 10, increasing the restriction (it had been 50 previously). Previous restrictions on places of worship continue (no more than 50 pct capacity), so re-imposed restrictions do not include numeric limits on religious gatherings: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/r00brFxTl2TJkofBUZUh_Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Places%20of%20Worship%20-%20Final%20Version%202.0%20Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits from religious gathering variables

PolicyCodingNotes: The advisory recommends a 14-day self-quarantine for travelers who went to any of eight states reporting positive testing rate equal to or greater than 15 percent-for COVID-19 testing. The advisory also includes one state quickly approaching a positive testing rate of 15 percent and one U.S. Territory. They include Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Nevada, South Carolina and Texas, Mississippi and Puerto Rico. On 20200824 removes Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Florida from the quarantine advisory and adds South Carolina https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=328.  As of 20200923, they include South Dakota, Kansas, Iowa and Wisconsin, Idaho. The list appears to be updated daily but not reported consistently via any government sources, and thus they cannot be tracked in an ongoing manner.https://govstatus.egov.com/kycovid19. Expanded to recommend quarantine from all states on 20201214: https://web.archive.org/web/20210331094147/https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-travel-advisory.

All bars must cease in-person operations for onsite consumption, permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages by delivery, to-go, or carryout. This order was announced on 20200727, but formally issued and signed on 20200728. In effect for 14 days. Eased on 20200811 https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf

Bars may resume in-person operations for onsite consumption effective August 11, 2020. Bars must limit in-person services indoors to 50 pct of capacity and must close at 11 pm for onsite services. Closing time extended to midnight on 20200915.

Permits indoor capacity to increase to 50 pct but must close at 1100 pm: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf. Closing time extended to midnight on 20200915.
(quote) The use of cloth face coverings (masks) should be required by all students and staff at all times while in the building or on the bus, unless medically waivered (quote)
Bars must limit in-person services indoors to 50 pct of capacity and must close at midnight for onsite services (was 1100 pm).
Restaurants must limit in-person services indoors to 50 pct of capacity and must close at midnight for onsite services (was 1100 pm).

Stay at home recommendation, coded as 0 for mandate. (quote) We need everybody to wear your masks and follow red zone reduction recommendations and school recommendations. It is a must if you want to lessen the impact in your community (quote). Red zone recommendations include (quote) Avoid non-essential activities outside of your home (quote)

Expands bar restrictions. Bars are no longer allowed to provide indoor service. Outdoor service is allowed (quote) provided that all customers are seated at tables, table size is limited to a maximum of 8 people from a maximum of 2 households, and tables are spaced a minimum of 6 feet apart. (quote)
Expands restriction on indoor gatherings to no more than 8 people (from 10) from no more than 2 households. Does not specify changes to outdoor gathering lmiits so kept at 10 people.

Expands restaurant restrictions. Restaurants are no longer allowed to provide indoor service. Outdoor service is allowed (quote) provided that all customers are seated at tables, table size is limited to a maximum of 8 people from a maximum of 2 households, and tables are spaced a minimum of 6 feet apart. (quote). Restaurants must close at midnight.

Requires that all public and private K-12 schools cease in-person instruction and transition to remote instruction beginning November 23. Will require that grades 6-12 remain remote until at least January 4, 2021 and may permit resumption on in-person instruction for K-5 from December 7 to January 4 if the school is not located in a red zone county

Eases bar/restaurant restrictions by allowing indoor service of (quote) 50pct of the maximum permitted occupancy or the greatest number that permits individuals not from the same household to maintain six (6) feet of space (quote). Physical barriers are okay to separate booths less than 6 feet apart. Last call at 11 p.m. and close by midnight except for drive-thru, carry-out, or delivery. Outdoor in-person services at bars/restaurants do not count against the 50pct capacity (quote) so long as those customers remain seated and at least six (6) feet of space is maintained between customers at different tables (quote). If an outdoor tent is used, at least 2 sides of the tent (50pct of the perimeter) must be open. Childrens play areas are closed. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity indoors: https://gscdn.govshare.site/855aaddbcca3a8df78517af64c60eaedcbede827/Healthy%20At%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Restaurants%20and%20Bars%20-%20Final%20Version%205.5.pdf.

Eases restriction on indoor gatherings to a recommendation of no more than 8 people from a maximum of 2 households (no limit for gathering within same household). Press release specifies no limit to outdoor gatherings. On 20210611, Ends all gathering restrictions by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders and all Orders of the Cabinet for Health and Family Services implementing those orders. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

Eases bar/restaurant restrictions by allowing indoor service of (quote) 50pct of the maximum permitted occupancy or the greatest number that permits individuals not from the same household to maintain six (6) feet of space (quote). Physical barriers are okay to separate booths less than 6 feet apart. Last call at 11 p.m. and close by midnight except for drive-thru, carry-out, or delivery. Outdoor in-person services at bars/restaurants do not count against the 50pct capacity (quote) so long as those customers remain seated and at least six (6) feet of space is maintained between customers at different tables (quote). If an outdoor tent is used, at least 2 sides of the tent (50pct of the perimeter) must be open. Childrens play areas are closed. Eased on 20210305 to permit up to 60 pct capacity indoors: https://gscdn.govshare.site/855aaddbcca3a8df78517af64c60eaedcbede827/Healthy%20At%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Restaurants%20and%20Bars%20-%20Final%20Version%205.5.pdf.

Schools may provide in-person instruction. Gov. Andy Beshear recommends that schools in Red Zone Counties wait to begin in-person classes until 20210111. All schools must comply with Safety Expectations and offer virtual alternatives to students, and schools in Red and Orange Zone counties that choose to meet in-person must provide accommodations to at-risk employees. No expiration date.

Extends bar restrictions, but now allows bars to be open until 1am (was previously midnight). Allows indoor service of (quote) 60pct of the maximum permitted occupancy or the greatest number that permits individuals not from the same household to maintain six (6) feet of space (quote). Physical barriers are okay to separate booths less than 6 feet apart. Last call at midnight except for drive-thru, carry-out, or delivery. Outdoor in-person services at bars/restaurants do not count against the 60pct capacity (quote) so long as those customers remain seated and at least six (6) feet of space is maintained between customers at different tables (quote). If an outdoor tent is used, at least 2 sides of the tent (50pct of the perimeter) must be open. Childrens play areas are closed. Eased on 20210528 https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf

Extends restaurant restrictions, but now allows restaurants to be open until 1am (was previously midnight). Allows indoor service of (quote) 60pct of the maximum permitted occupancy or the greatest number that permits individuals not from the same household to maintain six (6) feet of space (quote). Physical barriers are okay to separate booths less than 6 feet apart. Last call at midnight except for drive-thru, carry-out, or delivery. Outdoor in-person services at bars/restaurants do not count against the 60pct capacity (quote) so long as those customers remain seated and at least six (6) feet of space is maintained between customers at different tables (quote). If an outdoor tent is used, at least 2 sides of the tent (50pct of the perimeter) must be open. Childrens play areas are closed. Eased on 20210528 https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/HAWMinimumRequirements.pdf

Eases quarantine advisory to recommend a 10-day self-quarantine (from 14) or a 7-day quarantine with a negative test 3-5 days after arrival for travelers entering Kentucky from any other state. Vaccinated individuals are no longer advised to quarantine.

Eases the state mandate requiring face coverings, the statewide mask mandate will no longer be in effect when Kentuckians are outside at events or venues with 1,000 people or fewer. (quote) People in Kentucky must cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when they are in the following situations that represent a high risk of COVID-19 transmision (quote). Lists while inside or waiting in line to enter many businesses or indoor public space where it is difficult to physical distance, while waiting for or riding on public transportation or other vehicles (eg taxi, private car service, ride sharing), and in outdoor public spaces with 1,000 people or more. Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions), among others. Coded to Mandate2 as it applies broadly indoors but only in narrow contexts outdoors. Modified on 20210506 such that small groups of fully vaccinated individuals in a private business or home are now exempt: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210506%20EO%202021-312%20May%206%20face%20coverings%20renewal.pdf Eased on 20210513 https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/Executive%20Order%202021-326%20-%20Face%20Coverings.pdf

Eases the mask mandate (quote) Any person shall wear a face covering when riding on all planes, buses, trains, and other forms of  public transportation, in any K-12 educational, preschool, daycare, or other childcare setting, or in a healthcare or long-term care setting. Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions). Coded to Mandate1 as it applies only in narrow contexts indoors. We have not coded VaccineExempt==1 since technically, masks are required in the same contexts for the vaccinated and non-vaccinated. On 20210611 Rescinds EO 2021-326, which issued the most recent mask mandate and was set to expire on 20210612. However, some mask requirements are reissued here, but with no expiration date. Individuals are required, regardless of vaccination status, to wear a face covering (quote) when riding on all planes, buses, trains, and other forms of  public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in the U. S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations (quote), in healthcare settings, in long-term care settings, and (quote) it is recommended that face coverings be worn by any person: in a correctional facility, in a homeless shelter, or who is immune-compromised, is exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19, or has tested positive for COVID-19 in the prior ten (10) days (quote). Coded as easing, as masks are not required in all public transportation settings but only en route to airports. Coded as Mandate1 as masks continue to be required in a number of narrow indoor contexts. to Mandate1 as it applies only in narrow contexts indoors. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf. Expanded to include the requirement for all individuals to mask in state buildings, regardless of vaccination status, on 20210729 https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=894

Introduces school mask mandate (quote) Any person in a K-12 educational, preschool, daycare, or other childcare setting, including any student, employee, staff member or visitor, shall wear a face covering (quote). Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions). On 20210611, ends school mask requirements by rescinding all relevant Executive Orders. https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20210611_Executive-Order_2021-386.pdf

Eases bar restrictions, removing all restrictions except for a maximum capacity limit of 75 pct  (from 60 pct). Still requires face coverings indoors as per Minimum Requirements for all Entities. PolicyCodingNotes: Requires more non-essential businesse to close, but not a full non-essential business closure policy. Expressly closes the following businesses as well: places of public amusement (including amusement rides, carnivals, amusement parks, water parks, trampoline parks, aquariums, zoos, museums, arcades, fairs, pool halls, childrens play centers, playgrounds, theme parks, any theaters, concert and music halls, adult entertainment venues, racetracks), all personal care and grooming businesses, and all malls. Eases on 20200515 to permit malls and barbershops and salons to reopen to in-person services. Some portion of these businesses remain closed to 20201223: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/168-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf. Continues full closure of places of public amusement to 20210113 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/209-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf. Extended closure of places of public amusement to 20210210 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/6-JBE-2021-StateofEmergency.pdf. Extended to 20210303 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/17-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf. Extended closure of places of public amusement to 20210331, noting that businesses may submit reopening plans to the State Fire Marshal, who can approve opening up to 50 pct capacity: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/29-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-RenewingCOVID-19ResilientPhase3.pdf. On 20210331, allows for reopening of amusement parks, theme parks, concert and music halls, trampoline parks, and water parks, subject to 50 pct capacity and no more than 500 people in any indoor space. Fairs and festivals remain closed but can submit a reopening plan to the State Fire Marshal. https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/66-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-COVID.pdf. (quote) Every individual in Louisiana shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor. This shall include public or commercial modes of transportation (quote). Exemptions are for children under the age of 8 years (though 2-7 year-olds are encouraged to wear mask coverings), individuals who will be able to maintain strict social distancing outside of their immediate households, individuals with a medical condition that prevents the wearing of a face mask. Eases bar restrictions under the following conditions, if the bar is located in a parish with positivity rate lower than 5 pct for 2 consecutive weeks, it may reopen at maximum 25 pct occupancy or 50 patrons, whichever is less, service of alcohol must end by 10 pm (closed by 11 pm) and all patrons must be seated at tables. If these conditions are not met, all bars are to remain closed to in-person services. Take out via drive-thru or curbside delivery is permitted.

Eases gathering restriction to no more than 250 people in a single indoor space, and to no more than 250 people in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services shall not be limited by the crowd size restrictions of section E, see section D4. Extended to 20201106 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/135-JBE-2020-Renewal-of-SOE.pdf. Extended to 20201204: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/158-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf.

All bars shall be closed by 11pm. Therefore, the hours of permissible operation shall be 8am to 11pm. Extends eased requirements allowing bars to reopen at maximum 25 pct occupancy or 50 patrons, whichever is less, if the bar is located in a parish with positivity rate lower than 5pct for 2 consecutive weeks. All patrons must be seated at tables. If these conditions are not met, all bars are to remain closed to in-person services, irrespective of food service permit. Take out via drive-thru or curbside delivery is permitted. Extended to 20210113 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/209-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf. Extended to 20210210 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/6-JBE-2021-StateofEmergency.pdf. Extended to 20210303 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/17-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf. Eased on 20210303 such that bars may operate at maximum 50 pct occupancy indoor (from 25 pct) or 250 patrons (from 50), whichever is less, if the bar is located in a parish with positivity rate lower than 5 pct for 2 consecutive weeks. Bars in areas with higher positivity rates may operate at 25 pct capacity indoor, with a max of 250 patrons. https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/29-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-RenewingCOVID-19ResilientPhase3.pdf. Eased to remove capacity restrictions and curfew on 20210331, waiting areas must remain closed: 
https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/66-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-COVID.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions to 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct) or no more than 75 people (from 250) in a single indoor space, and to 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct) or no more than 150 people (from 250) in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services shall not be limited by the crowd size restrictions of section E, see section D4. They may continue operating at up to 75 pct of total occupancy. Extended to 20210113 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/209-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf. Extended to 20210210 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/6-JBE-2021-StateofEmergency.pdf. Extended to 20210303 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/17-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions to 50 pct capacity or no more than 250 people in a single indoor space (from 75), and 50 pct capacity in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services are not subject to crowd size limitations. Further eases on 20210331: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/66-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-COVID.pdf

Eases bar restrictions by removing capacity limits and curfew. All patrons must be seated at socially distanced tables. Extended to 20210526 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/79-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-renewingcovid19.pdf Ended restrictions on 20210526 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/93-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions to 50 pct capacity or no more than 500 people in a single indoor space (from 250), and 50 pct capacity in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services are not subject to crowd size limitations.

Extends recommendation for vulnerable individuals to stay at home. (quote) All individuals who are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should stay at home, unless travelling outside the home for an essential activity (quote) Now, no longer applies to fully vaccinated individuals. Extended to 20210526 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/79-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-renewingcovid19.pdf Extended to 20210623 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/93-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210721 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/117-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210811 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/131-JBE-2021-COVID-19PublicHealthEmergency.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions, removes numerical limit for people and allows 75 pct capacity  in a single indoor space with social distancing or 100 pct capacity with face masks required, removes limits outdoors. Church and faith-based services are not subject to crowd size limitations. Ended restrictions on 20210526 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/93-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf

Eases the mask mandate. All individuals shall wear a face covering while passengers and operators of public transportation and while visiting offices of the State of Louisiana. However, any agency or department head may opt out of this requirement. Exemptions are for people who are able to maintain strict social distancing from other individuals, children under the age of 8 years (though 2-7 year-olds are encouraged to wear mask coverings), individuals with a medical condition that prevents the wearing of a face mask. All local authorities and prviate business organizations may issue more restrictive measures. Coding to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use for very limited public settings. Extends the mask mandate and slightly modifies it on 20210514. All individuals shall wear a face covering while passengers and operators of public transportation but not while visiting offices of the State of Louisiana any longer. It also adds correctional facilities to the list of places where face coverings are mandatory. https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/85-JBE-2021-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Modificiation.pdf Extended to 20210623 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/93-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210721 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/117-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210811 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/131-JBE-2021-COVID-19PublicHealthEmergency.pdf

(quote) All individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings when indoors and when unable to socially distance from others outside of ones immediate family (quote), applying mask recommendation to both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals
(quote) Governor Mills is recommending the postponement of all non-essential large, indoor group gatherings in Maine of 250 or more attendees for the next 30 days (quote)

Strongly recommends postponing events with 50 or more people and that gatherings of more than 10 that includes individuals at high risk for illness (eg, seniors).
Strongly recommends ending classroom instruction in public school as soon as reasonably practical. Not coded as a mandate

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive-through only): bars. Eased restrictions, allowing for outdoor service of bars and tasting room in 13 counties starting on 20200612: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/light-data-trends-mills-administration-accelerates-business-openings-rural-counties-2020-06-04

Gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited throughout the state. Effective as of 6 pm on 20200318 until midnight of March 31. Includes faith-based events. Extended to 20200601, and eased on 20200601: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Further%20Implement%20the%20Restarting%20Plan.pdf

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive-through only): restaurants. Extended to 20200430 on 20200331, original expiry 20200408. The 20200429 executive order extends restaurant restrictions to at least 20200601 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf Easing of restrictions effective 20200518 subject to health precautions for the counties of Aroostook, Piscataquis, Washington, Hancock, Somerset, Franklin, Oxford, Kennebec, Waldo, Knox, Lincoln, and Sagadahoc. https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/governor-mills-introduces-rural-reopening-plan-2020-05-08

All non-essential businesses and operations must cease activities at sites that are public facing and thereby allow customer, vendor, or other in-person contact, or are at sites that require more than 10 workers convene in a space where social distancing is not possible. In effect at 1201 am on 20200325 and terminates at 1200 am on 20200408. First eased on 20200501: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf Last set of businesses were permitted to reopen on 20200701: https://web.archive.org/web/20200703195349/https://www.maine.gov/decd/covid-19-prevention-checklists

(quote) Public and private K12 schools statewide have terminated in-classroom instruction in accordance with my recommendation on March 15, 2020. It is hereby Ordered that all such schools shall remain closed for classroom or other in-person instruction until at least May 1, 2020 (quote). Extended until 20200807: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/Proclamation%20to%20Renew%20the%20State%20of%20Civil%20Emergency%20%28July%2008%2C%202020%29.pdf On 20200731, all counties are categorized at green risk level and thus can reopen schools per local authority discretion (which we are coding as an ending from state-coordinated policies): https://www.maine.gov/doe/sites/maine.gov.doe/files/inline-files/Framework%20for%20Returning%20to%20Classroom%20Instruction%20UPDATE%207-30.pdf

All persons to stay at their homes of residence effective as of 1201 am on 20200402. Ended on 20200531: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Further%20Implement%20the%20Restarting%20Plan.pdf

Any person traveling into Maine, irrespective of their state of residency, must self-quarantine for 14 days. State exemptions are added (or removed), over time. Eased on 20200701, allowing travelers to present a negative COVID-19 test rather than quarantine for 14 days: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO-57.pdf Further eased on 20201204, reducing the quarantine requirement to 10 days: https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/epi/airborne/documents/2020PHADV037ChangesMaineQuarantinePo.pdf

Visitors are instructed not to travel to Maine if they are displaying symptoms of COVID-19, and are advised not to travel to Maine if they are traveling from cities and regions identified as COVID-19 hotspots, including the cities of Detroit, Chicago, New York. Residents of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut should refrain from travel in compliance with CDC travel guidance. Extended to 20200601 on 20200429 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf. On 20201104, expands travel quarantine restrictions, requiring visitors from Connecticut, New York and New Jersey to complete a 14-day quarantine requirement or negative COVID-19 testing: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/cases-rising-maine-nationwide-mills-administration-announces-measures-prevent-spread-deadly.

Requires all employees in public settings indoors, outdoors where the public gathers, and enclosed or semi-enclosed transportation. (quote) Employers in settings that are not typically accessible to the public may determine the persons who should wear a cloth face covering at their workplace and shall permit any employee who wants to wear a covering to do so (quote). Expanded at various times to require masks of both employees and patrons at all times in public settings 20201104: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Revise%20Indoor%20Gathering%20Limits%2C%20Strengthen%20Face%20Covering%20Requirements%20and%20Delegate%20Certain%20Authority.pdf) and enforcement. Extended to 20210612: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/SOE%2016%20May.pdf. On 20210524, Ends public mask mandate, now only requiring their use in schools and childcare settings. Governor now encourages individuals follow current CDC masking guidelines, which recommends the use of masks for unvaccinated individuals in indoor public spaces and for all individuals in some settings, like on public transportation and in congregate living situations. https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO%2097%2039.pdf

Eases restrictions on a subset of non-essential business closures if appropriate safety precautions are taken as part of the stage 1 restart plan: specific personal services (barber shops, hair salons, pet grooming), drive-in movie theaters, auto dealerships and car washes. Outdoor service is limited to 75 pct capacity. Effective 20210524, all Maine businesses are restricted to maximum indoor capacity of 75 pct, 50 people, or 5 people per 1,000 sq ft, whichever is greatest. Outdoor service is limited to 100 pct capacity. https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO%2093%2035.pdf. Extended to 20210514 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/Proclamation%20to%20Renew%20the%20State%20of%20Civil%20Emergency%20Signed%20April%2014%2C%202021.pdf. Eases restrictions on a subset of outdoor recreation (eg, guided outdoor activities like fishing and hunting, golf courses, marinas) and some state parks (i.e., those not on coastal sites). Individuals must wear cloth face coverings in public settings where other physical distancing measures are difficult to maintain. Public settings are defined as indoor spaces accessible to the public (e.g., grocery stores, retail stroes, retail stores, pharmacies, healthcare facilities), outdoor spaces (e.g., playgrounds, busy parking lots, and other areas such as lines for take-out service where the public typically gathers in a small area), public transportation (eg, taxi, ride-sharing, ferry, bus, train, and any semi-enclosed transit stop or waiting area). Exemptions are for children under the age of 2, anyone who cannot wear a mask due to a condition, medical or other types of physical or mental conditions. Coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires mask use in both indoor and outdoor settings. On 20200531, clarified that masks were required for large gatherings, including those outside: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Further%20Implement%20the%20Restarting%20Plan.pdf. On 20201104, clarifies that masks are required in all public spaces regardless of ability to maintain physical distance: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Revise%20Indoor%20Gathering%20Limits%2C%20Strengthen%20Face%20Covering%20Requirements%20and%20Delegate%20Certain%20Authority.pdf.

Eases restrictions on fitness and exercise gyms statewide, permitting re-opening for outdoor classes of 10 or fewer, as well as 1-on-1 personal training for inside of fitness centers. (quote) Until further notice, persons who are over age 60 or who have a medically compromised condition are strongly urged to limit their movement and activities that expose them to persons other than immediate household members, and to avoid large gatherings, especially those occurring indoors or in otherwise confined settings (quote) Coding as a stay-at-home recommendation for sub-populations (i.e., persons older than 60 and with medical conditions that put them at higher risk for COVID-19). Eases public mask requirements, no longer requiring their use in outdoor spaces (quote) including but not limited to playgrounds, parking lots, sidewalks, athletic and sports venues, and other areas such as lines for takeout service where the public typically gathers in a smaller area (quote). Use of masks continue to be required in other public settings, defined as indoor spaces accessible to the public and public transportation (eg, taxi, ride-sharing, ferry, bus, train, and any transit stop or waiting area). Exemptions are for children under the age of 5 (children aged 2-4 are recommended to wear face coverings), anyone who cannot wear a mask due to a condition, medical or other types of physical or mental conditions. Coding as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it no longer requires mask use in outdoor settings, but continues to require them in indoor spaces and public spaces, broadly. Extended to 20210612: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/SOE%2016%20May.pdf. On 20210524, Ends public mask mandate, now only requiring their use in schools and childcare settings. Governor now encourages individuals follow current CDC guidelines, which recommends the use of masks for unvaccinated individuals in indoor public spaces and for all individuals in some settings, like on public transportation and in congregate living situations. https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO%2097%2039.pdf

Maine Department of Economic and Community Development offers clearer guidelines for businesses regarding the use of masks, following the general mask mandate repeal. They state that they are deferring to the CDC for industry-specific guidelines, but generally recommend the following: (quote) Recommend individuals in your establishment who are not fully vaccinated for COVID-19 wear a mask, per U.S. CDC recommendations and any relevant Federal requirements. Patrons and staff who are not fully vaccinated should: 1. Wear a mask correctly and consistently for the best protection. Information about proper use of masks is available from the U.S. CDC (see: Considerations for Wearing Masks). 2. Change your mask if it becomes wet or soiled. 3. During unmasked activities such as communal eating and drinking additional mitigation strategies should be used, such as physical distancing and increased ventilation. 4. Masks are recommended for individuals who are not fully vaccinated outdoors when 6 feet of physical distance is difficult to maintain. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Added 1 to VaccineExempt and updated PolicyCodingNotes

Coded as VaccineExempt as this recommendation primarily applies to individuals who are not fully vaccinated.
