Eases restrictions of businesses previously closed under the non-essential business closure, specifically golf courses and driving ranges, as well as outdoor archery and shooting ranges, marinas and watercraft rental businesses and campgrounds. Coded as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel. Eased on 20200619, permitting indoor services: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf

Extends gathering restrictions for more than 10 people for social, community, recreational, leisure and sporting events. Starting May 15, places of worship may reopen to up to 50 pct capacity. Religious gatherings are no longer included in the 10 person gathering prohibition, so coding as easing. Mandate ended on 20200610: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf

Eases restrictions on having in-person services conditional on continued restrictions: retail establishments (ie, no more than 50 percent capacity), beauty salons and barbers (have to wear masks, on appointment basis only, no more than 50 percent capacity), horse boarding and riding facilities. On 20200904, further eases restrictions to allow for up to 75 capacity: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-12th-AMENDED-9.1.20.pdf. On 20201120, expands restrictions on retail establishments (now can be up to 50 pct capacity). Extends eased restrictions on salons, barbers, horse boarding and riding facilities. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf Further eases on 20210312, permitting up to 100 pct capacity but continues requirements on at least 6 ft distancing: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Under the new Safer at Home public health advisory, (quote) Marylanders, particularly older and more vulnerable Marylanders, are strongly advised to continue staying home as much as possible. (quote).

Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to reopen for on-premises consumption in outdoor seating areas. Patrons must be seated at least 6 ft away from each other, groups no larger than 6 unless they are members of the same household. Eased to allow for indoor services at 50 pct on 20200612: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants and other foodservice establishments, permitting them to reopen for on-premises consumption in outdoor seating areas. Patrons must be seated at least 6 ft away from each other, groups no larger than 6 unless they are members of the same household.
Recommends Marylanders to avoid large gatherings and crowded places, ending gathering formal gathering restrictions.

Further eases bar restrictions, permitting indoor in-person services up to 50 pct capacity. Customers can only be served seated, cleaning and disinfecting procedures in place. On 20200612, eased to up to 75 pct capacity indoors: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-13th-AMENDED-9.18.20.pdf On 20201110, reduces to 50 pct capacity indoors: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-11.10.20.pdf.

Further eases restaurant and like venue restrictions, permitting indoor in-person services up to 50 pct capacity. Customers can only be served seated, no buffets, cleaning and disinfecting procedures in place. On 20200921, increased capacity limits up to 75 pct: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-13th-AMENDED-9.18.20.pdf On 20201110, decreased capacity limits to 50 pct: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-11.10.20.pdf.

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesss, allowing the following to re-open at 50 pct capacity indoors: shopping centers with closed pedestrian concourses, indoor recreation establishments (eg bingo halls, bowling alleys, skating rinks), social and fraternal clubs. Also permits the opening of fitness centers, health clubs, gyms, aquatic centers, casinos, racetracks, and betting facilities. Also permits previously outdoor only (eg, golf courses, driving ranges, archery ranges) to reopen at 50 pct capacity. Eases on 20210312, permitting up to 100 pct capacity conditional on 6 ft distancing continuing: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Maryland Department of Health and State Department of Education requires school staff to wear cloth face coverings in the school building and school grounds, and while on the school bus.  Extended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Gatherings-24th-AMENDED-5.14.21.pdf Extended to 20210712 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/2656_001.pdf. Ended on 20210701 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Termination-Roadmap-6.15.21.pdf

(quote) Any Marylander who travels to a state with a COVID-19 test positivity rate above 10 pct should get tested and self-quarantine at home until the test result is received. (quote) The District of Columbia and Virginia are exempt. This advisory is tied to CDC-based updates, which can update every day. Due to the advisory nature of this quarantine policy (also does not provide specificity around quarantine length beyond the test result received) and that locations it applies to is not actually provided with a state-coordinated source (defers to the CDC), we are not including locations to which this policy applies at present.

(quote) The Maryland Department of Health strongly recommends that all Marylanders refrain from nonessential travel outside of Maryland (quote) Ended on 20210312 with travel advisory rescinding: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf

All persons in Maryland over the age of 5 years are required to wear a face covreing when they are in or on any public trnasportation, indoors at any location (inclusive of religious facilities), outdoors and unable to consistently maintain at least 6 ft. Additional exemptions are for individuals with a disability or medical condition. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf  Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf

Theaters and entertainment venues may reopen subject to rules. Indoor theaters shall have 50 pct capacity limit (or 100 persons) and outdoor venues shall have a 50 pct capacity limit (or 250 persons). Eases on 20210312, permitting up to 50 pct capacity without absolute limits: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Eased on 20210515 to allow up to 100 pct capacity with face coverings required https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All Marylanders should refrain from attending public and private indoor gatherings of more than 25 individuals in one location and should practice physical distancing to the extent possible (quote). Effective 20201120, religious facilities can operate up to 50 pct capacity (previously 75 pct) https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf

Effective 20201120, all bars must close between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., except for the purposes of carryout and delivery. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf Effective 20210201, curfew restrictions are lifted, while maintaining indoor services restrictions at 50 pct capacity maximum and requirement that patrons be seated for service https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Gatherings-18th-AMENDED-01.28.21.pdf.

Effective 20201120, all restaurants must close between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., except for the purposes of carryout and delivery. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf. Effective 20210201, curfew restrictions are lifted, while maintaining indoor services restrictions at 50 pct capacity maximum and requirement that patrons be seated for service https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Gatherings-18th-AMENDED-01.28.21.pdf.

Expands gathering recommendation. (quote) All Marylanders should refrain from attending either public or private indoor gatherings of more than 10 individuals at one location and should practice physical distancing to the extent possible. (quote) Eased on 20210312: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateExpiry and DateEased, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All Marylanders who travel outside of Maryland and individuals who travel to Maryland, shall immediately get a COVID-19 test upon arrival in Mayrland or within 72 hours before travel to Maryland....symptomatic travelers shall self-isolate upon arrival...asymtpomatic individuals shall self-quarantine while awaiting test results (quote). Exempts travel to District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Virginia, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and the States of Delaware and West Virginia by Marylanders, as are individuals who regularly commute outside of the state and if they have work-based COVID-19 screening. Turns into a recommendation on 20210312: https://phpa.health.maryland.gov/Documents/2021.03.09.02%20-%20MDH%20Order%20-%20Amended%20Various%20Health%20Care%20Matters%20Order.pdf

Extends restrictions on bars, ending curfew restrictions, while maintaining indoor services restrictions at 50 pct capacity maximum and requirement that patrons be seated for service. In effect for duration of state of emergency. Eased on 20210312, allowing up to 100 pct capacity but requires continued 6 ft distancing: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Gatherings-20th-AMENDED-3.9.21.pdf Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Further eased on 20210428 to allow unseated service outdoors https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Gatherings-22d-AMENDED-4.28.21.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Further eased on 20210515 to allow unseated service indoors https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Extends restrictions on restaurants, ending curfew restrictions, while maintaining indoor services restrictions at 50 pct capacity maximum and requirement that patrons be seated for service. In effect for duration of state of emergency. Eased on 20210312, permitting up to 100 pct capacity but still requiring at least 6 ft distancing. Extended to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Further eased on 20210428 to allow unseated service outdoors https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Gatherings-22d-AMENDED-4.28.21.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Further eased on 20210515 to allow unseated service indoors https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Lifts recommendation of no more than 10 on 20210312, and permits religious venues to operate at 100 pct capacity (though still requires social distancing). Extends recommendation to avoid large gatherings. Extends to 20210417: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Renewal-of-State-of-Emergency-March-18.pdf Extended to 20210516: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/State-of-Emergency-Renewal-April-16-2021.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Ended on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-76.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Advisory recommendations continue for Marylanders who travel outside of Maryland and individuals who travel to Maryland, recommending them to get a COVID-19 test upon arrival in Mayrland or within 72 hours before travel to Maryland, and otherwise quarantine awaiting test results. Exempts travel to District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Virginia, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and the States of Delaware and West Virginia by Marylanders as are individuals who regularly commute outside of the state and they have work-based COVID-19 screening.

Eases face covering requirement, no longer requiring them outdoors, even if 6 ft of distance is not possible. Continues to require them for all persons in Maryland over the age of 5 years at Outdoor Venues, like large sporting event arenas and venues, and on public transportation, and indoors at any location (inclusive of religious facilities). Exemptions continue for individuals with a disability or medical condition. Coded as a Mandate 2 for PublicMaskLevel as no longer requires them for most outdoor spaces, while still requiring them in all indoor spaces and outdoor venues. Extended to 20210611 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Scanned-from-a-Xerox-Multifunction-Printer-77.pdf Eased on 20210515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Gatherings-24th-AMENDED-5.14.21.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and DateExpiry and Added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases face covering requirement. Requires them for all persons in Maryland over the age of 5 years at in or on any Public Transportation or School Bus, obtaining healthcare services, indoors in any portion of a School where interaction with others is likely, including without limitation, classrooms, hallways, cafeterias, auditoriums, and gymnasiums. Exemptions continue for individuals with a disability or medical condition. Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as it does not broadly apply across indoor settings. Extended to 20210712 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/2656_001.pdf. Ended on 20210701 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Termination-Roadmap-6.15.21.pdf
State of Emergency declared. No clear expiry provided. Rescinded on 20210615: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download.
Prohibits gatherings of 250 or more throughout the Commonwealth, inclusive of faith-based gatherings.

Limited operations required (off premise only): bars. Closure on bars in MA extends through Phase II: https://www.mass.gov/doc/reopening-phase-2-step-2-order/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download
Expands gathering restriction to no more than 25 people, inclusive of faith-based events.

Limited operations required (off premise only): restaurants. Restrictions continued with 20200518 re-opening order: https://www.mass.gov/doc/may-18-2020-re-opening-massachusetts-order/download Effective 20200608 restaurants can provide service outside https://www.mass.gov/doc/june-6-2020-phase-ii-reopening/download

All public and private elementary and secondary K-12 schools in the Commonwealth are to suspend in-person instruction starting on 20200317. Eased on 20200706, permitting summer school instruction: https://www.doe.mass.edu/covid19/on-desktop/2020-0701summer-comp-guide-document.docx

Gatherings of people more than 10 prohibited, inclusive of faith-based events. Explicitly does not prohibit gatherings of more than 10 in an unenclosed, outdoor space (e.g., park). Eased on 20200518, lifting absolute limits on religious gatherings: https://www.mass.gov/doc/may-18-2020-re-opening-massachusetts-order/download

All non-essential services shall close their physical workplaces and facilities to workers, customers, and public. Easing starts on 20200518: manufacturing, construction, firearms retailers and shooting ranges. https://www.mass.gov/doc/may-18-2020-re-opening-massachusetts-order/download

Issues a stay-at-home advisory (non-mandated) to the general population as well as people aged 70 and older. Extended to 20200518: https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-extends-non-essential-business-closures-to-may-18th-announces Eased on 20200518, to apply to only at risk populations and those aged 65 older: https://www.mass.gov/news/safer-at-home-advisory

People arriving in MA are (quote) instructed (quote) to self quarantine for 14 days, no expiry date provided. Gov language and press release references CDC and dept of state guidance. Easing began on 20200801, such that All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/doc/july-24-2020-travel-order-pdf/download Effective Friday, August 7, Rhode Island is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 14, Hawaii is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 29, Colorado, Delaware, Pennsylavnia and West Virginia are added to the list of lower-risk states. All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Vermont and West Virginia https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective September 5, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming are added to the list of lower-risk states https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order Effective September 12, 2020 Delaware, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia were removed from the list of lower-risk states, and New Mexico was added to the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, Washington, and Wyoming. https://boston.cbslocal.com/2020/09/11/massachusetts-removes-delaware-pennsylvania-west-virginia-lower-risk/ Effective September 19, 2020 Wyoming was removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, and Washington. Effective September 26, 2020 Oregon was removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Vermont, and Washington. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states-. Effective October 3, 2020, Washington D.C. was added and Colorado, New Jersey, and New Mexico were removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Connecticut, District of Columbia, Maine, New Hampshire, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states-. Effective 20201017, California, Hawaii, New Jersey, and Washington were added to list of lower-risk states. These states are now California, Connecticut, District of Columbia, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New York, Vermont and Washington. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201031, Connecticut and New Jersey were removed from list of lower-risk states https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order Effective 20201107, California is removed from the low risk list https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order Effective 20201114, District of Columbia, New York, Washington State are removed as low-risk states: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201120, Maine and New Hampshire are removed as low-risk states: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201128, Vermont is removed as a low-risk state: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20210101: Quarantine is shortened to 10 days (from 14), Hawaii remains the only lower risk state: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Extended on 20210108, Hawaii remains the only lower risk state: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Eased on 20210122, relaxing test negative requirement prior to entering Massashusetts and including an exception for those who have tested positive within 90 days of arrival: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. On 20210212, adds North Dakota and Puerto Rico to low risk states: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. On 20210224, removes North Dakota https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. On 20210303 adds Missouri, Oregon, and Washington https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20210322 the travel order becomes a travel advisory https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-66/download?n

(quote) All persons are required to wear masks or cloth face coverings at all times when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, and other retail stores. All persons are also required to wear masks or cloth face coverings when providing or using the services of any taxi, car, livery, ride-sharing, or similar service or any means of mass public transit, or while within an enclosed or semi­ enclosed transit stop or waiting area (quote). Also indicates that businesses can refuse entry to any patron who does not wear a mask or face covering. On 20200518, emphasizes the requirement of face coverings or masks for employees for sectors as they reopen: https://www.mass.gov/doc/may-18-2020-re-opening-massachusetts-order/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

(quote) Effective Wednesday, May 6, 2020, any person over age two who is in a place open to the public in the Commonwealth, whether indoor or outdoor, and is unable to or does not maintain a distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering, except where a person is unable to wear a mask or face covering due to a medical condition or the person is otherwise exempted by Department of Public Health guidance. (quote). Also emphasizes the requirement for persons to wear masks or face coverings at all times when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, and other retail stores, as well as all transportation services. Coded as Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or the equivalent in indoor and outdoor public areas. Amends on 20201102, now requiring children aged 5 and older: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-55/download. Eases on 20210430, now providing exemptions for mask use outdoors if more than 6 ft distancing can be maintained, but still coding as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-67/download. Largely eased effective 20210529 when governors mask mandate is rescinded and replaced with public health mandate for masks in limited settings: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Gatherings of people more than 10 are prohibited, but eases restrictions on houses of worship, permitting them to have up to 40 pct capacity conditional on adhering to at least 6 ft distancing between attendees from different households. Explicitly does not prohibit gatherings of more than 10 in an unenclosed, outdoor space. Does not expire until rescinded or the emergency ends. Eases on 20200706: https://www.mass.gov/doc/revised-gatherings-order-july-2-2020/download

Eases restrictions on several businesses, conditional on their compliance with workplace safety and standards (including at least 6 ft distancing): manufacturing, construction, firearms retailers and shooting ranges. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download
Issues safer at home advisory, recommending that people over the age of 65 and with underlying conditions that could put them at risk for COVID-19 to stay at home

Eases restrictions on additional businesses, conditional on compliance with business health and safety standards (at least 6 ft distancing): general use businesses, car washes, hair salons and barber shops, pet groomers, drive in-movie theaters, laboratories. Note that general use offices are for outside of Boston, which cannot open before June 1, but we are not coding this separately. Requires not having meetings of more than in offices/general use businesses, hair salons and barbershops require at least 6 ft distancing between chairs.

Eases restrictions on outdoor recreation and like venues: outdoor gardens, zoos, reserves and public installations, beaches, fishing, hunting and boating, outdoor adventure activities (including ski area summer activities, zip-lines, and mountain biking). Requires 6 ft distancing, prohibiting groups of 10 gathering, mask use, etc. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Eases restrictions on retail businesses (inclusive of auto dealerships), permitting curbside pick-up to begin on 20200525. Also permits libraries to reopen for curbside and delivery on 20200525. Eased on 20200608, permitting onsite services: https://www.mass.gov/doc/june-6-2020-regulating-gatherings-throughout-the-commonwealth/download

Eases restrictions on retail businesses (inclusive of auto dealerships, as well as malls), permitting onsite services conditional on following requirements: no more than 40 pct capacity or 8 persons per 1000 sq ft (whichever is higher), 6 ft distancing, etc. Expanded on 20201226, reducing capacity to 25 pct: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-59/download Re-eased on 20210208, allowing 40 pct capacity: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-63/download Further eased on 20210301, allowing 50 pct capacity: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-65/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Eases restrictions on the following businesses as part of Phase II, conditional on following health and safety protocols and limiting capacities: 1-on-1 personal services (eg, massage, nail salons, personal training) with no more than 2 people from the same household at the same time, limited sporting activities and professional sports, instructional classes and services that do not require close contact (eg, photography) while following at least 6 ft distancing and gathering restrictions. Further eased on 20200706, permitting expanded services for personal training, and professional sports teams can restart games without spectators: https://www.mass.gov/news/reopening-massachusetts-baker-polito-administration-initiates-transition-to-third-phase-of

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting outdoor services only: historical sites (but no functions or gatherings or guided tours), outdoor recreational facilities (pools playgrounds, spray decks, mini golf, go karts, batting cages, climbing walls, ropes courses) conditional on following gathering restrictions (no more than 10) and at least 6 ft distancing, outdoor driving ranges for golf (must follow social distancing requirements of at least 6 ft, no gatherings). Eases on 20200706, allowing indoor services: https://www.mass.gov/news/reopening-massachusetts-baker-polito-administration-initiates-transition-to-third-phase-of

Eases restrictions on restaurants, permitting outdoor services to resume for seated services only. Beer gardens, wineries, and distilleries with seated food services may also open under this policy. Requirements include at least 6 ft distancing between tables, party size of no more than 6 people at a time, no bar seating, etc. Eased on 20200622, permitting indoor services: https://www.mass.gov/doc/reopening-phase-2-step-2-order/download

Eases restrictions on restaurants, permitting indoor services to resume for seated services only. Beer gardens, wineries, and distilleries with seated food services may also open under this policy. Requirements include at least 6 ft distancing between tables, party size of no more than 6 people at a time, no bar seating, etc. No additional capacity limits provided.

(quote) All students are required to wear a mask/face covering that covers their nose and mouth...Adults, including educators and staff, are required to wear masks/face coverings...Exceptions to mask/face covering requirements must be made for those for whom it is not possible due to medical conditions, disability impact, or other health or safety factors (quote).  Ended and replaced with a recommendation on 20210730: https://www.doe.mass.edu/covid19/on-desktop/2021-0730fall-2021-covid19-guidance.pdf

Eases school restrictions, permitting limited in-person instruction for summer school no earlier than 20200706 and requires adherence to various requirements (e.g., no more than 10 people per classroom, having no more than 50 pct capacity or 300 people of the overall school, maintain at least 6 ft distancing betwen desks, and among students and staff). On 20200818, state-coordinated restrictions on schools are ended: https://mailchi.mp/doe.mass.edu/commissioners-weekly-update-8-10-20-reopening-plans-due-aug-14-noteworthy-practices-from-preliminary-plans-remote-learning-partner-survey

Eases gathering restrictions, permitting indoor gatherings up to 8 people per 1000 sq ft and no more than 25 people in a single space, and outdoor gatherings up to 25 pct capacity or 8 people per 1000 sq ft if no occupancy limit is on record, and no more than 100 people in a outdoor space that is enclosed, permitted, or leased. Continues to clarify these restrictions do not apply to unenclosed outdoor settings (eg, park, field, etc) though at least 6 ft distancing is required. This easing is not applicable to the city of Boston until 20200713. For houses of worship, Phase III has a maximum capacity of 50 pct for indoor services (and 10 persons per 1000 sqt feet for buildings without explicit capacity limits), at least 6 ft distancing among groups outside of ones own household. Capacity limits are not immediately clear for outdoor religious gatherings: https://web.archive.org/web/20200709142918/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/safety-standards-and-checklist-places-of-worship

Eases restrictions on some businesses as part of Phase III, permitting indoor services to resume for historical sites (no more than 40 pct capacity indoors, must have a least 6 ft distancing), indoor recreational facilities where there is low potential for contact, such as batting cages, driving ranges, bowling alleys, go-karts, rock climbing facilities, and arcades (no more than 40 capacity indoors, must have at least 6 ft distancing). Continues eased restrictions for outdoor only recreational facilities like playgrounds and pools. Also allows the follwoing to start indoor services: Eases restrictions on the following businesses as part of Phase III, Step 1: museums (no more than 40 pct capacity indoors, must have at least 6 ft distancing), gyms and fitness studios (no more than 40 pct capacity, ensure at least 6 ft distancing between groups outside of the same household, and more for equipment, at least 14 ft of distancing between group fitness classes), a subset of performance venues (indoor movie theaters, up to 40 pct capacity maximum, at least 6 ft distancing), casinos (must follow 40 pct capacity limits, at least 6 ft distancing).
Eases restrictions on the following, permitting outdoor services only: theaters and performance venues. Must ensure at least 6 ft distancing among groups in different households, etc.

Expands gathering restrictions, limiting outdoor gatherings to up to 25 pct maximum permitted occupancy (or 8 persons per 1000 sq ft), and no more than 50 people in a single outdoor space. Continues indoor gathering restriction of no more than 8 people per 1000 sq ft (and never more than 25 people in a single indoor space). At least 6 ft distancing required at all gatherings, and continues to clarify these restrictions do not apply to unenclosed outdoor settings (eg, park, field, etc) though at least 6 ft distancing is required. Continues prior requirements for houses of worship: 50 pct for indoor services (and 10 persons per 1000 sqt feet for buildings without explicit capacity limits), at least 6 ft distancing among groups outside of ones own household. Capacity limits are not immediately clear for outdoor religious gatherings: https://web.archive.org/web/20200812143621/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/safety-standards-and-checklist-places-of-worship

Amends gathering restrictions, requiring all gatherings to disperse by 930 pm. Public gathering are limited to no more than 25 people indoors and 50 people outdoors, while private gatherings are limited no more than 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. For lower-risk communities (at the municipality level), up to 100 people can gather outdoors. Requires 6 ft distancing between households, etc. Expands religious gathering restrictions on 20201213, reducing capacity to 40 pct: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-57/download

Amends business restrictions to require closure between 930 pm and 500 am for the following:  museums (no more than 40 pct capacity indoors, must have at least 6 ft distancing), gyms and fitness studios (no more than 40 pct capacity, ensure at least 6 ft distancing between groups outside of the same household, and more for equipment, at least 14 ft of distancing between group fitness classes), a subset of performance venues (indoor movie theaters, up to 40 pct capacity maximum, at least 6 ft distancing), casinos (must follow 40 pct capacity limits, at least 6 ft distancing), hair salons and barber shops,  indoor and outdoor arcades as part of recreational facilties, permitting them to reopen the following at no more than 40 pct capacity, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Also continues eased restrictions on historical sites (no more than 40 pct capacity indoors, must have a least 6 ft distancing), indoor recreational facilities where there is low potential for contact, such as batting cages, driving ranges, bowling alleys, go-karts, rock climbing facilities, and arcades (no more than 40 capacity indoors, must have at least 6 ft distancing), personal training, sporting activities and professional sports teams (only open without spectators), massage and nail salons, all other personal care services (e.g., day spas, tattoo parlors). Expanded restrictions to most businesses, requiring 25 pct capacity on 20201226: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-59/download Expanded restrictions continue through 20210125: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-62/download

Amends business restrictions for outdoor theaters and performance venues, and outdoor recreation, requiring closure of onsite services at 930 pm and that they cannot reopen until 500 am. Applies to outdoor gardens, zoos, reserves and public installations, beaches, fishing, hunting and boating, outdoor adventure activities (including ski area summer activities, zip-lines, and mountain biking). Expands on 20201226, requiring 25 pct capacity for most of these venues: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-59/download.

Amends restaurant restrictions, requiring closure of onsite services at 930 pm and that they cannot reopen until 500 am. Extends the following: eased restrictions on restaurants, permitting indoor services to resume for seated services only. Beer gardens, wineries, and distilleries with seated food services may also open under this policy. Requirements include at least 6 ft distancing between tables, party size of no more than 6 people at a time, no bar seating, etc. No additional capacity limits provided. On 20201226, expands requirements, limiting capacity to 25 pct: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-59/download

(quote) Beginning on Friday, November 6, 2020, all residents of Massachusetts are advised to stay home between the hours of 10 pm and 5 am (quote) Ended on 20210125: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-62/download

Expands gathering restrictions, such that all gatherings (public and private) are limited to no more than 10 indoors and 25 outdoors. Religious gathering capacity limits are 25 pct. Continues requirement for gatherings to disperse by 930 pm. Extends to 20210124: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-60/download Extends to 20210125: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-62/download

Removes requirement for gatherings to disperse by 930 pm. Extends expanded gathering restrictions, such that all gatherings (public and private) are limited to no more than 10 indoors and 25 outdoors. Religious gathering capacity limits are 25 pct. Eases on 20210208, allowing religious gatherings to occur at 40 pct: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-63/download Eases on 20210301, allowing religious gatherings to occur at 50 pct: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-65/download

Removes business restrictions requiring closure between 930 pm and 500 am for the following (but continues 25 pct capacity restrictions for most businesses): museums, gyms and fitness studios, a subset of performance venues, casinos, hair salons and barber shops,  indoor and outdoor arcades as part of recreational facilities, historical sites, indoor recreational facilities where there is low potential for contact, such as batting cages, driving ranges, bowling alleys, go-karts, rock climbing facilities, and arcades, personal training, sporting activities and professional sports teams (only open without spectators), massage and nail salons, all other personal care services (e.g., day spas, tattoo parlors). Eases restrictions on 20210208, permitting 40 pct capacity for these venues: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-63/download Further eases on 20210301, permitting 50 pct capacity: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-65/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Removes business restrictions requiring closure between 930 pm and 500 am for outdoor theaters and performance venues, and outdoor recreation, continuing 25 pct capacity requirements for outdoor theaters and performance venues. Eases on 20210208, allowing 40 pct capacity: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-63/download Eases on 20210301, permitting indoor theaters and performance venues: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-65/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Removes requirement to close onsite services between 930 pm and 500 am. Extends expanded restaurant restrictions, requiring no more than a 25 pct capacity limit at restaurants, as well as beer gardens, wineries, and distilleries with seated food services. Excludes staff/workers, and the 25 pct capacity limit applies separately for indoor and outdoor areas. Continues prior requirements on seated services only, at least 6 ft distancing between tables, party size of no more than 6 people at a time, no bar seating, etc. On 20210208, eases to 40 pct capacity indoors: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-63/download On 20210322, further eases to only limit to 6 ft distancing: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-65/download. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Eases restrictions theaters and performance venues, permitting indoor venues to open at no more than 50 pct (with no more than 500 people). Must ensure at least 6 ft distancing among groups in different households, etc. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Eases gathering restrictions, permitting public gatherings to occur at up to 100 people indoors and 150 people outdoors in a single venue or space. Private gatherings at residences are limited to no more than 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. Places of worship may continue to operate at 50 pct capacity, maintaining 6 ft social distancing and requiring all patrons to wear face coverings. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

Eases restrictions on the following, permitting them to reopen at 12 pct capacity after submitting a formal plan to the Department of Health: large capacity sports and entertainment venues (i.e., stadiums (indoors and outdoors), arenas, and ballparks). Further eases restriction son 20210510 permitting them to reopen at 25 pct capacity https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-massachusetts. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download

As of Monday, March 22, all visitors entering Massachusetts, including returning residents, are advised to quarantine for 10 days upon their arrival. Travelers in the following categories are exempt from this quarantine advisory: anyone who visits Massachusetts for less than 24 hours, anyone who has been out of state for less than 24 hours, anyone who has a negative COVID-19 test result within the last 72 hours, anyone who has been vaccinated (i.e. who has received two doses of either the Moderna or Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines OR who has received a single dose of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine, 14 days or more ago), and workers who enter Massachusetts to perform critical infrastructure functions.

Eases restrictions on the following businesses: amusement parks, theme parks, outdoor water parks, which will be permitted to operate at a 50 pct capacity after submitting safety plans to the Department of Public Health. Ended on 20210529: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-69/download
Declaration of Public Health Emergency. No expiration given. Reissued on 20210614: https://www.mass.gov/doc/reissuance-of-certain-public-health-orders/download

Eases public mask requirements (now authorized through new Public Health Emergency, as mask mandate under State of Emergency was rescinded). Masks are only required on public transportation, in schools, in healthcare facilities, in congregate care settings, in correctional facilities, in shelters, in HHS agencies, and for home health workers. Exemptions include children under 5 and for individuals with conditions that would make it medically unsafe to wear a mask, while eating or drinking, etc. Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as this policy applies to a very narrow list of settings. Reissued on 20210614: https://www.mass.gov/doc/reissuance-of-certain-public-health-orders/download. Extended 20210730: https://www.mass.gov/doc/updated-advisory-regarding-masks-and-face-coverings-july-30-2021-0/download

Recommends that unvaccinated people wear masks indoors. Also recommends that vaccinated people wear masks in indoor settings if they are at increased risk of severe disease or if other members are at risk or are unvaccinated. (Quote)  fully vaccinated person should wear a mask or face covering when indoors (and not in your own home) if you have a weakened immune system, or if you are at increased risk f or severe disease because of your age or an underlying medical condition, or if someone in your household has a weakened immune system, is at increased risk for severe disease, or is an unvaccinated adult. (quote).

Strongly recommends masking wearing for K-6 students. Strongly recommends mask wearing for unvaccinated students and staff in grades 7-12. (Quote) This fall, DESE and DPH strongly recommend that all students in kindergarten through grade 6 wear masks when indoors, except students who cannot do so due to medical conditions or behavioral needs. Masks are not necessary outdoors and may be removed while eating indoors. DESE and DPH also strongly recommend that unvaccinated staff in all grades, unvaccinated students in grades 7 and above, and unvaccinated visitors wear masks indoors, in alignment with the statewide advisory on masking. (quote)

Expanded to state of emergency and state of disaster on 20200401. Extended to 20200620 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/05/22/file_attachments/1458384/EO%202020-99%20Emergency%20declaration.pdf Extended to 20200717. Extended to 20200812: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/07/14/file_attachments/1495465/EO%202020-151%20Emerg%20declaration.pdf Extended to 20201002 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/09/03/file_attachments/1536731/EO%202020-177%20Emergency%20declaration.pdf Extended to 20201028: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540837--,00.html Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme Court striking down emergency orders: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEnded of 20201002 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Gatherings of more than 250 people are prohibited throughout the state.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Schools are to remain closed through 20200405, so coded to 20200406. Easing begins on 20200615, with some extracurricular activities being permitted to resume: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-531786--,00.html
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded, added NoInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations required (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption only): bars, taverns, brew pubs and like venues. Easing began for Regions 6 and 8 on 20200522: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html Became statewide on 20200608: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-530620--,00.html

Closure required: theaters, cinemas, and indoor and outdoor performance venues, libraries and museums, gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor exercise facilities, exercise studios, and spas, casinos and racetracks, hookah bars, cigar bars, and vaping lounges, other places of amusement (e.g., amusement park, arcade, bingo hall, bowling alley, indoor climbing facility, skating rink, trampoline park)

Limited operations required (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption): restaurants. Allows for easing of restaurant restrictions starting on 20200522 in Regions 6 and 8: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html Extended to 20200613 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/05/22/file_attachments/1458387/EO%202020-100%20Emerg%20order%20-%20amendments.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry, added BusinessRestrictLevel, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands gathering restriction to a limit of no more than 50
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands required business closures to include non-essential personal care services (i.e., hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services, and similar personal care services that require individuals to be within six feet of each other).
(quote) This order must be construed broadly to prohibit in-person work that is not necessary to sustain or protect life (quote), and thus coding as a non-essential business closure.

(quote) Subject to the same exceptions, all public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring among persons not part of a single household are prohibited (quote). Easing began on 20200518 for Regions 6 and 8, allowing up to 10 people in a gathering https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html
Issued on 20200323. to be enacted on 20200324. Ends on 20200601 https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-530620--,00.html

People with positive tests must stay in their homes for seven days, people with symptoms must stay in their homes until three days after symptoms resolve, people with contact with those with symptoms or positive tests must stay in their homes for 14 days. In effect until the emergency declaration ends. Extended on 20200807: 
https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/08/07/file_attachments/1513961/EO%202020-166%20Emerg%20order%20-%20worker%20protections%20-%20reissue.pdf Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

(quote) All businesses and operations whose workers perform in-person work must, at a minimum, provide non-medical grade face coverings to their workers (quote). Requires individuals who can medically tolerate a face covering must wear one when in any enclosed public place, so applies to employees and business staff. Ended as part of the Michigan Supreme Court ruling on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Any individual able to medically tolerate a face covering must wear a covering over his or her nose and mouth—such as a homemade mask, scarf, bandana, or handkerchief — when in any enclosed public space. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires face coverings for all enclosed spaces, implying this is only applicable to indoor and like settings.

Starting 20200507, permits the following industries to resume operations: workers who perform work that is traditionally and primarily performed outdoors, including but not limited to forestry workers, outdoor power equipment technicians, parking enforcement workers, and similar workers. Also permits construction industry and real estate industry to resume in-person services, as well as (quote) workers necessary to the manufacture of goods that support workplace modification to forestall the spread of COVID-19 infections (quote). All re-opening sectors must adhere to social distancing requirements (i.e., at least 6 ft distancing), limited number of people on-premises (e.g., no more than 4 people at at time for real estate functions). Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

For Regions 6 and 8, indivduals may gather in groups of 10 or fewer. Region 6: Manistee, Wexford, Missaukee, Roscommon, Benzie, Grand Traverse, Kalkaska, Crawford, Leelanau, Antrim, Otsego, Montmorency, Alpena, Charlevoix, Cheboygan, Presque Isle, and Emmet counties. Region 8: Gogebic, Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Iron, Baraga, Dickinson, Marquette, Menominee, Delta, Alger, Schoolcraft, Luce, Mackinac, and Chippewa counties.

For Regions 6 and 8, bars and like venues may re-open to in-person services conditional on following business health and safety protcols. Per EO 2020-91, capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.

For Regions 6 and 8, restaurants may re-open to in-person services conditional on following business health and safety protcols. Per EO 2020-91, capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.
Gathering restrictions for up to no more than 10 people are effective statewide immediately

Eases gathering restrictions to the following: (quote) Indoor social gatherings and events among persons not part of a single household are permitted, but may not exceed 10 people....Outdoor social gatherings and events among persons not part of a single household are permitted, but only to the extent that the gathering or event does not exceed 100 people and people not part of the same household maintain six feet of distance from one another (quote)
Eased bar restrictions are now statewide: capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.

Eased restaurant restrictions are now statewide: capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas. Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme Court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Statewide, eases restrictions on the following indoor businesses, with maximum of 25 pct capacity or maximum of 250 people, and requires physical distancing (6 ft between people and parties): arcade, bowling alley, cinema, climbing facility, convention center, performance space, meeting hall, night club, sports arena, theater, or similar venue. Also eases restrictions on outdoor businesses, conditional on opening for a maximum of 25 pct capacity or 500 people, whichever smaller, and requires social distancing (6 ft between people and parties: concert space, race track, sports arena, stadium, or similar venue. Allows outdoor recreational facilities to re-open. Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf
Eases indoor gathering restrictions for Regions 6 and 8, allowing for up to 50 people gatherings indoors and 250 people gatherings outdoors if they following distancing guidelines

For Regions 6 and 8, eases restrictions on non-essential personal care services (can reopen but only at 25 pct capacity, follow health and safety protocols), including hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services.

Allows for all regions to have eased restrictions on businesses: non-essential personal care services, including hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services may re-open at 25 percent capacity, physical distancing, and following business safety protocols. Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

(quote) K-12 school sports activities and other in-person extracurricular school activities may resume (quote), requiring the same gathering restrictions applied for a given region. Ends on 20200630, devolving to local authorities: https://www.michigan.gov/documents/whitmer/MI_Safe_Schools_Roadmap_FINAL_695392_7.pdf

Requires that facial coverings or masks be always worn by staff except for meals, and that pre K-12 students must always wear facial coverings in hallways and common areas. Also requires masks to be worn in classrooms by all students in grades 6 to 12. Ended on 20201002 with Supreme Court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Closes bars for indoor services in regions that are Phase 4 of the Michign Safe Start Plan (all regions but Regions 6 and 8). Outdoor service may remain at bars and like venues, but only for seated customers at socially distanced tables. Also clarifies that capcaity should be at no more than 50 pct (was not clearly provided in previous EOs), patrons must wear face coverings unless seated, distancing between tables, etc.

Any individual who leaves their home or place of residence must wear a face covering over their nose and mouth when in any indoor public space, when outdoors and unable to consistently maintain a distance of six feet or more from individuals who are not members of their household, and when waiting for or riding on public transportation, while in a taxi or ridesharing vehicle, or when using a private car service as a means of hired transportation. Makes exemptions for children under 5 years old, individuals who cannot medically tolerate a face covering, during exercise, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or face coverings in any indoor or outdoor space when unable to maintain physical distancing in public. On 20200717, order is extended and clarifies that this mandate is not required when at a polling place for purposes for voting, as well as when when engaging in religious worship while at a house of religious worship (though strongly encouraged to wear face coverings during religious services, per CDC): https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/07/17/file_attachments/1498115/EO%202020-153%20Emerg%20order%20-%20Masks%20-%20re-issue.pdf Starting on 20200811, all staff, visitors, and children over 2 required to wear face masks in childcare facilities https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/08/06/file_attachments/1512889/EO%202020-164%20Emerg%20order%20-%20masks%20and%20camps.pdf. Ended on 20201002 after Michigan Supreme Court overturns governors EOs. https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Closes bars for indoor services in all regions, making the closure of indoor bar service statewide. Outdoor service may remain at bars and like venues, but only for seated customers at socially distanced tables. Also clarifies that capcaity should be at no more than 50 pct (was not clearly provided in previous EOs), patrons must wear face coverings unless seated, distancing between tables, etc. Ends on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme court decision: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Statewide, indoor gatherings and events cannot exceed 10 people, and for regions that are not Region 6 and 8, outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 100 people. Exemptions for continue for professional sports leagues and teams (allowing them to resume operations without live audiences) and for polling places. Starting on 20201009, eased gatherings: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540568--,00.html

Statewide, indoor gatherings and events cannot exceed 10 people, though outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 250 people still in Regions 6 and 8. Exemptions for continue for professional sports leagues and teams (allowing them to resume operations without live audiences) and for polling places. Starting on 20201009, eased gatherings: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540568--,00.html

In all regions, effective September 9, 2020 indoor gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, sports facilities, exercise facilities, exercise studios, and the like may reopen. Requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals at all times, no steam rooms or saunas allowed to open. It appears that a 25 pct capacity limit is likely for these re-opened venues per EO capacity limits

Statewide, social gatherings and events at non-residential venues are limited to 500 people indoors (up to 20 pct capacity or 25 pct capacity for Regions 6 and 8) and 1000 people outdoors (up to 30pct capacity). Residential social gatherings are limited to 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.

Statewide, social gatherings and events at non-residential venues are limited to 500 people indoors (up to 20 pct capacity or 25 pct capacity for Region 6) and 1000 people outdoors (up to 30pct capacity). Residential social gatherings are limited to 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.

For non-residential venues (i.e., businesses) outside of Region 6, indoor gatherings from more than 10 up to 500 can occur only up to 20 pct capacity where there is fixed seating capacity and up to 20 persons per 1,000 sq ft in each room in venues without fixed seating. No capacity limits for 10 people indoors. For outdoors, capacity limits are actived from 100 to 1,000 persons such that 30 pct of capacity with fixed seating and 30 persons per 1,000 sq ft without fixed seating. No capacity limits for up to 100 people. While these restrictions are framed as gathering restrictions, they apply to (quote) non-residential venues (quote) that are not airports, bus stations, factory floor, restaurants, shopping malls, public pools, or workplace.

(quote) Businesses, goverment offices, schools, and other operations must not allow indoor gatherings of any kind unless they require individuals to wear a face covering (quote). Within the gathering section of the MDHHS order, indoor and outdoor gatherings are only permitted outside of residences if each person wears a face covering. Exceptions include children younger than 5 years old, if an individual cannot medically tolerate a face covering, while eating or drinking seated at a food service establishment, while exercising outdoors, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings. MDHHS orders requirements for school health and safety under Phase 4 of the MI Safe Start Plan, requiring all students in grades K on up to wear masks at school and requiring school districts and nonpublic schools to report on confirmed COVID-19 infections to Michigan Department of Health and Human Services. This applicable to all locations except for those in Region 6, where mask use is recommended

Requires no more than 15 pct total occupancy at non-tribal casinos, no more than 25 pct total occupancy at the following types of businesses: recreational sports and exercise facilities, such as gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, exercise studios, bowling centers, roller rinks, ice rinks, and trampoline parks. Also requires no more than 25 pct bather capacity limits for indoor pools and no more than 50 pct bather capacity limits for outdoor pools.

Business mask requirement: (quote) Except as provided elsewhere in this order, a person responsible for a business, store, office, government office, school, organized event, or other operation, or an agent of such person, must prohibit gatherings of any kind unless the person requires individuals in such gatherings (including employees) to wear a face mask, and denies entry or service to all persons refusing to wear face masks while gathered. For students PreK to grade 8, in-person instruction is permitted but all sports and extracurricular activities are prohibited. Eases restrictions on casinos, entertainment venues, including: auditoriums, arenas, banquet halls, cinema, conference centers, concert halls, performance venues, sporting venues, stadiums, and theaters. Also eases restrictions for amusement parks, arcades, and bingo halls, permitting them to re-open with a max of 100 people and requiring them to adhere to the business health and safety protocols, including on food or beverage sales. And eases restrictions on bowling centers and skating rinks. Bowling center are permitted them to re-open with a max of 100 people and requiring them to adhere to the business health and safety protocols, including on food or beverage sales. Eases restrictions on trampoline parks. For venues with fixed seating, occupancy must not exceed 20 pct of the limits established by the State Fire Marshal or a local fire marshal. For venues with non-fixed seating, occupancy is limited to 20 persons per 1,000 square feet, including within any distinct space within the venue. For all venues, no more than 100 persons may be gathered within any distinct space within the venue. Eases mask mandate such that masks are no longer required outdoors except in gatherings larger than 100 people, thus coded as Mandate2. Extends remaining components of mask mandate: (quote) All persons participating in gatherings are required to wear a face mask. (quote) Exemptions are for children under the age of 2, those who cannot medically tolerate a mask, while eating or drinking at a seated service, etc. Vaccinated individuals are not longer required to wear masks at indoor residential gatherings.

Extends business mask mandate, but vaccinated individuals are now exempt. Establishment owners must (quote) make a good faith effort (quote) to ensure that all unvaccinated individuals gathering indoors at their establishment are masked. Extended to 20210702 https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-560465--,00.html Ended on 20210622: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-562057--,00.html

Eases mask mandate such that masks are no longer required outdoors at all (from being required in crowds). Also exempts vaccinated individuals from mask mandate. Exemptions are for vaccinated individuals, children under the age of 2, those who cannot medically tolerate a mask, while eating or drinking at a seated service, etc. Extended to 20210702 https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-560465--,00.html. Extends school mask requirements, but vaccinated individuals are now exempt: all unvaccinated staff and children in schools are required to wear masks if the child is at least 2 years old in classrooms, hallways, buses, etc. For children ages 2 to 4, a good faith effort at masking is required. Limited operations required (to-go, delivery, off-site consumption required): bars. Extended to 20200518 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-48%20Final_tcm1055-430499.pdf. Eased on 20200601 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-63%20Final_tcm1055-433759.pdf

Closure required: hookah bars, cigar bars, and vaping lounges, theaters, cinemas, indoor and outdoor performance venues, and museums, gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor exercise facilities, exercise studios, and spas, amusement parks, arcades, bingo halls, bowling alleys, indoor climbing facilities, skating rinks, trampoline parks, and other similar recreational or entertainment facilities, country clubs, golf clubs, boating or yacht clubs, sports or athletic clubs, and dining clubs. On 20200318, clarifies that spas are tanning salons, tattoo and body art parlors, massage therapy establishments, nail salons, esthetician salons, and barber shops and similar establishments: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Filed%20EO-20-08_Clarifying%20Public%20Accommodations_tcm1055-423784.pdf Last businesses under this closure were allowed to re-open on 20200609: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf
Limited operations required (to-go, delivery, off-site consumption required): restaurants. Extended to 20200518 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-48%20Final_tcm1055-430499.pdf

With the stay-at-home order, requires sectors where employees can work from home to do so and lists exemptions for critical sectors. This is not coded as a non-essential business closure due to not requiring all non-essential businesses to close and phrasing to businesses that reflect more of a recommendation to close in-person operations (e.g., [quote] Workers should be encouraged to work remotely when possible and focus on core business activities. Inperson, non-mandatory activities should be delayed until the resumption of normal operations [quote]) and imposing the requirement on individuals to work from home rather than businesses to shutter operations. Office-based work, non-critical manufacturing, recreation outlets, non-essential retail and supply stores are by default required to close. Easing began on 20200418, permitting outdoor recreational services to re-open: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-38%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-429089.pdf
Initial gathering restriction coded with stay-at-home order (without specific numeric limits)

(quote) All persons currently living within the State of Minnesota are ordered to stay at home or in their place of residence except to engage in the Activities and Critical sector work set for below (quote). Ended on 20200518: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-433768.pdf

Eases restrictions to permit limited outdoor recreational facilities to re-open, conditional on no indoor facilities being re-opened: all state parks, public and private marinas, public and private golf courses and driving ranges, off-highway vehicle, snowmobiles, and watercraft repair shops, facilities, and showrooms, bait shops, outdoor shooting ranges and game farms

Permits some non-critical businesses to resume in-person operations (i.e., employees can be onsite): industrial and manufacturing businesses (excludes customer-facing retail) and office-based businseses for which their work does not primarily involve customer-facing retail. Requires following of COVID-19 preparedness protocols before workers can return to work. In effect through the peacetime emergency declaration. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf. Extended on 20210106 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Executive%20Order%2021-01%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-462272.pdf. Extended to 20210213 with extension of emergency declaration: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-04%20Final_tcm1055-463085.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-08%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-468348.pdf. Extended to 20210415: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-12_tcm1055-472035.pdf. Extended to 20210515 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-19%20Final%20%28003%29_tcm1055-476482.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://www.lrl.mn.gov/archive/execorders/21-22.pdf Ended on 20210528 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Signed%20Final%20EO-21-21%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-480440.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases business restrictions for non-critical businesses to include retail businessses. Businesses in this category include retail stores sell goods that can be picked up outside, without entering the place of business, with limited interaction between employees and customers. Salons and barbershops are included only to conduct retail product sales (no in-person services allowed). Eases in 20200518 to allow indoor services: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-433768.pdf

Strongly encourages all Minnesotans to wear cloth face coverings at all times when they leave their homes and travel to any public setting. Extends to 20200601 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-431921.pdfhttps://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-431921.pdf Extended on 20200605 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf
All gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. Eases gathering restrictions for places of worship on 20200526 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-62_tcm1055-433307.pdf

Eases prior restrictions, allowing outdoor recreation facilities to re-open indoor facilities conditional on following all capacity restrictions (i.e., no more than 50 pct of normal occupant capacity), requirements to maintain at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Applicable to the following businesses: all state parks, public and private marinas, public and private golf courses and driving ranges, off-highway vehicle, snowmobiles, and watercraft repair shops, facilities, and showrooms, bait shops, outdoor shooting ranges and game farms, ski areas. Also permits outdoor recreational equipment rentals, dispersed or single campsites, outdoor competitions, etc. Starting 20200609, removes 50 pct capacity limit: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf

Further eases restrictions on retail businesses, permitting in-person services and sales conditional strictly following DEED plan guidance, limit capacity to no more than 50 pct, and ensure maintaining at least 6 ft distancing between workers and customers. Further eased on 20200609 to remove 50 pct capacity limit: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf. Extended on 20210106 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Executive%20Order%2021-01%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-462272.pdf. Extended to 20210213 with extension of emergency declaration: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-04%20Final_tcm1055-463085.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-08%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-468348.pdf. Extended to 20210415: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-12_tcm1055-472035.pdf. Extended to 20210515 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-19%20Final%20%28003%29_tcm1055-476482.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://www.lrl.mn.gov/archive/execorders/21-22.pdf Ended on 20210528 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Signed%20Final%20EO-21-21%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-480440.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: All persons who are at risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are strongly urged to stay at home. Extended to 20201219: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-99%20Final%20%28002%29_tcm1055-454278.pdf. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf. Extended on 20210106 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Executive%20Order%2021-01%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-462272.pdf. No expiry specified, tied to emergency declaration. Extended to 20210213 with extension of emergency declaration: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-04%20Final_tcm1055-463085.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-08%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-468348.pdf. On 20210315, stay at home recommendation only applies to those who have not received the vaccine: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-11%20Final_tcm1055-471550.pdf.

A school district or charter school may safely open its building for a hybrid model of in-school learning and distance learning this summer for students eligible for summer learning or extended learning year services. (quote) The Summer Learning Period begins after the end of each school districts and charter schools respective 2019-2020 school year calendars and ends before their respective 2020-2021 school year calendars. Ended on 20200730: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-82%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-442391.pdf

Eases restrictions on gatherings of 10 or more for places of worship, funeral homes, and other venues that offer gathering space for weddings, funerals, or planned services of worship. Indoor settings cannot have more than 25 percent normal capacity with a maximum of 250 people with adherence to physical distancing. Outdoor settings must not exceed 250 individuals. Extended on 20200605 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf Eased on 20200605 and effective on 20200609 groups of less than 25 people can gather outside https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf

Eases bar restrictions to allow outdoor service. Restrictions on in-door service is still in place. Must ensure 6 feet can be maintained between tables, not to exceed 50 people. Eased on 20200609 to permit indoor services: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf

Requires some sectors to have employees and staff wearing masks or face coverings, including personal care services, restaurants and bars (and like venues) (quote) Workers, customers, and clients must follow face-covering requirements (quote) On 20200722, expands to apply more broadly across sectors: Mandates that employees working in outdoor situations where social distancing cannot be maintained must wear masks and requires individuals to wear face coverings in indoor businesses. Expands previous business mask requirements where only specific sectors were required https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-81%20Final%20Filed_tcm1055-441323.pdf. On 20201219, expands business mask requirements, requiring patrons of excercise facilities to wear face coverings at all times https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf. Extended on 20210106 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Executive%20Order%2021-01%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-462272.pdf. No expiry specified, tied to emergency declaration. Extended to 20210213 with extension of emergency declaration: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-04%20Final_tcm1055-463085.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-08%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-468348.pdf. Extended to 20210415: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-12_tcm1055-472035.pdf. Extended to 20210515 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-19%20Final%20%28003%29_tcm1055-476482.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://www.lrl.mn.gov/archive/execorders/21-22.pdf Ended on 20210514 https://www.lrl.mn.gov/archive/execorders/21-23.pdf
