Remaining counties are put under the directed health measures, and are thus required to close restaurants for on premises consumption (takeaway, curbside, delivery only). Different expiry dates are currently applied by county group so we are using the earliest: 20200430 for Cass, Douglas, Sarpy, 20200506 for Burt, Butler, Cuming, Dodge, Hall, Hamilton, Lancaster, Madison, Merrick, Polk, Saunders, Seward, Stanton, Washington, York and 20200511 Adams, Antelope, Arthur, Blaine, Boone, Banner, Box Butte, Boyd, Brown, Buffalo, Cedar, Chase, Cherry, Cheyenne, Clay, Colfax, Custer, Dakota, Dawes, Dawson, Deuel, Dixon, Dundy, Fillmore, Franklin, Frontier, Furnas, Gage, Garden, Garfield, Gosper, Grant, Greeley, Harlan, Hayes, Hitchcock, Holt, Hooker, Howard, Jefferson, Johnson, Kearney, Keith, Keya Paha, Kimball, Knox, Lincoln, Logan, Loup, McPherson, Morrill, Nance, Nemaha, Nuckolls, Otoe, Pawnee, Perkins, Phelps, Pierce, Platte, Red Willow, Richardson, Rock, Saline, Scotts Bluff, Sheridan, Sherman, Sioux, Thayer, Thomas, Thurston, Valley, Wayne, Webster, Wheeler. Extended to 20200504: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources Easing began on 20200504 for subset of counties: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx

Governor urges Nebraskans to (quote) stay home, stay healthy, and stay connected (quote) over the the coming weeks. On 20200409, Governor proclaims (quote) 21 days to stay home and stay healthy (quote), urging Nebraskans to stay home, with no non-essential errands and no gatherings: https://www.dropbox.com/s/mkgl9ho03rjhnsc/2020%2021%20Days%20to%20Stay%20Home%20and%20Stay%20Health%20.pdf?dl=0
Recommends that Nebraskans (quote) Wear a cloth face covering in public (grocery stores, pharmacies etc.) when you cant stay 6 feet away from others.(quote)

In-person services must cease for all beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy, gentlemans clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theatres, indoor theatres, tattoo parlors. Shared at a 20200409 press release, signed on 20200410, so the latter is coded as the enact date. Easing begins for some counties on 20200504: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx

(quote) Beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors/studios shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons. (quote) Applicable to counties where such businesses can reopen

Under the 19 regional directed health measures, gathering restrictions of 10 or more continue to at least 20200531. Religious services, including weddings or funerals are allowed but must maintain social distancing (6 ft apart) among parties of individuals. Coding easing, as religious services as now exempt. Will split by regional changes as needed in the future

Eases restrictions on beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors/studios, allowing up to 10 people in a single place but must uses mask or facial covering (both patrons and employees) starting on 20200504, current expiry is 20200531. Applicable to 10 of the 19 regional health departments: Douglas, East Central, Four Corners, Loup Basin, North Central, Northeast, Panhandle, Sarpy-Cass, Southeast, Southwest. Further eases on 20200601, allowing up to 25 people in a single place or up to 50 pct capacity: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/COVID-19-Outline-of-Changes-to-Upcoming-DHMs-Phase-II.pdf More counties join this level of restriction through 20200706: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-Directed-Health-Measures-for-Dakota-County-&-Central-District-Health-Department-Jurisdictions-Effective-July-6.aspx

Restrictions eased, allowing in-person services but must have no more than 50 pct occupancy, maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft, individual tables (no counter service, only seated service, a maximum of 6 people per table), alcohol can only be served while consuming a meal. Applicable to 10 of the 19 regional health departments: Douglas, East Central, Four Corners, Loup Basin, North Central, Northeast, Panhandle, Sarpy-Cass, Southeast, Southwest. More counties are added through 20200601
Eases bar restrictions for counties in Phase II, permitting them to reopen at up to 50 pct capacity, at least 6 ft distancing, no bar seating (all table service), no self-service.

(quote) Beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors/studios shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons. (quote) Applicable statewide as all counties can have these businesses reopen. Eased on 20200724, with some counties moving to a recommendation

Eases gathering restrictions to 25 people or 25 percent of applicable occupancy (whichever is greater) in 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County). Also exempts religious services.

Eases restrictions on gentlemans clubs, bottle clubs, bowling alleys, indoor theaters now can re-open at 50 percent capacity in 17 of 19 regional health districts (excludes Douglas County and Central public health district).

(quote) Every individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, and individuals who reside or resided with an individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, shall home-quarantine (quote) Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx Omitted from new set of directed health measures, now state recommendations are the policy and thus ends the mandate on 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Traveler-Recommendations.aspx

Eased restrictions on restaurants are now statewide. Dine in services are permited, but no more than 50 percent capacity and must maintain distancing standards, no more than 6 individuals seated together at a time, etc. Phase I and Phase II counties are under the same occupancy restrictions (50 pct, at least 6 ft distancing, only seated service, no more than 6 people at a table). Eased on 20200622, allowing some counties to open at 100 pct capacity but continued 6 ft distancing: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month

Eases restrictions on school-based activities, allowing school-based sports team practices to resume on June 1. Eases on 20200618, allowing school-based sports games to resume: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/COVID-19-Outline-of-Changes-to-Upcoming-DHMs-Phase-II.pdf Furthe eases on 20200701, allowing school contact sports events to begin (i.e., basketball, tackle football, soccer, wrestling): https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month Devolves school opening to local health departments on 20200720, constituting an ending: https://www.launchne.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/PlanningASafeReturn.pdf

For 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County) that move to Phase 3, gathering restriction eased to 50 pct for an indoor facility occupancy, or 75 pct of outdoor facility occpancy. No gathering more than 10,000 people

Now statewide, gentlemans clubs, bottle clubs, bowling alleys, indoor theaters now can re-open at 50 percent capacity for Phase II counties, and allowing these venues to operate at 100 percent capacity as long as 6 ft distancing between household units are followed in Phase III counties: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month Eased at the state level on 20200724, when counties started moving to Phase IV, where requirements became recommendations: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-Directed-Health-Measures-for-Dakota-County-&-Central-District-Health-Department-Jurisdictions-Effective-July-6.aspx

Now statewide,  beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors/studios can reopen at 50 pct for Phase II counties, and 75 pct capacity for Phase III counties. Eased at the state level on 20200724, when counties started moving to Phase IV, where requirements became recommendations: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-Directed-Health-Measures-for-Dakota-County-&-Central-District-Health-Department-Jurisdictions-Effective-July-6.aspx

Dakota County and Central regional health district (Merrick, Hall, Hamilton counties) move to Phase III, bringing the following eased bar and tavern restrictions statewide: permits in-person services at full capacity (100 pct), but must maintain distancing standards, no more than 8 individuals seated together at a time, etc. and thus is coded as additional easing versus ending of this policy. Eased on 20200724, when counties started to no longer have requirements on bar restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/LBHD-DHM-July24.pdf

Dakota County and Central regional health district (Merrick, Hall, Hamilton counties) move to Phase 3, bringing gathering restrictions statewide: 50 pct for an indoor facility occupancy, or 75 pct of outdoor facility occpancy. No gathering more than 10,000 people. On 20200724 and 20200801, regional health districts moved to Phase 4, easing their gathering restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Southwest-Nebraska-Public-Health-Department-Prepares-to-Move-to-Next-DHM-Phase.aspx Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200914, added DateEased of 20200724

PolicyCodingNotes: Eased restrictions for Phase III continue for the 18 other regional health districts: permits dine in services at full capacity (100 pct), but must maintain distancing standards, no more than 8 individuals seated together at a time, etc. More counties move out of this restriction through 20200914, when this ends policy ends: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx

Loup Basin health department region moves to Phase IV, where all previous requirements become recommendations, and thus masks are recommended for use at personal care services by both employees and patrons.

Loup Basin health department region moves to Phase 4, where indoor gatherings are now limited to 75 pct rated occupancy (previously 50 pct under Phase 3), and full occupancy for outdoor facilities. On 20200801, North Central and Southwest move to Phase 4, joining Loup basin with these gathering restrictions http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Southwest-Nebraska-Public-Health-Department-Prepares-to-Move-to-Next-DHM-Phase.aspx

Eased restrictions for Phase III continue for the 18 other regional health districts: allowing for up to 75 pct capacity in beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors/studios. Must use masks or facial covering (both patrons and employees) for personal care services. More counties move out of this restriction through 20200914, when this policy ends: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx

Eased restrictions for Phase III continue for the 18 other regional health districts for the operations of gentlemans clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theatres, and indoor theatres. Parties must remain limited to no more than 8, self-service buffets and bars are prohibited, and must maintain physical gathering restrictions (6 ft distancing). More counties move out of this restriction through 20200914, when this policy ends: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx

Eased restrictions for Phase III continue for the 18 other regional health districts: permits in-person services at full capacity (100 pct), but must maintain distancing standards, no more than 8 individuals seated together at a time, etc. More counties move out of Phase III through 20200914. Ends on 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx
For Phase IV counties, all previous requirements become recommendations, and thus masks are recommended for use at personal care services by both employees and patrons.

All regional health departments move to Phase 4, where indoor gatherings are now limited to 75 pct rated occupancy (previously 50 pct under Phase 3), and full occupancy for outdoor facilities. No absolute numeric limits.

New international travel quarantine recommendation issued: (quote) Nebraskans returning home from international travel (excluding healthcare workers, commuters, and other unique groups as defined below) should self-quarantine and self-monitor for 14 days upon return/arrival (quote). Note that these recommendations have been in place since June 1 but it was only in the latest set of directed health measures where explicit requirements on travel-based quarantines were excluded.

Expands gathering restriction in all regional health department areas, a maximum of 50 pct occupancy (not to exceed 10,000) indoors and maximum 10,000 for outdoors. Further expands on 20201111, reducing the capacity limit to no more than 25 pct capacity indoors (10,000 limit continues indoors and outdoors). Eases on 20201212, permitting up to 50 pct capacity (but still has a total capacity of 10,000). Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx.

At personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/body art facilities), both workers and patrons are required to wear masks at all times. Exemptions include when service are performed on faces, but 6 ft distancing must occur with all other customers and the provider must wear a face covering. Also requires that employees wear masks in the following settings: (quote) For beauty/nail salons, barbershops, massage therapy offices or centers, bowling alleys, pool halls, body art or tattoo establishments, and any other indoor businesses where staff and patrons are within six ( 6) feet of each other for fifteen (15) consecutive minutes or more: Such businesses shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons (quote) Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx. Eased on 20201212, masks are now recommended not required:https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-saturday.

Indoor carnivals, fairs, and dances are prohibited, and thus coding as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel. Note that many other businesses have requirements now for 6 ft distancing between parties (gyms/fitness centers, health spas, gentlemen and bottle clubs, personal care services like salons, barber shops, massage therapy, tattoo parlors) but this does not trigger a business closure under the current coding system (has to be a maximum of 25 pct capacity or less than 10 people on premises at a time). Eased on 20201212, permitting these venues to reopen indoors: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-saturday

Indoor gatherings are limited to no more than 25 pct of rated occupancy (no more than 10,000) for auctions, tracks, zoos, theaters, libraries, swimming pools, and thus is thus coded as a new restriction on businesses. For these venues, if they operate outdoors, they are limited up to 10,000 people. Also requires groups to be no larger than 8 individuals, 6 ft distancing required. Eased on 202001212, permitting up to 50 pct capacity (not to exceed 10,000): https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-saturday Further eased on 20201224, permitting up to 75 pct capacity and no 10,000 person limit indoors: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-thursday Ended on 20210130: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-January.pdf

For restaurants, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, private clubs, bottle clubs, and gentleman clubs, (quote) Individuals who are participating in games, including but not limited to: pool, darts, shuffleboard, air hockey, pinball or video/arcade games, must be required to wear a mask, except when those individuals are eating or drinking. (quote) In addition, (quote) For beauty/nail salons, barbershops, massage therapy offices or centers, bowling alleys, pool halls, body art or tattoo establishments, and any other indoor businesses where staff and patrons are within six (6) feet of each other for fifteen (15) consecutive minutes or more: Such businesses shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons, except for those patrons receiving services directly to their face. Patrons may remove their mask only while receiving services directly to their face (quote). Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as it does not broadly apply across indoor settings, providing exemptions for indoor setting where 6 ft distancing can be maintained for at least 15 minutes. DPM: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-November9.pdf Ended on 20201212: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-saturday
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and DateEnded, updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Mask use is recommended, rather than required, for personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/body art facilities), and recreation centers (bowling alleys, pool halls). District health deparments may implement stricter policies. Ended on 20210525 https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-first-lady-shore-launch-initiative-reconnect-nebraska

Eases business restrictions, permitting indoor carnivals, fairs, and dances to resume indoors at no more than 50 pct capacity limit for indoor facilities (up to 10,000 people) and 100 pct capacity for outdoor facilities (up to 10,000 people). Eased on 20201224, permitting up to 75 pct capacity and no 10,000 person limit indoors: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-thursday Ended on 20210130: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-January.pdf

Eases statewide gathering restrictions as Nebraska moves from yellow phase to blue phase. Indoor gatherings may be held at up to 75 pct capacity and outdoor gatherings may be held at 100 pct capacity (and removes the 10,000 limits for both). Gatherings are no longer limited to parties of 8. Religious gatherings have no restrictions but safety guidance remains and is recommended. District health deparments may implement stricter policies. Ended on 20210130: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-January.pdf

Eases case-based isolation requirements such that those who have recovered from the coronavirus in the past three months do not need to quarantine after a close contact, though they are encouraged to monitor for symptoms. Nebraskans who have been fully vaccinated (received both doses of the coronavirus vaccine) do not have to quarantine after a close contact. Instead, they will be in the (quote) self-monitor (quote) category, which involves wearing a mask for 14 days from the date of exposure and monitoring for symptoms. For everyone else: individuals who test positive must isolate for at least 10 days after testing positive but their isolation can end after they are fever-free, COVID-19 symptoms are improving, and a negative test. Individuals with close contact exposure with an individual who tests positive for COVID-19 can end their quarantine after 7 days if they have a negative test on day 5 after exposure, no symptoms are being experienced, and continued monitoring and mask wearing continues through day 14. Extended to 20210401: https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/ECHD-DHM-March.pdf. Extended to 20210501: https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-March.pdf. Extended to 20210601: https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-04142021.aspx. On 20210506, slightly eases for children aged 5-18, who now no longer have to quarantine after a close contact and can self-monitor instead: https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-05052021.aspx  Ended on 20210525 https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-first-lady-shore-launch-initiative-reconnect-nebraska

State of emergency declared. Extended through 20200630, so coded to 20200701. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf Extended without expiry on 20200731: http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-07-31_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_029/

Recommendation is only included in press script, and only emphasizes high-risk populations and (quote) older adult or Nevadan with an underlying serious or long-term medical condition, please take additional actions to reduce your risk of getting sick with this disease. I strongly urge you...(quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: All schools (public, private, charter) for K-12 closed effective 20200316, until order is rescinded. Cannot open earlier than 20200406. Extended to no earlier than 20200416 on 20200320 http://gov.nv.gov/uploadedFiles/govnewnvgov/Content/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-03-20%20-%20COVID-19%20Declaration%20of%20Emergency%20Declaration%20Directive%20005.pdf Extended.  to no earlier than 20200430 on 20200414 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Directive-014-Signed.pdf. On 20200421, school closure extended from 20200430 until the end of the school year. Ended for in-person instruction on 20200610 as authority granted to local school districts. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/2020-06-09.Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-022.pdf On 20200728 schools were directed to observe transmission rates in their community when deciding to adopt distanced, hybrid or in person reopening. Guidance was provided on social distancing, positive case scenario and athletic practice for students https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2020-07-28.Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-028.pdf

Recommendation expressed through press release script, but not codified in an order. (quote) All gatherings should be postponed or canceled. This is not the time for sleepovers, playdates, concerts, theater outings, or athletic events. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Verbally ordered on 20200317, formal issuance on 20200318 and goes into effect at 1159 pm on 20200318 for closing casinos (quote) Nevada general public shall cease gathering at gaming establishments, and all gaming devices, machines, tables, games, and any equipment related to gaming activity shall cease operations (quote). Eased on 20200604, as part of Phase 2: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf. Extended to 20200801 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf On 20210501 delegates mitigation measures for casinos (and other gaming properties)  to the Gaming Control Board effectively ending statewide restrictions https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Emergency-Directive-044.4-19-21.pdf
Goes into effect immediately, through 20200430. Public gathering directive was signed on 20200324 also banning groups more than 10

Closes all non-essential businesses that promote recreational social gatherings, which pertains to bars and like venues. Began easing on 20200529: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf. Extended to 20200801: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf On 20200710, requires bars and like venues not licensed to sell food to close for all in-person services in counties with Elevated Disease Transmission Risk (Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe): https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Emergency-Directive-027.pdf. On 20201124, expands statewide bar restrictions under the Nevada Statewide Pause. Allows indoor and outdoor service for breweries, distilleries, and wineries not licensed to sell food, allowing them to operate at a maximum of 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct), no more than 4 people per table, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, face coverings must be worn at all times, and reservations required at establishments that sell food. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf. Extended for 30 days on 20210111, so until 20210210: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Governor-Sisolak-Nevada-Department-of-Health-and-Human-Services-release-updated-COVID-19-Vaccination-Program-Playbook-Governor-extends-current-mitigation-measures.pdf. Eased on 20210215, now allowing indoor service at 35 pct capacity, no outdoor capacity limits, and no more than 6 people per table. Extended to 20210315: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf. Eased on 20210315, now allowing indoor service at 50 pct capacity: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf. Ended on 20210501 when the State Emergency Directives will no longer include social distancing and sanitation guidelines, and counties will have the authority to include social distancing measures within their mitigation plans. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Emergency-Directive-044.4-19-21.pdf

In effect on 20200320 at 1159 pm, coded to 20200321. Closure required: social gathering venues and businesses (recreation centers, clubhouses, nightclubs, movie theaters, massage parlors, adult entertainment establishments, brothels, and live entertainment venues), as well as businesses that promote extended periods of public interaction (fitness establishments and aesthteic services). In effect through 20200416 Extended to 20200801 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf. On 20201124, extends closure of night clubs, day clubs, brothels, adult entertainment facilities. Allows a maximum occupancy of 25 pct (from 50 pct) and adherence to safety measures. Applies to gyms, fitness centers, gaming venues, arcades, racetracks, bowling alleys, amusement and theme parks, libraries, museums, galleries, and zoos. Allows a maximum occupancy of 50 pct. Applies to retail, indoor malls, aestheticians and salons, body art or piercing establishments, and community and recreation centers. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf. Extended for 30 days on 20210111, so until 20210210: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Governor-Sisolak-Nevada-Department-of-Health-and-Human-Services-release-updated-COVID-19-Vaccination-Program-Playbook-Governor-extends-current-mitigation-measures.pdf. Eased for most businesses on 20210215, allowing operating at a greater capacity limit for gyms, fitness centers, personal care services (full capacity), libraries, museums, racetracks, arcades, gaming venues, etc. Continues capcity limits for retail and continues closure of night clubs, day clubs, brothels, and adult entertainment facilities. Extended to 20210315: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf. Eased on 20210315, allowing gyms and fitness centers, gaming venues, arcades, racetracks, bowling alleys, mini golf, pool halls, and amusement and theme parks to operate at 50 pct capacity. Continues capacity limits for libraries, museums, retail, etc and continues closure of night clubs, day clubs, brothels, and adult entertainment facilities: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf.  Ended on 20210501 when the State Emergency Directives will no longer include social distancing and sanitation guidelines, and counties will have the authority to include social distancing measures within their mitigation plans. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Emergency-Directive-044.4-19-21.pdf

In effect on 20200320 at 1159 pm, coded to 20200321. Limited operations required (onsite dining must cease): restaurants and food establishments. In effect through 20200416. Extends easing of restaurant operations (which allowed them to utilize tables and serve food within the bar area) quote (Directive 021, Phase 2 of the Nevada United: Roadmap to Recovery plan, is hereby extended to July 31st at 11.59pm) https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf On 20200710, re-imposes some restrictions for counties designated as Elevated Disease Transmission Risk (Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe), requiring bar areas and bar tops to close: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Emergency-Directive-027.pdf. On 20201124, expands statewide restaurant restrictions under the Nevada Statewide Pause. Allows indoor and outdoor service for restaurants and like venues, allowing them to operate at a maximum of 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct), no more than 4 people per table, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, face coverings must be worn at all times, and reservations are required. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf. Extended for 30 days on 20210111, so until 20210210: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Governor-Sisolak-Nevada-Department-of-Health-and-Human-Services-release-updated-COVID-19-Vaccination-Program-Playbook-Governor-extends-current-mitigation-measures.pdf. Eased on 20210215, now allowing indoor service at 35 pct capacity, no outdoor capacity limits, and no more than 6 people per table. Extended to 20210315: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf. Eased on 20210315, now allowing indoor service at 50 pct capacity: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Directive-037.pdf.  Ended on 20210501 when the State Emergency Directives will no longer include social distancing and sanitation guidelines, and counties will have the authority to include social distancing measures within their mitigation plans. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Emergency-Directive-044.4-19-21.pdf

More stringent restriction than the 20200319 issuance, governor indicates escalating penalties for not complying. On 20200408, also applies the 10+ ban to places of worship, so expanded. Eased on 20200529 with the introduction of gathering restrictions of up to 50: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf

Exemptions for outdoor activity as long as individuals do not congregate beyond members of their household. Exemption for individuals experiencing homelessness. PolicyCodingNotes: (Quote) Nevada public should utilize face coverings in public spaces (Quote)
All vulnerable people are strongly encouraged to stay home

(quote) Recognizing that COVID-19 is still present in Nevada and highly contagious, Nevadans are advised that they are safer at home and should avoid interpersonal contact with persons not residing in their households to the extent practicable.(quote)

Gatherings of more than 50 people prohibited. Extended without expiry on 20200731: http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-07-31_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_029/ Eased on 20201001: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-033.pdf.

(quote) Individuals not exempted by this Directive...shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a mask or face covering when in a public space (quote). Exempts children 9 years and younger, individuals who cannot wear a face covering due to a medical condition or disability, etc. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to public spaces broadly. On 20210503, Nevada rescinds Section 5 of Directive 24, which mandates the use of masks in all public spaces. Now specifies that individuals wear face coverings (quote) in a manner consistent with current guidance issued by the CDC, and any subsequent guidance issued by the CDC (quote). At this time, the CDC recommends the use of face coverings for all unvaccinated individuals in indoor and outdoor public spaces. Those who are fully vaccinated, however, may now gather indoors unmasked with other fully vaccinated individuals or with one household of unvaccinated individuals and in certain settings, may conduct activities unmasked, outdoors. As masks are still required indoors and outdoors for most individuals, still coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-045-JP.pdf

Bars, pubs, taverns, breweries, distilleries, and wineries not licensed to serve food must close for in-person service (take-out, curbside, and home delivery is permitted) in counties designated with Elevated Disease Transmission. As of 20200710, this applies to 7 counties: Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe. As of 20200804 this applies to Clark, Elko, Nye and Washoe. As of 20200821 this applies to Clark, Elko, and Washoe. As of 20200827 this applies to Elko. As of 20200921 this applies to no more counties, but it remains on the books - coding it as easing.

Restaurants and food establishments, as well as bars and like venues licensed to serve food, must operate under Phase One conditions (maximum of 50 pct capacity, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, no bar tops or bar areas open, buffets and self-serving dining facilities must remain closed) in counties designated with Elevated Disease Transmission. As of 20200710, this applies to 7 counties: Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe.

Eases gathering restrictions. Section 10 of Directive 021 is terminated, public gatherings are now restricted to the lesser of 250 persons, or 50 pct of the listed fire code capacity. Section 11 of Directive 021 is also terminated, houses of worship may now conduct indoor services so that occupancy shall not exceed the lesser of 50 pct capacity or 250 persons. Expanded for all counties other than Washoe (Carson City, Churchill, Clark, Douglas, Elko, Esmeralda, Eureka, Humboldt, Lander, Lincoln, Lyon, Mineral, Nye, Pershing, Storey, White Pine) on 20201105: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/11.5.20-Task-Force-Press-Release.pdf.

Expands gathering restrictions for Washoe County. (quote) Public gatherings in Washoe County are to be limited to 50 people or less for all indoor and outdoor events. (quote) Religious gatherings and places of worship are unspecified.

Statewide gathering restrictions under three week Nevade Statewide Pause. Public gatherings are restricted to the lesser of 50 persons (from 250), or 25 pct of the listed fire code capacity (from 25 pct). Places of worship are limited to gatherings of 50 people if capacity is fewer than 200 persons. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people from no more than 2 households, both indoors and outdoors. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf.

Expands gathering restrictions for places of worship. Faith gatherings and houses of worship are limited to 25 pct capacity. Coded as an expansion because although it no longer specifies absolute limits, it previously allowed for up to 50 people when capacity is 200 people and otherwise 25 pct capacity. Outdoor services are allowed subject to State guidance for gatherings, so coded as 50. Continues limits for public gatherings, which are restricted to the lesser of 50 persons, or 25 pct of the listed fire code capacity. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people from no more than 2 households, both indoors and outdoors. No expiry listed.

Eases gathering restrictions under Nevadas Roadmap to Recovery. Public gatherings and events are lmited to the lesser of 100 individuals or 35 pct capacity with strict social distancing requirements. Larger venues with a capacity of over 2,500 people may submit a safety plan, and if approved may hold gatherings at a 20 pct cap starting March 1. Places of worship may operate under strict social distancing requirements at no more than 50 pct occupancy (note that guidance document lists 35 pct capacity, in the case of this discrepancy we list limits listed in offical EO). Private social gatherings are restricted to 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. Guidance document issued on February 11 and official EO issued on February 14, so DateIssued coded as 20210211. Eases gathering restrictions on 20210305: larger venues with a capacity of over 2,500 people may now operate at the lesser of 50 pct capacity or 250 people. Continues the gathering restrictions for public gatherings, private gatherings, and gatherings at houses of worship: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Directive-040.pdf.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry, added DateEased, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions according to Executive Directive 037. Public gatherings are limited to the lesser of 250 individuals or 50 pct capacity with social distancing measures. Continues private social gatherings limits, which are restricted to 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. Places of worship may operate under strict social distancing requirements at no more than 50 pct occupancy. Under Emergency Directive 041, large gatherings in excess of 250 people may be held with additional mitigation measures set forth by the Department of Business and Industry, but may not exceed 50 pct capacity.  Eases gathering restrictions, as starting 20210501 the statewide directive stating that large gatherings in excess of 250 people may be held with additional mitigation measures set forth by the Department of Business and Industry, but may not exceed 50 pct capacity, will not apply anymore as decisions will be devolved to local authorities https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/large-gathering-venue-covid-19-preparedness-safety-guidance-apr-8.pdf.  Ended on 20210501 when the State Emergency Directives will no longer include social distancing and sanitation guidelines, and counties will have the authority to include social distancing measures within their mitigation plans. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Emergency-Directive-044.4-19-21.pdf df

Adds exemption for vaccinated individuals. Specifies that individuals wear face coverings (quote) in a manner consistent with current guidance issued by the CDC, and any subsequent guidance issued by the CDC (quote). At this time, the CDC recommends the use of face coverings for all unvaccinated individuals in indoor and outdoor public spaces. Those who are fully vaccinated, however, do not need to wear a mask in most indoor and outdoor locations, hence being exempted from the state mandate. As masks are still required indoors and outdoors for unvaccinated individuals, coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel.

Counties classified as high or substantial transmission, per CDC updates, must require the use of masks in public indoor settings, irrespective of their vaccination status. Indoor public settings include, but are not limited to, grocery stores, shops, malls, casinos, and other places of business, theaters, museums, art galleries, and other cultural venues, public buildings, including the DMV, social services offices, and similar locations, gyms, saunas, fitness studios, and similar venues, as well as riding on public transportation, shared transportation (eg taxi, ride share). Exemptions include children aged 9 years or younger, people with conditions in which wearing a mask would be harmful to their health, while eating or drinking, etc. Coded as Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across indoor settings.

(quote) Students should wear cloth face coverings in circumstances when physical distancing cannot be maintained (see classroom seating and transportation sections for additional guidance)....As with students, masks for educators and staff are strongly encouraged but not required....All educators and staff working with students are encouraged to wear cloth face coverings over their nose and mouth when at the educational facility and six feet of physical distancing may be difficult to maintain (including in the classroom) and/or when caring for potentially vulnerable students with underlying health conditions and disabilities. (quote)

Face coverings shall be required for all person who attend or are otherwise present at the following activities in New Hampshire: scheduled gatherings of 100 for social, spiritual, and recreational activities. Provides exemptions for gatherings where seating with at least 6 ft distancing occurs (and when seated), day-to-day operatins for profit and non-profit organizations (inclusive of government buildings and schools), and children under 2. Coded as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as this policy applies to very limited settings.

Effective 20201115, all residents and travelers in New Hampshire must comply with the following travel guidelines: Self-quarantine for 14 days following the last date of any high risk travel, which includes travel internationally, on a cruise ship, or domestically outside of the New England states of Maine, Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, or Rhode Island for nonessential purposes. People meeting the criteria for high-risk travel have the option of shortening their quarantine by getting a COVID test on day 7 of their quarantine. Eased on 20210115, now requiring only 10 day quarantine when arriving from high risk travel. Extended to 20210326: https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-82.pdf. Extended to 20210416 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-82.pdf Extended to 20210508 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-90.pdf Allowed to expire on 20210508

(quote) all persons over the age of 5 within the State of New Hampshire shall wear a mask or cloth face covering over their noses and mouths any time they are in public spaces, indoors or outdoors, where they are unable to or do not consistently maintain a physical distance of at least six feet from persons outside their own households (quote) Exemptions are for K-12 schools, individuals who are medically unable to wear a mask, eating/drinking, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20210327: https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-81.pdf. Extended to 20210417 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-87.pdf Allowed to expire on 20210417.

Universal Best Practices encourage face mask use (quote) for both staff and customers who are required to be within 6 feet of each other (or other customers) for at least 10 minutes or longer for delivery of service (quote)

Universal Best Practices introduce recommendation to avoid large gatherings. (quote) Ideally group sizes should be limited to 20 people or fewer, although exact group sizes will vary depending on situation and local context. Social/physical distancing, face mask use, and other mitigation measures should still be considered and implemented within the cohorting/grouping as feasible.... Work to maintain a distance of at least 6 feet or more of physical separation between people or related groups when possible. (quote)
Clarifies that a mask recommendation is not in effect indoors or outdoors for vaccinated or unvaccinated people, but high risk individuals are recommended to wear masks to protect themselves

State of Emergency declared (as well as Public Health Emergency). Extends to 20200704 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-151.pdf Extends to 20200801 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-162.pdf Extends on 20200801 to unspecified end date https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-171.pdf Extends on 20200827 to unspecified end date https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-180.pdf Extends to 20201025: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-186.pdf. Extends to 20201123 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-191.pdf. Extended to 20201222 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-200.pdf Extends to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210604 Ends the Public Health Emergency, while extending the State of Emergency for another 30 days. The Governor here orders and also signs onto in Assembly Bill No. 5820, (quote) which ensures that essential authorities, including the power of State agencies to modify existing emergency Orders and issue new Orders for certain purposes, can continue after the termination of the Public Health Emergency declared in Executive Order No. 103 (2020) to avoid disruption in New Jerseys emergency response (quote). This means that remaining policies related to the pandemic are extended under the State of Emergency for another 30 days, after which time they will expire. However, according to Assembly Bill No. 5820, state agencies may continue to implement policies related to testing, vaccination, and other pandemic responses until January 11 2022, at which time the Governor may extend those powers for another 90 days. Additionally, a number of administrative policies which we do not track (issued in fourteen different EOs, listed in Assembly Bill No. 5820) will be extended until January 1 2022, at which time they will expire (unless revoked by the Governor at an earlier date). EO: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-244.pdf, Assembly Bill 5820: https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2020/Bills/A9999/5820_I1.HTM. Expired on 20210704.
Recommending the cancellation of all public gatherings more than 250
LastUpdatedNotes: Added religious gathering limits and removed DateExpiry

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations required (limited to delivery, take-out services): bars.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes, added Date Expiry and TakeawayOnly

PolicyCodingNotes: All gatherings of persons in the state of New Jersey shall be limited to 50 or fewer, mandate passed after previous recommendation to limit gatherings to less then 250
Closure required: casinos, racetracks, gyms, fitness centers, entertainment centers such as theaters, nightclubs and concert venues. Goes in effect at 8 pm on 20200316
Limited operations required (limited to delivery, take-out services): restaurants. Eased on 20200615: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes, added Date Expiry and TakeawayOnly

PolicyCodingNotes: All schools close (public, private, parochial) for preschool, elementary and secondary school. Also ceases in-person instruction at all institutions of higher education. Goes into effect 20200318, in effect until the order expires (which does not seem to have formal expiry date). Began easing restrictions, allowing higher education institutions to resume in-person instruction on 20200618: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-155.pdf

Cancels all gatherings, and defers to State Director of Emergency Management to make clarifications on gathering limits. The administrative order 2020-04 defined gathering limits to no more than 10 people, and will be in effect for as long as EO-107 is in active. Extended to 20200605: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-142.pdf Eased on 20200522: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-148.pdf

(quote) The brick-and-mortar premises of all non-essential retail businesses must close to the public as long as this Order remains in effect. (quote) Also expressly closes the following: Also explicitly closes personal care services and libraries, all types of public amusement (locations with amusement parks, water parks, aquariums, zoos, arcades, fairs, childrens play centers, funplexes, theme parks, bowling alleys, family and childrens attractions), indoor malls. Expressly closes parks, golf courses, etc on 20200407: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-118.pdf Expressly halts non-essential construction on 20200408: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-122.pdf Begins easing on 20200502: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-133.pdf

(quote) All New Jersey residents shall remain home or at their place of residence unless they are…(quote) - until it is revoked or modified by governor. Takes effect at 9 pm 20200321. Ended on 20200609 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-153.pdf

Requires customers to wear cloth face coverings while on premises of essential retail businesses (e.g., groceries, pharmacies, among others). Exemptions are made for individuals under the age of two years and for individuals where wearing a mask would inhibit the individuals health. Coded as Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies to limited settings.

Requires adoption business health and safety protocols for essential retail businesses, including requiring workers and customers to wear cloth face coverings while on premises. In addition: (quote) If a customer refuses to wear a cloth face covering for non-medical reasons and if such covering cannot be provided to the individual by the business at the point of entry, then the business must decline entry to the individual (quote). Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf.

Eases restrictions on golf courses (public and private) and state parks and forests, if they follow requirements (golf courses: reservations only, stagger tee times, frequent sanitation, golf carts are single occupant only, recommended facial coverings. State parks and forests: employees and visitors should wear cloth face coverings while in the State Park or Forest in all settings, available parking must be limited at all State Parks and Forests at 50 pct of the maximum capacity at one time, no picnicking). Coded as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel because buildings such as visitor centers and pro shops are closed. Eases on 20200519, permitting more people at golf courses (still outdoor only).

Eases previous restrictions on closed businesses, allowing for curbside pickup for previously closed non-essential retail businesses. Eased on 20200615, permitting indoor services: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf

Eases gathering restriction for outdoors, allowing up to 25 people to gather if they also follow appropriate social distancing practices. Continues gathering restriction of 10 people indoors. Eases gathering restrictions on 20200609: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-152.pdf
Eases restrictions to allow restaurants and bars to have outdoor service starting on 20200615: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf. Extended to 20200704

Eases restrictions on non-essential retail, which may now operate at no more than 50 pct capacity and must require workers and customers to wear cloth face coverings while on the premises. Also permits other types of retail and rental services (e.g., watercraft rental) to re-open for in-person sales. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf Eased on 20210519, lifting the percentage-based capacity restriction. Now, capacity for these businesses is limited only by the requirement to maintain 6 ft of distance between groups or patrons. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210528, Ends restrictions for these businesses, which are now allowed to operate at full capacity, no longer limiting their occupancy such that 6 ft of distance can be maintained between individuals. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases restrictions to allow restaurants to have outdoor service starting on 20200615: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf. Extended to 20200704, and eases on 20200702: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf

Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 50 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 50 people. Still requires physical distancing (i.e., 6 ft distancing). If less than 10 people, face masks are not required (recommended). These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Eases restrictions to permit entertainment and recreational businesses closed under EO 107 Paragraph 9 to re-open for outdoor services, as long as they abide to gathering restrictions (i.e., no more than 100 people outdoors, maintain physical distancing of at least 6 ft). These include casinos, racetracks, gyms and fitness centers, enterainment centers (eg, movie theaters, nightclubs, performing art centers), malls, places of public amusement (aquariums, zoos, fairs, childrens play centers, bowling alleys, libraries), personal care services. Started easing on 20200622 to permit personal care services to reeopen for indoor services: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-154.pdf Continued easing to permit indoor services by sector until the last venues (indoor entertainment venues) were eased on 20200904: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-183.pdf

Eases restrictions on cosmetology shops, barber shops, beauty salons, hair braiding shops, nail salons, electrology facilities, spas, including day spas and medical spas, at which solely elective and cosmetic medical procedures are performed, massage parlors, tanning salons, and tattoo parlors, collectively referred to as personal care service facilities, which are permitted to reopen for in-person services indoors provided that the facility complies with standards issued by the Division of Consumer Affairs and DOH, as applicable. Further eases on 20200702, allowing more services to be performed on customers not wearing masks: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-157.pdf Reexpands restrictions on 20201112, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-194.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Eased on 20210205, now allowing businesses of this kind to operate at 35 pct of the stated maximum capacity ttps://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-219.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf. Eased to 50 pct capacity on 20210319: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-230.pdf. Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf  Eased on 20210519, lifting the percentage-based capacity restriction. Now, capacity for these businesses is limited only by the requirement to maintain 6 ft of distance between groups or patrons. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210528, Ends restrictions for these businesses, which are now allowed to operate at full capacity, no longer limiting their occupancy such that 6 ft of distance can be maintained between individuals. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases school closures, allowing higher-education institutions to reopen, schools K-12 remain closed for instruction. High school sporting activities can begin June 30, constituting further easing. On 20200813, ends state-coordinated school closures: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-175.pdf

Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 100 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 100 people. Gathering restriction for outdoor gatherings is 250 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Quarantine advisory of 14 days for all individuals traveling from states with significant community spread of COVID-19, as operationalized by a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents or a 10 pct or higher positivity rate over a 7-day rolling average. While New York and Connecticut issued formal EOs for the quarantine, New Jersey never had a formal issuance - currently coding as an advisory. Initial list of states are: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah and Washington. By 20200630, list is 16 states. Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah. Washington state is no longer on the list https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey. By 20200707 list is 19 states: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey On 20200714, added Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, Wisconsin: https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey On 20200721 the list includes 31 states, expands to include Alaska, Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Virginia and Washington. Minnesota was removed from the list. https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/travel-information/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey On 20200728 the list was expanded to include District of Columbia, Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Nebraska, Puerto Rico. Expands mask requirement, requiring all customers to wears or cloth face coverings in all retail establishments, all of which may now re-open to the public (indoor and outdoor), restaurants (which are re-opened for indoor services on 20200702, already open for outdoor), and recreational and entertainment businesses when in the indoor portions of premises or distancing is not possible (such venues are health clubs, gyms, movie theaters). Coded as Mandate2 as this mandate now applies to broader set of indoor settings, inclusive of transportation services.

Further eases bar restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. quote (Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements such as patrons may only consume food or beverages while seated).

Further eases restaurant restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. (quote) Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements (quote)

Further eases bar restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. (quote) Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements such as patrons may only consume food or beverages while seated (quote)

Rescinds the easing of in-door restaurant dining that was to be implemented on July 2. (quote) Paragraph 5 of Executive Order No. 157 (2020), which allowed food or beverage establishments to offer in person service at indoor areas effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, is hereby rescinded. (quote) In-person services for outdoors only remain permitted. Extended to 20200926. Eased on 20200904: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-183.pdf
Limits outdoor gathering restrictions to no more than 500 people may gather in one location, physical distancing rules are adhered to, etc. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Expands mask requirement, mandating that (quote) when it is not practicable for individuals in outdoor spaces to socially distance and keep a six-foot distance from others...all individuals shall wear face coverings (quote). Previous orders focused on indoor spaces or confined areas, or specified gatherings. Clearly details that individuals must wear face coverings in indoor settings that are accessible to members of the public (e.g., retail, recreational and entertainment businsesses), government buildings open to the public, and mass transit buses, trains, and stations. Coded as a Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings broadly. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf On 20210519, Eases public mask restrictions by no longer requiring their use at outdoor religious or political gatherings, such as a protest. Also clarifies that masks are only required at outdoor gatherings when 6 ft of distance is difficult to maintain (quote) in accordance with CDC recommendations (quote). Continues to require the use of face coverings in all indoor settings that are accessible to members of the public (e.g., retail, recreational and entertainment businsesses), government buildings open to the public, and mass transit buses, trains, and stations. Coded as a Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings broadly. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf

Expands indoor gathering restrictions to no more than 25 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. This does not apply to indoor religious gatherings, which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 100 people. Extends gathering restriction of up to 250 people outdoors. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

As preK-12 schools reopen, includes the mandatory use of face coverings by staff, students, and visitors except for individuals who are under 2 years old, are not medically able, when eating or drinking, etc. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf. Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to re-open for indoor services up to 25 pct capacity, require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, seated service only, required mask use, etc.

Eases indoor gathering restrictions for religious indoor gatherings which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 150 people. Any other indoor meeting shall not exceed exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings. All attendees at an indoor gathering must wear face coverings at all times.

Eases restrictions on indoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues, which are allowed to reopen at 25 pct capacity on September 4, 2020. Extended to 20201222: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-200.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Eased on 20210205, now allowing venues of this kind to operate at 35 pct of the stated maximum capacity ttps://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-219.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf On 20210402, eases restrictions on outdoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues, which are now allowed to operate at up to 200 people (from 150). Indoor entertainment centers are still limited to 35 pct capacity, up to 150 people. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-234.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf On 20210507, eases restrictions on outdoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues, now allowing them to operate at up to 500 people as long as six feet of distance between individuals remains possible. Indoor entertainment centers are still limited to 35 pct capacity, up to 150 people. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-238.pdf On 20210519 Eases restrictions for indoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues. Percentage-based capacity restrictions have been lifted and these venues may now operate with up to 250 (up from 150) patrons per room. Restrictions for outdoor entertainment centers are also eased, no longer limiting capacity by a numerical cap but rather by the requirement to maintain 6 ft of distance between groups or patrons. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210528, Eases restrictions for indoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues. These venues are no longer required to limit occupancy such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between groups or individuals, neither indoors nor outdoors. However, continues to limit indoor occupancy to 250 individuals per room. On 20210604, Ends final restrictions on indoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues. These venues that host private catered events are no longer required to limit indoor capacity to 250 attendees. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants, which are now allowed to offer in person service at indoor areas effective at 6:00 a.m. on September 4, 2020 subject to requirements, including 25 pct capacity. Extended to 20201123.

Extends eased restrictions for bars (25 pct capacity indoors, at least 6 ft distancing between tables, no seating at bar areas), but now requires bars to close from 10 pm to 5 am for in-person services. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf.

Extends restrictions for restaurants. Adds restrictions including prohibiting seating at bar areas and requiring restaurants to close from 10 pm to 5am.
