PolicyCodingNotes: Expands indoor gathering restrictions to no more than 10 people given any size of the room. This does not apply to indoor religious gatherings, which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 150 people. Extends gathering restriction of up to 500 people outdoors. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Expands outdoor gathering restrictions to no more than 150 people. This does not apply to indoor gatherings, which should not exceed 10 people. Extends indoor religious gathering restriction of up to 150 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.
New Jersey strongly discourages all non-essential interstate travel at this time.

Expands restrictions for outdoor gatherings, which are now limited to 25 people. Continues prior gathering restrictions: indoor social gatherings of no more than 10 people, religious gatherings indoors are limited to 25 pct capacity, up to 150 people, and outdoor religious gatherings remain not having any explicit capacity limit beyond maintaining 6 ft of distancing. Prohibits sporting activities more broadly in indoor settings. Extended to 20210120 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-210.pdf. Extended to 20210218: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-215.pdf. Eased indoor gathering restrictions for religious services or celebrations, political activities, wedding ceremonies, funerals, or memorial services, which are now limited to (quote) 35 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be larger than 150 persons or smaller than 10 persons (quote). Gathering restrictions in other contexts unchanged. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-219.pdf. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf. On 20210222, further aased indoor gathering restrictions for religious services or celebrations, political activities, wedding ceremonies, funerals, or memorial services, which are now limited to (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be larger than 150 persons or smaller than 10 persons (quote). Gathering restrictions in other contexts unchanged. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-225.pdf. Further eased on 20210305 to allow up to 35 pct capacity for wedding receptions, not including venue staff, and such that the limit is no smaller than 10 persons and no larger than 150 persons: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-228.pdf.

Eases restrictions for bars, now allowing 35 pct capacity indoors and ending curfew requirements for in-person services. Continues to require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, no seating at bar areas, and limit to parties of 8 or less. Now allowed to operate within the hours of 10pm and 5am unless otherwise restricted by municipal or county ordinance. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf. Eased to 50 pct capacity on 20210319: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-230.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf On 20210507, restrictions for bars are eased in four ways. First, bars who host outdoor, catered events, now allowing events with up to 500 attendees, as long as six feet of distance between individuals remains possible. For indoor catered events, bars may operate at (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be smaller than 25 persons or larger than 250 persons, excluding the venue’s staff (quote). Second, dance floors may open indoors and outdoors for private, catered events, provided that all participants wear face coverings and remain (quote) six feet apart from the other attendees at all times, excluding immediate family members, caretakers, household members, or romantic partners, as well as excluding individuals organizing or maintaining the gathering (quote). Third, bars may open indoor bar areas for seated-only service. Fourth, bars may open self-service food areas, such as buffets or salad bars. For all other operations which are not private, catered events, bars and like venues must continue to limit indoor capacity to 50 pct, to require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, and limit to parties of 8 or less. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-238.pdf On 20210519, further eases restrictions for bars. First, restaurants no longer must limit their capacity by percentage, but rather must limit capacity such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between tables. Second, individuals at indoor bar areas may be seated closer than 6 ft to each other if they arrived in the same party, but groups must be 6 ft apart from one another. If 6 ft of distrance is not possible between bar groups or tables, restaurants must erect barriers between them pursuant to DOH policy. Third, for bars that host private catered events, capacity must be limited indoors to 250 attendees (removing the percentage-based capacity restriction) and outdoors to a number that ensures 6 ft of distance between individuals or groups (removing the 500 person cap). https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf. On 20210528 Eases restrictions on bars, no longer them to limit their capacity such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between tables. Also now allows un-seated service, opens dance floors, and no longer requires tables be seated 6 ft apart. Continues to require that bars that host private catered events limit indoor capacity to 250 attendees, but no longer requires them to maintain 6 ft of distance between guests either indoors or outdoors. On 20210604, Ends final restrictions on bars, no longer requiring bars that host private catered events limit indoor capacity to 250 attendees. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases restrictions for restaurants and like venues, now allowing 35 pct capacity indoors and ending curfew requirements for in-person services. Continues to require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, no seating at bar areas, and limit to parties of 8 or less. Now allowed to operate within the hours of 10pm and 5am unless otherwise restricted by municipal or county ordinance. Extended to 20210319 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-222.pdf. Eased to 50 pct capacity on 20210319: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-230.pdf Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf Eases restrictions for restaurants in four ways. First, restaurants who host outdoor, catered events, now allowing events with up to 500 attendees, as long as six feet of distance between individuals remains possible. For indoor catered events, restaurants may operate at (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be smaller than 25 persons or larger than 250 persons, excluding the venue’s staff (quote). Second, dance floors may open indoors and outdoors for private, catered events, provided that all participants wear face coverings and remain (quote) six feet apart from the other attendees at all times, excluding immediate family members, caretakers, household members, or romantic partners, as well as excluding individuals organizing or maintaining the gathering (quote). Third, restaurants may open indoor bar areas for seated-only service. Fourth, restaurants may open self-service food areas, such as buffets or salad bars. For all other operations which are not private, catered events, restaurants and like venues must continue to limit indoor capacity to 50 pct, to require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, and limit to parties of 8 or less. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-238.pdf On 20210519, further eases restrictions for restaurants. First, restaurants no longer must limit their capacity by percentage, but rather must limit capacity such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between tables. Second, individuals at indoor bar areas may be seated closer than 6 ft to each other if they arrived in the same party, but groups must be 6 ft apart from one another. If 6 ft of distrance is not possible between bar groups or tables, restaurants must erect barriers between them pursuant to DOH policy. Third, for restaurants that host private catered events, capacity must be limited indoors to 250 attendees (removing the percentage-based capacity restriction) and outdoors to a number that ensures 6 ft of distance between individuals or groups (removing the 500 person cap). https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf. On 20210528 Eases restrictions on restaurants, no longer them to limit their capacity such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between tables. Also now allows un-seated service, opens dance floors, and no longer requires tables be seated 6 ft apart. Continues to require that restaurants that host private catered events limit indoor capacity to 250 attendees, but no longer requires them to maintain 6 ft of distance between guests either indoors or outdoors. On 20210604, Ends final restrictions on restaurants, no longer requiring restaurants that host private catered events limit indoor capacity to 250 attendees. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases restrictions on large entertainment venues, specifically (quote) sports and entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums, with fixed seating capacity of 5,000 or greater (quote). These venues may now allow up to 10 pct capacity indoors and 15 pct capacity outdoors, as long as attendees wear masks and are seated six feet away from individuals outside their party. Extended on 20210317, https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf. Eased on 20210402, first by redefining large venues as (quote) sports and entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums, with fixed seating capacity of 2,500 or greater (quote), down from 5,000. Second, these venues may now allow up to 20 pct capacity indoors (up from 10) and 30 pct capacity outdoors (up from 15), as long as attendees wear masks and are seated six feet away from individuals outside their party. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-234.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf On 20210507, eases restrictions for large entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums, with fixed seating capacity of 1,000 or greater, to operate up to (quote) 50 percent of the stated maximum capacity of any outdoor area where such event is held (quote), as long as attendees wear masks and are seated six feet away from individuals outside their party. Continues to allow large venues with fixed seating capacity of 2,500 or greater to allow up to 20 pct capacity indoors and 30 pct capacity outdoors, as long as attendees wear masks and are seated six feet away from individuals outside their party. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-238.pdf On 20210519 eases restrictions for large entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums, first by combining restrictions for venues with fixed seating capacity of 1,000 or greater and venues with fixed seating capacity of 2,500 or greater (these differently-sized venues previously had unique indoor and outdoor capacity restrictions). Now, these venues may operate indoors at 30 pct capacity (up from 20) and may operate outdoors with no percentage-based capacity limits. Outdoor capacity for these venues is now limited only by the requirement to maintain 6 ft of distance between individuals or groups. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-239.pdf Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210528, Eases restrictions for large entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums with fixed seating capacity of 1,000 or greater. These venues are no longer required to limit occupancy such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between groups or individuals, neither indoors nor outdoors. However, continues to limit indoor occupancy to 30 pct capacity. On 20210604, Ends final restrictions for large entertainment venues, including concert venues and stadiums with fixed seating capacity of 1,000 or greater. These venues are no longer required to limit indoor occupancy to 30 pct capacity. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases indoor gathering limits to 25 (from 10) and outdoor gathering limits to 50 (from 25). Religious services or celebrations, political activities, and wedding ceremonies, funerals, or memorial services that (quote) involve religious services (quote) are limited to (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be larger than 150 persons or smaller than 25 persons (quote). Indoor gathering restrictions for wedding receptions, addiction support groups, and other types of ceremonies that do not involve religious services are limited to 35 pct capacity such that the limit is no smaller than 25 persons or larger than 150 persons. Venue staff are not included in the capacity limit. Extended to 20210416 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-231.pdf

Eases outdoor gathering restrictions, now limiting attendees to 200 (from 50). Indoor gatherings continue to be limited to 25. Religious services or celebrations, political activities, and wedding ceremonies, funerals, or memorial services that (quote) involve religious services (quote) are limited to (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be larger than 150 persons or smaller than 25 persons (quote). Indoor gathering restrictions for wedding receptions, addiction support groups, and other types of ceremonies that do not involve religious services are limited to 35 pct capacity such that the limit is no smaller than 25 persons or larger than 150 persons. Venue staff are not included in the capacity limit. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-234.pdf Extended to 20210515 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-235.pdf

On 20210428, Adds an exemption to the quarantine advisory for those who are fully vaccinated and for those who have recovered from COVID within the last three months. Otherwise, extends the following: Travelers and residents returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond the immediate region (New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and Delaware) should self-quarantine at their home, hotel, or other temporary lodging for 10 days, or 7 days with a negative test result. . On 20210517, Governor Murphy announces an end to the interstate travel quarantine advisory for both vaccinated and unvaccinated travelers. Travelers are now advised to follow the latest CDC recommendations regarding quarantining and testing following interstate travel. So coded as Ended. https://nj.gov/governor/news/news/562021/approved/20210517b.shtml

Eases outdoor gathering restrictions, limiting attendees to 500 (up from 200). Indoor gatherings continue to be limited to 25. Additionally, it combines religious gatherings with non-religious gatherings under the same group of restrictions (previously, religious gatherings had less-restrictive capacity caps than non-religious gatherings) and eases those restrictions in two ways. Now, a gathering which is a (quote) religious service or celebration, political activity, wedding ceremony, funeral, memorial service, meeting of an addiction support group, legislative proceeding of State, county, or local government, including local Boards of Education, or State or local judicial proceeding (quote) may take place with 1) no numerical limits to participants outdoors and 2) indoors attendees must be limited to (quote) 50 percent of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, but regardless of the capacity of the room, such limit shall never be larger than 250 persons or smaller than 25 persons, excluding staff of the gathering venue (quote), provided these gatherings continue to require six feet of distance between parties and the use of face coverings. This eases restrictions for religious and non-religious gatherings by raising the indoor cap from 150 to 250 and by raising the indoor capacity for non-religious gatherings from 35 pct to 50 pct.

Eases restrictions on gatherings in five ways. First, private indoor gatherings are now limited to 50 attendees (up from 25). Second, it removes the percentage-based capacity limit on religious gatherings, now capacity for these gatherings are limited only by the requirement to maintain 6 ft of distance between individuals or groups. Third, non-religious gatherings, which include political activities, wedding ceremonies, funerals, memorial services, are now limited only by a 250 person cap, removing its percentage-based capacity restriction. Fourth, legislative proceedings of State, county, or local government, may now take place with no capacity limits, provided these gatherings continue to require six feet of distance between parties and the use of face coverings.  Fifth, the capacity restrictions on outdoor gatherings are lifted entirely, provided attendees maintain 6 ft of physical distance from individuals outside their household and wear masks when that distance is not possible (this restriction does not apply to religious services or political activities, such as a protest). Extended to 20210613 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-240.pdf On 20210528, Eases restrictions on all indoor and outdoor gatherings, no longer limiting attendance such that 6 ft of distance is maintained between individuals or groups. Continues to limit occupany for private indoor gatherings to 50 attendees and to limit other indoor gatherings, like political activities, wedding ceremonies, funerals, and memorial services, to 250 attendees. Unvaccinated individuals are encouraged to continue to social distance, but this is not required. On 20210604, Ends restrictions on all indoor and outdoor gatherings, no longer limiting private indoor gatherings to 50 attendees nor other indoor gatherings, like political activities, wedding ceremonies, funerals, and memorial services, to 250 attendees. Unvaccinated individuals are encouraged to continue to social distance, but this is not required. https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-242.pdf

Eases mask requirements, no longer requiring their in most outdoor settings, regardless of social distance or vaccination status. Masks must continue to be worn in some outdoor settings, like healthcare settings, schools, and congregate settings like long term care facilities. Individuals at indoor private gatherings of 50 people or less are also no longer required to wear a face covering, regardless of social distancing or vaccination status. Continues to require the use of face coverings in all other public indoor settings  (e.g., retail, recreational and entertainment businsesses), government buildings open to the public, and mass transit buses, trains, and stations. Coded as a Mandate2 as it applies to indoor settings broadly and outdoor settings narrowly. Expires on 20210704.

Extends business mask requirements, but now exempts fully vaccinated employees from the requirement to wear masks when working in indoor public spaces. For those who do not work in spaces open to the public, all individuals must continue to wear masks, except when working at individual work stations or when 6 ft of distance is maintained. Businesses may choose, however, to impose stricter face covering requirements for employees and guests. Indoor public spaces, as defined by Executive Order 241, include but are not limited to (quote) retail, recreational, and entertainment businesses, food or beverage establishments, and casinos (quote). This definition is clarified in this Order as exclusive of 1) indoor worksites of employers (quote) that do not open their indoor spaces to the public for purposes of sale of goods, attendance at an event or activity, or provision of services (quote) and also of 2) (quote) child care centers, other child care facilities, youth summer camps, and public, private, and parochial preschool program premises and elementary and secondary schools, including charter and renaissance schools (quote). Masks also continue to be required at public facing state offices, like the department of motor vehicles. Extended to 20210704 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-244.pdf . Expires on 20210704.

Extends mask requirements, now exempting fully vaccinated individuals from wearing masks in most indoor spaces. Continues to permit individuals to unmask in most outdoor settings, regardless of social distance or vaccination status. Continues to require the use of face coverings for all individuals, regardless of vaccination status, in some public indoor and outdoor settings (per CDC recommendations) like healthcare settings, schools, public transportation, and congregate settings like long term care facilities. Also extends eased restrictions on indoor private gatherings of 50 people or less, where individuals are no longer required to wear a face covering, regardless of social distancing or vaccination status. Coded as a Mandate2 as it applies to indoor settings broadly and outdoor settings narrowly. Extended to 20210704 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-244.pdf . Expires on 20210704

Extends restrictions on businesses with indoor work sites that are not open to the public, including non-essential construction projects, but provides an exemption for employees who demonstrate they are vaccinated. Employees that are not vaccinated and work in these spaces must continue to wear masks and maintain six feet of distance from others to the maximum extent possible. Also clarifies that these businesses may allow (quote) customers, visitors, and other authorized individuals to enter the worksite without requiring use of a mask or adherence to social distancing, regardless of their vaccination status. (quote) Indoor public spaces, as defined by Executive Order 241, include but are not limited to (quote) retail, recreational, and entertainment businesses, food or beverage establishments, and casinos (quote). This definition is clarified in Order 242 as exclusive of 1) indoor worksites of employers (quote) that do not open their indoor spaces to the public for purposes of sale of goods, attendance at an event or activity, or provision of services (quote) and also of 2) (quote) child care centers, other child care facilities, youth summer camps, and public, private, and parochial preschool program premises and elementary and secondary schools, including charter and renaissance schools (quote). Extended to 20210704 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-244.pdf. Expires on 20200704.

Both vaccinated and unvaccinated people are recommended to wear masks in indoor settings in which there is high risk. (Quote) Governor Phil Murphy and New Jersey Department of Health Commissioner Judy Persichilli today strongly recommended that both vaccinated and unvaccinated residents wear masks in indoor settings when there is increased risk. Examples of such situations include: Crowded indoor settings; Indoor settings involving activities with close contact with others who may not be fully vaccinated; Indoor settings where the vaccine status of other individuals in the setting is unknown; Where an individual is immunocompromised or at increased risk for severe disease (quote) https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/announcements/all-announcements/governor-murphy-and-commissioner-persichilli-strongly-recommend-masking-in-indoor-settings-with-increased-risk

Limited operations required (take-out or home delivery only): bars. No in-door service operations are allowed. In effect for as long as EO 2020-004, which is 20200410. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/UPDATED-DOH-PHO-03-19-2020-r.pdf Extended to 20200919: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PHO-August-28.pdf Extended to 20201003 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf. Red to Green substate framework is enacted as of 20201202. All counties are still required to close bars except for take-out or delivery. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210114 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/121520-PHO_mass-gatherings.pdf. In these counties, bars are allowed to operate at 33 pct indoor capacity and 75 pct outdoor capacity. All other applicable food and drink establishment rules also apply, such as maintaining 6 ft of distance between tables, must be seated to order food and drink to be consumed on the premises, no more than 6 people per table, no bar or counter seating, delivery and take out allowed. Restrictions are also eased in Green level counties, where bars may now operate at up to 25 pct maximum capacity outdoors. Shall remain in effect until the end of the public health emergency. Quarantine of 14 days for anyone entering the state. Extended to 20200630: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Executive-Order-2020-054.pdf Extended to 20200918: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/EO-2020-059.pdf. Extends to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Executive-Order-2020-072-1.pdf On 20201014, applies to the following high-risk states: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia, Wisconsin, Wyoming https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/ On 20201021 removes California, District of Columbia and Washington https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. On 20201028 adds California, District of Columbia, and Washington https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. On 20201104, adds New Hampshire and New York https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. On 20201110, adds Maine and Hawaii https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/ Extended to 20201211: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-2020-080.pdf. On 20201119, adds Vermont https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Restrictions extended on 20201125 https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Restrictions extended on 20201202: https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Restrictions extended on 20201209 to 20210108: https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Extended on 20201216 https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Extended on 20201230: https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Extended on 20210106: https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Extended to 20210205 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Executive-Order-2021-001.pdf Removes Hawaii from the list on 20210202 https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. Extends quarantine restriction under Emergency Declaration to 20210305 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Executive-Order-2021-004.pdf. List of states updated on 20210209, still includes all states besides Hawaii. https://cv.nmhealth.org/travel-recommendations/. On 20210210 quarantine mandate for individuals arriving from another state or from outside the United States is ended. Travelers are now recommended to (quote) self-isolate or self-quarantine fo ra period of at last 14 days from the date of their entry into the State of New Meico or for the duration of their presence in the State, whichever is shorter (quote) and to be (quote) tested for COVID-19 as promptly as possible following their arrival to New Mexico (quote). No expiry provided and will remain in effect until it is rescinded. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Executive-Order-2021-006.pdf.

Hotels, motels, RV parks, and other places of lodging shall not operate at more than 25 pct capacity of maximum occupancy. Prior orders required up to 50 pct capacity operations, but at present that threshold is above what triggers including a tracked policy in this dataset. Easing began on 20200601, when capacity limits permitted up to 50 pct capacity: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/060120-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

(quote) Golf courses may open on a modified basis. They may be open for golf only and shall not provide any dine-in or retail services. they shall minimize staff and operations the greatest extent possible and follow all sanitation and social distancing protocols (quote). Applies to all counties except for Cibola County, McKinley County, and San Juan County. Starting on 20200515, permitted to reopen for all services including indoor services

Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate to the minimum extent necessary to provide curbside pickup and/or delivery to customers. Coding as a an eased business closure to TakeawayOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel. On 20200516, Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed areas, https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/051520-PHO.pdf

Beginning May 6, all essential businesses that operate as a retail space that have a footprint greater than 50,000 or are operating a restaurant must wear face coverings or masks. Beginning May 11, all essential businesses operating a retail space shall require employees to wear facing coverings, irrespective of size. Also still applies to restuarants. Expanded on 20200630 to such that retail businesses now can refuse entry of patrons who are not wearing a mask or multilayer face cloth unless they have a written exemption from a health provider. Also requires employees to wear facing coverings. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/063020-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf. Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed areas. They must comply with COVID-19 safe practices and must take reasonable mesaures to ensure that customers maintain a distance of at least 6 ft. Only applicable to counties that are not Cibola, McKinley, San Juan

All individuals shall wear a mask or multilayer cloth face covering in public settings except when eating, drinking, or exercising. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to public settings (and not does specify indoor versus outdoor settings). On 20210430, begins to now allowing all individuals to gather unmasked when (quote) attending a small, outdoor gathering of fully vaccinated individuals no larger than the applicable mass gathering limit for the county or twenty (20) individuals, whichever is less. (quote) Alternatively, (quote) fully vaccinated individuals are not required to wear a mask when attending small, outdoor gatherings of vaccinated or unvaccinated individuals no larger than the applicable mass gathering limit for the county or twenty (20) individuals, whichever is less (quote). Also allows all individuals to exercise unmasked when outdoors alone or with members of their household. Continues to require all individuals shall wear a mask or multilayer cloth face covering in public settings except when eating, drinking, or exercising. Continues to be coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to public settings, indoors and outdoors, apart from small, private, outdoor gatherings. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/NCOV-PHO-Amendment-20210428.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants, allowing them to have dine-services in outdoor seating areas up to 50 percent capacity. No indoor dine-in services permitted. Applicable to all NM counties except for Cibola, McKinley, and San Juan Counties. Note that breweries, wineries, and distilleries are being grouped with restaurants and separate from bars in PHOs, but remain limited to take-away only. https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DOH-PHO-5-27.pdf

Statewide, outdoor tennis facilities may open for outdoor use only and provided they operate in accordance with relevant health and safety protocols. State parks may be open for day use only, with all indoor enclosed areas closed to the public. Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

Statewide, retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed area. In addition, gyms and fitness centers and public swimming pools (can operate up to 50 percent occupancy). Indoor shopping malls (permitting maximum of 25 pct occupancy), close contact personal services like hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, spas, massage parlors (permitting a maximum of 25 pct capacity). On 20200713, capacity limits were decreased to up to 25 pct for gyms and fitness centers, coding as a re-expansion: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/7.13.20-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions in all counties, allowing statewide eased restrictions for restaurants to provide dine-in services if they comply with the COVID-19 safe practices for restaurants and operate at no more than 50 percent capacity. Note that breweries, wineries, and distilleries are being grouped with restaurants and separate from bars in PHOs, and remain limited to only take-away. On 20200612, eases restrictions on breweries and like venues, allowing breweries to re-open for dine-in services up to 50 pct of capacity. Wineries and distilleries are still closed on-site consumption. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/063020-PHO-1.pdf

Guidance on re-opening schools for in-person instruction. Expands restrictions on restaurants and like venues, requiring them to close dine-in services in indoor areas. Outdoor dine-in service may only be provided up to 50 pct capacity. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, while local wineries and distilleries must remain closed for in-person operations (they are treated separately from bars in these orders). https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/7.13.20-PHO-1.pdf. Eased on 20200730, now also includes wineries and distilleries (they were previously closed for all in-person operations), permitting them to re-open for outdoor services. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/07.30.20-PHO.pdf

Public schools will not reopen for in-person instruction until at least after labor day https://www.newmexico.gov/2020/07/24/state-updates-school-reopening-guidance-hits-pause-on-hybrid-model-for-start-of-school-year/ Extended to 20200919: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PHO-August-28.pdf Extended to 20201003 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf On 20200908, 25 counties met gating criteria for in-person K-12 school instruction and thus school districts in those counties could re-open to a hybrid model https://www.newmexico.gov/2020/09/03/schools-in-25-counties-may-launch-hybrid-model-sept-8/ Extended restrictions to private schools to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/120220-PHO.pdf

Eases previous gathering restrictions, limiting gatherings to no more than 10 people indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings, and permits houses of worship to have up to 40 pct occupancy (which is easing from the prior restrictions, up to 25 pct occupancy) Extended to 20201003 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf

Eases previous restrictions, permitting up to 25 pct occupancy for enclosed spaces at restaurants and like venues. Outdoors dine-in service is permitted with no explicit occupancy limits. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, wineries and distilleries. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PHO-August-28.pdf. On 20200904, somewhat expands restrictions on restaurants and like venues, requiring up to 75 pct occupancy in outdoor dine-in areas. Extends previous indoor restrictions, permitting up 25 pct occupancy for enclosed spaces at restaurants and like venues. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, wineries and distilleries. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf As of 20201030, indoor dining at food and drink establishments is prohibited unless that establishment completes the New Mexico Safe Certification training program. If they do, food and drink establishments may continue to offer limited indoor dining at a maximum of 25 pct occupancy. If an establishement does not complete the training, it can operate at 75 pct outdoors. https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/102220-PHO.pdf

Chaves, Eddy, Hidalgo, Lea, Luna, Roosevelt, and Quay counties are designated in the red color, Dona Ana in orange, and McKinley and Curry in yellow, and thus school districts in those counties are not eligible to re-open for in-person instruction. On 20200918, McKinley, Hidalgo, Dona Ana and Curry counties have moved into the green zone, they are hence cleared to begin a hybrid mode of learning that allows students from pre-K through fifth grade to come to school two days a week wearing face masks and staying at least 6 feet away from others (quote), with a maximum occupancy of 25 pct for any enclosed place. Coding as easing for this dataset: https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/news-releases/ Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/120220-PHO.pdf

Expands gathering restriction, prohibiting gatherings of 5 or more people indoors and outdoors, excludes religious gatherings which only need to adhere to 40 pct capacity rule. Extends to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

As of 20201030, indoor dining at food and drink establishments is prohibited unless that establishment completes the New Mexico Safe Certification training program. If they do, food and drink establishments may continue to offer limited indoor dining at a maximum of 25 pct occupancy. If an establishment does not complete the training, it can operate at 75 pct outdoors. Extends to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

Somewhat expands gathering restriction, prohibting gatherings of 5 or more people indoors and outdoors, and reduces capacity limits of houses of worship to the lesser of 25 pct or up to 75 people at a time. Extended to 20201202, after which state went to county color-coded framework: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf

Effective 20201202, close-contact businesses (e.g., barbershops, hair salons, group fitness classes, tattoo parlors, nail salons, spas, massage therapy services, esthetician clinics, tanning salons, guided raft tours, guided balloon tours, bowling alleys, ice skating rinks, and personal training services) in red and yellow counties may open for in-person services up to 25pct capacity. Places of lodging may open to 40 pct occupancy in red counties if they have completed NM Safe Certified training and 60 pct in yellow counties if they have completed NM Safe Certified training. All other businesses (e.g., non-essential retail) can operate up to 25 pct of maximum capacity (or 75 customers at one time for red counties and 125 customers at one time for yellow counties), whichever is smaller. San Miguel moves to Red Level (Very High Risk), making gathering restrictions statewide. Counties can have gathering restrictions of no more than 5 people indoors and outdoors, and no more than 10 vehicles. For houses of worship, no more than 25 pct capacity but no explicit limits provided.

San Miguel moves to Red Level (Very High Risk), making restaurant restrictions statewide. Restaurants are prohibited from having indoor dining. Allowed to have 25 pct capacity outdoor. All establishments selling alcohol must close by 9 pm and cannot reopen until 4am.

No in-person learning will be permitted during the weeks of January 4 and January 11, 2021, except for small groups of pre-K to third-grade students and students with disabilities. Schools previously operating in the hybrid model may return to their hybrid schedules the week of January 18, 2021. This order is statewide. Eased to allow a hybrid model on 20210126: https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/news-releases/. Ended on 20210405: https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/news-releases/

It is advised that travelers entering New Mexico (quote) self-isolate or self-quarantine for a period of at last 14 days from the date of their entry into the State of New Meico or for the duration of their presence in the State, whichever is shorter (quote) and to be (quote) tested for COVID-19 as promptly as possible following their arrival to New Mexico (quote). No expiry provided and will remain in effect until it is rescinded.

Eases business mask requirements detailed in the PHO, no longer stating that retail businesses must refuse entry of patrons who are not wearing a mask or multilayer face cloth unless they have a written exemption from a health provider. Now directs that businesses must follow the latest guidance from the CDC regarding masks, which recommends employees wear facing coverings while working but also states that fully vaccinated individuals no longer must wear masks in any indoor or outdoor setting, so coding as VaccineExempt as 1. Extended to 20210701 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/060221-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210731 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210816: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/NCOV-EO-2021-044.pdf. Extended to 20210828: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/NCOV-PHO-20210730.pdf. Eased on 20210730.

Extends public mask mandate, now directing that individuals follow the latest guidance from the CDC regarding masks, which no longer recommends them for fully vaccinated individuals in any indoor or outdoor setting, so coding as VaccineExempt as 1. Continues to require all individuals shall wear a mask or multilayer cloth face covering in public settings except when eating, drinking, or exercising. Continues to allow all individuals to gather unmasked when (quote) attending a small, outdoor gathering of fully vaccinated individuals no larger than the applicable mass gathering limit for the county or twenty (20) individuals, whichever is less. (quote) Alternatively, (quote) fully vaccinated individuals are not required to wear a mask when attending small, outdoor gatherings of vaccinated or unvaccinated individuals no larger than the applicable mass gathering limit for the county or twenty (20) individuals, whichever is less (quote). Continues to be coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to public settings, indoors and outdoors, apart from small, private, outdoor gatherings. Extended to 20210701 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/060221-PHO.pdf. Amended and extended to 20210731 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210816: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/NCOV-EO-2021-044.pdf.   Eased on 20210730.

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, bars are allowed to operate at 33 pct indoor capacity and 75 pct outdoor capacity. All other applicable food and drink establishment rules also apply, such as maintaining 6 ft of distance between tables, must be seated to order food and drink to be consumed on the premises, no more than 6 people per table, no bar or counter seating, delivery and take out allowed. Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, houses of worship may operate at 100 pct capacity both outdoors and indoors. Mass gatherings continue to be limited to 150 people.  Ended and replaced with a recommendation on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, close-contact businesses (e.g., barbershops, hair salons, group fitness classes, tattoo parlors, nail salons, spas, massage therapy services, esthetician clinics, tanning salons, guided raft tours, guided balloon tours, bowling alleys, ice skating rinks, and personal training services) can open up to 75 pct maximum indoor capacity, with no restrictions on outdoor spaces. Places of lodging may operate at 100 pct occupancy for those who complete NM Safe Certified training, and up to 50 pct occupancy for all others. 15 guests maximum for vacation rentals. All other businesses (e.g., non-essential retail) can operate up to 75 pct of maximum capacity. Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, outdoor recreational facilities (outdoor golf courses, public swimming pools, ski basins, youth programs, youth livestock shows, horseracing tracks, botanical gardens, and outdoor zoos) can operate at a maximum of 75 pct capacity. Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, clubs, including adult entertainment venues, nightclubs, and dance clubs may operate at 33 pct indoor capacity if completed NM Safe Certified training, and 75 pct outdoor capacity, regardless of training status.  Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, close-contact recreational facilities, which are now recategorized as large entertainment venues (indoor movie theaters, indoor museums with interactive displays or exhibits and other similar venues, miniature golf, arcades, amusement parks, aquariums, casinos, concert venues, professional sports venues, event venues, performance venues, go-kart courses, automobile racetracks), defined separately from adult entertainment venues and clubs, may operate at 50 pct indoor capacity. Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Beginning 20210602, all counties, regardless of their transmission risk level, are entitled to operate at the Turquoise level. Policy chain now coded as StateWide and no longer tracking county transmission levels. At the Turquoise level, restaurants may operate at 75 pct indoors if they have completed NM Safe Certified training and must comply with contact tracing and testing requirements. 75 pct outdoor capacity allowed for all establishments, regardless of NM Safe Certification. In all instances, establishments must maintain 6 ft of distance between tables, customers must be seated to order food and drink to be consumed on the premises, no more than 6 people per table, no bar or counter seating, delivery and take out allowed. Ended on 20210701 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/063021-PHO.pdf

Eases mask guidance, mandating only that New Mexicans follow the CDC mandates on mask wearing, and recommending New Mexicans follow CDC recommendations. Eases mask guidance, mandating only that New Mexicans follow the CDC mandates on mask wearing, and recommending New Mexicans follow CDC recommendations. Current CDC mandates only require masking on public transit, airports, and in federal buildings. Coded as Mandate1 due to the narrow range of circumstances in which masks are mandated.

For regions moving to Phase Two, restrictions are eased on the following to permit in-person services: professional services, administrative support, information technology, real estate services (including building and property management, leasing, rental and sales services), barbershops and hair salons (limited services), motor vehicle leasing, rental, and sales. As of 20200529, Phase Two regions are: Finger Lakes, Central New York, Mohawk Valley, Southern Tier, and the North Country. New York City moves to Phase Two, easing restrictions to allow for the following businesses to be re-opened statewide: professional services, administrative support, information technology, real estate services (including building and property management, leasing, rental and sales services), barbershops and hair salons (limited services), motor vehicle leasing, rental, and sales. Limited operations include no more than 50 pct capacity for these businesses: https://forward.ny.gov/phase-two-industries Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

New York City moves to Phase Two, easing restrictions to allow for in-person retail up to 50 pct. Now a statewide policy. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

(quote) All travelers entering New York from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10 pct test positivity rate, over a seven day rolling average, will be required to quarantine for a period of 14 days consistent with Department of Health regulations for quarantine (quote). On 20200630, expands states under the quarantine order, adding California, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada and Tennessee to the required quaratine list (originally, Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah). Full list is now as follows: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah. On 20200707, Expands states under the quarantine order, adding Delaware, Kansas, and Oklahoma: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-three-additional-states-will-be On 20200714, expands states under the quarantine order, adding Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, and Wisconsin: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-four-additional-states-will-be-required. Adds 10 states under the quarantine order, adding Alaska, Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Nebraska, Virginia and Washington to the required travel quarantine of 14 days if arriving in New York from these states as points of origin. As of 20200721, this list includes the following: Alaska, Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maryland, Missouri, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washingon, Wisconsin: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-10-additional-states-will-be-required On 20200728, adds Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Puerto Rico, and District of Columbia to the quarantine order https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-three-additional-states-puerto-rico-and On 08/05 adds Rhode Island to the quarantine order, but removes DC and Delaware https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-additional-state-will-be-required On 20200811, quarantine order removes Alaska, New Mexico, Ohio, Rhode Island, and Washington but adds Hawaii, South Carolina, and the Virgin Islands https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-two-additional-states-virgin-islands On 20200818, added Alaska and Delaware: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-two-additional-states-added-travel-advisory On 20200825, added Guam and removed Arizona, Alaska, Delaware, Maryland and Montana https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-five-states-removed-covid-19-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day On 20200901 added Alaska and Montana to the list https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-two-states-added-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines On 20200908 removed Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands and added Delaware, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-four-states-added-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines On 20200915, removes California, Hawaii, Maryland, Minnesota, Nevada, and Ohio and adds Puerto Rico to the quarantine order: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-six-states-removed-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines. On 20200922, adds Arizona, Minnesota, Nevada, Rhode Island, and Wyoming to the quarantine order: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-five-states-added-travel-advisory-and-10-million-covid-19-diagnostic. On 20200928 expands quarantine order to travelers entering the United States from any country with a CDC Level 2 or Level 3 health notice: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_205.1.pdf. On 20200929 removes Arizona and Virginia and adds Colorado to the quarantine order: https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory. On 20201006 adds New Mexico to the quarantine order. governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-new-mexico-added-travel-advisory. On 20201013 adds Ohio, Michigan and Virginia to the travel quarantine requirement. https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-three-states-added-travel-advisory. On 20201020 adds Arizona and Maryland to the travel quarantine requirement https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantine. On 20201027 adds California to the travel quarantine requirement https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantine-0. Beginning 20201104, travel quarantine order is expanded, requiring (quote) All travelers entering New York from a state which is not a contiguous state shall quarantine for a period of 14 days consistent with Department of Health regulations for quarantine (quote). Exemptions are permitted travelers who travel outside of New York for less than 24 hours (but will still require a diagnostic test by the 4th day upon arrival). Further clarifies (quote) The traveler must, upon arrival in New York, quarantine according to Department of Health guidelines for a minimum of three days, measured from time of arrival and on day 4 may seek a diagnostic test to exit quarantine. The traveler may exit quarantine upon receipt of the second negative test result. (quote) https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO205.2.pdf. Extends expanded travel restrictions on 20201230 https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.87.pdf. On 20201230, modifies the travel quarantine order to require quarantine for travelers entering from (quote) a country or territory subject to a CDC Level 2 or higher COVID-19 Risk Assessment Level or for which the COVID-19 risk level is designated by the CDC as Unknown, unless such traveler has traveled for less than 24 hours, is deemed an essential worker, or obtains two negative COVID-19 diagnostic test results (quote) in addition to those entering from a state not contiguous with NY https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_205.3.pdf. On 20210303, exempts vaccinated individuals from quarantine requirements: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-event-arts-and-entertainment-venues-can-reopen-33-percent-capacity.

Eases restrictions for the following businesses for regions in Phase 4 (Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, North County, Southern Tier): low-risk outdoor arts and entertainment (e.g., outdoor zoos, botanical gardens, nature parks, grounds of historic sites and cultural institutions, outdoor museums, outdoor agritourism, local agricultural demonstrations and exhibitions, and other similar institutions/activities - must be limited to no more than 33 pct capacity/occupancy, physical distancing, mandated mask use), low-risk indoor arts and entertainment (e.g., indoor museums, historical sites, aquariums, and other related institutions or activities- must be limited to 25 pct capacity/occupancy, physical distancing, mandated mask use), media and production (i.e., all activities undertaken in motion picture, music, television, and streaming productions on set, on location, or at any production or recording site - must be at no more than 50 pct capacity, physical distancing, mask use).

(quote) Any time individuals come within 6 ft. of another person who does not reside in the same residence (e.g. roommate), acceptable face coverings must be worn (quote). Applicable to higher education only at present. On 20200827, expands requirements to include PreK-12 schools: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/Pre-K_to_Grade_12_Schools_MasterGuidance.pdf. On https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.87.pdf, extends expanded requirements. Eased on 20210607 such that mandate no longer requires masks outdoors: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-school-districts-can-allow-students-remove-masks-outdoors

Eases gathering restrictions for regions moving to Phase 4 (Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, Southern Tier), permitting gatherings up to 50 people as long as gatherings do not exceed 50 pct capacity in an indoor area. Capacity limits also 50 pct for religious gatherings

New York City moves to Phase Four, bringing Phase 4 statewide and permitting gatherings up to 50 people as long as gatherings do not exceed 50 pct capacity in an indoor area (50 pct capacity limit for religious gatherings too). Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits, updated DateExpiry

PolicyCodingNotes: Bowling alleys may re-open statewide under strict safety protocols and under 50 pct maximum capacity. These requirements also include face coverings and social distancing, every other lane must be closed, patrons must stay with parties at an assigned lane, thorough cleaning and disinfection of shared equipment, and food service must follow regional requirements (e.g., no indoor service in New York City region). https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-bowling-alleys-can-reopen-50-percent-capacity-starting-monday. Extended to 2020920. Extended to 2020105.  Extended to 20201104. Extended to 20201204.

Eases restrictions on New York City, allowing museums and other low-risk cultural institutions (e.g., aquarariums, low-risk indoor cultural arts venues) to reopen. (quote) All institutions that reopen will be subject to state guidance. These institutions must obey strict safety protocols, including a 25 percent maximum occupancy limit, timed ticketing required with pre-set, staggered entry, strict enforcement of face coverings, social distancing, controlled traffic flow to avoid crowding, and enhanced cleaning and disinfection protocols. (quote) Easing of museums and other low-risk cultural institutions is now statewide, albeit at different capacity limits for New York City region versus other Phase Four regions. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

Gyms and fitness centers may reopen conditional on operating at a 33 pct occupancy limit, appropriate face coverings worn at all times, social distancing of at least 6 ft, cleaning and disinfection of shared equipment after each use, must meet air handling system standards. These facilities can reopen as early as August 24 per local officials, while all gyms and fitness centers can reopen by September 2. Notes that the governor may opt for delaying indoor fitness classes until after September 2. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions in New York City region, permitting for indoor services at 25 pct occupancy limit and strict safety protocols (e.g., temperature checks, contact information for tracing, face coverings when not seated, tables required to be to at least 6 ft apart). Bar service is not permitted and restaurants are required to close by midnight. Further detail is provided here: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/NYC_Indoor_Food_Services_Summary_Guidelines.pdf Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202_67.pdf

Requires bars to close for in-person services from 1000 pm to 500 am. Extends Phase Four region eased bar restrictions for all regions except New York City: allowing both indoor and outdoor in-person services conditional on following guidelines (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks). Phase Four regions: Capitol Region, Central New York, Finger Lakes, Long Island, Mid-Hudson, Mohawk Valley, North Country, Southern Tier, Western New York. Extended to 20210102: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO%20202.79-new.pdf Extended to 20210130 https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.87.pdf. Allows for reopening of indoor and outdoor places of public amusement. As of 20210223, event venues with capacities of at least 10,000 are permitted to open at 10 pct capacity with testing, mask, and distancing requirements: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-sports-and-entertainment-events-major-stadiums-and-arenas-can-reopen. As of 20210325, indoor places of amusement may open up to 25 pct capacity. As of 20210409, amusement parks may open up to 33 pct capacity: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-indoor-family-entertainment-centers-can-open-march-26-outdoor. Extended to 20210329, with revised date for indoor amusement of 20210326: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-20296-continuing-temporary-suspension-and-modification-laws-relating-disaster-emergency. Eased on 20210402 to allow venues with capacity less than 10,000 to open to 33 pct capacity, up to 100 people indoors and up to 200 people outdoors. If all attendees present proof of negative test prior to entry, capacity can increase up to 150 people indoors and up to 500 people outdoors. https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-event-arts-and-entertainment-venues-can-reopen-33-percent-capacity. Extended to 20210421: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-20298-continuing-temporary-suspension-and-modification-laws-relating-disaster-emergency. Extended to 20210426: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-20299-continuing-temporary-suspension-and-modification-laws-relating-disaster-emergency. Modified and eased on 20210406 (effective 20210401) such that outdoor stadiums and arenas with capacity greater than 10,000 and for outdoor performing arts venues with capacity greater than 2500, capacity is eased to 20 pct (from 10 pct) with no absolute person limit. Venues that hold at least 1500 people indoors or 2500 outdoors are permitted to operate up to 10 pct indoors and 20 pct outdoors, with no absolute person limit. Staff and spectators must have a negative COVID test within 72 hours of the event or full vaccination, and masks and social distancing are required. https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-202101-continuing-temporary-suspension-and-modification-laws-relating-disaster-emergency. Requires bowling alleys (licensed by the State Liquor Board or that serve food) to close by 1100pm and remain closed until 0500 am. Extends 50 percent capacity restrictions.  Extended to 20210417. Extended to 20210421. Extended to 20210426.

Exempts vaccinated individuals from quarantine requirements. Unvaccinated individuals must quarantine or present a negative test if traveling from a state not contiguous with NY. Additionally, travelers must quarantine if traveling from (quote) a country or territory subject to a CDC Level 2 or higher COVID-19 Risk Assessment Level or for which the COVID-19 risk level is designated by the CDC as Unknown, unless such traveler has traveled for less than 24 hours, is deemed an essential worker, or obtains two negative COVID-19 diagnostic test results (quote). Mandate for domestic travelers ended on 20210401 (quarantine still mandatory for international travelers): https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-quarantine-domestic-travel-will-no-longer-be-required-starting-april.

All travelers entering New York from another US state or US territory are advised to quarantine. International travelers are required to quarantine. All travelers must fill out the Travel Health Form. Vaccinated individuals are exempt from quarantine recommendations.  Ended 20210625 https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-210-expiration-executive-orders-202-and-205

Eases gathering restrictions: (quote) non-residential social gatherings of up to 100 people can occur indoors and up to 200 people can occur outdoors (quote). Eases gathering restrictions for outdoor social gatherings at non-residential events, arts, and entertainment venues to 500 (from 200). Non-residential social gatherings of up to 100 people can occur indoors and up to 500 people can occur outdoors (from 200). Residential gatherings are limited to no more than 10 people indoors or 25 people outdoors. No capacity limits for religious gatherings.

Eases gathering restrictions. Non-residential social gatherings of up to 250 people can occur indoors (from 100) and up to 500 people can occur outdoors. Residential gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people indoors (from 10) with no limit outdoors (from 25). No capacity limits for religious gatherings.

Removes curfew for outdoor on-site services. Extends Phase Four region eased bar restrictions for all regions except New York City: allowing both indoor and outdoor in-person services conditional on following guidelines (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks). Phase Four regions: Capitol Region, Central New York, Finger Lakes, Long Island, Mid-Hudson, Mohawk Valley, North Country, Southern Tier, Western New York. Indoor service must cease between midnight and 5am, but effective 20210531, indoor curfew will no longer apply.

Removes curfew for outdoor on-site services. Extends New York City modified Phase Three bar restrictions: outdoor in-person services are permitted, conditional on following guidelines (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks). Indoor services remain prohibited.

Removes curfew for outdoor on-site services. Eases restrictions for New York City to 75 pct capacity (from 50 pct), making the policy statewide. Indoor and outdoor in-person services are permitted up to 75 pct capacity. Customer-facing staff must wear masks. Indoor service must cease between midnight and 5am, but effective 20210531, indoor curfew will no longer apply.

Removes capacity limits on bars statewide, but distancing requirements still apply. Indoor service must cease between midnight and 5am (no curfew on outdoor services), but effective 20210531, indoor curfew will no longer apply. Vaccinated individuals are now exempt from mask and distancing requirements. Vaccinated individuals are now exempt from all state mask mandates. Businesses must provide, at their expense, such face coverings for their employees (quote). Removes capacity requirements for most businesses (indoor and outdoor places of public amusement, gyms, offices, retail, personal care services). Social distancing requirements still apply. Eases restrictions on event and entertainment venues. Outdoor stadiums and arenas with capacity greater than 10,000 and outdoor performing arts venues with capacity greater than 2500 no longer have capacity limits (from 20 pct). Venues that hold at least 1500 people indoors also no longer have capacity limits (from 10 pct). Masks and social distancing are required. For indoor venues with capacity above the gathering limit, all patrons over age 4 who cannot show proof of vaccination must present a negative covid test. Venues may designate vaccinated (with proof of vaccination) and unvaccinated sections, with vaccinated sections not subject to distancing requirements. Vaccinated individuals are exempt from mask and distancing requirements. Extended through 20210624: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/no-202109-continuing-temporary-suspension-and-modification-laws-relating-disaster-emergency. Indoor venues with capacities less than 5000 persons no longer have limits.  Indoor venues with capacities of 5000 or more still require social distancing and masks for unvaccinated individuals, but not for vaccinated persons.   https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/default/files/2021-06/EO_202.111_v2.pdf.
