State of emergency declared, no expiry provided.

Recommends the cancellation of all gatherings with 100 attendees or more: (quote) these events include large gatherings where people are in close contact (less than 6 feet), for example concerts, conferences, sporting events, faith-based events and other large gatherings.

Recommends that people at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should stay at home to the extent possible. Defines at risk people as those who are 65 years or older, with underlying health conditions (e.g., heart disease, lung disease, or diabetes, or weakened immune systems
Prohibits gatherings of more than 100. In place for 30 days.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure of all K-12 public schools effective 20200316. Closes K-12 schools through the remainder of the 2019-2020 year: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf Eased starting 20200817, with schools being permitted to operate under a hybrid model: https://files.nc.gov/covid/documents/guidance/Strong-Schools-NC-Public-Health-Toolkit.pdf

Bars are directed to close, without the option for takeaway or delivery (those options are limited to restaurants only). Order in place through 20200331. Eased on 20201003: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf
Limited operations required (drive-thru, carry-out, and delivery only): restaurants. Eased on 2020522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf
Prohibits gatherings of more than 50. In place for 30 days.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: bingo parlors, bowling alleys, indoor exercise facilities, health clubs, pools, live performance venues, movie theaters, spas, gaming establishments, personal care services like barber shops and salons, massage parlors, tattoo parlors. Effective at 5 pm on 20200325. Incorporated into the non-essential business closure starting 20200330: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO121-Stay-at-Home-Order-3.pdf Eased on 20200522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf

Mass gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. Exceptions are for funerals, where no more than 50 people may gather while observing social distancing requirements to the extent possible. Religious entities, outside of funerals, are subject to the mass gathering requirements as well. Eased on 20200508, removing religious gathering limits: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf

(quote) non-essential business and operations must cease (quote). Effective 5 pm on 20300330, in place for 30 days unless repealed, replaced, or rescinded. Eased on 20200508, permitting retail businesses to reopen at 50 pct capacity: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf

(quote) All individuals currently in the State of North Carolina are ordered to stay at home (quote). Effective 5 pm on 20300330, in place for 30 days unless repealed, replaced, or rescinded. Extended to 20200522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf Ended on 20200522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf

(quote) All retail establishments are encourage to supply, provide education on the proper use, and encourage the use of cloth face coverings for all employees in positions that do not allow them to maintain a 6 ft distance from other employees or customers (quote). On 20200508, all businesses are recommended to encourage the use of face coverings by workers: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf

Extends mass gathering prohibition of more than 10 people, but explicitly indicates that mass gatherings do not include those for worship (and thus is coded as easing). For religious gatherings, people must following the social distancing recommendations (i.e., maintaining at least 6 ft distancing between individuals outside of the home). Funerals remain limited to no more than 50 people, with recommendations to maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Eased on 20200522, increasing limit for outdoor gatherings: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf

Eases restrictions on retail businesses, permitting them to operate at no more than 50 pct stated fire capacity, or up to 12 customers per 1000 sq ft (whichever is lower). Customer occupancy also must enable at least 6 ft distancing between customers.
Individuals are encouraged to wear a mask or face covering when they leave the home.

Requires workers at personal care, grooming, and tattoo businesses to wear face coverings when within 6 ft of another person. Extends the recommendation that all businesses encourage the use of face coverings by workers. Explicitly strongly recommends the use of face coverings by employees at restaurants as they reopen. As more businesses re-open, requires mask use by employees. Extended to 20210228: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210326: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO195-Easing-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210430 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf Eased on 20210430 to apply only indoors, extended to 20210602 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210514 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf

Eases previous gathering restriction of up to 10 people in a gathering, allowing up to 25 people to gather outdoors (e.g., in a park, on a beach or trail). Extended to 20200717: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO147-Phase-2-Extension.pdf Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf Eased on 20200904 with increasing numeric limits on gatherings: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting them to re-open conditional on following requirements: personal care, grooming and tattoo businesses (i.e., requires no more than 50 pct capacity or no more than 12 customers per 1000 sq ft, whichever is lower, and requires at least 6 ft distancing between patrons), indoor and outdoor pools (i.e., no more than 50 pct capacity, or 33 people per 1000 sq ft on deck areas and 10 people per 1000 sq ft in the water), drive-in movie theaters (i.e., not considered a mass gathering event if all participants stay in their cars). Under Phase 2, large venues (i.e., with at least 500 people capacity) can re-open to allow for the recording and broading of sporting or entertainment events (no spectactors beyond the 10 people indoors and 25 outdoors, with the specific entertainers, performers, athletes, and coaches, as well as venue employeees, not counting toward this gathering limit). Further eases on 20200904, allowing very large venues to have a higher capacity: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions, allowing for onsite services both indoors and outdoors conditional on the following: no more than 50 pct capacity, no more than 12 customers per 1000 sq ft, maintain 6 ft physical distancing between tables, no more than 10 people seated together at a time, encourages mask use by employees and customers)

(quote) People who are at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are very strongly encouraged to stay home and travel only for absolutely essential purposes (quote). High risk populations are defined as those 65 or older, and people of any age with a serious medical condition. Extended to 20210108: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf

(quote) People are required to wear Face Coverings in the following settings, whether they are inside or outside (quote): retail businesses, restaurants, personal care services, child care and camps, government, on transportation, high-density occupational settings (eg, manufacturing), health care settings, processing plants. Applies to customers, patrons, employees. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as the order approaches the mandate by listing out applicable settings rather than a more sweeping policy across indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf. Extended to 20201003: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf

With statewide mask mandate, (quote) Masks are required for all school staff and adult visitors, and all middle and high school students when they are or may be within 6 feet of another person, unless the person (or family member, for a student) states that an exception applies. Cloth face coverings must be worn by students and staff inside school buildings, and anywhere on school grounds, including outside. They will also be required while traveling on buses or other transportation vehicles. Cloth face coverings remain strongly encouraged for elementary school students, if appropriate for that child, but are not required for them (quote). Expands requirements on 20200904, lowering age limit to 5 years: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO163-New-Phase-2.5.pdf Expands on 20201125, now applying to public and nonpublic schools, for indoors and outdoors: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210326: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO195-Easing-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210430 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf Eased on 20210430 to apply only indoors, extended to 20210602 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20210611 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf Extended to 20210730 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO220-Extension-of-EO215.pdf. Ended on 20210729: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO224-COVID-19-Measures.pdf

Eases restrictions on K-12 public schools, allowing districts to choose between Plan B (hybrid model), which will be the state default, or Plan C (fully remote) based on public health metrics, and requirements listed under the NC School Toolkit. August 17 is state government determined re-opening date for public schools, so treating is the date at which limited in-person instruction can resume. https://www.ednc.org/nc-governor-announces-what-schools-will-look-like-in-the-fall-reopen-2020/

Eases previous gathering restriction of up to 10 people in a gathering, allowing up to 25 people to gather indoor and up to 50 (from 25) outdoor. Extended to 20201023 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf

Further eases school restrictions, permitting public K-5th grade students to operate under Plan A (in-person permitted), while 6-12th grade students must continue operating under either Plan B (hybrid) or Plan C (fully remote). Coding as InPersonAllowed but not ending the school closure policy at the state level yet.

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to re-open. Outdoor seating areas may open at 30 pct of outdoor capacity, or 100 guests, whichever is less. No indoor seating permitted, all guests must be seated and 6 ft social dsitancing required between tables. Alcohol sales and consumption onsite are not permitted between 11 pm and 7 am.

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting them to reopen conditional on requirements: amusement parks (i.e., can re-open at 30 pct capacity and with outdoor attractions only, though permits indoor restaurants, gift shops and retail areas, and restrooms indoors to reopen), as well as night clubs, bingo parlors, indoor movie theaters, gaming and business establishments with gaming activities, night clubs, dance halls or music halls (i.e., can re-open at 30 pct capacity indoors or up to 7 people per 1000 sq ft for outdoor areas and up to 25 pct capacity for indoors, requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals, requires seating, etc).

Expansion of prior mask mandate. (quote) Face Coverings must be worn in any public place, business or establishment, indoor or outdoor, where it is not possible to consistently be physically distant by more than six (6) feet from non-household members. (quote) Exemptions include children under the age of 5, due to medical or behavioral conditions that may put wearers at risk, etc. Coded now as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings, whereas the prior mask mandate under Phases 2-2.5 were more limited (i.e., listing many settings where masks were required in public). Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf. Expanded on 20201125 to require face coverings indoors if a member of another household is present, irrespective of physical distancing: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210326: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO195-Easing-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210430 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf

Expands previous restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibits gatherings that bring together more than 10 people indoors, and more than 50 outdoors. Extended to 20201211: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf. Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

New order now requires business closure between 10 pm and 5 am, and does not allow alcohol sales between 9 pm and 7 am. Extends eased restrictions on bars, allowing them to re-open. Outdoor seating areas may open at 30 pct of outdoor capacity, or 100 guests, whichever is less. No indoor seating permitted, all guests must be seated and 6 ft social dsitancing required between tables. Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

All previously closed businesses that remain under eased restrictions and some kind of capacity limits from prior executive orders must close for on-premises services between 10 pm and 5 am. Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

New order now requires business closure between 10 pm and 5 am, and does not allow alcohol sales between 9 pm and 7 am. Extends eased restrictions for restaurants, allowing them to be open for in-person services indoors and outdoors conditional on operating at no more than 50 pct capacity, no more than 12 customers per 1000 sq ft, maintain 6 ft physical distancing between tables, no more than 10 people seated together at a time. Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

Mandates the (quote) following curfew and restriction upon movement of persons within the emergency area, which is the entire State of North Carolina. Between 1000 PM and 500 AM, all individuals in North Carolina must stay at home or at the place they will stay for the night. (quote) Exceptions apply (traveling to or from work, visiting essential businesses, personal safety, public transit, travel between households, out of state travel, etc.) Extended to 20210129: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO188-Extension-of-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

North Carolina Department recommends that all North Carolinans to (quote) stay at home. Limit your public interactions to essential activities such as goind to work or school, for healthcare purposes, to care for family members or to buy food (quote). Also extends the following via EO 188: (quote) People who are at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are very strongly encouraged to stay home and travel only for absolutely essential purposes (quote). High risk populations are defined as those 65 or older, and people of any age with a serious medical condition. Extended to 20210228 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO189-Further-Extension-of-Stay-at-Home-Order.pdf.

Eases restrictions on bars by allowing indoor consumption. Outdoor and indoor seating areas are limited to 30 pct capacity with a maximum of 250 people in any indoor space. All guests must be seated and 6 ft social distancing required. Does not allow alcohol sales between 11 pm and 7 am. Eased on 20210326 by increasing outdoor and indoor seating capacity to 50 pct (from 30) https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20210602 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210514 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf

Eases restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibits gatherings that bring together more than 25 people indoors (from 10), and more than 50 outdoors. Religious gatherings are exempted from these requirements and are strongly encouraged to maintain at least some 6 ft distancing from other individuals.

Removes curfew and eases restrictions on businesses. Night clubs, gaming facilities, indoor areas of amusement parks, and movie theaters may operate at 30 pct capacity with a maximum of 250 people indoors. Gyms, pools, personal care services, outdoor areas of amusement parks, museums, aquariums, and retail may operate at 50 pct capacity. Larger event venues may exceed the 250-person limit and operate at up to 15 pct capacity with additional safety measures. Further eases restrictions on 20210326: Museums and Aquariums, Retail Businesses, Salons, personal care and grooming businesses, tattoo parlors may operate Outdoors up to 100pct Capacity and indoors they are required to limit capacity to whichever is less: 100 pct of capacity or no more than 24 guests per 1000 sq ft of the total square footage of the location. Subject to Masks and 6 ft Social Distancing. Recreation ( bowling, skating, rock climbing), Fitness and Physical Activity Facilities (gyms, yoga studios, fitness centers), Pools and Amusement Parks may operate Indoors up to 75 pct and Outdoors up to 100 pct Capacity, Subject to Masks and 6 ft. Social Distancing. Movie Theaters and Gaming Facilities may operate at 50 pct capacity indoors and 75 pct capacity outdoors. Meeting, Reception, and Conference Spaces, Lounges (including tobacco) and Night Clubs, Auditoriums, Arenas, and other venues for live performances, Sports Arenas and Fields (includes professional, collegiate, and amateur may operate Indoors and Outdoors up to 50 pct Capacity, Subject to Masks and 6 ft. Social Distancing https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20210602 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210514 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf

Removes curfew and eases restrictions for restaurants by removing the limit on the number of people allowed to be seated together. Continues to require no more than 50 pct capacity, no more than 12 customers per 1000 sq ft, and must maintain 6 ft physical distancing between tables. No alcohol sales between 11 pm and 7 am. Eased on 20210326 by increasing capacity to 75 pct indoors and 100 pct outdoors https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO204-Further-Easing-Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20210602 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210514 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf

Eases restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibits gatherings that bring together more than 50 people indoors (from 25), and more than 100 outdoors (from 50). Religious gatherings are exempted from these requirements and are strongly encouraged to maintain at least some 6 ft distancing from other individuals.

Eases restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibits gatherings that bring together more than 100 people indoors (from 50), and more than 200 outdoors (from 100). Religious gatherings are exempted from these requirements and are strongly encouraged to maintain at least some 6 ft distancing from other individuals.  Ends restrictions on 20210514 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO215-Lifting-COVID-19-Restrictions_0.pdf

Eases mask mandate. Masks will still be required indoors but are no longer mandated outdoors. (quote) Face Coverings must be worn indoors if anyone else is in that space who is not a member of the same household (quote). Exemptions include children under the age of 5, due to medical or behavioral conditions that may put wearers at risk, etc. Coded now as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it only applies to indoor settings.

Eases mask mandate. Masks will still be required in child care facilities, childrens day or overnight camps, certain health care settings like long term care centers, public or private transportation regulated by the State of North Carolina and North Carolina airports, bus and train stations or stops, prisons and establishments that are providing shelter to people experiencing homelessness. It is (quote) strongly recommended that all individuals continue to wear Face Coverings in all large indoor seating facilities with a seating capacity of over five thousand (5,000) seats (quote). Exemptions include children under the age of 5, due to medical or behavioral conditions that may put wearers at risk, etc. Coded now as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it only applies to very limited indoor settings. Extended to 20210730 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO220-Extension-of-EO215.pdf

Recommends that all businesses require unvaccinated employees to wear masks and to recommend that vaccinated workers and guests to wear masks indoors when other people are likely to be present. https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO224-COVID-19-Measures.pdf

Mandates that unvaccinated individuals wear masks in state buildings. Masks are still recommended for vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals in public indoor spaces where other people are likely to be present. Expires 20210830: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO224-COVID-19-Measures.pdf

Public and nonpublic schools are recommended, but not mandated, to require that all workers, teachers, guests, other adults and children five (5) years or older wear face coverings indoors at all times.  https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO224-COVID-19-Measures.pdf

State of Emergency declared. No formal expiry provided. Ended on 20210430 https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202021-09%20rescind%20COVID-19%20dec.pdf

Public school closure, extended closure on 20200322: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-10.pdf. On 20200511, on-site summer programs allowed starting 20200601: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-04.2%20Burgum%20Grants%20Access%20to%20Schools%20for%20Certain%20Programs%20and%20Testing.pdf.
LastUpdatedNotes: Added NoInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Effective at 12 pm on 20200320, all bars, breweries, and similar venues are closed to on-site patrons. Take-out, delivery, curbside, drive-through, and off-sale services are permitted. Requirement continues through 20200406, so expiry coded as 20200407. Eased as of 20200501 - must follow specific guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf

Closure required: recreational facilities, health clubs, athletic facilities, and theaters. In effect 12 pm on 20200320, initial expiry is 20200406, extended to 20200430 on 20200415. As of 8 am on 20200501, allows health clubs and athletic activities to open, but must adopt and rigorously follow Fitness Center ND Smart Restart conditions. Movie theaters also may open, but must follow the movie theater specific standards https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf Ends required guidelines to be followed on 20200522: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose under BusinessRestrictLevel, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Effective at 12 pm on 20200320, all resturants, cafes and similar on-site dining establishments are closed to on-site patrons. Take-out, delivery, curbside, drive-through, and off-sale services are permitted. Requirement continues through 20200406, so expiry coded as 20200407. Eased as of 20200501 - must follow specific guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added TakeawayOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: personal care services (eg, cosmetologists, salons, barbers, tattoo parlors, tanning facilities, and massage therapists). In effect at 1200 am 20200328. On 20200401, extended to 20200420: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.2.pdf As of 8 am on 20200501, allows salons, tattoo and piercing salons, and massage therapists to re-open, but must follow each of their industry-specific standards under the ND Smart Restart Guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf Ends required guidelines to be followed on 20200522: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose under BusinessRestrictLevel, removed DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 must self-quarantine for 14 days, as must family or household members residing with an individual who tests positive. Extended on 2020508, no clear end date. Expanded on 20200923 to include close contacts: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-06.1_Amended_Close_Contact.pdf Eased on 20200926, to remove close contacts: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-06.2_Revocation_Order.pdf Further eased on 20201109, Individuals must self-quarantine for 10 days, and healthcare workers who test positive but are asymptomatic are exempt provided that they work in a covid unit https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-05.2_isolation_health_care_excemption.pdf. Ended on 20201218: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-44%20-%20Recissions.pdf.

Any person entering North Dakota traveling from another state or country is subject to immediate quarantine for a period of 14 days. Extended on 2020508, no clear end date. Extended on 20200728, no clear end date https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-02.3_International_Travel.pdf Quarantine order for people traveling from another country was ended on 20200921: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020_02.4_Lifted_Travel_Order.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and added 20200921 to DateEnd to reflect the end of this order.

PolicyCodingNotes: Restrictions are eased such that bars, breweries, distilleries, and like venues can re-open for in-person service under the broader ND Smart Restart standards and must follow the specific standards set for these businesses. Per ND Smart Restart at this point, capacity will be limited to 50 pct normal operating capacity, tables are limited to no more than 10 people, physical spacing of at least 6 ft between tables, no standing at bar areas, dance floors are closed. On 20200522, moves to recommendations, ending the mandate: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Requires employees to wear masks at personal care services (i.e., hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, tanning salons, waxing studios, and other cosmetology related businesses). Mask use by staff and patrons are encouraged for fitness centers, movie theaters, massage therapy. Also, more broadly (quote) Encourage use of cloth face coverings to employees and contracted workers whose duties require close contact (within six feet for ten minutes or more) with other employees and/or the public

Eases restrictions, allowing salons, tattoo and piercing salons, and massage therapists to re-open, but must follow each of their industry-specific standards under the ND Smart Restart Guidelines (i.e., employees must wear masks, no walk-in appointments). Also allows health clubs and athletic activities to open, but must adopt and rigorously follow Fitness Center ND Smart Restart conditions (limit groups to no more than 10, ensure spacing at least 1 person 100 square ft, keep certain group settings like indoor playgrounds closed). Movie theaters may open as well, but must follow the movie theater specific standards (i.e., no more than 20 pct capacity, allow for at least 6 ft spacing). All re-opened businesses the number of people occupying facilities to ensure all maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Ends on 20200522, shifting to only encouraging following Smart Restart guidelines: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Restrictions are eased such that, restaurants, cafes, and like venues can re-open for in-person service under the broader ND Smart Restart standards and must follow the specific standards set for these businesses. Per ND Smart Restart at this point, capacity will be limited to 50 pct normal operating capacity, tables are limited to no more than 10 people, physical spacing of at least 6 ft between tables, no standing at bar areas. On 20200522, ends mandated restrictions, coding as ending: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Summer school programs may be allowed on-site starting 20200601 provided the school district adheres to Department of Public Instructions ND K-12 Smart Restart Guidelines. Students allowed to enter school buildings to retrieve their property from 20200515 to 20200530.Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel, as schools do not appears to be fully open for in-person instruction yet.    https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-04.2%20Burgum%20Grants%20Access%20to%20Schools%20for%20Certain%20Programs%20and%20Testing.pdf Starting on 20200715, allows K-12 schools to choose to re-open, coding as ended at the state-level: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-38%20FINAL.pdf
Recommends mask use, (quote) In order to provide in-person learning, schools should require the use of masks by school-aged individuals and staff (quote)

Recommends that North Dakotans use cloth face coverings in public places where social distancing cannot be maintained. Also explicitly recommends wearing face coverings/masks when within a six foot distance of others, in particular to protect high-risk individuals. Wearing of masks or cloth face coverings is also recommended for customers/clients in various sectors under ND Smart Restart. It is likely that this recommendation was also under the original version of ND Smart Restart (announced on 20200429), but pdf documentation is not longer findable.
Strongly encourages businesses to require use of face coverings across sectors, but does not explicitly mandate mask use.

(quote) All remaining counties in the moderate risk (yellow) level under the ND Smart Restart guidelines are being moved to the high-risk (orange) level, indicating the seriousness of the situation. Businesses and events/gatherings are recommended to reduce occupancy to 25 percent, with a cap of 50 people (quote). Coded as mandate as 0 because it is a recommendation.

(quote) Burgum urged North Dakotans to try to limit gatherings to their immediate household group as much as possible for the next four weeks (quote). Coding as a recommendation with blanks in gathering limits, as we avoid coding 0 for non-mandated gathering restrictions.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed Gath limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Businesses must require that all persons, including workers...wear face coverings as required by this order (quote). Extended to 20210118: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-08.1_Mask_Order.pdf. Ended on 20210118, now encourages businesses follow Smart Restart Guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.5.pdf

Beginning 20201114, (quote) Businesses must require that all persons, including workers...wear face coverings as required by this order (quote). https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/SHO%20Order%202020-08%20Signed.pdf. Extended on 20201209, now set to expire on 20210118. https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-08.1_Mask_Order.pdf. Expired and replaced with a recommendation on 20210118 https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.5.pdf

Face coverings are required in indoor and indoor public settings, and must also be worn in outdoor business and public settings when it is not possible to maintain physical distancing, as well as public transportation or shared transportation. Exemptions are for individuals for whom conditions would make it unsafe to wear a face covering, children 4 years old and under, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-08.1_Mask_Order.pdf After expiring on 20210118, the ND public mask mandate will not be extended by the Governor and will be allowed to end. While some city governments will continue local mask mandates for another month, the State will allow its mandate to expire. https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.5.pdf Press release: https://www.thedickinsonpress.com/news/government-and-politics/6846684-As-statewide-mandate-expires-North-Dakota-cities-hang-onto-mask-requirements

Restrictions on banquets, ballrooms, wedding, and event venues. Effective 20201116, must not exceed 25 pct capacity. Tables must be 6 ft apart, dance areas are closed, face coverings must be worn by employees and patrons. Religious events are exempt. Extended to 20210108: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.2%20(corrected).pdf. Eased on 20210108, increasing maximum capacity of banquets, ballrooms, wedding, and event venues to 50 pct. Tables still must be 6 ft apart, dance areas are closed, face coverings still must be worn by employees and patrons. Religious events are still exempt. Extended to 20210129 and eased to 50 pct capacity: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.4%20-%20Restaurant%20and%20bar%20capacity%20limits.pdf. On 20210118, mandated restrictions are ended and encourages business follow Smart Restart Guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.5.pdf.

All extra-curricular activities for K-12 schools are suspended. Coding as InPersonAllowed under SchoolRestrictLevel as, at the state-level, this still permits in-person instruction but limits all extra-curricular activities. Expired on 20201214 and formally ended on 20201218: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-44%20-%20Recissions.pdf.
The governor (quote) strongly encourages residents to wear masks in public (quote)

Under Smart Restart Guidelines, strongly encourages businesses to require use of face coverings across sectors, but does not explicitly mandate mask use. Recommendation ended on 20210222 https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202021-05.pdf.
State of Emergency declaration. Has no formal expiry. Ended 20210618 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/executive-order-2021-08d.pdf

(quote) Im recommending that Ohio limits a variety of large gatherings in order to protect public health (quote), including that organizers of any events involving a large gathering of individuals in close proximity be canceled or postponed

Mass gatherings are prohibited in the State of Ohio, defined as any event or convening that brings together 100 or more people into a single room or space at a time, such as an auditorium, stadium, arena, large conference room, meeting hall, theater, or any other confined indoor or outdoor space (also includes parades, fairs, and festivals). Expressly excludes religious gatherings

Closure of all K-12 schools for in-person instruction effective at 1201 am on 20200317, issued on 20200314. Initial expiry is 1159 pm 20200403, so 20200404. Governor announced this on 20200312: https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/announces-school-closures Extended to 20200701: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Second-Amended-Order-the-Closure-K-12-Schools-Ohio.pdf Eased on 20200522, permitting school-based gyms and extracurriculars to open: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Extend-Expiration-Date-Various-Orders.pdf

Limited operations required (take-out and delivery only): bars. Goes in effect at 9 pm on 20200315 per Ohio Department of Health. Easing began on 20200515: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Order-Dine-Safe-Ohio.pdf

Limited operations required (take-out and delivery only): restaurants. Goes in effect at 9 pm on 20200315 per Ohio Department of Health. Eased on 20200515: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Order-Dine-Safe-Ohio.pdf

Mass gatherings of 50 or more are bannned in Ohio, but does not ban religious gatherings. Also includes recommendation to limit to 10 or fewer for non-family social gatherings, but clearly indicates that it is not a mandate.

Requires the closure of the following businesses for in-person operations: bowling alleys, gyms and fitness centers, indoor trampoline parks, indoor water parks, movie theaters and all performance theaters, public recreation centers, indoor sports facilities. First eased on 20200526: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use/new-restartohio-opening-dates

Requires the closure of the following businesses for in-person operations: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, body piercing locations, massage therapy, and tanning facilities. First eased on 20200515: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Order-Personal-Services.pdf

Requires the closure of the following businesses: indoor family entertainment businesses and venues, including laser tag, roller skating rinks, ice skating rinks, arcades, indoor miniature golf facilities. Also closes any establisment whose primary business is operating any adult or child skill based amusement machine, no-chance pre-reveal games, or amusement machines (appears to be targetting casinos), as well as any dance studios. First eased on 20200526: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use/new-restartohio-opening-dates

Expands prior gathering restriction, prohibiting all gatherings of more than 10 people (though exempts religious gatherings and houses of worship). Extended and reinstated multiple times since 20200324. Replaced with a recommendation on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

(quote) Non-essential businesses must cease (quote). Also expressly closes all places of public amusement (eg, amusement rides, carnivals, amusement parks, water parks, aquariums, zoos, museums, arcades, fairs, childrens play centers, playgrounds, funplexes, theme parks, bowling alleys, movie and other theaters, concert and music halls, and country clubs or social clubs), though most of these venues had been previously closed Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

(quote) With exceptions as outlined below, all individuals currently living within the State of Ohio are ordered to stay at home or at their place of residence except as allowed in this Order. (quote) Exteneded to 20200530: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Stay-Safe-Ohio-Order.pdf Ended on 20200520: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2020/05/20/file_attachments/1456369/Stay%20Safe%20Partial%20Rescission.pdf

People entering the state from all points of origin are (quote) asked to self-quarantine themselves (quote). Shall be enacted on 1159pm on 20200406, expires 1159 pm 20200501, coded accordingly. Ended on 20200530 by no longer including this section in the extension: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/revised-business-guidance-sd.pdf

(quote) Persons who have tested positive for COVID-19, are presumptively diagnosed with COVID-19 or are exhibiting the symptoms identified in the screening guidance available from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Ohio Department of Health shall not enter the State (quote). Extended to 20200707: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Extend-Expiration-Date-Various-Orders.pdf Ended on 20200706: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Second-Order-Extend-Exp-Date-Various-Orders.pdf

(quote) Ohio Governor Mike DeWine, Lt. Governor Jon Husted, and Dr. Amy Acton, MD, MPH, today urged Ohioans to begin wearing cloth masks while in public, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)...Wearing a cloth mask in public is not mandatory, but it is strongly recommended. (quote)

(quote) Businesses must require all employees to wear facial coverings (quote), with some exemptions (eg, face coverings are not advisable due to health reasons, in violation with industry standards or regulations, etc). Further stressed as part of the Responsible Restart: safe business practices required of all businesses as they reopen include (quote) requiring face coverings for all employees, and recommending them for clients and customers at all times (quote). Extended and amended over time as more businesses reopened. Re-issued on 20210405 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2021/04/05/file_attachments/1744809/Director%27s%20Order%20for%20Social%20Distancing,%20Facial%20Coverings,%20and%20Non-Congregating%2004.05.21.pdf

Eases restrictions on retail establishments and facilities, permitting them to reopen to curbside pick-up, delivery, or appointment-only (limited to 10 customers at any one time) effective 1159 pm May 1 (so coded to 20200502 for date enacted). Coded to IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel given that up to 10 customers at a time can be present for in-person services. Further eased on 20200512, permitting retail to open as long as 6 ft distancing protocols are adhered to: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Stay-Safe-Ohio-Order.pdf  Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to re-open for outdoor services only. Seated service only, required 6 ft distancing, reservations of no more than 10 people in a party, open congregate areas must remain closed. Eased on 20200521 to permit indoor services: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Order-Dine-Safe-Ohio.pdf

Hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, body piercing, tanning facilities, massage therapy, acupunture can be open for full service as long as they follow all health and safety protocols (i.e., required 6 ft distancing among employees and members of the public. Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants, allowing them to re-open for outdoor services only. Seated service only, required 6 ft distancing, reservations of no more than 10 people in a party, open congregate areas must remain closed. Eases to permit indoor services on 20200521: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Order-Dine-Safe-Ohio.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to re-open for indoor and outdoor services. Seated service only, required 6 ft distancing, reservations of no more than 10 people in a party, open congregate areas must remain closed. On 20200605, eases further to permit open congregate areas to reopen and resume live entertainment: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/dao-Reopens-Restaurants-Bars.pdf

Further eases restrictions on restaurants, allowing them to re-open for indoor and outdoor services. Seated service only, required 6 ft distancing, reservations of no more than 10 people in a party, open congregate areas must remain closed. Further eases on 20200605, opening congregate areas and allowing live entertainment to occur: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/dao-Reopens-Restaurants-Bars.pdf Extended beyond 20200707: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Second-Order-Extend-Exp-Date-Various-Orders.pdf Re-issued on 20210405 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2021/04/05/file_attachments/1744809/Director%27s%20Order%20for%20Social%20Distancing,%20Facial%20Coverings,%20and%20Non-Congregating%2004.05.21.pdf Extended to 20210602, starting 20210514 Vaccinated individuals no longer have to wear masks when not seated https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/rev-2nd-final-amended-do-soc-dist-remove-face-cover-21.pdf Restrictions on restaurants are allowed to Expire and replaced with recommendations. docs.google.com/forms/d/1yMpxJPzdPYeugmIjPvaDPpoD91YXZhJ6uecrTPAYl_U/edit

(quote) people at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19, including those who are elderly and those who are sick, are strongly urged (but not required) to stay in their residence to the extent possible except as necessary to seek medical care. According to the CDC, those at high-risk for severe illness from COVID-19 include people who are 65 years or older and people of all ages with underlying medical condition, particularly if not well controlled (quote). Extended without expiry on 20200706: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Second-Order-Extend-Exp-Date-Various-Orders.pdf Ended on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases school restrictions, permitting school-based gyms and like fitness venues reopen for limited use. Otherwise K-12 buildings are closed for in-person instruction through at least 1159 pm on 20200630 (so coded to 20200701). Extended to 20200707: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Extend-Expiration-Date-Various-Orders.pdf Ended on 20200702, devolving authority to local school districts: http://education.ohio.gov/getattachment/Topics/Reset-and-Restart/Reset-Restart-Guide.pdf.aspx?lang=en-US

Eases restrictions on the following businesses and sectors, permitting them to reopen conditional on following health and safety protocols (eg, at least 6 ft distancing between patrons and employees at all times): gyms and fitness centers, inclusive of yoga studios and dance instruction studios (at least 6 ft distancing between all equipment), pools and aquatic centers. Also eases restrictions on the following conditional on extensive requirements, including at least 6 ft distancing between patrons and employees: baseball and softball batting cages, golf courses, miniature golf, aquatic centers and pools, tennis facilities, general non-contact sports including bowling alleys. Extended beyond 20200707: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Second-Order-Extend-Exp-Date-Various-Orders.pdf On 20200710, further eases for sporting activities: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/do-guidance-contact-and-noncontact-sports.pdf Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting them to reopen if they follow retail, consumer, service and entertainment guidelines (eg, at least 6 ft distancing, employees wearing masks): aquariums, art galleries, country clubs, ice skating rinks, indoor family entertainment centers, indoor sports facilities, laser tag facilities, movie theaters (indoor), museums, playgrounds (outdoor), public recreation centers, roller skating rinks, social clubs, trampoline parks, zoos. Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following, permitting them to reopen: county fairs (including animal exhibitions at fairs). Expanded restrictions on 20200731, only permitting junior county fairs: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2020/07/30/file_attachments/1507895/Director%27s%20Order%20County%20Jr%20Fair.pdf Eased restrictions again on 20210311, permitting all fair activities: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/do-reopens-fairs-animal-exhibitions-with-exceptions.pdf Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, allowing them to re-open conditional on following overall and sector-specific requirements (eg, for overall, at least 6 ft distancing among patrons and employees): casinos, racinos, amusement parks, and water parks Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

(quote) Just as we have done in the business sector with employees, we are requiring school staff to wear face coverings to reduce the spread of the virus, unless it is unsafe or when doing so could significantly interfere with the learning process. When face coverings arent practical, face shields may be considered....We strongly recommend that students in 3rd grade and up wear face coverings as well (quote) Further expanded on 20200814, requiring all students, faculty, and staff in school buildings K-12 to wear facial coverings indoors, outdoors when unable to consistently maintain at least 6 ft distancing, riding school bus. Exempts individuals with medical conditions, while eating or drinking beverages: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/DO-K-12-facial-coverings.pdf  Ended on 20210602 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders-06-02-21.pdf

Mandates face coverings in any indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors and unable to maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft, and waiting for riding public transportation, taxi, ride sharing. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor settings, as well as outdoor settings where social distancing is not possible. This is applicable to all counties that are designated as a Red Alert Level 3 Public Health Emergency or a Purple Alert Level 4 Public Health Emergency. As of 20200707: Butler County, Cuyahoga County, Franklin County, Hamilton County, Huron County, Montgomery County, Trumbull County. On 20200709, Huron is downgraded to Level 2: https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-07092020 On 20200710, more counties added, bringing the list to: Clermont, Fairfield, Lorain, Pickaway, Summit, Wood, Butler, Cuyahoga, Franklin, Hamilton, Montgomery, Trumbull. As of 20200716, Trumball is downgraded to Level 2 and in effect on 20200717, these additional counties are added: Athens, Allen, Delaware, Licking, Lucas, Richland, Scioto, Union. https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-0716-2020
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes to reflect changes in county alert levels

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Those entering Ohio after travel to states reporting positive testing rates of 15 pct or higher for COVID-19 are advised to self-quarantine for 14 days (quote). States for which this quarantine advisory will be updated every Wednesday. As of 20200722, the current list is: Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Mississippi, Nevada, South Carolina, Texas. Gets updated every week to 20210310, when it was ended: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/families-and-individuals/covid-19-travel-advisory/covid-19-travel-advisory

Statewide mask mandate is issued and in effect at 6 pm on 20200723, requiring all individuals in Ohio to wear facial coverings in public at all times when at an indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors (but unable to maintain six-foot social distance from people who are not household members), waiting for, riding, driving, or operating public transportation, such as a taxi, a car service, or a private car used for ride-sharing. Exemptions are for individuals under the age of 10 years old, with a medical conditions or disability, etc. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal PHO was signed on 20200723, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722).  Re-issued on 20210405 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2021/04/05/file_attachments/1744809/Director%27s%20Order%20for%20Social%20Distancing,%20Facial%20Coverings,%20and%20Non-Congregating%2004.05.21.pdf

Governor and Liquor Board institute a more restrictive rule on liquor permit establishments, requiring bars and like venues to not permit on-premises consumption from 1100 pm and 530 pm. In effect at 10 pm on 20200731 to 20201129. Continues the prior eased restrictions, whereby live entertainment and allowing open congregate areas (billiards, card playing, etc.) are permitted. Requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals/parties, no more than 10 people per table, required seated service when consuming beverages.

Expands restrictions on county fairs, limiting participation to only junior fair activities. Also imposes a curfew on fair grounds of 10 pm. Ends the curfew-based restrictions on 20210311: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/do-reopens-fairs-animal-exhibitions-with-exceptions.pdf Ends all restrictions on 20200405 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on entertainment venues (auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, concert and music halls, theaters, ballrooms, gymnasiums, convention centers, arcades, bingo halls, adult and child skill or chance games, laser tag facilities, and interactive game facilities hosting non-sports events), permitting them to reopen with limited capacity: no more than 1500 people or 15 pct for outdoor entertainment venues, and up to 300 people or 15 pct for indoor entertainment venues. Also must have at least 6 ft distancing between individuals/groups, etc. Eases on 20210302, permitting up to 25 pct indoors and 30 pct outdoors of fixed seated capacity: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/addenda-for-sports-and-entertainment-capacity.pdf The Directors Order that Provides Mandatory Requirements for Entertainment Venues signed on August 25, 2020 is rescinded. New Directors Order for Social Distancing is signed on 20210405 and extends restrictions for indoor entertainment venues: auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, concert and music halls, theaters, ballrooms, gymnasiums, convention centers, arcades, bingo halls, adult and child skill or chance games, laser tag facilities, and interactive game facilities hosting non-sports events). Eases capacity restrictions for spectators by removing outdoor capacity limit (was 30 pct) and continues permitting up to 25 pct of the capacity indoor. Also must have at least 6 ft distancing between individuals/groups, etc.         https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders.pdf Extended to 20210602 https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/rev-2nd-final-amended-do-soc-dist-remove-face-cover-21.pdf Restrictions on businesses are allowed to Expire and replaced with recommendations. docs.google.com/forms/d/1yMpxJPzdPYeugmIjPvaDPpoD91YXZhJ6uecrTPAYl_U/edit

(quote) All individuals residing within the State of Ohio are ordered to stay at a place of residence during the hours of 1000 pm until 500 am except as otherwise expressly permitted in this Order (quote). Exemptions are made for work and essential activity, etc. Extended to 20201231: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/all-pers-stay-at-home-specified-hours.pdf. Extended to 20210123: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/stay-home-tonight-second-amended.pdf. Extended to 20210130: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/stay-home-tonight-third-amended.pdf.

Time-limited liquor restrictions are not renewed, but all other prior eased restrictions on bars in effect: requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals/parties, no more than 10 people per table, required seated service when consuming beverages, live entertainment and congregate areas (billiards, card playing, etc.) are permitted. Re-issued on 20210405 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/OHOOD/2021/04/05/file_attachments/1744809/Director%27s%20Order%20for%20Social%20Distancing,%20Facial%20Coverings,%20and%20Non-Congregating%2004.05.21.pdf Extended to 20210602, starting 20210514 Vaccinated individuals no longer have to wear masks when not seated https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/rev-2nd-final-amended-do-soc-dist-remove-face-cover-21.pdf Restrictions on bars are allowed to Expire and replaced with recommendations. docs.google.com/forms/d/1yMpxJPzdPYeugmIjPvaDPpoD91YXZhJ6uecrTPAYl_U/edit

Extends time-based stay at home order, but now requiring residents remain in place of residence from 11pm (from 10pm) to 5am. (quote) All individuals residing within the State of Ohio are ordered to stay at a place of residence during the hours of 1100 pm until 500 am except as otherwise expressly permitted in this Order (quote). Exemptions are made for work, essential activity, health and safety, government services, etc. Ends time-based stay at home order on 20210211: https://twitter.com/GovMikeDeWine/status/1359945215629484042.
When gathered together, individuals should be in a group of no more than 10 individuals that is separated from other groups by at least 6 feet. This limit does not apply to religious gatherings.

Extends business mask mandate, but adds exemption for fully vaccinated individuals, who do not have to wear a mask in any indoor or outdoor setting, except for public transportation. Public Mask mandate applies to businesses as it specifies that: All unvaccinated individuals, in the State of Ohio shall wear facial coverings at all times when at an indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors (but unable to maintain six-foot social distance from people who are not household. On 20210602, business mask requirements are formally rescinded on the same day they were set to expire. https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/directors-order-rescinding-various-orders-06-02-21.pdf

Extends gathering recommendations, but now introduces exemption for vaccinated individuals, who may gather freely. Unvaccinated individuals should be in a group of no more than 10 individuals that is separated from other groups by at least 6 feet. This recommended limit does not apply to religious gatherings. On 20210608 Gathering recommendation is reissued under Department of Health guidance, with no expiration date. Continues to provide an exemption for vaccinated individuals. Unvaccinated individuals not gather in groups greater than 10 individuals and should attempt to maintain 6 ft of distance from each other. docs.google.com/forms/d/1yMpxJPzdPYeugmIjPvaDPpoD91YXZhJ6uecrTPAYl_U/edit

Extends public mask mandate,  but adds exemption for fully vaccinated individuals, who do not have to wear a mask in any indoor or outdoor setting, except for public transportation. All unvaccinated individuals, in the State of Ohio shall wear facial coverings at all times when at an indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors (but unable to maintain six-foot social distance from people who are not household members), waiting for, riding, driving, or operating public transportation, such as a taxi, a car service, or a private car used for ride-sharing. Exemptions are for individuals under the age of 10 years old, with a medical conditions or disability, etc. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Allowed to Expire on 20210602 and replaced with a masking recommendation.
As public mask mandate expires, the Governor issues an informal recommendation for unvaccinted individuals to continue to wear face coverings indoors.

Recommends mask wearing in schools indoors for teachers, staff, and students over two years of age.  Also recommends masks be worn outdoors in crowded settings in areas with substantial or high transmission. https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/responsible/schools/K-12-Schools-Guidance.pdf

State of Emergency declared. Each EO involves amendments or extensions to the original state emergency, so the latest is through 20200524: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1937.pdf. Extended to 20200611: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1943.pdf Extended to 20200712 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1949.pdf Extended to 20200829 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1953.pdf. Extended to 20201025 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1962.pdf. Extended to 20201122 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1967.pdf. Extended to 20201216: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1971.pdf. Extended to 20210113: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1975.pdf. Extended to 20210213: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1977.pdf. Extended to 20210314: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf. Extended to 20210411: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1992.pdf. Extended to 20210511: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1996.pdf Ended on 20210504 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1999.pdf

Original issuance in effect on 20200317. By 20200325 closed all public schools through the end of the academic year https://sde.ok.gov/sites/default/files/documents/files/20200325124831229.pdf. During Phase 2 of the OURS plan, starting on May 15, school buildings are open to staff and camp and summer school small groups with safety guidelines.

Recommends Oklahomans follow the presidential coronavirus guidelines, specifically avoid social gatherings of more than 10 people. Not coded as formal restriction. Initial expiry is 30 days from this order
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Recommends Oklahomans follow the presidential coronavirus guidelines, specifically that older person or a person with a serious underlying health condition, (quote) stay home and away from people (quote). Effective until the end of 30 days of filing this order, so 20200417.

Extended to 20200430 with 20200401 issuance https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1926.pdf. Extended to 20200509 with extended State of Emergency https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1929.pdf Ended on 20200424 when mandate changes to a recommendation to follow CDC guidelines.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEased, updated PolicyCodingNotes, changed DateExpiry to 20200520, added 20200424 to DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands stay at home order recommendation to mandate for vulnerable individuals. Older persons or a person with a serious underlying health condition, (quote) stay home and away from people (quote). Effective until the end of 30 days of filing this order. Ends mandate on 20200530, moves to recommendation: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1946.pdf

Bars are permitted operations for takeout and curbside delivery under the non-essential business closure with in counties with community spread. Effective at 1159 pm on 20200325, so coded to 2020036. Effective until April 16, 2020, so coded as 20200416.

All non critical businesses must close. Effective at 1159 pm on 20200325, so coded to 2020036. Only applicable to counties with community spread, so coded as not statewide. Since what constitutes community spread is not clearly defined, we are not listing counties under AppliesTo. Effective until April 16, 2020, so coded as 20200416.
All non-essential businesses close per executive order but nothing shall prevent restuarants from providing takeout, curbside and delivery. Only applicable to counties with community spread.

Mandates 14-day quarantine for any individual entering Oklahoma by air from areas with (quote) substantial community spread (quote), specifically Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Washington state, California, and Lousiana. Initial expiry is 30 days after issuance. Ends mandate and moves to recommendation on 20200512: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1943.pdf

Bars are permitted operations for takeout and curbside delivery under the non-essential business closure. Initial expiry is until 20200430. Began easing on 20200515: https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf

Amends the previous non-essential business closures to all non-essential businesses, irrespective of location within Oklahoma. Initial expiry is until 20200430. Now applies statewide. Began easing on 20200424, allowing personal care services to reopen https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf

All non-essential businesses close per executive order but nothing shall prevent restuarants and bars from providing takeout, curbside and delivery. On-premise services to resume starting 20200501 https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf
State health emergency declared. Duration will be for 30 days after filing https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/Executive/1927.pdf

(quote) individuals should follow CDC guidelines for social distancing by staying out of crowded places, not gathering in groups (quote). Extended to 20210113: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1975.pdf. Extended to 20210213: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1977.pdf. On 20210212, gathering recommendation not renewed, effectively ending the policy: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf.

Personal care businesses (hair salons, barbershops, spas, nail salons, pet groomers) can reopen for appointments only and must adhere to sanitation protocols and social distancing guidelines. State parks and otudoor recreation also may reopen. Entertainment, movie theaters, sporting venues, gyms can reopen conditional on adhering to sanitation and CDC distancing protocols. Tattoo parlors can reopen to appointment only. Ends on 20200601 with Oklahoma going to Phase 3: https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/oklahoma-to-begin-phase-3-of-open-up-and-recover#:~:text=OKLAHOMA%20CITY%20(May%2029%2C%202020,5%2C236%20people%20have%20already%20recovered

Dining restablishments can reopen for in-person services conditional on adhering to sanitation and CDC distancing protocols. Ends mandate on 20200601, as Oklahoma goes to Phase 3: https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/oklahoma-to-begin-phase-3-of-open-up-and-recover#:~:text=OKLAHOMA%20CITY%20(May%2029%2C%202020,5%2C236%20people%20have%20already%20recovered

Bars can reopen under proper social distancing and sanitation protocols. Ended on 20200601 when the state went to Phase 3 and business mandates went to recommendations: https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/oklahoma-to-begin-phase-3-of-open-up-and-recover#:~:text=OKLAHOMA%20CITY%20(May%2029%2C%202020,5%2C236%20people%20have%20already%20recovered

(quote) All persons who enter the State of Oklahoma from another state or country are directed to follow CDC travel guidelines (quote). Extended to 20201216: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1971.pdf. Extended to 20210113: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1975.pdf. Extended to 20210213: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1977.pdf. On 20210212, quarantine recommendation not renewed, effectively ending the policy: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf.

During Phase 2 of the OURS plan, which began May 15, small meetings of staff and summer school can happen inside school buildings. Ends state-level restrictions on 20200728: https://sde.ok.gov/sites/default/files/documents/files/Oklahoma%20School%20Safety%20Protocols.pdf

Recommends vulnerable individuals to continue staying home. Extended to 202007012 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1949.pdf Extended to 20200829 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1953.pdf. Extended to 20201025 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1962.pdf. Extended to 20201122 https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1967.pdf Extended to 20201216: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1971.pdf. Extended to 20210113: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1975.pdf. Extended to 20210213: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1977.pdf. On 20210212, stay at home recommendation not renewed, effectively ending the policy: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf.

In red or orange counties, it is recommended that individuals 11 or older wear a face covering when inside a business, public building, using public transportation, or outside when social distancing it not possible. Because it is not clear where or how the red and orange counties are updated, no counties are listed under AppliesTo at this time

(quote) all persons on property, including buildings and office space, owned or leased by the State of Oklahoma shall wear a facial covering or mask over the mouth and nose at all times where physical distancing measures may be difficult to observe. This only applies to persons while indoors or when in an outdoor space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distance from another person (quote) Exemptions are for children under the age of 10, when eating or drinking, when medically unable, etc. Coding as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as this policy only applies to buildings and office spaces owned or leased by the state of Oklahoma. Extended to 20210113: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1975.pdf. Extended to 20210213: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1977.pdf. Extended to 20210314: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf. EO on 20210312 allows the public mask mandate to expire, effectively ending the policy: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1992.pdf

State of emergency proclamation.
