PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all public schools in Oregon from 20200316 to 20200428 for in-person instruction. Extends closure of in-person services to 20200701. https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-20.pdf Ends restrictions to permit in-person instruction conditional on district decisions based on public health guidelines from Department of Education: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-29.pdf Ready Schools, Safe Learners plan to guide reopening process. Version 2.7.2 released on 20200722 https://www.oregon.gov/ode/students-and-family/healthsafety/Documents/Ready%20Schools%20Safe%20Learners%202020-21%20Guidance.pdf

Limited operations required (off-premises consumption only): bars, taverns, wine bars, and like venues. In effect as of 5 pm on 20200317, with an initial expiry of 20200414. On 20200407 a non-dated extension was issued https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-14.pdf Bar restrictions eased in Phase One counties start on 20200515 https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-25.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added TakeawayOnly to BusinessRestrictLevel and removed DateReexpanded1

PolicyCodingNotes: Prohibition of gatherings of 25 or more, inclusive of spiritual gatherings. In effect as of 5 pm on 20200317, with an initial expiry of 20200415
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations required (off-premises consumption only): restaurants, coffee shops, cafes, and like venues. In effect as of 5 pm on 20200317, with an initial expiry of 20200414. On 20200407 a non-dated extension was issued https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-14.pdf Restaurant restrictions eased in Phase One counties start on 20200515 https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-25.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added TakeawayOnly to BusinessRestrictLevel and removed DateReexpanded1

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes in-person instruction at all colleges, universities, community colleges, etc. Ends restrictions starting 20200614, allowing for in-person instruction and residential activities conditional on following Oregon Health Authority: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-28.pdf

Non-essential social and recreational gatherings of individuals outside of a house are prohibited immediately, regardless of size. Expands gathering restriction previously of maximum of 25, now coded as 0. Easing began on 20200515, as counties began different phases of higher limits on gatherings: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-25.pdf

Formal stay-at-home order, violation will result in penalty. In effect immediately on 20200323, no formal expiry provided. Eases for Phase One counties https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-25.pdf Ends on 20200619 with Multnomah county moving to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=36806

Requires closure of the following businesses: amusement parks, aquariums, arcades, art galleries (to the extent that they are open without appointment), barber shops and hair salons, bowling alleys, cosmetic stores, dance studios, esthetician practices, fraternal organization facilities, furniture stores, gyms and fitness studios (including climbing gyms), hookah bars, indoor and outdoor malls (i.e., all portions of a retail complex containing stores and restaurants in a single area), indoor party places (including jumping gyms and laser tag), jewelry shops and boutiques (unless they provide goods exclusively through pick-up or delivery service), medical spas, facial spas, day spas, and non-medical massage therapy services, museums, nail and tanning salons, non-tribal card rooms, skating rinks, senior activity centers, ski resorts, social and private clubs, tattoo/piercing parlors, tennis clubs, theaters, yoga studios, and youth clubs. Also requires all pools, skate parks, outdoor sports courts, and playground equipment areas. Private and public camp grounds also must be closed immediately.    https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-12.pdf On 20200505, camp grounds are permitted to reopen, representing first easing: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/jkAULYKcSh6DoDF8wBM0_EO%2020-12.pdf

Per EO 20-25, indicates that there was a directive effective May 5 that allows private and public campgrounds the option of reopening if they are able to complicy OHA guidances regarding outdoor recreation. Coding this policy to this executive order as the May 5 directive is not currently findable.

Statewide easing of restrictions on the following businesses, conditional on them following health and safety guidelines: ski resorts. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel as no stipulations closing indoor portions of ski resorts are included.

Bar restrictions eased for 31 counties approved for Phase One (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), conditional on meeting health and safety guidelines: in-person service at tables only, 6 ft distancing, open until 10 pm only

For baseline counties (Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), social gatherings of more than 10 people remain prohibited. Religious gatherings up to 25 can occur. Eased when Multnomah moved to Phase One, with no more counties under this level: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=36806

For Phase One counties (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), all gatherings more than 25 are prohibited. For baseline counties, this gathering restriction applies for cultural, civic, and faith gatherings (otherwise a restriction of 10 for social gatherings). Easing began on 20200605 when counties could move to Phase 2: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-27.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide easing of restrictions on the following businesses, conditional on them following health and safety guidelines: art galleries, boutiques, furniture stores, jewelry shops, retail businesses may re-open to in-person services. Requires that the number of customers in the retail store enable at least 6 ft of distancing between individuals and customers. As counties move from different phases, more sectors can re-open separately. Starting on 202001118, all retail services must operate up to 75 pct: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37702

For Phase One counties (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), the following businesses can have in-person services conditional on following health and safety protocols: personal care businesses and facilities (e.g., salons, gyms), all retail businesses, including malls and shopping centers. Requires at least 6 ft distancing. More counties move to Phase One through 20200619, when it becomes statewide

Restaurant restrictions eased for 31 counties approved for Phase One (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), conditional on meeting health and safety guidelines: in-person service at tables only, 6 ft distancing, dine in services until 10 pm only. More counties move to this level to 20200619, and some move to Phase Two, where there are the same restrictions but dine in service can operate until 12 am.
Phase Two counties have similar physical distancing requirements as Phase One counties, but can now remain open up to midnight

Phase Two counties may have gatherings up to 50 in indoor spaces and 100 on outdoor spaces, conditional on following distancing requirements. For June 5, 14 counties went to Phase 2: Benton, Curry, Douglas, Grant, Jackson, Klamath, Lake, Lane, Linn, Morrow, Union, Wallowa, Wasco, Wheeler. For June 6, 14 more counties - Baker, Deschuetes, Clatsop, Columbia, Coos, Crook, Gilliam, Harney, Jefferson, Josephine, Malheur, Sherman, Umatilla, Yamhill - were added. For June 8, Tillamook moved to phase two, bringing the total to 29 of 36 counties in Phase Two.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Phase Two counties have eased restrictions on the following businesses previously closed statewide: pools, skate parks, outdoor sports courts, playgrounds, amusement parks, social clubs, theaters. For June 5, there are 14 Phase Two counties: Benton, Curry, Douglas, Grant, Jackson, Klamath, Lake, Lane, Linn, Morrow, Union, Wallowa, Wasco, Wheeler. Continues to add (and shift back) counties. Starting on 20201118 with the Two Week Freeze, businesses that are not closed for in-person services must be limited to no more than 50: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37679
Phase Two counties have similar physical distancing requirements as Phase One counties, but can now remain open up to midnight

Multnomah county moves to Phase One, allowing for eased restrictions on the following: personal care businesses and facilities (salons, gyms), all retail businesses, including malls and shopping centers. Now all counties (Phase One and Two) have eased restrictions on these businesses, so coding as statewide

Requires employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, and visitors to wear a mask, face shield, or face covering in businesses listed in the order (eg grocery stores, fitness organizations, personal service providers, retail, restaurants and bars and like venues, etc), as well as for ride-sharing and public transit, when they are not eating or drinking. Also does not require employees to wear them if they are not interacting with patrons and can maintain at least 6 ft of distancing. Applies to the following counties: Clackamas, Hood River, Lincoln, Marion, Multnomah, Polk, and Washington (mixture of Phase One and Phase Two counties). Starting on 20200701, Clatsop added to the list: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=36861

Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when at a place of business (sectors listed in the order), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Applies to the following counties: Clackamas, Hood River, Lincoln, Marion, Multnomah, Polk, and Washington (mixture of Phase One and Phase Two counties). Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.

Expands mandate statewide, requiring employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, and visitors to wear a mask, face shield, or face covering in businesses listed in the order (eg grocery stores, fitness organizations, personal service providers, retail, restaurants and bars and like venues, etc), as well as for ride-sharing and public transit, when they are not eating or drinking. Also does not require employees to wear them if they are not interacting with patrons and can maintain at least 6 ft of distancing.

Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering indoors for all counties, expanding the previous order that was only applicable to a subset of counties. Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.

Restricts social gatherings indoors to 10 or fewer, expanding restrictions for Phase One counties (Lincoln, Washington, Clackamas, Multnomah, Union). Continues previous restrictions for outdoor gatherings in general and religious gatherings.

Restricts social gatherings indoors to 10 or fewer, expanding restrictions for Phase Two counties (31 counties). Continues previous restrictions for outdoor gatherings in general and religious gatherings.

Expands requirement to wear face coverings in outdoor public spaces when 6 ft of distance cannot be maintained, and continues previous order (i.e., public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when in indoor public spaces), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Coding to Mandate3 as it applies to broadly across indoor and outdoor settings. Starting 20200724, mandate is somewhat strengthened, applying to individuals 5 years and older: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37003. Modified on 20210511: vaccinated individuals are not required to wear masks in uncrowded outdoor spaces or at private indoor gatherings with other vaccinated individuals or one unvaccinated household. https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2288K.pdf  Eased on 20210518 https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2288K.pdf

Statewide, somewhat expands restrictions, now limiting capacity no more than 100 (previously just needed to maintain at least 6 distancing). Also must close by 10 pm. No formal order has been published, so the governors press release is being used for documentation.

Statewide, somewhat expands restrictions, now limiting capacity no more than 100 (previously just needed to maintain at least 6 distancing). Also must close by 10 pm. No formal order has been published, so the governors press release is being used for documentation.

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay at Home Status, requiring bars and like venues to close for in-person operations (take-out and delivery only). Ends on 20200821 as Umatilla goes back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein all indoor and outdoor social gatherings are limited to 10 people while civic, cultural, and faith-based gatherings are limited to 25. Eased on 20200821 with Umatilla going back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay Home status, wherein personal care businesses and facilities (salons, gyms), retail businesses such as malls and shopping centers must close. On 20200821, this was ended for Umatilla: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay at Home Status, requiring restaurants to close for in-person operations (take-out and delivery only). On 20200821, Umatilla moves back to Phase One, allowing for in-person services: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein (quote) all individuals should minimize all non-essential travel and stay at their home or place of residence as much as possible (quote). Coded as a recommended stay-at-home order. Ended on 20200821 when Umatilla is approved to go back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Malheur, Marion, Multnomah, Jackson, Umatilla go to two-week pause, reducing social gatherings to no more than 6 people. More counties are added to the Two-Week Pause on 20201111 https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37679

Travel advisory issued, (quote) Persons arriving in Oregon from other states or countries, including returning Oregon residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. These persons should limit their interactions to their immediate household. This recommendation does not apply to individuals who cross state or country borders for essential travel. (quote) Eased on 20200604  Individuals arriving in Oregon from other states or counties for non-essential travel, including Oregon residents, should, but are not required to: Self quarantine for 10 days after arrival and limit their interactions with those outside their immediate household.  Advisory does not extend to people who are fully vaccinated. Quarantine period eased from 14 to 10 days. (quote)

Statewide, bars and like venues must move to take-out and delivery only as part of the Two-Week Freeze. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Statewide, social gatherings are limited to no more than 6 people indoors and outdoors (from no more than 2 households), and faith-based organizations can have a maximum of 25 people indoor and 50 people outdoors. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

The following businesses must close as part of the Two-Week Pause: gyms and fitness organizations and indoor recreational facilities, movie theaters, bowling alleys, arcades and pools, as well as recreational and youth sports. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Statewide, restaurants and like venues must move to take-out and delivery only with the Two-Week Pause. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Lower risk (Green) counties can have bars re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am.

Moderate risk (Yellow) and High Risk (Orange) counties can reopen to indoor services at different levels of capacity indoors and outdoors, must close at 1100 pm.  Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Extreme risk (Red) counties can only have bars re-open for outdoor services at a maximum of 50 people capacity, 6 people per table, limit 2 households. Take-away remains highly recommended. Must close by 1100 pm. Eased to 100 people outdoors on 20210428: https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3461.pdf

Lower risk (Green) counties can have up to 10 people indoors (no more than 4 households recommended) and 12 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 75 pct capacity indoors, a maximum of 300 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf.

Moderate risk (Yellow) counties can have up to 8 people indoors (no more than 2 households recommended) and 10 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 50 pct capacity or 150 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 250 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

High risk (Orange) counties can have up to 6 people indoors (no more than 2 households recommended) and 8 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 25 pct capacity or 150 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 200 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Extreme risk (Red) counties can have up to 6 people indoors and outdoors (no more than 2 households recommended) for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 25 pct capacity or 100 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 150 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Lower risk (Green), Moderate risk (Yellow), and High Risk (Orange) counties can re-open entertainment and recreational establishments at 50 pct capacity indoors (varying maximum of people) and varying maximum number of people outdoors. As of 20210204, indoor venues must close at midnight in Green counties and 11pm in all other counties: https://web.archive.org/web/20210205064642/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3461.pdf.
Extreme risk (Red counties) can only have entertainment and recreational establishments re-open to outdoor services up to 50 people

Lower risk (Green) counties can have restaurants and like venues re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am.

Moderate risk (Yellow) and High Risk (Orange) counties can reopen to indoor services at different levels of capacity indoors and outdoors, must close at 1100 pm. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Extreme risk (Red) counties can only have restaurants and like venues re-open for outdoor services at a maximum of 50 people capacity, 6 people per table, limit 2 households. Take-away remains highly recommended. Must close by 1100 pm. Eased to 100 people on 20210428: https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3461.pdf

Eases restrictions in Extreme Risk counties, where indoor recreation and fitness establishments (gyms, fitness organizations, recreational sports, pools, personal training, school sports, dance, campsites, etc) and entertainment establishments (including aquariums, theaters, arenas, concert halls, gardens, museums, entertainment activities, event spaces) are allowed to operate under the following conditions: max of 6 people indoors at facilities over 500 square feet. For facilities smaller than 500 square feet, 1:1 customer experiences, such as personal training are allowed. Max 50 people outdoor. Eased on 20210428 to permit 100 people outdoors: https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3461.pdf. All entertainment venues must close by 11pm. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view
Lower risk (Green) counties can re-open entertainment and recreational establishments at 50 pct capacity indoors and outdoors. Must close by midnight.

Moderate risk (Yellow) and High Risk (Orange) counties can re-open entertainment and recreational establishments at 25 pct or 50 people (Orange) to 50 pct or 100 people capacity (Yellow) indoors and 15 pct (Orange) to 25 pct (Yellow) capacity outdoors. All venues must close by 11pm. Eased for Moderate counties on 20210527, such that establishments in Moderate counties may open to 20 pct capacity indoors or 100 people, whichever is larger (from the smaller of 50 pct or 100 people): https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3461.pdf Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Continues to apply the business mask mandate to all individuals unless a business, employer or faith institution has a policy for checking for proof of vaccination status of individuals, in which case vaccinated individuals do not have to wear masks any longer. Otherwise, it continues requiring employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, and visitors to wear a mask, face shield, or face covering in businesses listed in the order (eg grocery stores, fitness organizations, personal service providers, retail, restaurants and bars and like venues, etc), as well as for ride-sharing and public transit, when they are not eating or drinking. Also does not require employees to wear them if they are not interacting with patrons and can maintain at least 6 ft of distancing.  Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Modifies mask mandate such that vaccinated individuals are not required to wear masks either indoors or outdoors (except when riding public transportation,  in health care settings, and in jails). Eases mask mandate for unvaccinated individuals, who no longer have to wear masks outdoors, but they are recommended to do so. Prior mandate stipulations otherwise continue: unvaccinated individuals must wear face coverings when in indoor public spaces, as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 5 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Coding to Mandate2 as it still applies broadly to indoor settings for unvaccinated individuals.  Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Capacity limits no longer apply to vaccinated individuals in Lower Risk counties with proof of vaccination in vaccinated-only sections. Lower risk (Green) counties can have bars re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Capacity limits no longer apply to vaccinated individuals in Lower Risk counties with proof of vaccination in vaccinated-only sections. Lower risk (Green) counties can have up to 10 people indoors (no more than 4 households recommended) and 12 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 75 pct capacity indoors, a maximum of 300 people outdoors. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Capacity limits no longer apply to vaccinated individuals in Lower Risk counties with proof of vaccination in vaccinated-only sections. Lower risk (Green) counties can re-open entertainment and recreational establishments at 50 pct capacity indoors and outdoors. Must close by midnight. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Capacity limits no longer apply to vaccinated individuals in Lower Risk counties with proof of vaccination in vaccinated-only sections. Lower risk (Green) counties can have restaurants and like venues re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am. Ended on 20210630 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view

Eases travel advisory, (quote) Individuals arriving in Oregon from other states or counties for non-essential travel, including Oregon residents, should, but are not required to: Self quarantine for 10 days after arrival and limit their interactions with those outside their immediate household.  Advisory does not extend to people who are fully vaccinated. Quarantine period eased from 14 to 10 days. Ended on 20210630: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJ0W1RrRpAGJvvZNl4TJneql8a7t6B3c/view
Oregon recommends universal mask wearing in all indoor settings: https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/ORDHS/bulletins/2ea4ad0.

The governor directed the OHA and the Board of Education to create a policy mandating mask wearing in all K-12 schools. The rule will require (quote) face coverings in all indoor school settings, both public and private, for all individuals two years and older, including all students, staff, contractors, volunteers and visitors. (end quote) There are exceptions for eating and drinking, playing instruments, swimming, sports where mask wearing could introduce a strangulation risk, and if mask wearing violates ADA provisions. https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=64174

State employees, visitors, and customers are directed to wear masks in government buildings. (quote) The new guidance requires all state employees (regardless of vaccination status) in any indoor state agency space to wear face coverings; the requirement also applies to visitors and customers who enter state agency indoor spaces. (quote)

All K-12 schools to close for 10 business days effective 20200316. Expiry would then be 20200330. Extended through 20200406: https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/Education-Details.aspx?newsid=814 Extended through further notice: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-and-sec-of-health-expand-stay-at-home-order-to-carbon-cumberland-dauphin-and-schuylkill-counties-extend-school-closures-indefinitely/ Eased on 20200603, when green counties can open for in-person instruction: https://www.education.pa.gov/Documents/K-12/Safe%20Schools/COVID/GuidanceDocuments/Pre-K%20to%2012%20Reopening%20Guidance.pdf

Limited operations required (to carry out, delivery, drive-through only) in bars in Alleghany, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, and Montgomery counties. In effect at 1201 am on 20200316 and for 14 days, so expiry coded to 20200330
Limited operations required (to carry out, delivery, drive-through only) in restaurants in Alleghany, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, and Montgomery counties

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive-though only): bars. In effect 20200317 at 1201 am https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-puts-statewide-covid-19-mitigation-efforts-in-effect-stresses-need-for-every-pennsylvanian-to-take-action-to-stop-the-spread/ Easing for green phase counties began on 20200529 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-issues-updated-green-phase-order-guidance-on-dining-and-professional-sports/

(quote) strongly encourages the suspension of large gatherings, events, and gatherings of more than 10 people...The Wolf Administration encourages religious leaders to exercise discretion in order to mitigate the spread of illness (quote). We thus are coding this recommendation as not applying to religious gatherings.

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive-though only): restaurants In effect 20200317 at 12:01 am https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-puts-statewide-covid-19-mitigation-efforts-in-effect-stresses-need-for-every-pennsylvanian-to-take-action-to-stop-the-spread/. Easing for green phase counties began on 20200529 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-issues-updated-green-phase-order-guidance-on-dining-and-professional-sports/

Non-life sustaining businesses closure to be enacted on 20200319 at 8 pm. Was supposed to go in effect on 20200321 at 1201 am, but enforcement was delayed until 20200323 at 8 am, and thus 20200323 is used as the date of enactment: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/waiver-extension-revised-timing-of-enforcement-monday-march-23-at-800-am/ In effect for the duration of the disaster emergency (i.e., the mechanism by which the governor can impose these restrictions). Initial easing occurred on 20200501, allowing construction businesses to reopen (was originally supposed to occur on 20200508, but governor permitted them to reopen a week earlier): https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-issues-guidance-as-construction-industry-prepares-to-resume-work-may-1/ Incremental easing of the non-essential business closure continues through 20200703, at which all counties are at the green phase

(quote) gatherings of individuals outside of the home are generally prohibited except as may be required to access, support or provide life sustaining services (quote). Coded as a 0 for non-religious gathering limits, as gatherings outside the home are prohibited but religious institutions are exempt per the governor press release: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/governor-wolf-and-health-secretary-issue-stay-at-home-orders-to-7-counties-to-mitigate-spread-of-covid-19/ Applicable to individuals residing in Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County. More counties are added over time

(quote) All individuals residing in Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County are ordered to stay at home except as needed to access, support, or provide life sustaining business, emergency, or government service (quote). In effect at 8 pm on 20200323, in effect until 20200406. Counties are added gradually over time, also extended to 20200430: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/20200330-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf

With the statewide stay-at-home order, the following also becomes statewide: (quote) gatherings of individuals outside of the home are generally prohibited except as may be required to access, support or provide life sustaining services (quote). Coded as a 0 for non-religious gathering limits, as gatherings outside the home are prohibited but religious institutions are exempt. Eased on 20200508, permitting up to 25 people gatherings in counties that move to yellow phase: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/20200507-TWW-Yellow-Phase-Order.pdf

Stay-at-home order becomes statewide, in effect to 20200430. Extended to 20200605: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200420-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf Eased on 20200508, with first counties moving to yellow phase and no longer under the stay-at-home order: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-sec-of-health-take-actions-on-stay-at-home-orders-issue-yellow-phase-orders/ Fully ended on 20200605: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/reopening-phase-orders-updated-to-include-10-additional-counties-moving-to-yellow-and-16-to-green-on-june-5/
Recommends that all Pennsylvanians wear a mask any time they leave their homes for life-sustaining reasons

Requires businesses to provide masks for employees to wear during their time at business and make it a mandatory requirement to wear masks while on the work site, except whth the student is using break time to eat or drink. Expanded on 20200701, broadening requirements for their use (i.e., any kind of work with contact with the public, any outdoor location where physical distancing is not possible, working in or walking through common areas): https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/20200701-SOH-Universal-Face-Coverings-Order.pdf Expanded on 20201118, including broadened requirements for employee mask use (i.e., any kind of work with contact with the public, any outdoor location where physical distancing is not possible, working in or walking through common areas). Now requires that a business must (quote) require that all people, including their employees, customers... and visitors, wear a face covering and take reasonable steps to enforce the requirement. (quote) Allows businesses to decline service to individuals who are not wearing a face covering and not exempt from wearing a face covering. https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201117-SOH-Universal-Face-Coverings-Order-Update.pdf

Requires all customers to wear masks while on business premises and deny entry to individuals not wearing masks. However, individuals who cannot wear a mask due to a medical condition or are under 2 years old, per CDC guidance, may enter the premises and are not required to provide documentation of such medical condition. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to all essential retail in operation.

Allows for construction businesses to resume in-person operations on May 1 (one week earlier), conditional on following business guidelines. Eased on 20200529, as counties moving to green phase can resume construction business operations at full capacity: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/20200527-TWW-green-phase-order.pdf Ended when all counties move to green phase on 20200703: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/reopening-phase-orders-updated-to-include-last-county-moving-to-green-on-july-3/

Eases restrictions on golf courses, marinas, privately owned campgrounds to permit limited outdoor recreation. Eased on 20200529, as green phase counties restrictions on outdoor recreational activities (golf, marinas, privately owned campgrounds, etc) lifted beyond any food- or beverage-related restrictions (e.g., restaurants or bars at a golf course). Ended when all counties move to green phase on 20200703: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/reopening-phase-orders-updated-to-include-last-county-moving-to-green-on-july-3/

Counties that move to yellow phase are permitted to have gatherings up to 25 people indoor and outdoors. Religious institutions remain exempt from these restrictions Applies to: Bradford, Cameron, Centre, Clarion, Clearfield, Clinton, Crawford, Elk, Erie, Forest, Jefferson, Lawrence, Lycoming, McKean, Mercer, Montour, Northumberland, Potter, Snyder, Sullivan, Tioga, Union, Venango, Warren. Eased on 20200529, when counties start moving to green phase: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/20200527-TWW-green-phase-order.pdf

Eases restrictions on in-person retail businesses for counties in yellow phase, allowing them re-open for limited in-person services (though curbside and delivery is preferable) up to 50 pct capacity, required masking, etc. Capacity limits are per business operation limits issued by the Department of Health in April: www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/20200504-COVID-19-Business-Guidance.pdf Eased on 20200529, with counties moving to green phase, where a 75 pct capacity limit is permited for retail: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/20200527-TWW-green-phase-order.pdf

For green phase counties (18 as of May 29), on-premises services may resume at indoor and outdoor seating areas in bars may resume conditional on strict adherance to published guidelines (including 50 pct occupancy). Bar seating may only occur if physical distancing is conducted or physical barriers are provided. More counties keep moving to green phase through July 3.

Counties that move to the green phase cannot have gatherings of more than 250 people (includes, but is not limited to, a concert, festival, fair, conference, sporting event, movie showing, or theater performance). Expressly exludes religious gatherings and places of worship. Applies to the following counties: Bradford, Cameron, Centre, Clarion, Clearfield, Crawford, Elk, Forest, Jefferson, Lawrence, McKean, Montour, Potter, Snyder, Sullivan, Tioga, Venango, Warren. More counties move to green phase through July 3, at which this policy becomes statewide.

For counties moving to green phase, eased restrictions apply to the following businesses: personal care services (by appointment only), gyms and spas (encouraged to only go by appointment or reservation), and all other businesses previously closed to in-person operations (e.g., indoor recreation facilities, and entertainment facilities, including theaters, casinos, and nightclubs) may operate up to 50 pct maximum capacity, required masking, ensuing physical distancing.

For green phase counties (18 as of May 29), on-premises services in indoor and outdoor seating areas may resume conditional on strict adherance to published guidelines (including 50 pct occupancy). Bar seating may only occur if physical distancing is conducted or physical barriers are provided

For green counties, schools may open for in-person instruction conditional on following Department of Education requirements. Green counties are currently 18: Bradford, Cameron, Centre, Clarion, Clearfield, Crawford, Elk, Forest, Jefferson, Lawrence, McKean, Montour, Potter, Snyder, Sullivan, Tioga, Venango, and Warren)

Eases restrictions for yellow phase counties, which can reopen for outdoor services only at bars conditional on strict adherance to published guidelines (including 50 pct occupancy). Bar seating may only occur if physical distancing is conducted or physical barriers are provided

Continues yellow phase restrictions, permitting dine-in services for outdoors dining arenas for all yellow counties (33 counties), conditional on strict adherance to published guidelines (including 50 pct occupancy). Bar seating may only occur if physical distancing is conducted or physical barriers are provided

Eases school restrictions for yellow phase counties, permitting pre-K to 12 school sports may resume at schools if they follow guidelines and CDC considerations. Also must follow gathering restrictions corresponding with phase. Depends on expanded DOE guidelines that outline phase scenarios. Schools remain close until at least July 1 for resuming other operations. Applicable to 33 counties in yellow phase.

Expands public mask mandate, requiring individuals to wear face coverings if they are outdoors and unable to maintain distance of six ft from others, in any indoor location, waiting for or riding on public transportation, taxi, ride share and like vehicles, etc. Provides some exemptions (i.e., medical/disability, under the age of 2 years). Coded as Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks across outdoors and indoors settings. Expanded on 20201118 to require face coverings in all indoor locations, irrespective of physical distancing. Continues outdoor requirement when physical distancing is not possible: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201117-SOH-Universal-Face-Coverings-Order-Update.pdf. Beginning 20210427, no longer requires mask use for those who are fully vaccinated outdoors. Continues to require individuals to wear face coverings if they are indoors with individuals of other households, irrespective of physical distancing. Indoor spaces includes retail establishments, gyms, doctors offices, public transportation, and anywhere food is prepared, packaged or served. Continues outdoor requirement if individuals are not vaccinated and unable to maintain physical distancing. Provides some exemptions (i.e., medical/disability, under the age of 2 years). Continues to be coded as Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it still requires masks across outdoors and indoors settings for most individuals. https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/Health-Details.aspx?newsid=1425

(quote) all students, staff and visitors age two and older while in school entities, including public K-12 schools, brick and mortar and cyber charter schools, private and parochial schools (quote) are required to wear face coverings per the Department of Health order on universal face coverings. Allows similar exemptions (e.g., removal while eating or drinking, for individuals for whom wearing a mask would cause medical issues). Expands the policy on 20201118, , corresponding with the expanded public mask mandate (i.e., wearing masks indoors irrespective of physical distancing). Emphasizes to (quote) require that all people, including their employees, customers, teachers, student and visitors, wear a face covering (quote): https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201117-SOH-Universal-Face-Coverings-Order-Update.pdf

(quote) If you have traveled, or plan to travel, to an area where there are high amounts of COVID-19 cases, it is recommended that you stay at home for 14 days upon return to Pennsylvania. If you travel to the following states, you will need to quarantine for 14 days upon return: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah (quote). No expiry provided, not mandated. Expanded to include more states on 20200710 (Delaware, Iowa, Kansas and Oklahoma): https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/dashboard-data-confirms-need-for-masking-social-distancing/ On 2020717, removed Delaware from the list, continued for the others: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200724 added Missouri and Wyoming to the list. State list is now: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Wyoming. On 20200806, Wyoming is removed from the list and Nebraska, North Dakota, and Wisconsin are added to the list: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200814 Iowa, Nebraska, North Carolina, Utah and Winsconsin are removed from the list https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200821 Arizona is removed from the list https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200828 adds Hawaii, Illinois, South Dakota.Adds Hawaii, Illinois, South Dakota https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200904 adds Iowa and North Carolina and removes California https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200911 removes Hawaii, North Carolina and Texas https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20200918 removes Nevada and adds Nebraska and Wisconsin https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx. On 20200925 removes Louisiana and adds Kentucky, Utah, and Texas. https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx On 20201002 removes Georgia and adds Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, Wyoming. https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx. On 20201009 adds Alaska, Indiana, and North Carolina https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx. On 20201016, removes Texas https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx. On 20201030 adds Colorado, Louisiana, Michigan, New Mexico, Rhode Island, and Texas https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx. On 20201106 adds Arizona, Connecticut, Georgia, Massachusetts: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx Added Virginia and removed Louisiana on 20201113: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Travelers.aspx

Lebanon county moves to green phase, bringing the full state under green phase requirements and guidelines: personal care services (by appointment only), gyms and spas (encouraged to only go by appointment or reservation), and all other businesses previously closed to in-person operations (e.g., indoor recreation facilities, and entertainment facilities, including theaters, casinos, and nightclubs) may operate up to 50 pct maximum capacity, required masking, ensuing physical distancing.

Lebanon county moves to green phase, bringing the full state under green phase requirements and guidelines: prohibits gatherings of more than 250 people (includes, but is not limited to, a concert, festival, fair, conference, sporting event, movie showing, or theater performance). Expressly exludes religious gatherings and places of worship.

Lebanon county moves to green phase, bringing the full state under green phase requirements and guidelines. Statewide, eases restrictions on the following businesses: personal care services (by appointment only), gyms and spas (encouraged to only go by appointment or reservation). All other businesses previously closed to in-person operations may operate up to 50 pct maximum occupancy, enforce distancing requirements - these businesses include the following: indoor recreation facilities and all entertainment (such as casinos, theaters).

Lebanon county moves to green phase, bringing the full state under green phase requirements and guidelines: in-person retail businesses can operate up to 75 pct capacity. Expands restrictions on 20201212, requiring capacity limits of 50 pct: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/20201210-TWW-Limited-Time-Mitigation-Order.pdf Returns to 75 pct capacity on 20210104: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-announces-lifting-of-time-limited-mitigation-on-jan-4-dashboard-to-track-progress-of-covid-19-vaccine-distribution/. Extended until 20210521: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Lebanon county moves to green phase, bringing the full state under green phase requirements and guidelines. Eased restraurant restrictions are now statewide, dine-in services in indoor and outdoor seating areas may resume conditional on strict adherence to published guidelines (including 50 pct occupancy). Bar seating may only occur if physical distancing is conducted or physical barriers are provided. Capacity reduce to 25 pct indoors, expanding the policy on 20200716: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-announces-targeted-mitigation-efforts-in-response-to-recent-covid-case-increases/ Capacity is increased to 50 pct on 20200921: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-signs-orders-that-restaurants-may-increase-indoor-occupancy-to-50-percent/ Capacity is reduced to 25 pct capacity on 20201123: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201124-TWW-3rd-Amendment-COVID-19-Proclamation.pdf

Bars must close for on-premises services (take-away permitted). Venues that operate as restaurants (i.e., offer sit-down, dine-in meals) can continue operating and sell alcohol conditional on having a meal purchased alongside it. Due to these stipulations, we are coding this as a closure of bar for on-premises services (takeaway only) as the base policy. Extended to 20210222: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201124-TWW-3rd-Amendment-COVID-19-Proclamation.pdf. Extended until 20210521: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Eased on 20210404 to permit indoor service: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf.

Re-imposes gathering restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibiting indoor events and gatherings of more than 25 people. Outdoor gatherings continue to have a limit of no more than 250 people. Ended mandate with court ruling on 20200914: https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/dailyamerican.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/40/640080a6-f6c8-11ea-977f-d37f8b7ed48f/5f5fd1ffd6dbe.pdf.pdf

Closes nightclubs, prohibiting their operations. Extended to 20210222: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201124-TWW-3rd-Amendment-COVID-19-Proclamation.pdf. Extended until 20210521: 
https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Eased on 20210404 to permit indoor service: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf.
With court ruling ending the gathering mandate, Pennsylvania continues to recommend that gatherings are limited to no more than 25 indoors and no more than 250 outdoors

Expands restrictions on gatherings, making it a mandate from a recommendation. Allows the following for indoor events: 20 pct occupancy for 0-2,000 people, 15 pct occupancy for 2,001-10,000 people, 10 pct occupancy for over 10,000 people up to 3,375. Allows the following for outdoor events: 25 pct occupancy for 0-2,000 people, 20 pct occupancy for 2,001-10,000 people, 15 pct occupancy for over 10,000 people up to 7,500.

(quote) I hereby strongly advise all Pennsylvanians to only leave home to go to work or school, or for essential needs of themselves or persons they are caring for (quote). Announced on 20201230 that temporary measures are allowed to expire on 20210104, thereby ending the recommendation for all Pennsylvanians to only leave home to go to work or school, or for essential needs of themselves or persons they are caring for: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-announces-lifting-of-time-limited-mitigation-on-jan-4-dashboard-to-track-progress-of-covid-19-vaccine-distribution/.

Expands previous quarantine order from a recommendation to a mandate. The quarantine order now requires all travelers to get tested 72 hours prior to entering Pennsylvania or quarantine for 14 days upon entering, and the order now applies to all states and international locations. Exemptions include those who commute to neighboring states for work or health care. Eased on 20201125 to only apply to individuals age 11 and up and to allow for a negative test result during quarantine: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/Documents/Diseases%20and%20Conditions/SOH%20Travel%2011-25-2020.pdf. Further eased on 20201209 to shorten quarantine to 10 days: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/Documents/Diseases%20and%20Conditions/Travel%20Order%20Amendment.pdf. Terminated on 20210301: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/2021.3.1-TWW-termination-of-travel-mitigation-order.pdf.

Expands non-religious gathering restrictions, now limiting indoor and outdoor occupancy of events of up to no more than 500 people for indoors (if the maximum occupancy is 10,000), with different maximums for smaller venues (10 pct capacity for venues with 0-2,000 people capacity, 5 pct capacity for venues of 2,001-10,000 people capacity indoors) and then up to 2500 people outdoors (in venues that can have up to 10000 people, 5 pct capacity up to 2500). For smaller venues, outdoor capacitys are 15 pct capacity for venues 0-2000 and 10 pct capacity for 2,001 to 10,000 people capacity venues. Religious gatherings and places of worship are exempted from these limits. Social distancing continues to be required.

Expands gathering restrictions. Regardless of capacity limits, indoor gatherings of more than 10 persons are prohibited. Indoor religious gatherings are exempt from indoor gathering restrictions but are strongly encouraged to enforce physical distancing and other mitigation measures at gatherings. Outdoor gatherings of more than 50 persons are prohibited. Religious gatherings are exempt: (quote) Churches, synagogues, temples, mosques, and other places of congregate worship are specifically excluded from the limitations set forth above during religious services, these institutions are strongly encouraged to find alternative methods for worship, as in person gatherings pose a significant risk to participants at this time. (quote)

Expands business restrictions, (quote) all in-person businesses in the entertainment industry serving the public within a building or indoor defined area, including, but not limited to, theaters, concert venues, museums, movie theaters, arcades, casinos, bowling alleys, private clubs, and all other similar entertainment, recreational or social facilities, are prohibited from operation (quote). Eased on 20210104, when time-limited mitigation order is lifted: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-announces-lifting-of-time-limited-mitigation-on-jan-4-dashboard-to-track-progress-of-covid-19-vaccine-distribution/

Expands restrictions for gyms and fitness facilities. Indoor operations at gyms and fitness facilities are now prohibited. Outdoor operations may continue, but all participants must wear face coverings and practice physical distancing requirements.   Eased on 20210104, when time-limited mitigation order is lifted: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-announces-lifting-of-time-limited-mitigation-on-jan-4-dashboard-to-track-progress-of-covid-19-vaccine-distribution/

Expands restaurant restrictions. All in-person indoor dining is prohibited. Outdoor dining may continue, where customers are served at tables, physical distancing and masks are required, and alcohol service must stop at 10pm.

Temporary gathering restrictions are allowed to expire on January 4, 2021, thereby reverting to mitigation orders in place on December 11, 2020. Limits indoor and outdoor occupancy of events of up to no more than 500 people for indoors (if the maximum occupancy is 10,000), with different maximums for smaller venues (10 pct capacity for venues with 0-2,000 people capacity, 5 pct capacity for venues of 2,001-10,000 people capacity indoors) and then up to 2500 people outdoors (in venues that can have up to 10000 people, 5 pct capacity up to 2500). For smaller venues, outdoor capacitys are 15 pct capacity for venues 0-2000 and 10 pct capacity for 2,001 to 10,000 people capacity venues. Therefore coded as 500 indoors and 2,500 outdoors to account for maximum capacity limits. Religious gatherings and places of worship are exempted from these limits. Social distancing continues to be required. Extended until 20210521: 
https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf.

Indoor businesses in the entertainment industry including theaters, concert venues, museums, movie theaters, arcades, casinos, bowling alleys, and other social and recreational facilities may operate at up to 50 pct of the maximum capacity. Extended until 20210521: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Eased on 20210404 to permit 75 pct capacity: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

All gyms and fitness facilities are permitted to continue indoor operations at up to 50 pct occupancy but must prioritize outdoor physical fitness activities and mandates face coverings. Extended until 20210521: 
https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Eased on 20210404 to permit 75 pct capacity: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Temporary restaurant restrictions are allowed to expire on January 4, 2021, thereby reverting to mitigation orders in place on December 11, 2020. Allows restaurants to operate at 50 pct capacity for indoor services if self-certified and 25 pct capacity if not self-certified. Alcohol sales must cease by 1100 pm and on-premise alcohol consumption must cease by 1200 am. Customers must be served at tables, physical distancing, masks, etc are required. Extended until 20210521: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/TWW-COVID-disaster-emergency-amendment-digital-sig-2-19-21.pdf. Eased on 20210404 to permit 75 pct capacity for self-certified and 50 pct capacity if not self-certified. Removes restrictions on alcohol sales: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Eases gathering restrictions by removing absolute cap on number of people. Venues are now permitted to operate at 15 pct capacity for indoor events and 20 pct capacity for outdoor events. Religious gatherings and places of worship are exempted from these limits. Social distancing continues to be required. Eased on 20210404 to permit 25 pct capacity for indoor events and 50 pct capacity for outdoor events: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2021.4.1-TWW-v2-amended-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf. Further eased on 20210517: Venues are now permitted to operate at 50 pct capacity for indoor events (from 25 pct) and 75 pct capacity for outdoor events (from 50 pct). Religious gatherings and places of worship are exempted from these limits. Social distancing no longer required, requires attendees and workers to wear masks or face coverings in compliance with the Updated Order Requiring Universal Face Coverings. https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/2021.5.13-TWW-amendment-to-mitigation-enforcement-immunity-order.pdf Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Eases bar restrictions by allowing indoor service for seated patrons without requiring food purchase. Retail food service establishments, including bars, may operate at up to 50 pct capacity or up to 75 pct capacity if they self-certify. Social distancing and masks are required. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Permits nightclubs to reopen to 50 pct capacity. Patrons must remain seated for bar service, and social distancing and face coverings are required. Extended to 20210820 https://www.pema.pa.gov/Governor-Proclamations/Documents/Proclamation-Amending-Disaster-Emergency-COVID19-052021.pdf Ended on 20210531 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-pennsylvania-businesses-events-venues-return-to-100-capacity-on-memorial-day-masking-order-remains-until-70-of-adults-fully-vaccinated-or-june-28/

Adds exemption for vaccinated individuals. Specifies businesses must prohibit unmasked customers from entering any indoor premises and that all individuals are required to use face coverings in a manner consistent with current guidance issued by the CDC, and any subsequent guidance issued by the CDC. At this time, the CDC recommends the use of face coverings for all unvaccinated individuals in indoor and outdoor public spaces. Those who are fully vaccinated, however, do not need to wear a mask in most indoor and outdoor locations, hence being exempted from the state mandate.  Ended on 20210628: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Guidance/Universal-Masking-FAQ.aspx

Adds exemption for vaccinated individuals. Specifies that individuals wear face coverings (quote) in a manner consistent with current guidance issued by the CDC, and any subsequent guidance issued by the CDC (quote). At this time, the CDC recommends the use of face coverings for all unvaccinated individuals in indoor and outdoor public spaces. Those who are fully vaccinated, however, do not need to wear a mask in most indoor and outdoor locations, hence being exempted from the state mandate. As masks are still required indoors and outdoors for unvaccinated individuals, coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel. Ended on 20210628: https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Guidance/Universal-Masking-FAQ.aspx

Eases quarantine restriction. Any person coming to Rhode Island for a non-work-related purpose from locations with a high community spread rate must immediately self-quarantine for 10 days (down from 14 days) or until such time as they receive a negative COVID-19 test. Does not apply to a person who has a negative COVID19 test from a specimen taken no more than seventy-two (72) hours prior to arrival in Rhode Island. This threshold of (quote) high community spread is higher than a 5 pct positivity rate of COVID-19. (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-09.pdf. PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All Rhode Island residents are required to stay home (quote). As of 20200509, Repeals the portion of the stay-at-home EO to stay at home, ending the order http://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-32.pdf

All non-critical retail businesses to cease operations as of 20200330. Easing began on 20200509, permitting non-critical retail businesses to reopen for limited services: http://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-32.pdf

Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 must self-isolate until they have had no fever for at least 72 hours, they have experienced resolution of symptoms and at least 7 days have passed since their symptoms appeared . Family or household members residing with an individual who tests positive must self-quarantine for 14 days. (quote) any person who is in a place open to the public, whether indoors or outdoors, shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering (quote). Also explicitly requires masks or cloth face coverings when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, other retail stores, and on public transit, taxi, ride sharing or similar service. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly calls for mask use across indoor and outdoor settings. Mandate3 Mask rule extended for a month on 20200803. Aside from this new exception, the following continues to be required: (quote) Any person who is in a place open to the public, whether indoors or outdoors, shall continue to cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering unless doing so would damage the persons health. No person under two years of age or any person whose health would be damaged thereby shall be required to wear a face covering. (quote) Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly calls for mask use across indoor and outdoor settings, apart from the narrow exemption for those who are vaccinated and outdoors. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-42.pdf

Restaurant restrictions eased, allowing for outdoor portions of venues to have limited in-person services https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-40.pdf. Eased on 20200601 to allow in-person operations.
