Eases bar restrictions allowing for indoor dining at 50 pct capacity. Service to standing customers is prohibited. On 20200630, further eases restrictions on bars, which can now operate at 66 percent of capacity. On 20200807, adds a minor restriction, (quote) From 11.00 p.m. until closing, a licensee must close their bar area, including but not limited to the bar counter and seating at the bar counter, and ensure that the bar area is not accessible to patrons. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateIssued and DateEnacted, added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Original easing of the 5 person gathering restrictions, now groups of 15 allowed. Eased to being 25 people gatherings indoors on 20200629
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on certain personal care businesses (hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning parlors, estheticians, and massage therapists ) and gyms and fitness centers allowing them to reopen subject to guidelines. For gyms and fitness centers, no more than 1 person per 150 sq ft, and maximum of 15 people with distancing for group classes. Also eases restrictions on some recreational businesses and historical/cultural establishments, may conduct limited outdoor operations and, under certain circumstances, indoor activites that go along with them (i..e, 25 pct capacity). Examples of these operations include outdoor mini golf courses, batting cages, go-kart tracks, rail biking, bumper cars, zoos, horseback riding, and historical sites. State parks and beaches are open as well. Also permits in-person offices to re-open at limited capacity. Starting on 20200630, begain easing more, permitting higher capacity limits and opening of more sectors (though night clubs remained close): https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-50.pdf. In-person office restrictions extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extends rules on office-based restrictions. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. On 20201221, restrictions for offices are extended to 20210120. Extends rules on office-based restrictions to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf. Extends rules on office-based restrictions to 20210228 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-09.pdf On 20210205, eases office-based businesses. Now allows up to 33 pct of workers may work on site at the same time. Extended to 20210307 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-11.pdf. Extended to 20210326 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-18.pdf. Extended to 20210405 thttps://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-22.pdf. On 20210319, eases restrictions on personal care services (now allowing no more than 1 customer per 50 sq ft) and eases rules on office-based businesses, now allowing up to 50 pct of workers to work on site at the same time. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf Extended to 20210517 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-36.pdf On 20210507, Eases rules on office-based businesses, allowing them to operate at up to 80 pct office capacity (up from 50 pct). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf. Expiration date moved up from 20210528 to 20210522 and 3 ft social distancing requirements removed: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Ends restrictions on office based businesses on 20210521, no longer limiting capacity. Businesses are encouraged to (quote) remain vigilant (quote) and may choose to implement stricter protocols, but this is left to their discretion. (quote) All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOHs regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at ReopeningRI.com (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions allowing for indoor dining at 50 pct capacity. Service to standing customers is prohibited. On 20200630, further eases restrictions on restaurants, which can now operate at 66 percent of capacity. On 20200807, adds a minor restriction , (quote) From 11.00 p.m. until closing, a licensee must close their bar area, including but not limited to the bar counter and seating at the bar counter, and ensure that the bar area is not accessible to patrons. (quote)

Variable mask requirements based on re-opening scenarios, but at minimum requires students over the age of 2 on buses to wear masks under the full-reopening and partial reopening scenario, and high school students are required to wear masks if 6 ft of distancing is not possible.
Gatherings of up to 25 indoors are now permitted. Also allows gatherings of up to 50 outdoors. Religious gatherings are permitted up to 125 people indoors and 250 people outdoors.

Allows the reopening of convention hall, theaters and performance venues provided that they maintain 66 percent capacity or fewer than 125 people. Fairs and festivals are also able to reopen provided they remain at 66 percent capacity or under 250 people. On 20201105, reduces capacity limits to 50 pct for these venues: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-95.pdf

(quote) All indoor and outdoor social gatherings of more than fifteen (15) people in any public or private space are prohibited. (quote) Includes exceptions for receptions for weddings (50 indoor and 100 outdoor under strict distancing guidelines). Indoor gatherings at religious institutions can have 125 max. (quote) religious and faithbased organizations may conduct indoor in-person activities up to 66 pct percent of worship space capacity, subject to a cap of one hundred and twenty-five (125) people and to the Phase III guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations (quote). Outdoor religious events can have 250, but distancing and masking must be in effect. All houses of worship must develop a COVID control plan. Extended to 20201028 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-79.pdf. Extended to 20201128 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-88.pdf

(quote) All indoor and outdoor social gatherings of more than ten (10) people in any public or private space are prohibited. (quote) Includes exceptions for receptions for weddings (50 indoor and 100 outdoor under strict distancing guidelines). Indoor gatherings at religious institutions can have 125 max. (quote) religious and faithbased organizations may conduct indoor in-person activities up to 66 pct percent of worship space capacity, subject to a cap of one hundred and twenty-five (125) people and to the Phase III guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations (quote). Outdoor religious events can have 250, but distancing and masking must be in effect. All houses of worship must develop a COVID control plan.

On 20201108, Extends restrictions on bars but changes permitted hours of operation (quote) Effective Sunday, November 8th restaurants and bars may serve patrons on-site, indoors and outdoors, until 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and until 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, after which times restaurants and bars shall only offer pickup, delivery and drive-through service. (quote) Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Continues previous restrictions (can operate at 66 percent of capacity). On 20201130, Expands capacity restrictions on bars. An establishments indoor dining capacity is limited to 33pct ( was 66pct) of an establishment regular seating capacity. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Eased on 20201221, where restaurants are allowed to have indoor dining at 50 pct capacity (up from 33 pct). Services to seated customers only, up to 8 people can be seated at an individual table indoors but must be from the same household. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf

Effective Sunday, November 8 recreational or entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments shall not operate after 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday or after 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Extends restrictions on recreational and historical/cultural establishments. Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. (quote) Subject to strict adherence to social distancing, masking, screening and sanitation protocols, recreational or entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments, that are not venues of assembly, may conduct indoor and outdoor operations subject to a capacity limit of up to 66 pct capacity or 1 per 100 sq ft.

On 20201108, extends restrictions on restaurants but changes permitted hours of operation (quote) Effective Sunday, November 8th restaurants and bars may serve patrons on-site, indoors and outdoors, until 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and until 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, after which times restaurants and bars shall only offer pickup, delivery and drive-through service. (quote) Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Continues previous restrictions (can operate at 66 percent of capacity). On 20201130, Expands capacity restrictions on restaurants. An establishments indoor dining capacity is limited to 33pct ( was 66pct) of an establishment regular seating capacity. https//governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Eased on 20201221, where restaurants are allowed to have indoor service at 50 pct capacity (up from 33 pct). Services to seated customers only, up to 8 people can be seated at an individual table indoors but must be from the same household. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf

Effective Sunday, November 8, all Rhode Island residents are advised to stay home from 10 pm to 5 am Sunday through Thursday unless traveling to or from work or school, traveling for medical treatment or obtaining necessities (food, medicine, gas, etc.). For Friday and Saturday, residents are advised to stay home from 1030 pm to 5 am. Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Extended to 20201214. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf. Ended on 20210129 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-09.pdf

Effective 20201119, expands gathering restrictions. (quote) attendance at all indoor public and private social gatherings, including holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations shall be limited to members of a single household (quote), so numeric limitations coded as 0. Religious gatherings are limited to 125 people indoors and 150 outdoors.

Personal service businesses and gyms shall not operate after 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday or after 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguishing between different curfews by day. (quote)Personal care services can have 1 customer per 100 sq ft. (quote) Personal services businesses and operations, including, but not limited to, hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning parlors, estheticians, and massage therapists may open subject to all of the requirements of their professional or facility licensing, the requirements of the Phase III guidelines for personal services at https://ReopeningRI.com and regulations set forth by RIDOH. Such personal service businesses may allow up to one customer per 100 square feet. (quote). For gyms, Phase III rules continue. (quote) Outdoor group fitness activities are preferred but are limited to one person per 100 square feet, with all physical distancing guidelines to be observed. (quote). Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Restrictions for personal care services are extended. Restrictions on gyms are eased: Capcity limits: one (1) person per 150 square feet with individuals remaining fourteen (14) feet apart indoors and six (6) feet apart outdoors, subject to Phase III guidance. (quote). Masks must be worn at all times.https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf.

Effective 20201130, expands gathering restrictions for outdoor gatherings, which is now 150 people (from 250 people). (quote) attendance at all indoor public and private social gatherings, including holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations shall be limited to members of a single household (quote), so numeric limitations coded as 0. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf. Extended to 20210228: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-09.pdf. Eased on 20210212 to allow indoor gatherings of two households and outdoor gatherings of three households: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-13.pdf.

Expands restrictions on gyms and fitness centers. Must close all indoor operations. Outdoor gym and fitness activities may continue but outdoor group fitness classes are not permitted. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf.

Expands restrictions on convention halls, theaters, concert halls, performances venues, requiring them to close during the Pause. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf.

Eases restrictions on convention halls, theaters, concert halls, allowing for indoor occupancy up to 25 pct capcity, up to 125 people. Extended to 20210218 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-05.pdf. Extended to 20210228 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-09.pdf Extended to 20210307 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-11.pdf. Eased on 20210212, now allowing indoor occupancy up to 40 pct capcity from 25 pct, still capped at 125 people. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-13.pdf. Extended to 20210326 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-18.pdf. Extended to 20210405 thttps://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-22.pdf Further eased on 20210319, now allowing for indoor and outdoor occupancy up to 50 pct capcity, capped at 250 people indoors and 500 people outdoors. Also announces two more phases of eased restrictions for outdoor venues of assembly, which may operate up to 10 pct of capacity with a cap of 1,000 people beginning 20210501 and with more than 1,000 people beginning 20210714. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf On 20210409, this schedule of phased easing is accelerated. Now, venues of assembly may allow (quote) 50 pct capacity with a cap of 250 people indoors and 500 people outdoors (quote). Additionally, any event occurring between 20210501 and 20210514 when these restrictions will be further eased, (quote) may apply for approval from the Department of Business Regulation (DBR) to hold events up to 500 people indoors or 1000 outdoors (quote) by submitting a number of application materials and requirements. Beginning 20210515, further eases restrictions for indoor and outdoor venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues, and theaters, now allowing (quote) 50 pct capacity with a cap of 500 people indoors and 1000 people outdoors (quote). This easing accelerates the previously announced easing for outdoor venues, originally slated to occur on 20210715. Beginning 20210604, eases restrictions for indoor and outdoor venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues, and theaters, now allowing (quote) 50 pct capacity with a cap of 1000 people indoors and 2000 people outdoors (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-34.pdf On 20210507, eases restrictions for indoor and outdoor venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues, and theaters. This easing takes places ahead of the planned easing schedule to take place on 20210515 and 20210604 and eases those restrictions to a greater extent than originally planned. Effective immediately, these venues may operate at up to 80 pct capacity with a cap of 500 indoors and with no limit outdoors, apart from 3 ft of distance between individuals. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf. Eased on 20210518 to remove 3 ft distancing requirements: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Ends restrictions on indoor and outdoor venues of assembly on 20210521, no longer limiting capacity. Businesses are encouraged to (quote) remain vigilant (quote) and may choose to implement stricter protocols, but this is left to their discretion. (quote) All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOHs regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at ReopeningRI.com (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

Extends bar restrictions allowing for indoor dining at 50 pct capacity. Services to seated customers only, up to 8 people can be seated at an individual table indoors but must be from the same household. (quote) Service to standing customers (e.g., in a bar area) is prohibited with the exception of food pick-up, must follow existing Phase III rules and make a COVID Control plan. (quote) No longer has a time restriction. On 20210205, eases restrictions on table seating, allowing groups from two households to be seated at indoor tables and groups from three households to be seated at outdoor tables, but no more than 8 people total. Indoor dining remains at 50 pct capacity and other restrictions such as (quote) regulations prohibiting service to standing customers and mingling or congregating (quote) remain in place. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-11.pdf. On 20210212, restrictions are further eased, allowing bars and restaurants to open bar seating areas until 23h00, provided parties are limited (quote) to two households per party, up to a maximum of four people in the party, and separate parties must be seated at least six feet apart unless a plexiglass or similar partition is installed, in which case separate parties must be seated at least three feet apart. Parties at bar areas may not be seated for more than 90 minutes (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-13.pdf Extended to 20210326 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-18.pdf. Further eased on 20210305 to allow up to 66 pct capacity indoors. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-22.pdf. Extended to 20210411, but now amends restrictions on service in bar areas after 23h00: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-24.pdf. On 20210319, restrictions on bars and restaurants are further eased, now allowing indoor dining up to 75 pct capacity and lifting the households per party restriction for both indoor, outdoor, and bar seating (parties are still limited to eight people and four in bar areas). In bar areas, parties still may not be seated for more than 90 minutes and bar areas must close service at 23h00, exclusive of customers who have ordered food before 23h00 can remain until midnight. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf. Slightly eased on 20210326 to permit parties of 10 (from 8) outdoors: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-29.pdf. Extended to 20210517 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-36.pdf  Further eases restrictions on bars and restaurants on 20210507, allowing indoor dining up to 80 pct capacity (up from 75) and outdoor dining with no capacity restrictions, provided 3 ft of distance is maintained between parties in both settings. No longer limits party sizes indoors, outdoors, or in bar areas. Also removes time limit for parties seated in bar areas and the requirement to close service in bars at 23h00. Service to standing people is still prohibited. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf. Eased on 20210518 to remove 3 ft distancing requirements: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Ends restrictions on bars on 20210521. Standing service now allowed, no capacity restrictions for indoor dining, plexiglass no longer required in bar areas. Bars are encouraged to (quote) remain vigilant (quote) and may choose to implement stricter protocols, but this is left to their discretion. (quote) All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOHs regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at ReopeningRI.com (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

Extends restrictions for indoor entertainment, historical/cultural establishments, personal care services, and gyms without curfew limits. Recreational or entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments, that are not venues of assembly, may conduct indoor and outdoor operations subject to a capacity limit of up 1 person per 150 square feet. For museums, capacity is limited to 1 person per 100 square feet. Personal care services can have 1 customer per 100 sq ft. Gyms have a capacity limit of one (1) person per 150 square feet with individuals remaining fourteen (14) feet apart indoors and six (6) feet apart outdoors, subject to Phase III guidance. (quote). Masks must be worn at all times. On 20210205, eases capcity limits for gyms and recreational/cultural/historical facilities. Capacity is eased to 1 person per 125 sq ft. These changes and previous restrictions for personal care services extended to 20210307: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-11.pdf Extended to 20210326 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-18.pdf. Extended to 20210405 thttps://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-22.pdf Eased on 20210319, allowing gyms and fitness centers to operate with an indoor capacity of 1 person per 50 square feet, down from 100, and require 6 feet of physical distance both indoors and outdoors. Masks must be worn at all times. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf. Extended to 20210517 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-36.pdf On 20210507, eases restrictions for personal care businesses, allowing them to operate at up to 80 pct capacity. (quote) Personal services businesses and operations, including, but not limited to, hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning parlors, estheticians, and massage therapists may open subject to all of the requirements of their professional or facility licensing, the requirements for personal services at https://ReopeningRI.com and regulations set forth by RIDOH. (quote). Also Eases restrictions on gyms and fitness centers, allowing them to operate indoors with a capacity of 80 pct indoors and outdoors with no capacity restrictions, provided 3 feet of physical distance is maintained between individuals in both settings. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf. Eased on 20210518 to remove 3 ft distancing requirements: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Ends restrictions on personal care services, gyms and fitness centers, indoor entertainment businesses, and cultural or historical establishments on 20210521, no longer limiting capacity. Businesses are encouraged to (quote) remain vigilant (quote) and may choose to implement stricter protocols, but this is left to their discretion. (quote) All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOHs regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at ReopeningRI.com (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

On 20210319, restrictions on bars and restaurants are further eased, now allowing indoor dining up to 75 pct capacity and lifting the households per party restriction for both indoor, outdoor, and bar seating (parties are still limited to eight people and four in bar areas). In bar areas, parties still may not be seated for more than 90 minutes and bar areas must close service at 23h00, exclusive of customers who have ordered food before 23h00 can remain until midnight. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf. Slightly eased on 20210326 to permit parties of 10 (from 8) outdoors: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-29.pdf. Extended to 20210517 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-36.pdf Further eases restrictions on bars and restaurants on 20210507, allowing indoor dining up to 80 pct capacity (up from 75) and outdoor dining with no capacity restrictions, provided 3 ft of distance is maintained between parties in both settings. No longer limits party sizes indoors, outdoors, or in bar areas. Also removes time limit for parties seated in bar areas and the requirement to close service in bars at 23h00. Service to standing people is still prohibited. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf. Eased on 20210518 to remove 3 ft distancing requirements: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Ends restrictions on restaurants on 20210521. Standing service now allowed, no capacity restrictions for indoor dining or catered events, dance floors remain open, plexiglass no longer required in bar areas. Restaurants are encouraged to (quote) remain vigilant (quote) and may choose to implement stricter protocols, but this is left to their discretion. (quote) All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOHs regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at ReopeningRI.com (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

On 20210212, gathering restrictions are eased, now allowing two households at all indoor public and private social gatherings, three households at outdoor public and private social gatherings, and 40 pct capacity at indoor houses of worship. Religious indoor and outdoor gatherings continue to be limited to 125 people, however (quote) Houses of worship where the facilitys space can accommodate significantly more than 125 persons within the facilitys 40 pct capacity limit may submit a detailed COVID-19 control plan to DBR to exceed the 125-person cap (quote). https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-13.pdf. The average household size in Rhode Island from 2015-2019 is 2.47, so coding InGathLim as 5 and OutGathLim as 8. https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/RI/PST045219. Eased on 20210225.

Extends case isolation restrictions that requires those with close contact with someone diagnosed or clinically diagnosed with COVID-19 to self-isolate for 10 days from their last known exposure. Provides three new exceptions to these requirements: first, a person who (quote) (i) is not living in an assisted living facility or a nursing home, (ii) is not admitted to a hospital, (iii) has received the final dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccination series no more than 90 days and at least 14 days prior to the last date of close contact, and (iv) is asymptomatic (quote). Second, anyone who previously tested positive and was sympomatic, whose symptoms ended 90 days prior to the last date of close contact, completed isolation requirements at that time, and is now asymptomatic. Third, anyone who previously tested positive 90 days prior to the last date of close contact and was asymptomatic at that time, who completed isolation requirements, and remains asymptomatic. Those who obtain a negative result from a test taken at least 5 days after exposure may continue to shorten self-isolation to 7 days. Non-immunocompromised individuals diagnosed with COVID-19 must self-isolate at least 10 days since symptoms first appeared, at least 24 hours since last fever, and symptoms have improved. Immunocompromised individuals diagnosed with COVID-19 must self-isolate at least 20 days, with additional restrictions applying. Extended on 20210319, while providing a minor amendment to the first exemption path by removing the 90 day vaccination window, now allowing anyone who has been fully vaccinated 14 days prior to contact from isolation requirements. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-26.pdf Extended to 20210517 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-36.pdf  Extended to 20210615 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-52.pdf. Extended to 20210614 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-66.pdf. Extended to 20210812: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-78.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded and updated PolicyCodingNotes and Updated DateExpiry

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions on houses of worship, no longer capping capacity at 125. Rather, (quote) Religious and faith-based organizations may conduct in-person activities up to 40 pct of worship space capacity (quote) with no cap. Restrictions on indoor and outdoor weddings with a licensed caterer or restaurant are also eased, now allowing up to 50, up from 30. Other licensed catered events remain limited to 30. Continues to allow two households at all indoor public and private social gatherings, three households at outdoor public and private social gatherings. The average household size in Rhode Island from 2015-2019 is 2.47, so coding InGathLim as 5 and OutGathLim as 8. https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/RI/PST045219.

Extends quarantine restrictions, which requires (quote): Any person coming to Rhode Island for a non-work-related purpose from locations with a high community spread rate as set forth on a list maintained by RIDOH at https://covid.ri.gov/ must immediately self-quarantine for 10 days (quote). Provides three new exceptions to these requirements: first, a person who (quote) (i) has received the final dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccination series no more than 90 days and at least 14 days prior to the date of the persons arrival in Rhode Island and (ii) is asymptomatic upon arrival in Rhode Island (quote). Second, anyone who previously tested positive and was sympomatic, whose symptoms began 90 days prior to arrival, completed isolation requirements at that time, and is now asymptomatic. Third, anyone who previously tested positive 90 days prior to arrival and was asymptomatic at that time, who completed isolation requirements, and remains asymptomatic. Those who obtain a negative result from a test taken at least 5 days after arrival may continue to shorten self-isolation to 7 days. Those who obtain a negative result no more than 72 hours prior to arrival also continue to be exempt from quarantine restrictions. On 20210301, Removes Louisiana, Missouri, Nevada, and New Hampshire and adds Delaware https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vSUCk9FlHBoJt5ZO0U6PKTTY7jHH8V4MovED0WiqpTTixdgMSCnUWI25xX5DCmQmtLknzu7Bo0jwY02/pubhtml?gid=0&single=true. Eased on 20210305, no longer requiring travelers to obtain a negative result from a test taken at least 5 days after arrival in order to shorten self-isolation to 7 days. Instead, any traveler who obtains a negative test upon arrival is exempt from quarantine restrictions. Continues to provide exceptions to those who have been fully vaccinated, previously infected and now asymptomatic 90 days prior to arrival, and those who obtain a negative result no more than 72 hours prior to arrival. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-22.pdf. As of 20210308, these states include Alabama, Alaska, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Mississippi, Missouri, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX- 1vSUCk9FlHBoJt5ZO0U6PKTTY7jHH8V4MovED0WiqpTTixdgMSCnUWI25xX5DCmQmtLknzu7Bo0jwY02/pubhtml?gid=0&single=true. On 20210322 removes Arkansas, Oklahoma, and South Dakota and adds North Carolina and North Dakota to the list of states required to quarantine https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vSUCk9FlHBoJt5ZO0U6PKTTY7jHH8V4MovED0WiqpTTixdgMSCnUWI25xX5DCmQmtLknzu7Bo0jwY02/pubhtml?gid=0&single=true. Eases gathering restrictions. Indoor private gatherings are now limited to 15 people, rather than two households, and outdoor gatherings are limited to 50 people, rather than three households. Indoor events with a licensed caterer or restaurant now allow 75 pct seated capacity and up to 100 people, including staff and organizers, up from 50. Outdoor events may have up to 200 people. Houses of worship may operate at up to 75 pct indoor capacity with no cap, up from 40. Extended to 20210515 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-34.pdf Beginning 20210515, gathering restrictions on indoor events with a licensed caterer or restaurant are eased to allow 75 pct seated capacity and up to 150 people (up from 100), including staff and organizers. Restrictions on outdoor events are also eased and may have up to 250 people (up from 200). Houses of worship may operate at up to 75 pct indoor capacity with no cap. Indoor private gatherings are limited to 15 people and outdoor gatherings are limited to 50 people. Beginning 20210604, gathering restrictions on indoor events with a licensed caterer or restaurant are further eased to allow 75 pct seated capacity and up to 200 people (up from 150), including staff and organizers. Restrictions on outdoor events are also eased and may have up to 300 people (up from 250). Houses of worship may operate at up to 75 pct indoor capacity with no cap. Indoor private gatherings are limited to 15 people and outdoor gatherings are limited to 50 people. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-34.pdf. Ultimately, this gathering restrictions where easing more aggressively and earlier, on 20210507, so coded as the DateExpiry. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf

Eases business mask requirements, no longer requiring employees to wear a mask if 3 ft of distance (down from 6 ft) can be maintained between workers. Continues to require the use of face coverings by workers if interaction with customers, coworkers, or visitors can be reasonably expected. Additionally, the use of face coverings is no longer required for all individuals (regardless of vaccination status) who are outdoors and at least 3 ft of distance can be easily, measurably, and continuously maintained.

Eases gathering restrictions ahead of planned easings that were scheduled to take place on 20210515 and 20210604. Also eases gathering restrictions to a greater extent than originally planned in either future easing. Effective immediately, gathering restrictions on indoor events with a licensed caterer or restaurant are eased to allow 80 pct seated capacity and up to 200 people, including staff and organizers. Restrictions on outdoor events are also eased and may have up to 500 people. Houses of worship may now operate at up to 80 pct indoor capacity with no cap. Last, indoor private gatherings are now limited to 25 people and outdoor gatherings are limited to 75 people. Expiration date moved up from 20210528 to 20210522: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf. Gathering restrictions ended on 20210521 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf

Eases mandatory mask rule, no longer requires the use of face coverings for all individuals (regardless of vaccination status) who are outdoors and at least 3 ft of distance can be easily, measurably, and continuously maintained. Aside from this exception, continues to require: (quote) Any person who is in a place open to the public, whether indoors or outdoors, shall continue to cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering unless doing so would damage the persons health. No person under two years of age or any person whose health would be damaged thereby shall be required to wear a face covering. (quote) Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it calls for mask use broadly across indoor settings, but narrowly in outdoor settings for all individuals, regardless of vaccination status.

Modifies business mask requirements in accordance with public mask requirements, no longer requiring masks for vaccinated individuals. Employees are not required to wear a mask if 3 ft of distance can be maintained between workers. Continues to require the use of face coverings by unvaccinated workers if interaction with customers, coworkers, or visitors can be reasonably expected. On 20210521, eases business mask requirements. Unvaccinated employees are not required to wear a mask if they (quote) can easily, continuously, and measurably maintain three feet of distance in a workplace (quote) or when working alone. However, no longer specifies that they are required if (quote) interaction with customers, coworkers, or visitors can be reasonably expected (quote). This change represents a small easing, where workers are no longer required to wear a mask continuously if they expect it is possible they might come within 3 ft of someone. Now, mask use is only required when they do in fact come within 3 ft of another individual. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-58.pdf Further eases on 20210602, no longer requiring the use of masks for unvaccinated individuals who are outdoors. Continues to allow unvaccinated employees to not wear a mask if they (quote) can easily, continuously, and measurably maintain three feet of distance in a workplace (quote) or when working alone. However, no longer requires the use of masks oudoors, regardless of physical distancing and vaccination status. Continues to exempt fully vaccinated workers from face covering requirements indoors. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-62.pdf.  Extended to 20210718 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-69.pdf. Ended 20210706 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-76.pdf

Eases restrictions on nightclubs, allowing them to operate up to 50 pct capacity or 100 pct capacity with proof of full vaccination for all on-site. Extended to 20210619 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-57.pdf. Ended on 20210618 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-68.pdf

Modifies mask mandate such that fully vaccinated individuals are now exempt from all state mask requirements. Aside from this exception, continues to require unvaccinated individuals to wear a mask indoors and in outdoor setting where three feet of distancing cannot be maintained. No person under two years of age or any person whose health would be damaged thereby shall be required to wear a face covering. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it calls for mask use broadly across indoor settings, but narrowly in outdoor settings. Extended to 20210619, clarifying that fully vaccinated performers are also exempt from mask mandates, both indoors and outdoors https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-58.pdf. Eases on 20210602, no longer requiring masks outdoors, regardless of vaccination status. No longer requires masks at outdoor performances and no longer requires the use of masks for unvaccinated individuals when 3 ft of distance between individuals cannot be maintained. Continues to require unvaccinated individuals to wear a mask indoors. Also continues to require the use of face coverings for all individuals when using or providing public transportation or other forms of shared transportation, like taxis and ride sharing services, as well as while waiting in a closed or semi-closed stop or area. No person under two years of age or any person whose health would be damaged thereby shall be required to wear a face covering. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it calls for mask use broadly across indoor settings. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-63.pdf. Extended to 20210718 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-69.pdf. Ended 20210706 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-76.pdf

Closed public schools (including universities and technical colleges) in Kershaw and Lancaster counties beginning 20200316 for 14 days (so expiry is 20200330).

(quote) I urge that indoor and outdoor public gatherings be cancelled, postponed, or rescheduled, to the extent possible, or limited so as to not exceed 100 people (quote). Active for the duration of the State of Emergency.

All public schools (including universities and technical colleges) are closed starting on 20200316. Extends school closure by 3 days and now applies statewide. Extended every 15 days with state of emergency. The 20200626 executive order Executive order no longer requires public schools to remain closed, aligning with the 20200622 publication of the South Carolina reopening guidance for local authorities and districts. This is thus being coded as ending the state-coordinated closure of schools https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-06-26%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-42%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf

Limited operations required (off-premises consumption only, with takeaway, carry-out curbside, etc permitted): bars. Eased on 20200504, permitting outdoor service: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-03%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-31%20-%20Modification%20of%20Home%20or%20Work%20Order%20%26%20Authorization%20of%20Outdoor%20Dining%20Services.pdf

(quote) I hereby prohibit and direct the postponement, rescheduling, or cancellation, as applicable, of any organized event or public gathering scheduled to be hosted or held at any location or facility owned or operated by the State of South Carolina, or any political subdivision thereof, beginning Wednesday, March 18, 2020, and through Tuesday, March 31, 2020, if any such event or gathering could or would involve or require simultaneously convening fifty (50) or more persons in a single room, area, or other confined indoor or outdoor space. (quote) Although this gathering restriction appears to be limited to government owned locations, given some of the ambiguity and likely interpretation as a broader public gathering restriction on 50 or more people, we are coding it as a 50 person gathering mandate (but not applied to religious gatherings). Ended on 20200611, deleting that section of EO 2020-10: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-06-11%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-40%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf

Limited operations required (off-premise consumption only, with takeaway, carry-out, curbside, etc permitted): restaurants. Extended to 20200512: https://governor.sc.gov//sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Budget/2020-04-27%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-29%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency%20Due%20to%20COVID-19%20Pandemic%20Response%20%26%20Other%20Measures.pdf Eased on 20200504: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-03%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-31%20-%20Modification%20of%20Home%20or%20Work%20Order%20%26%20Authorization%20of%20Outdoor%20Dining%20Services.pdf

Mandates 14 day quarantine on people entering from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and New Orleans, Louisiana. Expires when emergency order expires. The 20200412 extension of the State of Emergency extends expiry to 20200427 https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-04-12%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-23%20-%20Third%20State%20of%20Emergency%20Due%20to%20COVID-19%20Pandemic.pdf  Extended to 20200512 on 20200427 https://governor.sc.gov//sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Budget/2020-04-27%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-29%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency%20Due%20to%20COVID-19%20Pandemic%20Response%20%26%20Other%20Measures.pdf Ended this policy on 20200501 https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-01%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-30%20-%20Rescinding%20Self-Quarantine%2C%20Lodging%2C%20%26%20Travel%20Restrictions%20for%20Individuals%20Entering%20S.C.%20from%20High-R
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEnded of 20200501. On 20200428, updated DateExpiry to 20200512.On 20200426, updated DateExpiry on 20200427. On 20200412, clarified that quarantine is required for individuals traveling from New Orleans, Louisiana not all of Louisiana

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all public beaches and water access, including parking lots and piers, docks, warfs, boat ramps, and boat landings.

Closes the following non-essential businesses: entertainment venues and facilities (including night clubs, bowling alleys, arcades, concert venues, theaters and like performing arts centers, tourist attractions like museums, aquariums and planetariums, racetracks, indoor childrens play areas, adult entertainment venues, bingo halls, social clubs), recreational and athletic facilities and activities (including fitness and exercise centers, spas and swimming pools, spectator sports, sports that involve interaction in close proximity to others, shared sporting activities, playgrounds), close contact service providers (i.e., hair salons, waxing salons, threading salons, nail salons, body art and tattoo, tanning salons, massage therapy). First group businesses are permitted to reopen on 20200518, ending mandated restrictions on recreational and athletic facilities, as well as close contact service providers: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-15%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-36%20-%20Additional%20Incremental%20Modification%20of%20Non-Essential%20Business%20Closures.pdf
Requires retail stores to close for in-person services but expressly permits curbside, delivery, pickup, etc. Coding as TakeawayOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel

Requires all residents and visitors to limit their movements outside of their home, place of residence, or current place of abode. Extended every 15 days with extensions of state of the emergency. Ended of 20200504: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-03%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-31%20-%20Modification%20of%20Home%20or%20Work%20Order%20%26%20Authorization%20of%20Outdoor%20Dining%20

Permits the reopening of public boat ramps and landings to allow for outdoor exercise and recreational activities. Public piers, docks, and wharfs providing public access to waters remain closed. Further eased on 20200421: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-04-20%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-28%20-%20Modification%20of%20Restrictions%20for%20Public%20Beaches%20%26%20Waters%20%26%20Incremental%20Modification%20of%20Non-Essential%20Business%20Closures.pdf Eased further on 20200508: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-08%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-34%20-%20Authorization%20of%20Limited%20Indoor%20Dining%20Services%20%26%20Rescission%20of%20Boating%20Restrictions.pdf Further eased on 20200611: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-06-11%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-40%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Ended state coordinated restrictions on beaches on 20200802: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-08-02%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-50%20-%20Initiating%20Additional%20Emergency%20Measures%20%26%20Consolidating%20Previous%20Orders.pdf

Eases restrictions on retail businesses, permitting them to re-open for in-person services up to 20 pct capacity or 5 customers per 1000 sq ft, whichever is lower. At least 6 ft distancing distancing between customers required. Ended on 20200611, with mandates turning to recommendations: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-06-11%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-40%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to re-open for outdoor on-premises services only. Requires at least 8 ft distancing between tables, limit table groups to 8 individuals. On 20200511, permits indoor services to resume and changes requirements to recommendations, subsequently ending the state-coordinated mandate on bars: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-08%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-34%20-%20Authorization%20of%20Limited%20Indoor%20Dining%20Services%20%26%20Rescission%20of%20Boating%20Restrictions.pdf While South Carolina has re-imposed some bar restrictions since, they have not met the threshold for coding new policies (i.e., maximum of 25 pct capacity, no more than 10 people in a room at a time).

Eases restrictions on restaurants to allow for outdoor customer dining services, in addition to off-premises consumption. Indicates that reasonable steps should be taken to promote public health and safety among restaurants that elect to provide outdoor customer dining. Active for the remainder of the emergency declaration (20200512). On 20200511, permits indoor services to resume and changes requirements to recommendations, subsequently ending the state-coordinated mandate on restaurants: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-08%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-34%20-%20Authorization%20of%20Limited%20Indoor%20Dining%20Services%20%26%20Rescission%20of%20Boating%20Restrictions.pdf While South Carolina has re-imposed some restaurant restrictions since (though then permitted 100 pct starting on 20201002), they have not met the threshold for coding new policies (i.e., maximum of 25 pct capacity, no more than 10 people in a room at a time).

Urges and encourages (quote) residents and visitors of the State of South Carolina to limit their movements outside of their home, place of residence, or current place of abode (quote). With the 20200802 order, omits language about a stay at home recommendation in the consolidated emergency orders for COVID-19, so coding as an ending: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-08-02%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-50%20-%20Initiating%20Additional%20Emergency%20Measures%20%26%20Consolidating%20Previous%20Orders.pdf

South Carolina DHEC recommends wearing cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery stores and pharmacies), especially in areas of significant community-based transmission. It is possible that earlier recommendations were provided by the DHEC, but this is the earliest documented recommendation with dates identified thus far.

Eases restrictions to permit the following to reopen at limited capacity: arcades, tourist attractions (including museums, aquariums, and planetariums), indoor childrens play areas, bingo halls, venues operated by social clubs, and recreational and athletic athletic activities that involve close proximity to or within 6 ft of a person, shared sporting apparatus, and commerical or public playground equipment. Included guidelines from accelerateSC requires no more than 50 pct capacity, which the governor has empowered to provide requirements as needed. https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/Guidelines%20for%20Reopening%20Attractions%20-%20FINAL.pdf Extended to 20210122: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-07%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-03%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210206: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-22%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-07%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210221: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-02-06%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-08%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210308: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-02-21%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-10%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Ended on 20210301, with requirements now becoming recommendations: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-01%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-111%20-%20Modifying%20%20Amending%20Emergency%20Measures.pdf

(quote) South Carolina Department of Education (SCDE) is requiring face coverings to be worn on school buses and within public school facilities (quote), including upon entering a school building, moving through hallways, during carpool/bus drop off or pickup. Exempts children the age of 2 years, individuals for whom wearing a mask may cause medical issues like trouble breathing, outside when social distancing is possible. SCDE requirements are not dated, but articles clearly indicate this was put in effect on 20200731: https://www.thestate.com/news/local/education/article244635332.html. Ends mandate on 20210511 https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-05-11%20FINAL%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-23%20-%20Emergency%20Measures%20Regarding%20Face%20Coverings%20Vaccine%20Passports%20%20Other%20Matters.pdf

The following businesses shall now require that all employees etc. wear face coverings except when actively eating or drinking: state government offices, buildings, and offices, restaurants, bars, festivals, parades, concerts, theaters, stadiums, arenas, coliseums, auditoriums, grandstands, event venues, dance halls, concert halls, amphitheaters, gymnasiums, chambers, assemblies, nightclubs, performing arts centers, parks, racetracks, or similarly situated or operated businesses, facilities, venues, services, activities, events, or mass gatherings. Extended to 20210122: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-07%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-03%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210206: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-22%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-07%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210221: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-02-06%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-08%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210308: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-02-21%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-10%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Eased on 20210301, now limiting requirements to state government offices, buidlings, offices, as well as bars. All other previous venues are now recommendations, not requirements: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-01%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-111%20-%20Modifying%20%20Amending%20Emergency%20Measures.pdf

Imposes new gathering restrictions: (quote) The total number of employees, customers, patrons, suppliers, vendors, vistors, or others present at the gathering shall not exceed 50 pct of the capacity limit, or 250 people, whichever is less. (quote) Explicitly does not apply to religious activities or services. Extended to 20210122: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-07%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-03%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210206: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-22%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-07%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Ended on 20210301, with requirements now becoming recommendations: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-01%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-111%20-%20Modifying%20%20Amending%20Emergency%20Measures.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting them to reopen at no more than 50 pct capacity or no more than 250 people, whichever is less: night clubs, theaters and performing arts centers, racetracks, adult entertainment venues. Extended to 20210122: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-07%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-03%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210206: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-22%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-07%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Ended on 20210301, with requirements now becoming recommendations: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-01%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-111%20-%20Modifying%20%20Amending%20Emergency%20Measures.pdf

Face coverings must be worn when in the presence of non-household members and when it is not feasible to maintain at least 6 ft of distancing between individuals at the following venues or businesses: state buildings, restaurants and bars, festivals, parades, concerts, theaters, stadiums, arenas, coliseums, auditoriums, grandstands, event venues, dance halls, concert halls, amphitheaters, gymnasiums, chambers, assemblies, nightclubs, performing arts centers, parks, racetracks, or similarly situated or operated businesses, facilities, venues, services, activities, events, or mass gatherings, the occurrence or resulting impacts of which could strain the public health, planning, and response resources of the community hosting the same. Exempts children who are younger than 2 years old, medical or behavioral conditions make it otherwise unsafe, etc. Coded as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it still applies to specific settings and does not broadly apply across indoor venues (per most orders classified as Mandate2). Extended to 20210122: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-07%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-03%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf Extended to 20210206: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-01-22%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-07%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Extended to 20210308: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-02-21%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-10%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Eased on 20210301, now limiting requirements to state government offices, buidlings, offices, as well as bars. All other previous venues are now recommendations, not requirements: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-01%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-111%20-%20Modifying%20%20Amending%20Emergency%20Measures.pdf

(quote) The total number of employees, customers, patrons, suppliers, vendors, visitors, or other persons present for or in attendance at the Gathering should not exceed fifty percent (50 pct) of the locations occupancy limit as determined by the fire marshal, if applicable, or two hundred fifty (250) persons, whichever is less (quote). Extended to 20210323: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2021-03-08%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-13%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf. Government offices are encourated to post guidelines for face coverings, and face coverings are recommended for employees in restaurants, bars, and other businesses. All unvaccinated individuals are encouraged to wear a face covering in public settings where they are in close proximity to others.
