State of Emergency declared with Executive Order 2020-04. Extended to 20201230 https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-26.PDF. Extended to 20210630 https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-34%20-%20.PDF. Allowed to expire without announcement on 20210630.

Governor issued on 20200313, closure started 2020316 for public K-12 schools. Only documentation via video: (quote) we are asking schools to close next week statewide. Im recommending that schools use this time to clean their facilities and prepare for the following week (quote). Documentation also via articles: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/03/13/south-dakota-coronavirus-cases-governor-noem-covid-19/5040643002/ Extends to 20200328: https://ktiv.com/2020/03/17/gov-noem-to-hold-news-conference-to-update-south-daktoa-on-covid-19 Extends to 20200501 on 20200324: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/politics/2020/03/24/gov-kristi-noem-announce-additional-measures-slow-coronavirus-spread/2906663001/ Recommends to stay to closed through the end of the academic year: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/education/2020/04/06/gov-noem-says-south-dakota-schools-remain-closed-rest-school-year/2955969001/ On 20200428, fully devolves to school districts and individual schools to determine closure status, so coding as ended: https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-20.PDF
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated Mandate to 0, DateEnacted to 20200316, and PolicyCodingNotes. Added NoInPerson to SchoolRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Instructs (quote) all local and municipal governments within the State of South Dakota should....restrict public gatherings of ten people or more, unless it is necessary (quote). Also includes a focus on recommended that enclosed businesses should suspend or modify practices that involve 10 or more people in an enclosed space where physical separation of at least 6 ft is not possible
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with Mandate 0

PolicyCodingNotes: State of Disaster declared for all 66 counties, in effect (quote) for three months from the date the Sec of US DHHS declares the public health emergency to end in the US (quote). Coded separately the state of emergency.

(quote) enclosed retail businesses that promote public gatherings...shall suspend or modify business practice as recommended by CDC guidance that involve 10 or more people to be in an enclosed space where physical separation of at least 6 ft is not possible. (quote) Encourages takeout, delivery, drive-through, curbside that do not involve public gatherings in an enclosed space but does not require it. Order defines these types of businesses as (quote) any enclosed facility operating...as a bar (quote) Ends on 20200428: https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-20.PDF

(quote) all local and municipal governments within the State of South Dakota shall...restrict public gatherings of 10 or more people, unless it is necessary (quote). This restriction ends on 2020428 with the EO being rescinded: https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-20.PDF
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated numeric gathering values and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) enclosed retail businesses that promote public gatherings...shall suspend or modify business practice as recommended by CDC guidance that involve 10 or more people to be in an enclosed space where physical separation of at least 6 ft is not possible. (quote) Encourages takeout, delivery, drive-through, curbside that do not involve public gatherings in an enclosed space but does not require it. Order defines these types of businesses as (quote) any enclosed facility operating...as a casino, recreational or athletic facility, health club, or entertainment venue (quote) Ends on 20200428: https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-20.PDF

(quote) enclosed retail businesses that promote public gatherings...shall suspend or modify business practice as recommended by CDC guidance that involve 10 or more people to be in an enclosed space where physical separation of at least 6 ft is not possible. (quote) Encourages takeout, delivery, drive-through, curbside that do not involve public gatherings in an enclosed space but does not require it. Order defines these types of businesses as (quote) any enclosed facility operating...as a restaurant, brewery, cafe, coffee shop (quote) Ends on 20200428: https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-20.PDF

Only applies to Minnehaha and Lincoln counties, and focuses on vulnerable individuals (i.e., adults 65 or older and those with serious medical conditions). Extended to 20200511 https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2020-18.PDF Stay-at-home order effectively ended on 20200511 when the governor decided not to renew the order https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/11/gov-kristi-noem-lifts-stay-home-order-those-65-sioux-falls-area/3111654001/
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEnded of 20200511 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Stay-at-home recommendation that vulnerable individuals (i.e., adults 65 or older and those with serious medical conditions) (quote) should remain home if possible (quote). Extended on 20200428 as under the new Back To Normal Plan, vulnerable individuals (i.e., adults 65 or older and those with serious medical conditions) (quote) should consider staying home whenever possible (quote) https://covid.sd.gov/docs/COVID_SDPlan_BackToNormal.pdf

Under the Back To Normal Plan, South Dakotans are encouraged to consider CDC guidance and use of masks in public. At this point, cloth facial coverings were recommended by the CDC. On 20200707, Recommendation from public health department in guidance re Considerations For Social Activities During COVID 19. (quote) Wear a mask when feasible. (quote): https://doh.sd.gov/documents/COVID19/COVID_Risks_Benefits_SocialActivities.pdf

Declared state of emergency, which based on date increments, has to be extended every 60 days to remain in effect. Extended to 20210228: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee73.pdf. Extended to 20210429: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee77.pdf. Extended as a (quote) limited state of emergency (quote) to 20210601 https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee80.pdf Extended to 20210801 https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee81.pdf. Extended to 20210901: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee82.pdf
(quote) Vulnerable populations should stay home where possible and avoid large gatherings or locations where they are more likely to contract the virus (quote).
(quote) we strongly discourage events of 250 people or more as an important step in limiting exposure to COVID-19 (quote)

(quote) I urge every school district in Tennessee to close as soon as practically possible, with all schools expected to close by Friday, March 20, 2020 at the latest. Schools should remain closed through March 31, 2020 to further mitigate the spread of this infectious disease and we will issue further guidance prior to March 31. (quote) Does not indicate state-mandated closure of schools. On 20200415: (quote) Gov. Lee has called on schools to remain closed through the end of the school year. (quote) No formal order or mandate has been identified, so continuing as a recommendation: https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/covid-19-bulletin/2020/4/15/covid-19-bulletin--9---april-15--2020.html Considered ended on 20200728, based on the following: Governor announcement includes the following language, specifying that state-level authority is encouraging in-person learning, thus ending the recommendation to keep school buildings closed: (quote) in-person learning is the medically sound, preferred option. Our state is doing everything we can to work with local school districts and ensure that in-person learning is made available in a way that protects the health and safety of our students and educators (quote). https://www.tn.gov/governor/news/2020/7/28/gov--lee-unveils-safe-reopening-plan-for-tennessee-schools.html

Limited operations (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption only): bars. On 20200429, ends state-coordinated bar restrictions for 6 counties, so coding as an easing at the state-level: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf

(quote) Persons in the State of Tennessee shall not participate in social gatherings of 10 or more people. (quote) No clear exemptions for religious gatherings. Eased starting 20200428, exempting religious gatherings from limits: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf

Closure required: gyms, fitness/exercise centers. Also requires the closure of nightclubs. On 20200429, ends restrictions for the 6 counties with locally run county health departments, constituting an easing at the state level: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf

Limited operations (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption only): restaurants. Ended on 20200427, moving from mandated restrictions to recommended ones statewide: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee29.pdf

Requires closure of businesses or organizations that perform close-contact personal services (barbershops, hair salons, nail salons, tanning, massage therapy, etc), as well as entertainment and recreational gathering venues (bowling alleys, arcades, concert venues, theaters and like performing ats facilities, racetracks, indoor childrens play areas, adult entertainment venues, amusement parks, roller or ice skating rinks, nightclubs). Continues prior closures: gyms and fitness/exercise centers. On 20200429, ends restrictions for the 6 counties with locally run county health departments, constituting an easing at the state level: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf

(quote) Businesses or organizations that do not perform Essential Services shall not be open for access or use by the public or its members (quote). For at least some non-essential businseses (e.g., non-essential retail), permitting them to re-open with recommended guidelines (e.g., 50 pct capacity at retail businesses) because the executive order and corresponding guidelines do not expressly require these capacity: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf
(quote) all persons in Tennessee are urged to stay at home (quote). Not currently coded as mandate. Expiry is 20200414 at 1159 pm, should be coded as 20200415

All persons in Tennessee required to stay home (replaces language from paragraph 1 from Exec order 22 issued March 30). Expiry date at midnight on April 14. updated to 20200430 at 1159 pm, which is entered as 20200501. Stay-at-home order mandate is ended and replaced with a recommendation (quote) all persons are strongly encouraged to continue to stay at home and to minimize in-person contact) https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee30.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEased and added to DateEnded, updated DateExpiry

PolicyCodingNotes: Per Tennessee pledge guidelines for businesses, (quote) face coverings are strongly encouraged for all persons (employee and guest) in all public places where close proximity to others is anticipated (quote). Coding as a mask recommendation for businesses. Starting on 20200429, the following is included in executive orders: (quote) persons, including employees or customers of businesses, are strongly urged to wear cloth face coverings or other similar coverings in public settings where being in close proximity to others is anticipated, and particularly where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain at all times (quote) Extended to 20210228: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee73.pdf

Per Tennessee pledge guidelines for businesses, (quote) face coverings are strongly encouraged for all persons (employee and guest) in all public places where close proximity to others is anticipated (quote). Coding as a mask recommendation for the public. Starting on 20200429, the following is included in executive orders: (quote) persons, including employees or customers of businesses, are strongly urged to wear cloth face coverings or other similar coverings in public settings where being in close proximity to others is anticipated, and particularly where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain at all times (quote) Extended to 20210228: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee73.pdf
Extends original bar restrictions (takeaway only) for the 89 counties without local county health departments

(quote) persons who test positive for COVID-19 or who are suffering COVID-19 symptoms shall stay at home, except to receive medical care, until satisfying the conditions for discontinuing home isolation per CDC. (quote) Extended on 20201001: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee63.pdf Extended to 20201230 https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee67.pdf Extended to 20210228 https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee73.pdf

Extends the prohibition of gatherings of more than 10 people indoors and outdoors, but explicitly exempts places of worship from that mandate. Strongly recommends that places of worship use alternative modes of service delivery, and are strongly encouraged to follow guidelines for in-person services (e.g., no more than 50 pct capacity in a given room). Eased on 20200522: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee38.pdf

Extends closure of the following businesses: close-contact personal services (eg, barber shops, hair salons, body art and tattoo, massage therapy), venues for entertainment and recreation (eg, night clubs, live performance venues, bowling alleys, arcades, concerts, sporting event venues, amusement parks, senior centers) for 89 out of 95 counties as the omitted 6 counties are empowered to institute their own policies regarding business operations during the state of emergency. On 20200506, ends restrictions on personal care services, consituting an easing of these business categories: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee33.pdf

(quote) all persons are strongly encouraged to continue to stay at home and to minimize in-person contact (quote). Extended to 20200701: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee38.pdf. Extended to 20200830.

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, conditional on their operations ensuring that all persons are in groups of less than 10 and such groups have to keep at least 6 ft distancing: bowling alleys, arcades, water sports activities, golf driving ranges and mini golf facilities, shooting ranges, dance classes, and (quote) other similar activities and venues that can achieve and maintain the necessary capacity and proximity limitations (quote). Ended on 20200522, with mandated restrictions becoming recommendations: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee38.pdf

Eases bar restrictions to allow for bars to resume in-person services, requiring them to only serve customers at seated tables and must follow the Tennessee Pledge guidelines for these establishments (i.e., no more than 10 guests per table, bar areas cannot be opened unless used to accommodate seated tables). Ends on 202001001: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee63.pdf

Prohibits gathering restrictions of 50 or more, but exempts places of worship and religious gatherings. Extended to 20200830: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee50.pdf Ended on 20201001: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee63.pdf

Eases restrictions on nightclubs and like venues (eg concert venues, adult entertainment), permitting them to re-open but only if customers are seated at tables and if the nightclubs follow the Tennessee Pledge guidelines for restaurants (i.e., no more than 10 guests per table, bar areas cannot be opened unless used to accommodate seated tables). Also eases restrictions on sporting event centers, race tracks, and like sporting events/venues, allowing them to re-open for as long as no more than 50 people are in a given set of viewing locations (e.g., bleachers) and watch an event with at least 6 ft distancing. Ended on 20201001, with all restricitions moving to recommendations: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee63.pdf

(quote) Local education agencies, schools, and institutions of higher education are strongly encouraged to implement a policy requiring the use of face coverings by students and staff, with appropriate exemptions, and consistent with any policies issued by the Tennessee Department of Education (quote). Coding as a school mask recommendation. Extended to 20210228: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee73.pdf

Introduces restrictions on indoor gatherings. (quote) Persons in the State of Tennessee should to the greatest extent practicable maintain at least six (6) feet of separation from persons outside their household, and shall not in any event be in a group of ten (10) or more persons in an indoor public place for the purposes of social gatherings, activities, or events (quote). This limit does not apply to religious gatherings. School atheletic events may be held, with attendence limited to officials, administrators, team personnel, and immediate family of participants.

State of Disaster Declared. Though it is not included in the order, Section 418.014 of the Texas Government Code indicates that a state of disaster cannot continue for more than 30 days unless it is renewed by the governor. (quote) every person in Texas shall avoid social gatherings in groups of more than 10 people. (quote) In effect statewide at 1159 pm on 20200320, coded to 20200321. Initial expiry is set to be 1159 pm 20200403, coded to 20200404

Limited operations required (drive-thru, pickup, delivery): restaurants. In effect statewide at 1159 pm on 20200320, coded to 20200321. Initial expiry is set to be 1159 pm 20200403, coded to 20200404

(quote) In accordance with Guidelines from the President and the CDC, schools shall temprorarily close (quote). Extended for the remainder of the school year on 20200417: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-16.pdf Eased to permit limited in-person instruction and campus vistation on 20200601: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-23.pdf

Mandates 14 day quarantine on individuals entering Texas whose point of origin or last departure was New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, or City of New Orleans. Adds California, Louisiana, Washington and the cities of Atlanta, Chicago, Detroit, and Miami on 20200330: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/DISASTER_renewing_covid19_disaster_proc_04-12-2020.pdf Removes Louisiana on 20200512: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-20.pdf Ended on 20200521: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-24.pdf

Requires that (quote) every person in Texas shall, except where necessary to provide or obtain essential services, minimize social gatherings and minimize in-person contact with people who are not in the same household. (quote) Coding as 0 for non-religious gatherings. Places of worship and religious services are classified as essential services, and thus are recommended to follow CDC guidance but do not have these limits applied. Eased on 20200427, with lifting of the stay-at-home order: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-18.pdf

Closes tattoo studios, piercing studios, or cosmetology salons as businesses, and also establishes list of essential critical infrastructure sectors, which omits in-person retail services and therefore closes those stores for in-person operations. Starts easing on 20200424, permitting retail to operate as takeaway: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-16.pdf

Requires Texans to stay at home except for essential activities (including everything listed by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, plus religious services) through 20200430, so coding to 20200501. Ended mandate on 20200427: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-18.pdf

Eases restrictions on non-essential retail businesses, permitting them to re-open for takeaway, delivery, or pickup. Onsite services remain prohibited. Eased on 20200501, allowing for in-person services to resume: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-18.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions with lifting of stay-at-home order, now requiring that people minimize social gatherings and in person contact except for providing or obtaining essential services or reopened services. Coding as no numeric limit for non-religious gatherings, while religious gatheings continue to have recommendations around keeping occupancy low, sufficient social distancing, etc. Ended on 20200603: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf
(quote) Individuals are encouraged to wear appropriate face coverings, but no jurisdiction can impose a civil or criminal penalty for failure to wear a face covering (quote)

(quote) People over the age of 65 are strongly encouraged to stay at home as much as possible (quote). Eases restrictions on retail businesses, allowing for in-person services up to 25 pct occupancy. Businesses should follow minimum standard health protocols by DSHS and should implement social distancing, practice good hygiene, etc. but is not expressly mandated. In counties with 5 or fewer cases of COVID-19, in-store retail can operate up to 50 percent vesus 25 percent of listed occupancy. These counties are not clearly identified, so including as notes at present. Further eased on 20200603, allowing them to reopen at 50 pct capacity: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf Further eased to up to 75 pct capacity on 20200921: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-30_expanded_openings_COVID-19.pdf Extended to 20210204: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc01052021_COVID.pdf. In counties with 5 or fewer cases of COVID-19, their eased restaurant restrictions can allow up to 50 percent maximum occupancy. These counties are not clearly identified, so including as notes at present. Eased for most of state on 20200522, allowing 50 pct capacity: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-23.pdf On 20200529, full state can operate at least 50 pct capacity: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-23.pdf Further easing occurred to allow for 75 pct capacity on 20200612: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf Reexpanded on 20200629, reducing capacity to no more than 50 pct: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-28_targeted_response_to_reopening_COVID-19.pdf Eased again on 20200921, permitting up to 75 pct capacity: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-30_expanded_openings_COVID-19.pdf. Eases restrictions on the following businesses, allowing in-person services and operations if they are at 25 percent occupancy and maintain appropriate social distancing measures: offices (or if they have a maximum of 5 indiviudals), manufacturing services, gyms and exercise facilities. In effect at 1201 am on 20200518. For counties with fewer than 5 COVID-19 cases, capacity or occupancy limits are 50 pct rather than 25 pct. These counties are not clearly identified, so including as notes at present. Further eases on 20200603, permitting up to 50 pct capacity: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf Further eases on 20200921, permitting up to 75 pct capacity: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-30_expanded_openings_COVID-19.pdf. Counties except for Deaf Smith, El Paso, Moore, Potter, and Randall are permitted to have bars and similar establishments to open at 25 pct capacity/occupancy.

Deaf Smith, El Paso, Moore, Potter, and Randall counties are permitted to have bars to open at 25 pct occupancy, bringing this easing to a statewide policy. Further eased on 20200603, permitting bars to operate at up to 50 pct capacity: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf Extended to 20200711: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/DISASTER-Renewing-Covid19-Disaster-Proclamation_06-11-2020.pdf

Eased restrictions on businesses statewide, allowing massage establishments and personal care and beauty services that have yet to re-open (e.g., tattoo, piercing, etc). Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Starting June 1, public school districts and public education students may visit school campuses for in-person classroom and instructional activities under minimum health standard protocols under Teaching Education Agency. Private schools and institutions of higher education may re-open campuses and encouraged to establish similar standards. Further eases on 20200603, permitting summer school activities to resume: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-26.pdf Ended on 20200717, with devolution to local authorities: https://tea.texas.gov/about-tea/news-and-multimedia/news-releases/news-2020/tea-announces-additional-reopening-guidance-including-local-option-for-an-online-only-start-to-the-2020-21-school-year

All gathering restrictions now advisory language (quote) Except as provided in this executive order, people should not be in groups larger than ten and should maintain six feet of social distancing from those not in their group. (quote) Also indicates that any outdoor gathering exceeding 500 may involve additional restrictions based on consultations with local public health authorities. Exempts religious gatherings/houses of worship.

Eases restrictions on amusement parks and carnivals, allowing them operate at no more than 50 pct operating limits. Note that counties with more than 1,000 cumulative COVID-19 cases cannot have amusement parks operating until June 19, 2020. Eased on 20201014, allowing them to operate up to 75 pct capacity: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-32_continued_response_to_COVID-19_IMAGE_10-07-2020.pdf. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Requires bars to close for on-premises consumption, expanding previously eased restrictions. Drive-thru, pickup, and delivery options are permitted. Eased on 20201014, permitting bars to reopen: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-32_continued_response_to_COVID-19_IMAGE_10-07-2020.pdf

Re-imposes gathering restrictions, (quote) for any outdoor gathering in excess of 100 people...the gathering is prohibited (quote). Allows for mayor of the city or county judge to approve of the gathering as long it is not inconsistent with other portions of EO-28. Indoor gathering restrictions are (quote) no more than 50 percent of the total listed occupancy (quote), not a numeric restriction. Also indicates that people should not be in groups larger than 10 (a recommendation). Religious services are exempted from occupancy limits.
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateExpiry and updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed religious gathering limits

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes commercial rafting and tubing businesses (serivces and rentals) for use. Eased on 20201014: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-32_continued_response_to_COVID-19_IMAGE_10-07-2020.pdf

Consistent with the statewide mask mandate, employees at businesses are required to wear face coverings in settings described in the order: (quote) every person in Texas shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial entity or other building or space open to public, or when in a outdoor public space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing (quote). Technically does not apply to any county that has met some minimum of COVID-19 cases and that a county judge as permitted opt-out per the TDEM form. Treating as a statewide mandate since these counties are not detailed. While technically there is no expiration date, the order draws from governor power to enact policies via the disaster declaration and thus it is in effect for the duration of the disaster declaration. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

(quote) every person in Texas shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial entity or other building or space open to public, or when in a outdoor public space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing (quote). Lists exemptions (e.g., person younger than 10, persons with medical conditions or disabilities that would prevent wearing a face covering). Technically does not apply to any county that has met some minimum of COVID-19 cases and that a county judge as permitted opt-out per the TDEM form. Treating as a statewide mandate since these counties are not detailed. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Exemption for religious gatherings. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Consistent with the statewide mask mandate, schools will also require masks to be worn for students 10 years and older, teachers, and visitors inside outdoors wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing. The alignment with the governors order is clearly emphasized by the department of education: https://tea.texas.gov/sites/default/files/covid/SY20-21-School-Reopening-Brief.pdf Technically does not apply to any county that has met some minimum of COVID-19 cases and that a county judge as permitted opt-out per the TDEM form. Treating as a statewide mandate since these counties are not detailed. While technically there is no expiration date, the order draws from governor power to enact policies via the disaster declaration and thus it is in effect for the duration of the disaster declaration. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions, (quote) people shall not be in groups larger than 10 and shall maintain six feet of social distancing from those not in their group (quote). Permits potential exemptions for outdoor gatherings of more than 10 if the mayor (in cities) or county judge (in unincorporated areas) approves. Religious services are exempted from occupancy limits. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Eases restrictions for bars. Bars may offer on-premises services up to 50 pct capacity if the bar or similar establishment is not in an area with high hospitalizations (for the last seven days, 15 pct or more of the hospitalizations have been from COVID‑19 in a Trauma Service Area) or the bar is in an area with high hospitalizations, but is located in a county that has filed with DSHS. It is not clear how frequently these county designations will be updated and thus how easily this will be tracked, and thus we are coding this as statewide. Extended to 20210204: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc01052021_COVID.pdf. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

Eases restrictions on rafting and tubing businesses, permitting them to reopen as long as groups of more than 10 people are prohibited. Extended to 20210306: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc02042021_COVID.pdf. Technically extended beyond 20210306 with emergency delcaration extension, though per executive order GA-34, all state-level COVID-19 policies will be ended on 20210310: https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2021/proc03062021_COVID.pdf Ended on 20210310: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf

(quote) individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings over the nose and mouth wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household, but no person may be required by any jurisdiction to wear or to mandate the wearing of a face covering. (quote)

Declares State of Emergency, with an initial expiry of 20200820. Extended to 20200919 https://governor.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2020/08/EO-2020-51.pdf. Extended to 20201021 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-2020-63.pdf
Recommendation to ban all gatherings 100 or more. Was originally coded as a ban, formal restriction based on previous documentation.

Dismissal of all schools as soft closure to start 20200316, issued on 20200313, school closure extended to the end of the school year on 20200414. Starting on 20200527, locations in yellow phase can resume school-based activities https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Phased_Health_Guidelines_V4.5.3_05262020.pdf
Gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited. In effect immediately, shall remain in effect through 20200401, so coded to an expiry of 20200402

Limited operations required (suspend dine-in operations): bars. Goes into effect on 1159 pm 20200318, coded to 20200319. On 20200429, in-person services are allowed (quote) with extreme caution (quote) upon the designation of the COVID19 public health risk being downgraded to orange. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/UtahLeads%20April2020%20v20%20(2).pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, added FullClose under BusinessRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Nightclubs must close, coding to a FullClose under BusinessRestrictLevel. Eases on 20200502 as the state goes to Public Health Orange Risk: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

Limited operations required (suspend dine-in operations): restaurants. Goes into effect on 1159 pm 20200318, coded to 20200319. Expanded State public health order issued on 20200401 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PH2tbSfCvKjtw7LG1PgqhPclCaqiu-q6/view On 20200429, dine-in services are allowed (quote) with extreme caution (quote) upon the designation of the COVID19 public health risk being downgraded to orange. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/UtahLeads%20April2020%20v20%20(2).pdf Extended to 20200808: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-44.pdf Extended to 20200920: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-62.pdf Extended to 20201021 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-2020-63.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, added TakeawayOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals over the age of 60 and individuals who are immunocompromised should avoid contact with other individuals. Also recommends that all individuals avoid discretionary travel, shopping trips (other than shopping for food and essentials), and social visits. In combination, coding as a stay-at-home recommendation for vulnerable populations.

Social distancing directives include (quote) Do not attend any in-person gathering of any number of people who are not of the same household or residence (quote). Restriction ended, replaced with a recommendation when the state moved to orange risk phase: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

(quote) I expect all residents...to follow these directives (quote) self--quarantine for 14 days after traveling. Ends when state goes to public health risk orange: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

All individuals to stay home as much as possible, but does not involve a formal mandate. (quote) these directives are not to be confused with a shelter-in-place order (quote). In effect until 1159pm on 20200413, so coded as an expiry of 20200414.

Stipulates self-isolation or quarantine for anyone who tests positive for COVID-19, exposed to someone who tests positive, or is a member of a household who tests positive. On 20200501, rescinds the prior order: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

Urges individuals to wear a cloth face covering in grocery stores, in retail, and in public when not able to social distance. Continues recommendations for mask use through Phases Orange and Yellow https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Phased%20Health%20Guidelines%20V4.0.1.pdf  Extended to 20200704 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-32.pdf

In-person services in bars, taverns, saloons, and like venues are allowed (quote) with extreme caution (quote) upon the designation of the COVID19 public health risk being downgraded to orange. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel. Eased on 20200612, as counties begin moving to Public Health Green and thus the requirements around maintaining 6 ft distancing at bars become recommendations: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, some level of bar restrictions continue (75 pct capacity for Moderate transmission counties and required at least 6 ft distancing among tables/groups in High transmission counties): https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-19-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf On 20201124 eases restrictions for High transmission counties, no longer requiring bars to close at 10 pm, but rather prohibiting the sale or offer of liquor or beer onsite after 10 pm and and ends distancing requirement for Low transmission counties https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf.. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210223 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-3-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210326 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-5_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210410 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-9-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20210616 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-10_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met, moving all business restrictions to recommendations. Businesses are encouraged to reference the Utah Business Manual, which contains guidance for topics like contact tracing, cleaning protocol, protecting vulnerable staff from the risk of infection, and other safety practices. Coded as Ending. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-11.pdf

Under Public Health Orange, service providers and customers must wear face coverings during services. Recommendations for employee mask use are listed under hotels and tourism businesses. On 20200516, expands businesses and sectors were employees are required to wear face coverings: restaurants and bars, gyms and fitness centers (patrons are encouraged to wear face coverings), presonal service providers and patrons (previously required). It is strongly recommended that customers and employees wear face coverings at retail, including grocery stores (does not use must like in other sectors): https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-22.pdf Eases on 20200612 as some counties move to Public Health Risk Green and thus those are recommendations: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

By moving the state to orange risk, recommends not having social interactions in groups of more than 20. Originally statewide, but increasingly becomes applicable to sub-state as locations are moved to Public Health Risk Yellow and Orange. Salt Lake City remains in the orange phase as of 20200808 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-44.pdf Extended to 20200821 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-49.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: In moving to public health risk orange, businesses may re-open with extreme caution. Applying to nightclubs, as they were closed alongside bars and restaurants. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel. Note that restrictions for bars are being applied to bars unless otherwise specified, as they were closed in the same manner. Starting on 20200612, eases policy to no longer apply to all locations when counties start going to Public Health Risk Green: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf Extends requirements for at least 6 ft distancing to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. On 20201124 Ends distancing requirement for Moderate and Low transmission counties https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met, moving all business restrictions to recommendations. Businesses are encouraged to reference the Utah Business Manual, which contains guidance for topics like contact tracing, cleaning protocol, protecting vulnerable staff from the risk of infection, and other safety practices. Coded as Ending. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-11.pdf

Dine-in services are allowed (quote) with extreme caution (quote) upon the designation of the COVID19 public health risk being downgraded to orange. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel. Began easing at the state level on 20200612 when counties began moving to Public Health Risk Green (no longer applied): https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf Extended to 20201113 under the new transmission phase risk levels: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf On 20201124 Ends distancing requirement for Low transmission counties https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met, moving all business restrictions to recommendations. Public Health Risk Status Yellow: recommends social gatherings of 50 or fewer. Applicable to locations that are not Grand County, Summit County, Wasatch County, Salt Lake City, West Valley City, and Magna metro township on 20200516. Increasingly more locations are phased to the yellow phase but then also some are phased to green starting on 20200612: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf Extended to 20200920: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-62.pdf Extended to 20201021 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-2020-63.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: For yellow phase locations, (quote) Beginning 1200pm noon on Wednesday, May 27, school activities, including sports, may resume under jurisdiction of district and school authorities in adherence to indoor and outdoor guidelines (quote) Instruction remains remote until the 2020-2021 academic year. On 20200626, green and yellow phase counties can re-open for in-person schooling: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-33.pdf Ended on 20200717, with Phased 4.8 guidelines allowing in-person instruction at all risk levels: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-44.pdf

Requires use of a face covering in state facilities (i.e., any building or structure that is owned or leased by the state or a state governmental entity - any department, board, commission, institution, agency or instition of a higher education of the state). State issued clarifying orders on 20200629 (EO 35: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-35.pdf) and 20200630 (EO 36: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-36.pdf) but did not change the policy substantively, or its timing. Coded as Mandate1 as it applies to limited settings (i.e., state facilities). Extended to 20200808: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-45.pdf Extended to 20200821 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-48.pdf Extended on 20200904 with no expiry date https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-59.pdf Extended to 20201021 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-2020-63.pdf

(quote) Each individual, including an employee, student, or visitor, on school property or on a school bus shall wear a face covering (quote) unless they can maintain physical distance of at least 6 from other individuals outdoors, when eating or drinking and maintaining at least 6 ft between individuals, children who are younger than 3, and for various medical exemptions. Applies to K-12 schools. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-28_Updated_School_Face_Mask_Order.pdf. Extended to 20210616 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-2-Updated-School-Face-Mask-Order.pdf. On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met and announces that the school mask mandate will remain in place until 20210616 or the last day of the school year, whichever occurs first. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-11.pdf On 20210513, moves the end date for school mask requirements forward, so that it will remain in effect until the Monday of the final week of school or May 31 in the case of non-traditional schools (DateExpiry coded as 20210531). The school mask mandate was originally scheduled to remain in place through the end of the school year or June 15th in the case of non-traditional schools. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-12-School-Face-Mask-Test-to-Play.pdf

Declares a public health emergency without clear expiry. Treating as separate from the original state of emergency declaration as this is a public health emergency declaration. According to Utah State Code (https://le.utah.gov/xcode/Title26/Chapter23B/C26-23b_1800010118000101.pdf), this declaration automatically expires after 90 days, in this case on 20210113. This public health emergency was thus extended on that date, issued by the Interim Executive Director of the Utah Department of Health, who (quote) finds and Governor Spencer J. Cox concurs that a public health emergency exists and that the continuation of the declaration of a statewide public health emergency is appropriate to protect public health and wellness and control the causes of the COVID-19 pandemic. (quote). Extended to 20210413. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/SPHO-2021-1-State-Public-Health-Emergency-Declaration.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in Low levels are strongly encouraged to have people wear masks or face coverings in public but do not require them beyond very specific settings (i.e., gatherings of more than 50). Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel, but treating as a an easing from the previous order (i.e., requirement to wear at state-owned buildings). Applies to Daggett, Kane, Piute, Rich, Wayne. A (quote) circuit breaker (quote) phase will occur where both Moderate and High transmission levels will be required to wear masks in public indoors and outdoors. Beyond 20201029, this applies to both Moderate and Low transmission counties (with requirements to wear masks in gatherings more than 25 for moderate transmission levels) https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in High transmission level have a mask mandate wherein masks or face coverings are required in all public places indoors and outdoors where at least 6 ft distancing cannot occur. Exempts children under 3 years old, due to medical conditions, etc. Coded as Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it is widely applicable across settings (indoors and outdoors). Applies to Beaver, Box Elder, Cache, Carbon, Davis, Emery, Garfield, Grand, Juab, Millard, Morgan, Salt Lake, San Juan, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Tooele, Utah, Wasatch, Washington, Weber. For 20201014 to 20201029, a (quote) circuit breaker (quote) this applies to Moderate transmission counties as well: Duchesne, Iron, Uintah. Starting 20201029, only applies to High transmission locations, so coding as easing: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in the high level of transmission require all employees to wear masks in public indoor settings and outdoors when physical distancing is not feasible. Businesses in moderate and low transmission levels are encouraged to have employees wear masks or individual businesses can determine requirements. Extended to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, for counties in the low transmission risk level, gatherings of more than 50 cannot occur unless people are wearing masks or face coverings. Coding as a gathering restriction of up to 50 being permitted. Applicable to Daggett, Kane, Piute, Rich, Wayne. Extended to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

WIth the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in Moderate and High transmission levels are not permitted to have gatherings more than 10 and face masks are required. Initially applicable to Duchesne, Iron, Uintah, Beaver, Box Elder, Cache, Carbon, Davis, Emery, Garfield, Grand, Juab, Millard, Morgan, Salt Lake, San Juan, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Tooele, Utah, Wasatch, Washington, Weber. Starting 20201029, Moderate transmission level counties can have gatherings up to 25 people, coding as easing. Also extends to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

Following the (quote) circuit breaker (quote) period, counties in Moderate transmission level can gatherings of more than 25 cannot occur unless people are wearing masks or face coverings. Coding as a gathering restriction of up to 25 being permitted. Applicable to Iron only on 20201029 and Millard starting 20201105: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf

Statewide, employees in business settings are required to wear masks and can ask patrons to wear masks or require them to leave if they refuse. Extended to 20201209: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210223 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-3-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210326 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-5_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210410 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-9-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf
State of emergency declared through December 8, 2020 (so coded to 20201209). Coded separately from the public health emergency

Statewide, requires social gatherings to be within households only. Coding as gathering of 0 at present. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/State_of_Emergency.pdf Ended on 20201124: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

Statewide, all individuals shall wear a face mask while within 6 ft of any individual from a separate household. Exemptions are for children under the age of 3 years old, individuals whose medical conditions would otherwise put wearing a mask unsafe, while eating/drinking, etc. Coding as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across settings (indoors and outdoors). Extended to 20201209: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210223 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-3-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210326 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-5_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210410 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-9-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf

For Low risk transmission counties, social gatherings are recommended to be no more than 50. Religious gatherings are exempt. In public gatherings at venues, at least 6 ft distancing is required, but this is being coded under business restrictions Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. As of 20201210, applicable to following counties: Daggett, Piute, Rich, Wayne. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. County levels updated every Thursday. Extended to 20210123 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210223 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2021-3-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. As of 20210204, applicable to the following counties: Daggett, Garfield, Piute. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. On 20210218 Wayne county joins Low Risk category https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. On 20210223 eases gathering restrictions for Low risk counties, where social gatherings are no longer recommended to be no more than 50 indoors or outdoors https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf

For Moderate and High risk transmission counties, social gatherings are recommended to be no more than 10. Religious gatherings are exempt. In public gatherings at venues, at least 6 ft distancing is required, but this is being coded under business restrictions Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Eases the statewide requirement that each employee and contractor must wear a face mask while at work. Masks are now required only at organized events hosted by a business, including a restaurant, and businesses must post conspicuous signage about the mask requirement. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-10_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met and no longer issues business-specific mask guidance. Masks are still recommended indoors with members outside your own household, but this recommendation is being coded under PublicMask. Coded as Ended. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-11.pdf

Eases the statewide mask requirement that previously required face coverings in most indoor and outdoor settings. Now, masks are required only in gatherings of 50 or more and while attending any organized event. Coding as Mandate1, given the very limited scope of the policy to certain large gatherings. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-10_Updated_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf On 20210504, Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met, moving the mask mandate to a recommendation. Coded as Ended. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2021-11.pdf

Utah announces that all COVID-19 thresholds established in HB294 have been met, moving the mask mandate to a recommendation. Now recommends that individuals wear a mask unless they are outdoors, by yourself, or with members of your own household.

Vermonters shall wear masks or cloth facial gatherings over their nose and mouth any time they are in public spaces, indoors or outdoors, where they come in contact with others from outside their households, especially in congregate settings, and where it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 6 ft. Exemptions are for children under the age of 2 years old, individuals with medical or developmental conditions that make wearing a facial covering not possible, during strenuous exercise or activity. In effect 20200801. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All multi-household social gatherings indoors and outdoors in public and private spaces are prohibited. This includes all public and private gatherings including but not limited to household gatherings, parties, weddings, events, etc (quote) Coding as 0 for indoor and outdoor gatherings. Religious gatherings must comply with venue capacity limits of no more than 50 pct or up to 75 total people for indoors and no more than 150 people for outdoors. Extended to 20210116: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%209%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. (quote) Expanded on 20210107, returning to the pre-holiday policy that prohibits all multi-household social gatherings indoors and outdoors in public and private spaces, including parties, weddings, events, etc. (quote) The holidays are over and the spread of COVID-19 in Vermont is still a concern. We have returned to the protocol that you may not gather with anyone you don’t live with. If you have gathered with people you don’t live with, you should quarantine. The Health Department strongly encourages getting tested as soon as possible and then again on day 7. (quote) No longer an expiration date, is effective until further notice. https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order. Extended on 20210115, https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2010%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Eased on 20201223 https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19.
