PolicyCodingNotes:
Extends restaurant restrictions, allowing restaurants, catering, food service may continue to allow 50 percent of fire safety occupancy or 1 person per 100 square feet, with a maximum of 75 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. This order adds that restaurants must be closed to in-person dining at 10:00 p.m, no more than one household per table. https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%208%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%209%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Extended to 20210216 https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2010%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2011%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Slightly eased on 20210312 to allow multiple households per table, but no more than six individuals per table: https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order. Extended to 20210416: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2012%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Extended to 20210516: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/Addendum%2014%20to%20Amended%20and%20Restated%20Executive%20Order%20No.%2001-20.pdf. Eased on 20210501 to remove capacity restrictions, as Group B sectors must now follow distancing and mask requirements in Universal Guidance. 10pm curfew remains. https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations. Extended to 20210616: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2016%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%20NO.%2001-20.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions for the holiday season, (quote) Governor Phil Scott announced a temporary modification to restrictions on multi-household gathers during the holidays. Between December 23rd and January 2nd, households may gather with one other trusted household. (quote) Coding InGathLim and OutGathLim as 5, as the average household size in Vermont from 2015-2019 was 2.3. https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/VT

Gathering restrictions are expanded on 20210107, (quote) returning to the pre-holiday policy that prohibits all multi-household social gatherings indoors and outdoors in public and private spaces, including parties, weddings, events, etc. (quote) Extended to 20210216, https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2010%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Extended to 20210316: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2011%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Effective 20210223, gathering restrictions are eased for vaccinated individuals and households only, permitting them to gather with one other household: https://governor.vermont.gov/press-release/governor-phil-scott-announces-new-covid-19-travel-and-gathering-guidance.

Exempts fully vaccinated individuals from travel restrictions: (quote) If you have been vaccinated, you do not need to quarantine to travel to Vermont or return to Vermont, as long as at least 14 days have passed since you received your final vaccine dose. (quote) For those who have not been vaccinated: Travelers arriving in Vermont must complete either a 14-day quarantine or a 7-day quarantine followed by a negative test. Extended to 20210416: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2012%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Eased on 20210409 such that travelers arriving in Vermont must test up to three days prior to travel and produce the negative result upon arrival. Returning Vermonters must test within three days of arrival. Quarantine is no longer required for those producing a negative test or while awaiting test results. https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/travel-quarantine. Extended to 20210516: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/Addendum%2014%20to%20Amended%20and%20Restated%20Executive%20Order%20No.%2001-20.pdf. Ended on 20210514: https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/travel-quarantine

Eases gathering restrictions for unvaccinated households such that up to two unvaccinated individials or households may gather. This includes all public and private gatherings including but not limited to household gatherings, parties, weddings, events, etc. Coded as limit of 5 people because average household size in Vermont is about 2.3. Religious gatherings must comply with venue capacity limits of no more than 50 pct or up to 75 total people for indoors and no more than 150 people for outdoors. Vaccinated individuals are no longer subject to gathering restrictions. Extended to 20210416: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2012%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf. Extended to 20210516: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/Addendum%2014%20to%20Amended%20and%20Restated%20Executive%20Order%20No.%2001-20.pdf.

Eases restrictions on bars to allow indoor services. Bars may operate at 50 pct of fire safety occupancy or 1 person per 100 square feet, with a maximum of 75 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. Bars must be closed to in-person dining at 10:00 p.m, no more than six individuals per table, can be from multiple households. Extended to 20210516: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/Addendum%2014%20to%20Amended%20and%20Restated%20Executive%20Order%20No.%2001-20.pdf. Eased on 20210501 to remove capacity restrictions, as Group B sectors 
must now follow distancing and mask requirements in Universal Guidance. 10pm curfew remains. https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations. Extended to 20210616: 
https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2016%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%20NO.%2001-20.pdf

Eases mask mandate for public outdoor spaces such that masks are required outdoors while in a crowd or with multiple other households where one cannot avoid close contact. Masks are still required in all public indoor spaces. Exemptions are for children under the age of 2 years old, individuals with medical or developmental conditions that make wearing a facial covering not possible, during strenuous exercise or activity. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor settings and very narrowly to outdoor settings.

Eases gathering restrictions. Unvaccinated individuals may gather indoors 1 person per 100 square feet or 150 people (whichever is fewer), up to 300 may gather outdoors. This includes all public and private gatherings including but not limited to household gatherings, parties, weddings, events, religious gatherings, etc. Vaccinated individuals are not subject to numerical gathering restrictions, but venues may not admit capacity that exceeds Universal Guidance spacing requirements.

Eases gathering restrictions. Unvaccinated individuals may gather indoors 1 person per 50 square feet (from 100) up to 300 people (from 150), up to 900 may gather outdoors (from 300). This includes all public and private gatherings including but not limited to household gatherings, parties, weddings, events, religious gatherings, etc. Vaccinated individuals are not subject to numerical gathering restrictions, but venues may not admit capacity that exceeds Universal Guidance spacing requirements. Extended to 20210616: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2016%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%20NO.%2001-20.pdf

Extends restrictions on Group B sectors, including bars and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Bars must follow Universal Guidance, which requires distancing and masks. Bars must be closed to in-person dining at 10:00 p.m. Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Exempts vaccinated individuals from state business mask policies. Extends requirement for unvaccinated people to be masked in businesses, noting that businesses may implement stricter mask policies than state requirements.

Extends restrictions on Group A Sectors, including farmers markets, and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Farmers markets must follow universal guidance, which requires ensuring six feet of distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Extends restrictions on Group A Sectors, including businesses which support outdoor recreation such as state and municipal parks, recreation associations, trail networks, golfcourses, big game check stations and guided expeditions, and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Such entities must follow universal guidance, which requires ensuring six feet of distancing and masks.Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Extends restrictions on Group A Sectors, including retail and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Retail establishments must follow universal guidance, which requires ensuring six feet of distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Extends restrictions on Group B sectors, including the following: gymnasiums, fitness centers and similar exercise facilities, massage therapists, nail salons, spas, tattoo parlors, indoor recreation facilities (such as skating rinks and field houses), and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Establishments must follow universal guidance, which requires ensuring six feet of distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Eases restrictions for event venues, arts, culture, sporting, concert and entertainment venues serving the public and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. These venues are subject to the state gathering restrictions, which permit one unvaccinated person per 50 sq feet indoors (from 100), up to 300 unvaccinated people (from 150), and as many vaccinated people as Universal Guidance spacing requirments permit. For outdoor venues, up to 900 unvaccinated people are permitted (from 300), and any number of vaccinated people as Universal Guidance spacing requirements permit. If an event cannot determine vaccination status, then all attendees should be assumed to be unvaccinated. Extends restrictions for Group B sectors, including galleries, museums, theaters and other indoor arts, culture and entertainment organizations, and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Establishments must follow universal guidance, which requires six feet of distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Exempts vaccinated people from mask mandate. Unvaccinated people must continue to wear masks in public indoor spaces and in crowded outdoor spaces. Exemptions are for children under the age of 2 years old, individuals with medical or developmental conditions that make wearing a facial covering not possible, during strenuous exercise or activity. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor settings and very narrowly to outdoor settings.

Extends restrictions for Group B sectors, including restaurants, and introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals. Restaurants, catering, and food service must follow Universal Guidance, which requires distancing and masks. Restaurants must be closed to in-person dining at 10:00 p.m, no more than six individuals per table, can be from multiple households.  Fully vaccinated individuals no longer need to socially distance or wear masks.

Extends restrictions on bars but removes 10 pm curfew. Unvaccinated individuals must follow Universal Guidance, which requires distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals do not need to socially distance or wear masks.

Extends restrictions on restaurants but removes 10 pm curfew. Unvaccinated individuals must follow Universal Guidance, which requires distancing and masks. Fully vaccinated individuals do not need to socially distance or wear masks.
Masks are encouraged for unvaccinated individuals.

State of Emergency declaration. Expiry is 20200610 unless amended or extended. Extended without formal expiry on 20200526: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-51-AMENDED-Declaration-of-a-State-of-Emergency-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Under Virginia law, a state of emergency expires on June 30 next after the end of the legislative session, so coding expiry as 20210630.  Allowed to expire on 20210630: https://www.insidenova.com/headlines/covid-19-state-of-emergency-over-but-cases-going-up-again-in-virginia/article_b67633ec-db3f-11eb-b79b-43636fd8e4ba.html
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateExpiry, DateEnded, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: All K-12 schools in Virginia to close Monday March 16 through Friday March 27, so expiry coded as 20200328
Governor Northam announced restrictions on gatherings of 100 or more at press conference. No further documentation has been identified to date

(quote) Observations of 10 or more patrons in a...fitness center or theater may result in immediate operation permit suspension (quote). Coding as a restriction on these businesses, with IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel
Mandated to reduce capacity to 10 patrons or close, or have carry-out or take-away

Limited operations required (delivery and take-out only): breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, tasting rooms. Grouping these as bar restrictions. Began easing on 20200515 for most of Virginia: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-61-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Three---Phase-One-Easing-Of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-To-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf.

In effect at 1159 pm on 2020034, coded to 20200325 enactment. Initial expiry is 20200423 at 1159 pm, so 20200424. Easing of the gathering restriction for 10 started on 20200515, allowing for religious services to exceed 10 as long as 50 pct capacity is not exceeded https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-61-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Three---Phase-One-Easing-Of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-To-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Extended to 20200529: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Closure required: theaters, performing arts centers, concert venues, museums, and other indoor entertainment centers, fitness centers, gymnasiums, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, and indoor exercise facilities, beauty salons, barbershops, spas, massage parlors, tanning salons, tattoo shops, and any other location where personal care or personal grooming services are performed that would not allow compliance with social distancing guidelines to remain six feet apart, racetracks and historic horse racing facilities, bowling alleys, skating rinks, arcades, amusement parks, trampoline parks, fairs, arts and craft facilities, aquariums, zoos, escape rooms, indoor shooting ranges, public and private social clubs, and all other places of indoor public amusement. On 20200515, eased restrictions on at least some of these businesses for most of Virginia: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-61-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Three---Phase-One-Easing-Of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-To-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf By 20200701, all businesses or venues that had been closed under this entry could re-open to some capacity: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

(quote) Any brick and mortar retail business not listed in paragraph 5 may continue to operate but must limit all in-person shopping to no more than 10 patrons per establishment. If any such business cannot adhere to the 10 patron limit with proper social distancing requirements, it must close (quote). Eases restrictions to permit at least 50 pct capacity for most locations in Virginia starting 20200515: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-61-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Three---Phase-One-Easing-Of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-To-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Becomes statewide at 50 pct capacity on 20200529: https://twitter.com/GovernorVA/status/1265681555969671176 Further eases on 20200701, removing capacity limits and only requires at least 6 ft distancing: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf.  Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Limited operations required (delivery and take-out only): restaurants and other dining establishments. Now no restricted in-person service allowed at all. Initial expiry is 20200423 at 1159 pm, so 20200424.

(quote) Closure of all public beaches as defined in 10.1-705 of the Code of Virginia for all activity, except exercising and fishing. Social distancing requirements must be followed (quote). Coding as a closure that still permits limited activity (OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel).

Closes institutions of higher education for in-person instruction, and cancels gatherings of more than 10 individuals. Treating as a separate closure from K-12 schools given separate orders for their closure. Initially ended (coding as eased at the state-level) for a subset of locations on 20200605: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/eo/EO-65-Phase-Two.pdf Fully ended at the state level on 20200612: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-65-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Six---AMENDED---Phase-Two-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

All individuals in Virginia shall remain at their place of residence. Ended on 20200605 by allowing EO-55 to expire then https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/eo/EO-65-Phase-Two.pdf
Closes all private campgrounds for stays less than 14 nights, which appears to be the definition of private campgrounds per Code of Virginia

Eases restrictions on breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, tasting rooms (broadly grouped as bars), allowing for outdoor services if they comply with requirements (ie, maximum of 50 percent occupancy, no more than 10 seated at a party, 6 ft social distancing, no bar seating, employees must wear masks or facial coverings in customer-facing areas). In effect at 12 am on 20200515. Between 20200512 and 20200514, portions of Virginia (Northern Virginia region and then Richmond, Accomack county) are moved back to Phase Zero where takeaway only is permitted, but these changes occurred before the policy went in effect - 20200512: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four---Jurisdictions-Temporarily-Delayed-From-Entering-Phase-One-in-Executive-Order-61-and-Permitted-to-Remain-in-Phase-Zero-Northern-Virginia-Region.pdf and 20200514: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Requires employees working in customer-facing areas to wear face coverings over their nose and months at all times at the following businesses: bars and restaurants, farmers markets, brick and mortar retail businesses, fitness and exercise facilities, personal care services, etc. As more sectors reopen, most are also required to have employees wear masks (or at least those with customer-facing roles). Extended on 20210301 with no new expiry: 
https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-THIRD-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

All public and private in-person gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited. As of 12 am on 20200515, individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items. This applied to Virginia excluding Northern Virginia Region and City of Richmond and County of Accomack, which still had gathering restrictions of 10 across settings beyond 20200515 after they were moved back to Phase Zero https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesses, allowing them to reopen for in-person services conditional on the following: personal care and grooming services (i.e., no more than 50 pct capacity, at least 6 ft distancing between stations, customers must wear face coverings during services, limiting services to those that can be done without customers removing their face coverings), indoor shooting ranges (i.e., no more than 50 pct capcity, at least 6 ft distancing between individuals at all times). Also permits farmers markets to reopen conditional on maintaining all physical distancing requirements. This was originally a statewide easing, but between 20200512 and 20200514, various locations in Virginia were moved back to Phase Zero: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesses, allowing them to reopen for in-person services conditional on the following: fitness and exercise facilities (i.e., at least 10 ft distancing, hot tubs, spas, spray pools etc must remain closed, no more than 10 people) for outdoor services only. This was originally a statewide easing, but between 20200512 and 20200514, various locations in Virginia were moved back to Phase Zero: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants and dining establishments, allowing for outdoor dining if they comply with requirements (ie, maximum of 50 percent occupancy, no more than 10 seated at a party, 6 ft social distancing, no bar seating, employees must wear masks or facial coverings in customer-facing areas). In effect at 12 am on 20200515. Between 20200512 and 20200514, portions of Virginia (Northern Virginia region and then Richmond, Accomack county) are moved back to Phase Zero where takeaway only is permitted, but these changes occurred before the policy went in effect - 20200512: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four---Jurisdictions-Temporarily-Delayed-From-Entering-Phase-One-in-Executive-Order-61-and-Permitted-to-Remain-in-Phase-Zero-Northern-Virginia-Region.pdf and 20200514: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Eases restrictions on Virginia Beach, allowing beaches to be open to individual and family recreational activity, in addition to exercise and fishing. Permits reopening at least some indoor areas, no more than 10 people groups permitted, physical distancing required, etc.

Requirement for all patrons 10 years and older to wear face coverings while inside public buildings and businesses. Explicitly lists personal care services, brick and mortal retail (essential and non-essential businesses), food and beverage establishments, entertainment and recreation businesses (also required in outdoor settings for these businesses if distancing cannot be maintained), shared transportation, and any indoor place shared by groups of people in close proximity to each other outside of personal residences. Coded as Mandate2 as it applies widely across indoor spaces. On 20201116, expanded to all individuals 5 years and over: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-63-AMENDED-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Five---Requirement-To-Wear-Face-Covering-While-Inside-Buildings.pdf.

All Virginia locations are now at Phase One for eased bar restrictions, allowing for outdoor services if they comply with requirements (ie, maximum of 50 percent occupancy, no more than 10 seated at a party, 6 ft social distancing, no bar seating, employees must wear masks or facial coverings in customer-facing areas). This includes breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, tasting rooms (broadly grouped as bars). Easing began for most of Virginia on 20200605: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/eo/Third-Amended-EO-61-Phase-I.pdf

All Virginia locations are now at Phase 1 for gatherings, such that gatherings of 10 or more are still prohibited, but with the exception that individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items.

All Virginia locations are now at Phase One for businesses, such that limited in-person services can occur for particular businesses (conditional on proper health and safety): personal care and grooming services (i.e., no more than 50 pct capacity, at least 6 ft distancing between stations, customers must wear face coverings during services, limiting services to those that can be done without customers removing their face coverings), indoor shooting ranges (i.e., no more than 50 pct capcity, at least 6 ft distancing between individuals at all times). Also permits farmers markets to reopen conditional on maintaining all physical distancing requirements. Further eases restrictions on 20200701, removing the 50 pct capacity limits for personal care and indoor shooting ranges: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

All Virginia locations are now at Phase One for businesses, with private campgrounds being able to reopen conditional on the following guidelines: at least 20 ft between units for lots for stays less than 14 days, provision of handwashing stations at bath houses, strong recommendations for customers to wear face coverings

All Virginia locations are now at Phase One for businesses, such that fitness and exercise facilities can reopen for outdoor services, with least 10 ft distancing, hot tubs, spas, spray pools etc must remain closed, no more than 10 people at a time for classes

All Virginia locations are now at Phase One for eased restaurant restrictions, allowing for outdoor dining if they comply with requirements (ie, maximum of 50 percent occupancy, no more than 10 seated at a party, 6 ft social distancing, no bar seating, employees must wear masks or facial coverings in customer-facing areas).

All public beaches may re-open to individual and family activity as long as physical distancing occurs, gatherings more than 10 are prohibited, cleaning schedules occurr for high-touch objectives, PPE for lifeguards, etc. Further eases restrictions on 20200701, allowing up to 250 people to gather with at least 6 ft distancing between different households at beaches: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Re-expands restrictions on public beaches at the state-level, reducing groups to no more than 25 people on 20201116: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Further-Adjusting-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Further expands restrictions on 20201214, reducing group size to no more than 10: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Common-Sense-Surge-Restrictions-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Extended until 20210301: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Common-Sense-Surge-Restrictions-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Eases public and private beach restrictions to 25 people outdoors (10 indoors) on 20210301: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-THIRD-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. On 20210401 eases restrictions in accordance with eased gathering restrictions to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-FOURTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Eased on 20210515 in accordance with eased gathering restrictions, allowing indoor class size up to 100 people and 250 people outdoors: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Eased restrictions on Phase Two locations, allowing for both indoor and outdoor services at bars and like venues as long as occupancy is not more than 50 percent, all parties must be lower than 50 patros or fewer, 6 ft distancing between tables, no self-service, customer-facing employees required to wear face covering. This includes breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, tasting rooms (broadly grouped as bars)

Eases gathering restrictions to no more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings for most of Virginia. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc

Further eases restrictions for fitness centers and gyms for locations in Phase Two, permitting both indoor and outdoor activities but with the following restrictions: at leats 10 ft distancing between patrons, no more than 50 people or 30 pct capacity for group exercises or classes, hot tubs spas spray pools, etc must remain closed, indoor and outdoor lap swimming permitted. Applicable to the following locations: Accomack, Albemarle, Alleghany, Amelia, Amherst, Appomattox, Augusta, Bath, Bedford, Bland, Botetourt, Brunswick, Buchanan, Buckingham, Campbell, Caroline, Carroll, Charles City, Charlotte, Chesterfield, Clarke, Craig, Culpeper, Cumberland, Dickenson, Dinwiddie, Essex, Fauquier, Floyd, Fluvanna, Franklin, Frederick, Giles, Gloucester, Goochland, Grayson, Greene, Greensville, Halifax, Hanover, Henrico, Henry, Highland, Isle of Wight, James City, King and Queen, King George, King William, Lancaster, Lee, Louisa, Lunenburg, Madison, Mathews, Mecklenburg, Middlesex, Montgomery, Nelson, New Kent, Northampton, Northumberland, Nottoway, Orange, Page, Patrick, Pittsylvania, Powhatan, Prince Edward, Prince George, Pulaski, Rappahannock, Richmond, Roanoke, Rockbridge, Rockingham, Russell, Scott, Shenandoah, Smyth, Southampton, Spotsylvania, Stafford, Surry, Sussex, Tazewell, Warren, Washington, Westmoreland, Wise, Wythe, York

Eased restrictions on Phase Two locations, allowing for both indoor and outdoor dining as long as occupancy is not more than 50 percent, all parties must be lower than 50 patros or fewer, 6 ft distancing between tables, no self-service, customer-facing employees required to wear face covering

Eases the closure of all K-12 schools. (quote) Governor Ralph Northam today announced a phased approach that allows Virginia schools to slowly resume in-person classes for summer school and the coming academic year. The K-12 phased reopening plan was developed by the Office of the Secretary of Education, Virginia Department of Health, and the Virginia Department of Education and is informed by guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ... Local school divisions will have discretion on how to operationalize within each phase and may choose to offer more limited in-person options than the phase permits, if local public health conditions necessitate. (quote) Decision power now localized, so state level authority no longer in control of school closures, but plans for reopening by local districts must be submitted to the state ahead of allowing in-person instruction again. On 20200706, devolves policy from state-level coordination to local levels, ending the state policy: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/Final-Phase-Guidance-for-Virginia-Schools-6.9.20.pdf

(quote) In every phase, PreK-12 schools must follow CDC Guidance for Schools, including social and physical distancing...The use of cloth face coverings by staff when at least six feet physical distancing cannot be maintained, and Encouraging the use of face coverings in students, as developmentally appropriate, in settings where physical distancing cannot be maintained (quote). Requirements are expanded on 20201116, lowering the age for mask requirements for ages 5 years and older and applying to children at schools (at least indoors): https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/frequently-asked-questions/schools-k-12/#:~:text=The%20measures%20include%20the%20expansion,exercising%20%2C%20at%20recess%20for%20example.

Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased bar restrictions: allowing for both indoor and outdoor dining as long as occupancy is not more than 50 percent, all parties must be lower than 50 patrons or fewer, 6 ft distancing between tables, no self-service, customer-facing employees required to wear face covering. This includes breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, tasting rooms (broadly grouped as bars). Eased on 20200701, removing capacity limits, continuing to require at least 6 ft distancing, seated services, etc: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased restrictions for gatherings. No more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes:
Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased restrictions and thus permitting both indoor and outdoor activities for fitness and exercise facilities but with the following restrictions: at least 10 ft distancing between patrons, no more than 50 people or 30 pct capacity for group exercises or classes, hot tubs spas spray pools, etc must remain closed, indoor and outdoor lap swimming permitted. Further eases restrictions on 20200701, allowing up to 75 pct capacity and no explicit limits for class sizes: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Reexpands policy on 20201116, further reducing class size restrictions (i.e., no more than 25 people): https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Further-Adjusting-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Further re-expands on 20201214, reducing class sizes to no more than 10: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Common-Sense-Surge-Restrictions-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Extended until 20210301: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Common-Sense-Surge-Restrictions-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Extended on 20210301 with no new expiry: 
https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-THIRD-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Eased on 20210401 in accordance with eased gathering restrictions, allowing indoor class size up to 50 people and 100 people outdoors: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-FOURTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Eased on 20210515 in accordance with eased gathering restrictions, allowing indoor class size up to 100 people and 250 people outdoors: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf Ends restrictions on 20210528 https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-79-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Ten-Ending-of-Commonsense-Public-Health-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased restaurant restrictions: allowing for both indoor and outdoor dining as long as occupancy is not more than 50 percent, all parties must be lower than 50 patrons or fewer, 6 ft distancing between tables, no self-service, customer-facing employees required to wear face covering, no bar seating. Futher eased on 20200701, removing capacity limits but continuing requirements for at least 6 ft distancing, remaining seated, etc: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Eases prior gathering restrictions, now (quote) All public and private in-person gatherings of more than 250 individuals are prohibited. (quote) No capacity limits for religious gatherings, requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting them to reopen indoors and outdoors at no more than 50 pct capacity (or no more than 1000 people, whichever is less) and requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals (and 10 ft distancing at venues with physical acitivity, singing, or cheering): amusement venues (historic horse racing facilities, bowling alleys, skating rinks, arcades, amusement parks, trampoline parks, fairs, carnivals, arts and craft facilities, escape rooms, and other places of indoor public amusement), entertainment venues (performing arts venues, concert venues, sports venues, movie theaters, museums, aquariums, zoos, and botanical gardens), outdoor racetracks, and public and private social clubs. Expands restrictions on 20201116, reducing capacity to no more than 30 pct or on more than 250 people (some exceptions for zoos and amusement parks): https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Further-Adjusting-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Outdoor restrictions eased on 20210301, allowing for up to 1000 individuals at certain outdoor venues: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-THIRD-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. Expands mask mandate, now requiring all Virginians 5 years and older (from 10 years) to wear face coverings in indoor public spaces and outdoors where 6 ft distance cannot be maintained.This requirement applies to state and local government settings, train stations, bus stations, and intrastate public transportation, including buses, rideshares, trains, taxis, and cars for hire, as well as any waiting or congregating areas associated with boarding public transportation. This mandate also applies outdoors when unable to maintain at least six feet of physical distance from other individuals who are not Family members. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies widely across indoor and outdoor spaces. Extended until 20210301: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Common-Sense-Surge-Restrictions-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. CDC guidelines stipulate masks for all indoor and outdoor public settings for unvaccinated persons. Vaccinated persons are recommended to wear a mask at public indoor settings and during crowded outdoor settings. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies widely across indoor and outdoor spaces for unvaccinated people, VaccineExempt is NA because the mask mandate still applies to vaccinated people in public indoor settings and crowded outdoor settings. https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-72-SIXTH-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Nine-Easing-of-Commonsense-Surge-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf. State of Emergency. Does not include a formal expiry date
Only applicable to King, Pierce, and Snohomish Counties. Initial expiry was midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401 per coding criteria
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all schools K-12 (public, private, and charter) for King, Pierce, and Snohomish counties. Goes in effect 1201 am 20200317, through 20200424 at 12 pm (unless extended). Eased for summer school on: _source=govdelivery.
Applies 250 gathering limit to all Washington state counties. Initial expiry was midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401 per coding criteria
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide closure of all public, private, and charter schools comes into effect 1201 am on 20200317, through 20200424 at 12 pm for initial expiry. Eases restrictions on K-12 summer operations starting 202000620: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20.09.2%20COVID19%20Phased%20Reopening%20of%20K12%20Schools.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Statewide closure of all private, public, and private-public universities, colleges, technical schools, etc. to in-person instruction. Treating separately from the K-12 closures. A 20200624 order declared that (quote) beginning on August 1, 2020, public and private universities, colleges, technical schools, apprenticeship programs, and similar schools and programs may resume general instruction, to include in-person classroom instruction, lectures and similar educational gatherings, only if they implement, follow, and enforce the requirements specified below (quote). Coding as ending the statewide closure of higher education on 20200801

Limited operations required (onsite consumption banned): bars and taverns. Initial expiry is through midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401. Began easing restrictions on 20200511, when restaurant and bar guidance was published for Phase 2 counties: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-issues-guidance-partially-resuming-dine-restaurant-and-tavern-industry-phase-2
Expands gathering restriction to no more than 50

Closure required: public venues in which people congregate for entertainment, social or recreational purposes, including but not limited to theaters, bowling alleys, gyms, fitness centers, non-tribal card rooms, barbershops and hair/nail salons, tattoo parlors, pool halls, and other similar venues. Also closes all retail businesses except groceries and pharmacy. Easing began on 20200508 with takeaway for non-essential retail: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.3%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Home%20Stay%20Healthy%20-%20Reopening%20%28tmp%29.pdf.

Limited operations required (onsite consumption banned): restaurants, coffee shops, any social club, etc. Initial expiry is through midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401. Easing begain on 20200511, with first counties moving to Phase 2:

(quote) All people in Washington state shall immediately cease participating in all public and private gatherings and multi-preson activities for social, spiritual and recreational purposes, regardles of the number people of involved (quote). Began easing on 20200508 with Phase 2 counties being able to have up to 5 people in a single gathering

State-wide immediate stay-at-home, effective immediately: https://mynorthwest.com/1782819/inslee-washington-stay-at-home-order/ Easing began with transition to Safe Start WA, no longer mandating statewide stay-at-home orders for all populations (high risk in Phase 1 counties) https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf Fully ended mandate on 20200703 as all populations are no longer mandate https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1

(quote) Effective midnight on March 25, 2020, all non-essential businesses in Washington State shall cease operations except for performing basic minimum operations (quote) Coding DateEnacted as 20200326.

With initial business restrictions being eased for Phase 1, requirements for employees to wear masks or face coverings being (e.g., vehicle and vessel sales under Phase 1). The May 4 Safe Start Washington also stipulates the following: (quote) Identify personal protective equipment (PPE) and cloth facial coverings in accordance with L and I requirements on facial coverings and industry specific COVID-19 standards. (quote) On June 8, this was substantially expanded, (quote) (quote) Beginning on June 8, 2020, when on the job, all employees must wear a facial covering except when working alone or when the job has no in-person interaction as detailed in the Safe Start Washington Phased Reopening Plan, and, further, that employers must provide cloth facial coverings to employees, unless their exposure dictates a higher level of protection (quote). Coding as an expanded business mask mandate: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf
Recommends that all individuals should wear cloth face coverings in public places when not eating or drinking

Eases restrictions on vehicle and vessel sales, permitting these businesses to resume in-person indoor services with limited capacity (50 pct capacity maximum, maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft). Permitted to re-open upon the release of guidelines for vehicle and vessal sales
Eases restrictions on retail, allowing for curbside pick-up orders only (no-onsite service)
Eases restrictions on the following outdoor businesses: landscaping and lawn care, pet walking

Once counties move to Phase 2, gatherings of 5 or fewer can occur. Eased on 20200527, with religious gatherings permitting more people: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-religious-and-faith-based-services-guidance

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, bar restrictions are eased such that in-person services can resume conditional on guidelines being followed (no more than 50 percent occupancy, 5 or fewer people per table, distancing, sanitation, no bar area seating). Though Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille moved to Phase 2 on 20200508, bar and restaurant guidelines were issued on 20200511 and thus could not re-open for in-person services until then. As of 20200511, applies to the following counties: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum. Continues to add more Phase 2 and then Phase 1.5 counties over time. Eased on 20200605 permitting for Phase 3 counties to have bar areas open: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, restaurant restrictions are eased such that in-person services can resume conditional on guidelines being followed (no more than 50 percent occupancy, 5 or fewer people per table, distancing, sanitation, no bar area seating). Though Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille moved to Phase 2 on 20200508, bar and restaurant guidelines were issued on 20200511 and thus could not re-open for in-person services until then. As of 20200511, applies to the following counties: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, retail businesses may resume in-person services at limited capacity, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Counties currently in Phase 2 moved there prior to 20200512, but they could not re-open retail for in-person services until the guideline were issued. Applies to: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum. From May through July, more counties move to this level of restriction until it is statewide. Ended 20210630.

Gathering restrictions are eased for Phase 2 counties, allowing up to 50 individuals or 25 pct capacity for indoor religious gatherings. No limit provided for indoor religious gatherings. Eased when counties could move to Phase on 20200605: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

Gathering restrictions are eased for Phase 1 counties, allowing up to 100 individuals for outdoor religious gatherings. No indoor gatherings permitted. Eased when counties could start moving to Phase 1.5 (King) on 20200605: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

For Phase 1 counties, stay-at-home order remains a mandate but only for high-risk populations (i.e., individuals 65 and older, those with underlying medical conditions that put them at higher risk for complications from COVID-19, persons living in nursing homes and long-term care facilities). Phase 1 counties as of Safe Start enactment are 13 in total (i.e., not Adams, Asotin, Clallam, Columbia, Cowlitz, Ferry, Garfield, Grant, Grays Harbor, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Lewis, Lincoln, Mason, Pacific, Pend Orielle, San Juan, Skamania, Spokane, Stevens, Thurston, Wahkiakum, Walla Walla, and Whitman) From 20200605 to 20200703, increasingly more counties moved out of Phase 1 and thus eased this policy. Ended on 20200703 when all counties moved out of Phase 1: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1

For Phase 2 counties, stay-at-home recommendation for high risk individuals (i.e., individuals 65 and older, those with underlying medical conditions that put them at higher risk for complications from COVID-19, persons living in nursing homes and long-term care facilities). Phase 2 counties as of Safe Start enactment are 26 in total (i.e., Adams, Asotin, Clallam, Columbia, Cowlitz, Ferry, Garfield, Grant, Grays Harbor, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Lewis, Lincoln, Mason, Pacific, Pend Orielle, San Juan, Skamania, Spokane, Stevens, Thurston, Wahkiakum, Walla Walla, and Whitman). From 20200605 to 20200703, increasingly more counties move to this policy to eventually become statewide https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1. Extended without expiry starting on 20200727: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Per issuance of Phase 1 and Phase 2 guidelines, limited library operations may occur statewide. For Phase 1 counties, Washington Talking Book and Braille Library establishments may resume operations for book orders by mail. For Phase 2 counties, libraries may resume operations for takeaway/curbside delivery only. Coding this easing as statewide as TakeawayOnly for BusinessRestrictLevel. Reexpanded on 20201117 as statewide, libraries can only provide curbside pick up. According to the most recent proclamation https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.8.pdf (quote) If an activity is not listed below, currently existing guidance shall continue to apply (quote). The guidance that is applying is then Phase 1 modified guidance (i.e. curbside library services). Restrictions on libraries are re-eased on 20210201 for both Phase 1 and Phase 2 counties: Libraries can reopen in person at 25 pct capacity. Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston move from Phase 1 to Phase 2. All other counties remain in Phase 1 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/roadmap-recovery-metrics

Once counties move to Phase 3, gatherings of 50 or fewer can occur. When the first set of counties moved to Phase 3, it applied to 7 countes (Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Stevens and Wahkiakum). By 20200611, this applies to 10 counties. On 20200618, eased for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-updated-religious-and-faith-based-services-guidance
King County is moved to Phase 1.5, where up to 5 people in a gathering may occur outside. Continues prior Phase 1 restrictions for religious gatherings

Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum move to Phase 3, where libraries can re-open to in-person services at more limited capacity (no more than 50 people) and physical distancing. On 20200606 Whitman moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/whitman-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200610 Asotin moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/three-additional-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200611 Skamania moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/skamania-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200616 Pacific County moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/pacific-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200617 Grays Harbor moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/grays-harbor-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200619 Island, Lewis and Mason move to phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/four-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan On 20200623 Kittitas moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/kittitas-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan  On 20200623 Thurston moves to Phase 3 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/thurston-county-approved-move-phase-3-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

Requires staff and students to wear cloth face coverings with the resumption of limited summer school services (quote) All students, volunteers, or guests must wear cloth face coverings at school. (quote)

Requires staff and students to wear cloth face coverings with the resumption of limited summer school services (quote) All students, volunteers, or guests must wear cloth face coverings at school. (quote).  Extended to 20200710 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/Safe%20Start%20Proc%2020-25.5.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery. Extended to 20200807 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.6%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery  Extended without expiry on 20200724 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery.  Reissued 20210630: Requires everyone five years or older to wear a mask regardless of vaccination status when in (quote) K-12 schools, childcare facilities, camps, or other youth settings where children are present or expected to be present (quote). In effect until rescinded or the end of the state of emegency. https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/Secretary_of_Health_Order_20-03_Statewide_Face_Coverings.pdf Eased to not require mask wearing outdoors except in crowded settings on 20210706: https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/820-105-K12Schools2021-2022.pdf. Adds that schools that do not adopt this guidance will not be allowed to open for in person instruction: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-09.4-COVID-19K-12Schools.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Eases restrictions on in-person instruction in K-12 schools, allowing schools to re-open starting June 20 for summer services subject to the requirements under school guidance documents. School reopening decisions now made at the local or district level. On 20200804, devolves authority to reopen schools to local authorities: https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/FallGuidanceK-12.pdf

For Phase 1.5 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 are in place: 5 people in a gathering may occur outside. Phase 1.5 counties now total 3 on 20200618: Chelan, Douglas, and King. By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 1.5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima.

For Phase 2 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 2 are in place: gathering restriction of more than 5 for Phase 2 counties, which are now 21 on 20200618: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Klickitat, Lewis, Mason, San Juan, Spokane, Thurston, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom. By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 2: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, San Juan, Spokane, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom.

For Phase 3 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 3 are in place: gathering restriction of more than 50 for Phase 3 counties, which are now 12 in Phase 3 on 20200618: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor. By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 3: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston.

(quote) Every person in Washington State must wear a face covering that covers their nose and mouth when in any indoor or outdoor setting (quote) Exemptions are for children younger than 5 or persons whose medical condition, mental health condition, or disability that would prevent earing a face covering. Expands prior recommendation to a full mandate. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200807: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.6%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery Effective 20200725, this mandate is somewhat expanded, explicitly requiring face coverings in public and non-public indoor and outdoor settings with few exemptions: https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/Secretary_of_Health_Order_20-03_Statewide_Face_Coverings.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateExpiry as latest extension has no expiry date

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide, bars can reopen for indoor and outdoor services across counties (though at different capacity levels across phases)

Benton, Franklin, Yakima move to Phase 1.5, allowing eased restrictions on retail to be statewide, though with variable occupancy limits by Phase (15 pct for Phase 1.5, 25 pct for Phase 2, and higher occupancy limits for Phase 3). On 20201117, indoor restrictions expanded, no more than 25 pct capacity and closed congregate areas https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.8.pdf. On 20210111, extends restrictions on retail under new Healthy Washington - Roadmap to Recovery regional plan, with every region beginning in Phase 1. In-store retail is limited to 25 pct capacity indoors. Curbside pick-up is encouraged. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.12.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery. Ended 20210630.

Statewide, restaurants can reopen for indoor and outdoor services across counties (though at different capacity levels across phases). From July to October, some changes in capacity and table size occurred across phases, and then were eased by 20201006: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Phase%202%20and%203%20Restaurant%20and%20Tavern%20Guidance.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Expands gathering restriction for Phase 3 counties, now limiting gatherings to no more than 10 people. Funerals, weddings, and religious activities are exempt from the new restrictions, which means the following continues: for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less. Phase 3 counties are 17: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston. Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Statwide, bars had to close indoor services unless some minimum food services were provided. Further expanded on 20201118, without the food service provision: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.8.pdf Extended to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions. Extended to 20210112: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.11%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Safe-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 counties, clarifying that up to 200 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue: up to 5 people can gather outside, for religious and faith-based services, indoor services can be at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 1.5 counties are now 5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima. Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed. Eased on 20201013 as Phase 1.5 counties move to Phase 2: https://twitter.com/GovInslee/status/1316143263309422592?s=20.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 2 counties, clarifying that up to 200 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue: gatherings of no more than 5 people, indoors and outdoors, for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 2 counties are 17: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, San Juan, Spokane, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom. Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed. On 20201013, Phase 1.5 counties move to Phase 2, which now has 22 counties: Adams, Benton, Chelan, Clallam, Clark, Cowlitz, Douglas, Franklin, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, Okanogan, Pierce, San Juan, Skagit, Snohomish, Spokane, Walla Walla, Whatcom, Yakima. https://twitter.com/GovInslee/status/1316143263309422592?s=20.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 3 counties, clarifying that up to 400 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue: gatherings of no more than 10 people, indoors and outdoors, for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people. Phase 3 counties are 17: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston. Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 counties, clarifying that up to 50 people may gather for a religious gathering indoors (or 25 pct capacity of venues, whichever is less). Previous gathering requirements continue: up to 5 people can gather outside, for religious and faith-based services, outdoor services can be at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 1.5 counties are now 5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima.

Eases restrictions on libraries for Phase 2 (and Phase 1.5) and Phase 3 counties. Permits libraries in Phase 2 (and Phase 1.5) counties, to provide in-person services and operate at 25 pct capacity, and permits libraries in Phase 3 counties, to provide in-person services and operate at 50 pct capacity.  Reexpanded on 20201117 to takeaway only statewide https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/SafeStartPhasedReopening.pdf. Restrictions on libraries are re-eased on 20210201 for both Phase 1 and Phase 2 counties: Libraries can reopen in person at 25 pct capacity. Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston move from Phase 1 to Phase 2. All other counties remain in Phase 1 https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/roadmap-recovery-metrics Further eased on 20210322 as all counties enter Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/HealthyWashington.pdf Extended to 20210630 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03

Persons arriving in Washington from other states or countries, including returning Washington residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. Coded as Mandate 0 because this is a recommendation.

Expands gathering restrictions, prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity, while outdoor gatherings follow phase requirements (Phase 3 permits 400)

Expands gathering restrictions, prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity, while outdoor gatherings follow phase requirements (Phase 2 permits 200)

Statewide, zoos and aquariums must close indoor services, as must gyms and fitness centers. Outdoor fitness classes may occur at no more than 5 people at a time. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions. Extended to 20210112: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.11%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Safe-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery. On 20210111, Extends restrictions for zoos and aquariums under new Healthy Washington - Roadmap to Recovery regional plan, with every region beginning in Phase 1. Indoor services are prohibited except for private tours. Outdoor establishments (zoos, stadiums, etc) can open for ticketed events only. Groups are limited to 10 people and max 2 households. Restrictions for fitness facilities are eased https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.12.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry, added DateEased (for gyms) and added to PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide, indoor movie theaters must close. Drive-in movie theaters can remain open. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions. Extended to 20210112: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.11%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Safe-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery.On 20210111, extends restrictions on theaters under new Healthy Washington - Roadmap to Recovery regional plan, with every region beginning in Phase 1. Indoor movie theaters must close. Outdoor theaters can reopen open for ticketed events, max of 10 people in groups from 2 households. https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-healthy-washington-roadmap-to-recovery-229b880a6859
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry and added to PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide, restaurants must close for indoor services. Outdoor services and to-go services permitted, with no more than 5 people at a table and proper distancing between tables. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions. Extended to 20210112: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.11%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Safe-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery.

Expands gathering restrictions for outdoor religious gatherings, now permitting 200 people maximum or 25 percent capacity. Continues prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor and outdoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity. Joins phase 3 to phases 1 and 2, gathering restrictions are now the same across the state. Eased on 20201221, where 200 person limit for religious gatherings becomes a recommendation. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Continues prohibiting indoor non-religious social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor non-religious social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Phase%201%20to%203%20Religious%20and%20Faith%20Based%20Organization%20Guidance.pdf. Extended to 20210112: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.11%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Safe-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery.

Quarantine recommendation is expanded to mandate for any individual who has been present within the prior 14 days in any country where the SARS-CoV-2 variant 501Y.V is circulating, as listed on the Department of Healths website, including but not limited to the United Kingdom and South Africa. These individuals are prohibited from entering or being present in the State of Washington unless they quarantine until fourteen days (14) after arriving in the State of Washington. Continues recommending that persons arriving in Washington from other states or countries, including returning Washington residents, practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. On 20210301, quarantine madate is expanded to all air travelers arriving from outside the US, requiring travelers to follow CDC guidelines of producing a negative test or proof of recovery before boarding the aircraft. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-83.1.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery. Ended on 20210319 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID-19%20Travel%20Advisory%20-%202021.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Under new Healthy Washington - Roadmap to Recovery regional plan, every region is beginning in Phase 1. Extends restrictions for bars under Phase 1 of Healthy Washington plan, with indoor services prohibited and outdoor services permitted, must stop serving alcohol by 1100 pm. Requires a maximum of 6 people per table and 2 households per table, and bars can only be operational if they serve some kind of food (otherwise takeway only). All counties are in Phase 1 starting on 2021011. DateIssued is coded as 20210105 as the Healthy Washingotn plan was released then. The formal policy guidance was published on 20210108 and the proclamation was published and signed on 2021011 (and thus 2021011 is DateEnacted).

Eases gathering restrictions under Phase 1 of Healthy Washington plan, such that outdoor gatherings can have up to 10 people with a maximum of 2 households. Indoor gatherings remain prohibited. For religious gatherings, the 25 pct maximum capacity is still a mandate, the 200 person limit is a recommendation. We are therefore leaving the absolute religious gathering limit variables blank. All counties are in Phase 1 starting on 2021011. DateIssued is coded as 20210105 as the Healthy Washington plan was released then. The formal policy guidance was published on 20210108 and the proclamation was published and signed on 2021011 (and thus 2021011 is DateEnacted).

Eases fitness restrictions under new Healthy Washington - Roadmap to Recovery regional plan, with every region beginning in Phase 1. Gyms and fitness establishments are limited to low and moderate risk sports, and appointment-based excersise. Outdoor guided activities are also permitted. Limited to 1 patron per 500 sq ft. for indoor activies.

Eases restrictions on outdoor live entertainment under Phase 1 of Healthy Washington, but for ticketed events only. Groups are limited to 10, with a limit of 2 households. Also eases restrictions for outdoor recreation. Low and moderate risk sports permitted for practice and trainingonly (no tournaments). Outdoor guided activities, hunting,motorsports, parks, camping, hiking, biking, running, snow sports,permitted. All counties are in Phase 1 as of 2021011. DateIssued is coded as 20210105 as the Healthy Washington plan was released then. The formal policy guidance was published on 20210108 and the proclamation was published and signed on 2021011 (and thus 2021011 is DateEnacted).

Extends restrictions on restaurants under Phase 1 of Healthy Washington: indoor on-premises dining services are prohibited, with outdoor dining allowed, must stop serving alcohol by 1100 pm. Requires a maximum of 6 people per table and 2 households per table. All counties are in Phase 1 starting on 2021011. The DateIssued is coded as 20210105 as the Healthy Washington plan was released then. The formal policy guidance was published on 20210108 and the proclamation was published and signed on 2021011 (and thus 2021011 is DateEnacted).

For counties in Phase 2 of Healthy Washington, bars can open indoor at 25 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service/delivery at 11PM. Max 6 per table, limit 2 households per table. Bars can only be operational if they serve some kind of food (otherwise takeway only). Because this means bars can open indoors even if their revenue is less than 50 pct from food, we code this as easing bar restrictions, rather than just easing restaurants.
