As of 20210201, applies to: Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston.

For counties in Phase 2 of Healthy Washington, indoor gatherings are limited to 5 people (max 2 households) and outdoor gatherings are limited to 15 people (max 2 households). For religious gatherings, the 25 pct maximum capacity is still a mandate, the 200 person limit is a recommendation. We are subsequently leaving the absolute religious gathering limit variables blank. As of 20210201, applies to: Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston.

For counties in Phase 2 of Healthy Washington, outdoor live entertainment is limited to groups of 15 people and 2 households. Maximum 200 spectators. Outdoor recreation is limited to 200 spectators for low, moderate and high risk competitions. As of 20210201, applies to: Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston.

For counties in Phase 2 of Healthy Washington, indoor live entertainment, including zoos, aquariums, theaters and museums, can open indoor at 25 pct capcity, or 200 people, whichever is less. Fitness and training centers can operate indoor at 25 pct capacity. As of 20210201, applies to: Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston.

For counties in Phase 2 of Healthy Washington, restaurants can open indoor at 25 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service/delivery at 11PM. Max 6 per table, limit 2 households per table. As of 20210201, applies to: Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Pacific, Pierce, Snohomish, and Thurston.

Phase 2 restrictions become statewide on 20210214, where bars can open indoor at 25 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service/delivery at 11PM. Max 6 per table, limit 2 households per table. Bars can only be operational if they serve some kind of food (otherwise takeway only). Because this means bars can open indoors even if their revenue is less than 50 pct from food, we code this as easing bar restrictions, rather than just easing restaurants. Starting 20210322, all counties enter Phase 3 of Health Washington, easing bar restrictions. Bars can open indoor at 50 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service and delivery at midnight. Max 10 people per table. Bars can only be operational if they serve some kind of food (otherwise takeway only). https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/HealthyWashington.pdf As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2 As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03

Phase 2 restrictions become statewide on 20210214, where indoor gatherings are limited to 5 people (max 2 households) and outdoor gatherings are limited to 15 people (max 2 households). For religious gatherings, the 25 pct maximum capacity is still a mandate, the 200 person limit is a recommendation. We are subsequently leaving the absolute religious gathering limit variables blank. On 20210309, adds an exemption for vaccinated individuals, who can gather indoors with other fully vaccinated people in private residences without wearing a mask. They can also gather indoors with unvaccinated people from one other household in private residences without masks, unless any of those people or anyone they live with has an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19. https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/department-health-adopting-cdc-guidance-safe-behaviors-post-vaccine

Phase 2 restrictions become statewide on 20210214, where outdoor live entertainment is limited to groups of 15 people and 2 households. Maximum 200 spectators. Outdoor recreation is limited to 200 spectators for low, moderate and high risk competitions. Starting 20210322, all counties enter Phase 3 of Health Washington, easing restrictions for outdoor live entertainment. Outdoor live entertainment is limited to a maximum of 400 spectators, with capacity restriction depending on facility. Walk-up tickets are allowed with restrictions. Outdoor recreation is limited to 400 spectators with capacity restrictions depending on the facility. Sports competitions and tournaments allowed at all risk categories. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/HealthyWashington.pdf As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2 As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03

Phase 2 restrictions become statewide on 20210214, where indoor live entertainment, including zoos, aquariums, theaters and museums, can open indoor at 25 pct capcity, or 200 people, whichever is less. Fitness and training centers can operate indoor at 25 pct capacity. Starting 20210322, all counties enter Phase 3 of Health Washington, where indoor live entertainment, including zoos, aquariums, theaters and museums, can open indoor at 50 pct capcity, or 400 people, whichever is less. As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2 As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03

Phase 2 restrictions become statewide on 20210214, where restaurants can open indoor at 25 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service/delivery at 11PM. Max 6 per table, limit 2 households per table. Starting 20210322, all counties enter Phase 3 of Health Washington, easing restaurant restrictions. Restaurants can open indoor at 50 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service and delivery at midnight. Max 10 people per table. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/HealthyWashington.pdf As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2 As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03

For unvaccinated individuals, indoor gatherings are limited to 5 people (max 2 households) and outdoor gatherings are limited to 15 people (max 2 households). For religious gatherings, the 25 pct maximum capacity is still a mandate, the 200 person limit is a recommendation. We are subsequently leaving the absolute religious gathering limit variables blank. Vaccinated individuals are exempt from gathering restrictions in private residences. Vaccinated individuals may gather indoors with other fully vaccinated people in private residences without wearing a mask. They can also gather indoors with unvaccinated people from one other household in private residences without masks, unless any of those people or anyone they live with has an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19. https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/department-health-adopting-cdc-guidance-safe-behaviors-post-vaccine As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2  On 20210503 introduces exceptions for vaccinated individuals in religious organizations. For religious gatherings, capacity restrictions are at 50 pct, but religious organizations are allowed to reserve sections only for those who are fully vaccinated or who have negative COVID-19 tests where groups do not need to be physically distanced six feet apart. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Religious%20and%20Faith%20Based%20Organization%20Guidance.pdf

Starting 20210322, all counties enter Phase 3 of Health Washington. Eases gathering restrictions where indoor gatherings are limited to 10 people and outdoor gatherings are limited to 50 people. For religious gatherings, capacity restrictions are eased to 50 pct. Vaccinated individuals are exempt from gathering restrictions. As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman go back to Phase 2 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-three-counties-rollback-phase-2 On 20210503 introduces exceptions for vaccinated individuals in religious organizations. For religious gatherings, capacity restrictions are at 50 pct, but religious organizations are allowed to reserve sections only for those who are fully vaccinated or who have negative COVID-19 tests where groups do not need to be physically distanced six feet apart. https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Religious%20and%20Faith%20Based%20Organization%20Guidance.pdf As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03. Ended 20210630.

Introduces exceptions for vaccinated individuals: For outdoor spectator events in Phase 2 (As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman are in Phase 2) the occupancy of the facility may not exceed 25 percent of seated capacity, or 200 people max, whichever is less. For very large venues over two acres in size, the capacity is capped at 300 people. For Phase 3 counties smaller facilities  are limited to up to 400 spectators maximum allowed at 50 pct capacity. In order to exceed 400 spectators a facility must be able to accommodate over 400 spectators at 25pct capacity and capacity must not exceed 9,000 spectators total. Outdoor spectator facilities (including stadiums,  ballparks, motorsports racetracks, rodeos and similar venues with permanent or temporary seating) may add vaccinated sections until their total capacity is 50pct maximum or 22,000 people, whichever is lower, inclusive of both vaccinated and unvaccinated sections. Outdoor unvaccinated spectators cannot exceed 9,000 people.   Eased on 20210513 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Sporting%20Activities%20Guidance.pdf  As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03 Eased on 20210526 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Spectator%20Event%20Guidance.pdf. Ended 20210630. .  Ended on 20210630.

Introduces exceptions for vaccinated individuals: Indoor facilities (indoor arenas, indoor sports facilities, indoor performance and event facilities) may add vaccinated sections until their total capacity is 50pct maximum, or maximum 2000 people, whichever is lower, inclusive of both vaccinated and unvaccinated sections. Indoor unvaccinated spectators in Phase 2 (As of 20210416 Cowlitz, Pierce, and Whitman are in Phase 2) cannot exceed 200 people, or 300 for rooms greater than 100,000 square feet of space—and indoor unvaccinated spectators in Phase 3 cannot exceed 400 people, or 600 for rooms greater than 100,000 square feet of space. Fitness and training centers continue to operate indoor at 25 pct capacity. Eased on 20210513 https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Sporting%20Activities%20Guidance.pdf As of 20210518 all counties are in Phase 3 https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-statewide-reopening-date-june-30-and-short-term-statewide-move-phase%C2%A03. Ended 20210630.

Extends business mask requirements, but introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who no longer have to wear masks in any indoor or outdoor settings (except for public transportation, health care settings like hospitals, long-term care, or doctors offices, correctional facilities, homeless shelters)Businesses retain the right to require masks in their establishments for staff and/or customers, and to ask for proof of vaccination. For unvaccinated individuals, (quote) No employee may work unless that employee wears a face covering when working, except when working alone or when the job involves no in-person interaction, as detailed in the Safe Start Washington Phased Reopening Plan, and, further, that employers must provide cloth facial coverings to employees (quote).  Eased on 20210630: require masks only for the unvaccinated in indoor public settings (including public areas of congregate living settings), though the vaccinated must still wear masks in a limited number of settings (health care settings like hospitals, correctional facilities, homeless shelters, and schools), and masks are not required in small private gatherings where only one unvaccinated household is present, provided that no one in that household is at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 (that is, has a medical condition listed by the CDC as high risk). The unvaccinated are recommended to wear masks in crowded outdoor settings where social distancing cannot be maintained. Exemptions for children under 5, persons with conditions that prevents wearing a face covering (e.g., medical, disability, mental health). In effect until rescinded or the end of the state of emegency. https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/Secretary_of_Health_Order_20-03_Statewide_Face_Coverings.pdf

Extends mask mandate but introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who no longer have to wear masks in any indoor or outdoor settings (except for public transportation, health care settings like hospitals, long-term care, or doctors offices, correctional facilities, homeless shelters). All unvaccinated individuals in Washington are required to wear face coverings when they are outside of their homes in public and non-public settings, explicitly requiring coverings in congregrate living setting (e.g., apartments) in hallways, elevators, etc and broadly outdoors unless exercising, outdoors with at least 6 ft distancing betwen non-household members. Exemptions for children under 5, persons with conditions that prevents wearing a aface covering (e.g., medical, disability, mental health). Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across indoor and outdoor settings. Eased on 20210630.

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are exempt from the requirement to wear a face covering and from social distancing requirements. Otherwise, bars can open indoor at 50 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service and delivery at midnight. Max 10 people per table. Bars can only be operational if they serve some kind of food (otherwise takeway only).

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are exempt from the requirement to wear a face covering and from social distancing requirements. Otherwise,   indoor live entertainment, including zoos, aquariums, theaters and museums, can open indoor at 50 pct capcity, or 400 people, whichever is less. On 20210630, restrictions on zoos, aquariums, theaters, and museums are ended.  Restrictions on other indoor events are eased: Eases restrictions on indoor live entertainment: (quote) Large indoor events are defined as any event with more than 10,000 simultaneous participants located in an indoors enclosed space. Large indoor events are restricted to 75 percent capacity, unless vaccination verification is occurring. If vaccination verification is occurring prior to entry, and the venue requires all attendees be vaccinated, there are no capacity restrictions. However, we will not allow vaccinated sections as a way to go above 75 percent capacity unless all attendees are vaccinated. No physical distancing requirements apply and attendees must follow the current masking requirements. We will reevaluate the restrictions on large indoor events on July 31, 2021. (quote)

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are exempt from the requirement to wear a face covering and from social distancing requirements. Otherwise, libraries in Phase 3 counties can reopen in person. If the building is less than 100,000 square feet, no more than 400 people or 50 pct of the buildings occupancy, whichever is less, is permitted. If the building is more than 100,000 square feet, no more than 600 people or 50 pct of the buildings occupancy, whichever is less, is permitted. Ended on 20200630.

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are exempt from the requirement to wear a face covering and from social distancing requirements. Otherwise, restaurants can open indoor at 50 pct capacity, and must end alcohol service and delivery at midnight. Max 10 people per table. Ended 20210630.

Eases mask mandate to require masks only for the unvaccinated in indoor public settings (including public areas of congregate living settings), though the vaccinated must still wear masks in a limited number of settings (health care settings like hospitals, correctional facilities, homeless shelters, and schools), and masks are not required in small private gatherings where only one unvaccinated household is present, provided that no one in that household is at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19. The unvaccinated are recommended to wear masks in crowded outdoor settings where social distancing cannot be maintained. Exemptions for children under 5, persons with conditions that prevents wearing a face covering (e.g., medical, disability, mental health). In effect until rescinded or the end of the state of emegency. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across indoor settings.

(quote) Governor Justice recommended that all West Virginians who are at the highest risk of having complications related to COVID – including seniors and those with chronic health conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease – avoid large crowds. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StateWide to 0 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure of all public pre-K to 12th grade schools, in effect on (quote) at the conclusion of the school day on Friday, March 13 (quote), and thus coded as enacted on 20200314. Community and private schools are recommended to follow this closure, but not mandated. Closure extended through the academic year on 20200421: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-announces-West-Virginia-schools-to-remain-closed-for-rest-of-academic-year.aspx Easing began on 20200608, permitting limited school-based activities
State of emergency declared for all 55 counties, no expiry provided.

Limited operations required (limited to take-away services): bars. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Easing began on 20200526: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf
(quote) Gov. Justice is continuing to encourage West Virginians to follow the guidelines presented Monday by President Trump to avoid social gatherings of more than 10 people (quote)
Closure required: casinos. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Note that order announcement occurred on 20200317 via press release. no expiry provided.

Limited operations required (limited to take-away services): restaurants. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Note that order announcement occurred on 20200317 via press release. Began easing on 20200504, allowing outdoor services: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-30-2020-Safer-At-Home-Order.pdf

Closure required: fitness centers, gymnasiums, recreation centers, and similar recreation locations. In effect at 1200 am 20200319, no expiry provided. Eased on 20200518: https://apps.sos.wv.gov/adlaw/executivejournal/readpdf.aspx?DocID=89852

Closure required: salons, barbers, nail salons, hair salons by 1200 am 20200319. Starts easing on 20200504: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-30-2020-Safer-At-Home-Order.pdf

Expands closure of businesses and venues where (quote) people tend to gather together in close proximity (quote), closing all state park lodges and the Hatfield McCoy Trail (ATV and jeep trails and corresponding lodging). Eases on 20200526, permitting state lodges to reopen as long as distancing occurs: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf
(quote) Gov. Justice also asked all citizens who have the ability to stay home to make doing so a top priority. (quote)

(quote) Any gathering of more than 10 people is prohibited unless exempted by this Order (quote). Religious gatherings are told that they should practice proper social distancing, and thus are exempted from the 10 person limit

(quote) Non-essential business and operations must temporarily cease operations (quote). Clearly expands on previous business closures (quote) in addition to those businesses directed to close or limit occupancy pursuant to previous executive orders (quote). Also very clearly closes the following: (quote) All places of public amusement, whether indoors or outdoors, including but not limited to locations with amusement rides, canivals, zoos, museums ... (quote) Further expands on 20200331, (quote) All state park campgrounds shall be closed. (quote): https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/SGovernor%27s20033014470.pdf Starts easing on 20200504: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-30-2020-Safer-At-Home-Order.pdf

Colleges and universities are only open for distance learning, but higher educational facilities can continue critical research provided that 6 feet of distance is maintained to the greatest extent possible. No clear expiry provided. Easing began on 20200608, permitting limited on-campus activities: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-signs-order-formalizing-May-30-reopenings,-WVSSAC-athletics-and-additional-sports-scheduled.aspx

(quote) all individuals within the State of West Virginia are under a general stay-at-home order and are directed to stay at home or their place of residence unless performing an essential activity (quote) In effect at 800 pm on 20200324. Ended on 20200504, with the mandate being replaced with a recommendation: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-30-2020-Safer-At-Home-Order.pdf

Gov. Justice also made it clear that while many across the country may be looking to West Virginia as a potential (quote) safe haven (quote) from the pandemic, that people coming from out-of-state, especially from Hot Zones like New York, (quote) should self-quarantine for 14 days. (quote) Also from the governor: (quote) We welcome you and will embrace you after those 14 days, but these guidelines and recommendations have got to be followed (quote).

(quote) All individuals who are travelling from areas with substantial community spread of COVlD-19, including without limitation Louisiana, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Italy, and China, are required to isolate for a period of 14 days upon entry to West Virginia or for the duration of their visit (quote). Ended on 20200521: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-19-2020.pdf

Expands gathering restriction to no more than 5 people to Berkeley, Jefferson, and Morgan counties. Between 20200404 and 20200414, the counties covered under this expanded restriction increased to Cabell, Ohio, Wayne, Wood, Marion, Harrison, Kanawha, Monogalia, Berkeley, Jefferson, Morgan, and Jackson. Started easing on 20200425, when Morgan was moved to a gathering restriction of 10 (the statewide policy): https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-24-2020-Morgan-County-Lifted.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: For restaurants (quote) require all employees to wear cloth face coverings at all times. Such coverings shall be cleaned or replaced daily (quote). Strongly recommends use of face coverings at personal care businesses that re-open. As more sectors reopen, employees are required to wear face coverings for many of them. On 20201114, with statewide mask mandate strengthening, requirements are expanded: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO%2077-20%20Face%20Covering%20Amendment.pdf

Gathering restrictions are now for no more than 25 people, easing previous restrictions of 10. Continues to exempt religious gatherings. Applies to counties that are not under the hotspot designation: Barbour, Boone, Braxton, Brooke, Calhoun, Clay, Doddridge, Fayette, Gilmer, Grant, Greenbrier, Hampshire, Hancock, Hardy, Lewis, Lincoln, Logan, McDowell, Marshall, Mason, Mercer, Mineral, Mingo, Monroe, Morgan, Nicholas, Pendleton, Pleasants, Pocahontas, Preston, Putnam, Raleigh, Randolph, Ritchie, Roane, Summers, Taylor, Tucker, Tyler, Upshur, Webster, Wetzel, Wirt, Wyoming

Eases non-essential business closures, allowing the following to resume operations: small businesses (e.g., home-based businesses, businesses with 10 or fewer employees, and/or those that have 50 or fewer customers per day) conditional on having no more than 2 people per 1000 sq ft at a time, barbers and cosmetologists (requires masks for all staff and employees, appointments only, distancing between stations), dog groomers (must follow small business requirements). Eased further on 20200521, requiring only 6 ft distancing now: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-19-2020.pdf Further eased on 20210306, permitting up to 100 pct capacity as long as physical distancing is maintained for small businesses and retail: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2021/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-loosens-restrictions-on-businesses,-social-gatherings,-and-youth-travel-sports.aspx  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Eases restaurants by allowing restaurants to have outdoor service: (quote) Restaurants and other facilities that prepare and serve food/drinks, but only for outdoor service and consumption on such property as the restaurant or other facility owns or has a right to occupy or use (quote).

(quote) all individuals are strongly encouraged to stay at home (quote). Special emphasis on vulnerable populations: (quote) Elderly and vulnerable populations, including those who are 65 or older or have pre-existing conditions, are strongly encouraged to remain at home or their place of residence to the greatest extent possible (quote). Ends recommendation on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Drive-in movie theatres are permitted to reopen, conditional on following requirements for small businesses and outdoor dining. Coding as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel as it focuses on permitting re-opening with drive-in operations and patrons staying in their cars, etc.  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Fitness centers, gymnasiums, recreation centers, and similar businesses may reopen, conditional on strictly following guidelines (i.e., up to 40 pct capacity, requirements around social distancing, limited access to shared facilities, 40 pct of typical group classes). Further eases restrictions on 20200530, permitting pools to reopen: https://governor.wv.gov/Pages/The-Comeback.aspx Further eased on 20210306, permitting up to 100 pct capacity as long as physical distancing is maintained: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2021/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-loosens-restrictions-on-businesses,-social-gatherings,-and-youth-travel-sports.aspx Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

All counties are removed from the hotspot list, applying the 25 person limit on gatherings indoors and outdoors statewide. Eased on 20200605, with gathering limits increasing to 100: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO%2042-20.pdf

Further eases the restaurant restrictions, allowing now indoor seating to be able to resume at 50 percent capacity. At least 6 ft distancing required between tables, outdoor dining party size at tables are no more than 6 people. Eases on 20210220, increasing capacity limits to 75 pct: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-6-21-February-19-2021.pdf. Further eases restrictions on 20210306, increasing capacity up to 100 pct as long as physical distancing can be maintained: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-8-21-March-5-2021.pdf  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Eases bar restrictions, explicitly allowing them to re-open for on-premises consumption provided that indoor seating occpancy is no more than 50 pct of capacity. At least 6 ft distancing required between tables, outdoor dining party size at tables are no more than 6 people.

Further eases restrictions, permitting state lodges alongside state campgrounds to reopen conditional on maintaining at least 6 ft distancing. Continues eased restrictions to permit indoor malls and similar facilities, as well as large/specialty retail stores to reopen. Requires no more than 2 persons per 1000 sq ft, 6 ft distancing. Also eases restrictions on various outdoor recreational rental and whitewater rafting companies, only requiring at least 6 ft distancing between groups, and does not expressly prohibit indoor interactions.  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Eases preK-12 school closures to permit WVSSAC-sanctioned athletics and band summer training program on school premises. Further eases on 20200622 to permit competitions: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-June-22-Reopenings.pdf

Eases college and higher education closures to permit low-contact athletics practice. Further eases on 20200622 to permit competitions: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-June-22-Reopenings.pdf

Eases restrictions on the following businesses, permitting to them to reopen conditional on the following: casinos (no more than 50 pct capacity, required 6 ft distancing) and theaters (both indoor and outdoor, with capacity limited to no more than the number of people who can be in a facility while adhering to 6 ft distancing).  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf
Any gathering of more than 100 people, unrelated to any Essential Businesses and Operations, is prohibited unless exempted by this Order.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and PolicySource, removed numeric gathering restrictions for religious gathering variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Press release involves governor recommendation of (quote) For crying out loud, wear a mask (quote)

Allows for the re-opening of amusement parks, fairs, and carnivals, per guidelines (i.e., social distancing requirements and occupancy requirements) Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

(quote) All individuals age 9 and over within the State of West Virginia shall wear an adequate face covering when in confined, indoor spaces, other than when in ones residence or when actively engaged in the consumption of food and/or beverage, and when not able to adequately social distance from other individuals who do not reside in the same household (quote). Coded to Mandate2 as it applies broadly to indoor settings. Expanded on 20201114, eliminating clause for when social distancing can occur indoors: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO%2077-20%20Face%20Covering%20Amendment.pdf

All bars in Monongalia County shall not allow on-premises consumption of food or drink, and thus bars are limited to take-away or delivery only. In effect until 1201 am on 20200724. Extended to 20200831 on 20200819: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-62-20-August-19-2020-Mon-County-Bars-5.pdf On 20200831 these restrictions are ended, allowing bars to be open subject to requirements (such as 50 pct capacity limit) https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-provides-opportunity-for-student-athletes-in-orange-counties-to-play-immediately.aspx. Now bar policy reflected in statewide BarRestrict row.

Expands the 100 person limit to a 25 person gathering restriction on both indoor and outdoor gatherings. (quote) All public and private gatherings of any number occurring outside a household are prohibited. ... Any gathering of more than 25 people, unrelated to essential businesses or operations, is prohibited unless exempted by this order. (quote) No expiry provided. Does not apply to religious gatherings. Eased at the state level on 20210220: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-6-21-February-19-2021.pdf
Reinstitutes closure of the following: fairs and carnivals. Eased on 20210325 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-9-21-March-24-2021.pdf

Slightly eases restrictions to permit one-person live music performances in outdoor or open-air settings, as well as larger live music performances held as drive-in events outdoors. Eased on 20201006: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-74-20-October-5-2020.pdf

(quote) Face coverings are required of all staff when they cannot provide instruction in a socially distanced manner (quote), and (quote) Unless medically waived, students grades 3 and above are required to wear face coverings when outside of their core classroom group or in congregant areas. (quote) On 20200821, these requirements are modified to vary by county risk level (which we are not currently coding separately): https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-provides-opportunity-for-student-athletes-in-orange-counties-to-play-immediately.aspx  Ended on 20210620 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-20-21-June-18-2021.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars in Monongalia, which may now reopen (up to 50 pct capacity indoors) subject to additional safety measures. Joins the rest of the state at this level of restricted operations (50 pct capacity indoors)

All bars in Monongalia County shall not allow on-premises consumption of food or drink, and thus bars are limited to take-away or delivery only. https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-65-20-September-2-2020-Mon-County-Bars-6.pdf On 20201013, restrictions are eased to 50 pct capcity, joining state-level restrictions: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-75-20-October-13-2020-Mon-County-Bars-7.pdf

Monongalia county is required to stay fully-remote for in-person instruction with no school-related extracurricular activities permitted in-person. From 20200908 onward, counties are added and removed from the red status fully remote requirements

Eight counties are in the orange category, which means they must stay remote for in-person instruction but limited extracurricular activities are permitted (i.e., marching bands must be outside, WVSSAC limited athletics). Orange counties are: Fayette, Kanawha, Logan, Mercer, Mingo, Monroe, Putnam, Wayne. From 20200908 onward, counties are added and removed from the orange status requirements

Of the 55 counties in West Virginia, 46 were permitted to re-open for in-person instruction due to their yellow or green designation. Some additional limitations for yellow counties (i.e., limited assemblies and large group activities), all requiring masks for grades 3-5 on buses and congregate settings. Coding as InPersonAllowed under SchoolRestrictLevel but not ending yet. On 20200915, gold category is added to this grouping: https://wvde.us/west-virginia-department-of-education-issues-new-gold-edition-school-alert-system-map/ Counties are added and removed from this level of permitted in-person instruction since 20200908

Expands the 25 person limit to a 10 person gathering restriction on both indoor and outdoor gatherings for any county that is in any of the Red, Orange, or Gold color categories. No expiry provided. Does not apply to religious gatherings. As of 20200916, red counties are: Kanawha, Monongalia. Orange counties are: Boone, Fayette, Mingo, Putnam. Gold counties are: Cabell, Calhoun, Lincoln, Logan, Ohio, and Pocahontas. Since 20200916, counties have shifted from the 10 to 25 (and back) gathering restriction per the color-coding scheme (with first easing of counties moving back to 25 on 20200918): https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/default.aspx. Counties continue to go back and forth between gathering designations. Eased at the state level on 20210220: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-6-21-February-19-2021.pdf

Monroe moves to green status, where gathering restrictions are 25 for indoor and outdoor gatherings (religious gatherings exempt). Counties keep going back between 10 and 25 gathering limits based on map updates. Eased at the state level on 20210220: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-6-21-February-19-2021.pdf

Eases restrictions on live music performances such that they can occur indoors but only for simulcast, broadcast, or remote audiences where no audience is present for indoor performances. Continues the following: live one-person music performances in outdoor or open-air settings can occur, as well as larger live music performances held as drive-in events outdoors. On 20210217, further eases restrictions, permitting up to 50 pct capacity seated without vocals or wind instruments: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-5-21-February-17-2021.pdf Further eases restrictions on 20210325 permitting them to occur without capacity limits, as Section 4 of EO 9-20, as amended, relating to prohibited activities, is hereby terminated and of no further effect. These activities are now considered essential activities and may operate in accordance with all applicable health and safety guidelines (e.g., Limit facility occupancy as necessary to ensure proper social distancing may be maintained between patrons who do not reside together or did not otherwise arrive together, up to 100 pct of seating capacity to the extent square footage and/or seating permits), https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-9-21-March-24-2021.pdf  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars in Monongalia, which may now reopen (up to 50 pct capacity indoors) subject to additional safety measures. Joins the rest of the state at this level of restricted operations (50 pct capacity indoors). Eases on 20210220, increasing capacity limits to 75 pct: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-6-21-February-19-2021.pdf Further eases restrictions on 20210306, increasing capacity up to 100 pct as long as physical distancing can be maintained: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-8-21-March-5-2021.pdf  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

School restrictions are now statewide. Requirements in orange, gold, yellow, and green counties expand to join red counties, allowing only remote instruction. (quote) From Jan. 4 through Jan. 15, counties will move to remote learning, and educators will use this two-week period to prepare for the return to in-person instruction. (quote). DateExpiry coded as 20210119 since that is the day (Monday) when school should be back in session.

Eases school closure for grades pre-K to 8 in all counties and for grades 9-12 in all counties other than red (orange, gold, yellow, green). Students will continue in-person learning five days a week. Ended on 20210324 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-10-21-March-24-2021.pdf

Eases school closure for grades pre-K to 8 in red counties. Grades 9-12 in red counties must close to in-person instruction. This is not a remote-only policy because grades pre-K to 8 may continue in-person instruction in red counties. Ended on 20210324 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-10-21-March-24-2021.pdf
Eases gathering restrictions to permit up to 75 people indoors and outdoors for social gatherings. Exempts religious gatherings.

Eases restrictions on gatherings to permit up to 100 people indoors and outdoors (was previously 75 people) for social gatherings. Exempts religious gatherings. Ends all restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-12-21-April-19-2021.pdf

Concert and music halls, adult entertainment venues may resume operations on 20210325 as Section 4 of EO 9-20, as amended, relating to prohibited activities, is hereby terminated and of no further effect.These activities are now considered essential activities and may operate in accordance with all applicable health and safety guidelines (e.g., Limit facility occupancy as necessary to ensure proper social distancing may be maintained between patrons who do not reside together or did not otherwise arrive together, up to 100 pct of seating capacity to the extent square footage and/or seating permits)  Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Fairs and carnivals may resume operations as of 20210501. Must follow applicable health and safety guidelines, but updated guidance is not yet available. Ends restrictions on 20210420 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are no longer subject to the requirement to wear face coverings when indoors. For unvaccinated individuals, businesses and organizations continue to be required to comply with public mask restrictions by posting signage and enforcing mask requirements. (quote) All individuals age 9 and over within the state of West Virginia must wear an adequate face covering when in confined, indoor spaces (quote). Ended on 20210620 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-20-21-June-18-2021.pdf

Introduces exemptions for fully vaccinated individuals, who are no longer subject to the requirement to wear face coverings when indoors. For unvaccinated individuals,(quote) All individuals age 9 and over within the state of West Virginia must wear an adequate face covering when in confined, indoor spaces, where other individuals may be present, regardless of ones perceived ability to social distance from one other (quote). Coded to Mandate2 as it applies broadly to indoor settings. Ended on 20210620 https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2021%20Executive%20Orders/EO-20-21-June-18-2021.pdf

Public Health Emergency declaration, which designates Department of Health Services as the lead agency to respond. No formal expiry included in order, but such orders expire after 60 days according to Wisconsin statutes, so coded as 20200511. Not renewed before expiry, so this declaration expired 20200511.

in effect 20200318. Order was for all public and private Wisconsin schools, with an anticipated re-opening for in-person instruction on 20200406. Closure of public and private K-12 schools for the 2019-2020 school year. On 20200416 this was extended to 20200526. https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/04/16/file_attachments/1428995/EMO28-SaferAtHome.pdf. Guidance from Dept of Ed on 20200622 provides for the reopening of schools in the Fall, devolves all decision making to district and school level, ending formal school closure: https://dpi.wi.gov/education-forward/returning-schools/the-foreword
in effect at 1201 am on 20200317. Explicitly includes places of worship and religious gatherings under this order. In effect for as long as the public health emergency is in effect
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: All bars were closed on 20200317

Effective as of 5 pm 20200317, prohibits gatherings of more than 10 people. No formal expiry date, indicates in effect for as long as the public health emergency. No exemptions for religious gatherings.
Indoor shopping malls must close. No formal expiry date, indicates in effect for as long as the public health emergency
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNoes, Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Gatherings of more than 10 in a single room or confined or enclosed place are prohibited, and the order expressly lists theaters, movie theaters, museums, stadiums, arenas, exhibition centers, health and fitness centers, recreation centers. Coding as a closure with indoor services permitted, requiring no more than 10 people on premises at a time (and thus substantially affecting business operations)

Effective as of 5 pm 20200317 all restaurants shall close for in-person services. Take out or delivery service is allowed. Extended to 20200526. WI supreme court ruling ended EO 28 and thus restaurant restrictions on 20200513. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.

Eases restrictions on bars, wineries, and breweries to allow for take away services. Appears to be a clarification that had the effect of changing the level of BusinessRestrictLevel, rather than an intentional easing. No seating or consumption of food/drinks indoor or outdoor is allowed. Extended to 20200526 but restrictions on bars ended with the WI supreme court ruling on 20200513.
Requires the following to close: close-contact personal services: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, body art establishments, and tanning facilities

Expands gathering restrictions. (quote) All public and private gatherings of any number of people that are not part of a single household or living unit are prohibited (quote). Exception provided for religious facilities, which allow up to 10 people to gather. Ended by WI Supreme Court Ruling on 20200513: https://www.wpr.org/sites/default/files/wi_legislature_v._andrea_palm_-_decision.pdf

In effect at 8am on 20200325 non-essential business and operations must cease.Began easing on 20200424: https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EMO28-SaferAtHome.pdf WI Supreme court ruling ended EO 28 and thus NE business closure on 20200513.
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose under BusinessRestrictLevel, updated DateEased, updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: WI Supreme court ruling ended EO 28 and thus stay at home order on 20200513. Currently coding as ended for 20200513, but may change in the coming days.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200526 and DateEnded to 20200513

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions for public and private golf courses. Clubhouses and pro shops must remain closed. On 20200511, operations at drive-in movies can resume. WI supreme court ruling ended EO28 and thus restrictions on NE businesses. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.

Eases business closures for library. Curb-side pick-up of books and other library materials is allowed. On 20200427, eases restrictions on what constitues minimum basic operations for non-essential businesses: allows for curbside drop-off and pick-up of good and animals, outdoor rental of recreational equipment. WI supreme court ruling ended EO28 and thus restrictions on NE businesses. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.

Eases restrictions on some businesses, allowing standalone or strip mall-based retail stores with an entrance or entrances to the outside may offer in-person shopping for up to five customers at a time. WI supreme court ruling ended EO28 and thus restrictions on NE businesses. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.
Governor encourages Wisconsinites to wear masks via radio address

Declares Public Health Emergency, effective for 60 days. On 20200922, extended for 60 days until 20201121. https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/09/22/file_attachments/1552234/EO090-DeclaringPublicHealthEmergency.pdf Extended to 20210119: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/11/20/file_attachments/1607583/EO095-DeclaringPublicHealthEmergencyNov2020.pdf. Extended to 20210320 https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO104-DeclaringPublicHealthEmergencyJan2021.pdf. Extended to 20210405 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2021/02/04/file_attachments/1684995/EO105-PHE.pdf. Ended with Wisconsin Supreme Court decision on 20210331: https://www.wicourts.gov/sc/opinion/DisplayDocument.pdf?content=pdf&seqNo=352043.

Every individual aged 5 years and older shall wear a face covering if the individual is indoors or in an enclosed space, other than a private residence. Face coverings are strongly recommended in all other settings, including outdoors when it is not possible to maintain physical distancing. Exemptions for individuals with conditions that would prohibit safe mask use, during speech (including religious) when at least 6 ft distancing can occur. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel due to its broad applications indoors but only recommendation outdoors. On 20200922, extended for 60 days until 20201121. https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/09/22/file_attachments/1552176/EmO01-SeptFaceCoverings.pdf Extends to 20210119: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/11/20/file_attachments/1607585/EmO01-NovFaceCovering.pdf. Extended to 20210320 https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EmO01-JanFaceCoverings.pdf. Again extended to 20210320 after state legislator repeals previous order https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EmO01-JanFaceCoverings.pdf. Extended to 20210405: https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EmO01-FebruaryFaceCoverings.pdf. Ended with Wisconsin Supreme Court decision on 20210331: https://www.wicourts.gov/sc/opinion/DisplayDocument.pdf?content=pdf&seqNo=352043.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry, added DateEnded, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Restrictions on bars are imposed at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus bar restrictions at the state-level are also ended.

Indoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 25 pct of the total occupancy for the room or building, and for indoor spaces without an occupancy limit for the room or building, public gatherings are limited to more than 10 people. Exemptions are child care settings, schools, healthcare settings, churches and places of worship, political rallies, etc. Ended on 20201023 with Supreme Court ruling against gathering restrictions put in place by EO3: https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350.

Restrictions are imposed on businesses at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor in-person services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus business restrictions at the state-level are also ended. https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350

Restrictions on restaurants are imposed at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus restaurant restrictions at the state level are also ended https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350

Recommendation on staying home. (quote) The best way you can help support our frontline healthcare workers and providers is by staying home as much as possible (quote). On 20201105, On a radio address, governor recommends the following: (quote) I know everyone is tired of all the court decisions whiplash, so here s the bottom line: stay home...Don t have people at your home who are outside of your immediate family or household. Don t host or go to gatherings with people outside of your immediate family or household. Limit your social interactions to a circle of 5, and start planning your holidays to happen virtually (quote): https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/WIGOV/bulletins/2aa3b4c On 20201111, Governor issues executive order with the following recommendation: (quote) All individuals should stay home as much as possible and only make trips when necessary, such as to go to work, pick up groceries, or refill prescriptions (quote) https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EO094-COVIDRecommendations.pdf

On a radio address, governor recommends the following: (quote) Don t have people at your home who are outside of your immediate family or household. Don t host or go to gatherings with people outside of your immediate family or household. Limit your social interactions to a circle of 5, and start planning your holidays to happen virtually (quote). Coding as a recommendation for no more than 5 people at gathering.

Via executive order, (quote) All individuals should....Avoid gatherings of any size between individuals who are not members of the same living unit or household, to the extent possible (quote). Coding as a recommendation with blanks in gathering limits, as we avoid coding 0 for non-mandated gathering restrictions.
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed Gath Limits and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Modifies gathering recommendation such that vaccinated individuals are now exempt, per new CDC guidance. (quote) If you are not fully vaccinated yet, DHS continues to advise against attending and hosting gatherings with people who don’t live with you and who are not fully vaccinated (quote).
Declares State of Emergency and Public Health Emergency. No clear expiry provided

Fourteen day quarantine for all individuals entering the state. Exceptions appear to be very strict: people passing through the state en route to another destination, citizens returning from receiving critical medical care in other states, parents transporting minor children for custodial purposes. Staff coming within 6 feet of customers or staff must wear a face covering in personal care services, gymnasiums, restaurants and bars. Extended to 20210126 https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/19th-Continuation-Public-Health-Order-1.pdf. Extended to 20210215: https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Order1_TwentiethContinuation_Jan212021.pdf. Also permits gyms to re-open under similar limits. Eased on 20200615, allowing up to 50 people at gyms: https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Sixth-Continuation-and-Modification-of-Statewide-Public-Health-Order-1.pdf Reexpands on 20201124, reducing gym limits and does further on 20201209: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1C6W9xONgVUvY3ILlSa3KQWnHtzI8lhrF/view Extends social distancing restrictions for personal care services until 20210126 https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/19th-Continuation-Public-Health-Order-3.pdf. Extended to 20210215: https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Order1_TwentiethContinuation_Jan212021.pdf (gyms) and https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Order3_TwentiethContinuation_Jan212021.pdf (personal care services). PolicyCodingNotes: Gatherings of more than 25 people prohibited. Does not include religious gatherings. The following and similar events can allow groups of up to 100 indoors and 250 outdoors under strict guidelines. (quote) These events include by way of example but are not limited to rodeos, speedway races, outdoor concerts, sporting events, fair, track and field races, farmers markets (quote), etc.

Expands restrictions on bars. The permitted number of persons at a table is now 6 persons (from 8). Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Bars are prohibited from operating from 10pm to 5am.

Expands gatherings rules, defines gathering as 10 people gathered (from 25). Gatherings of more than 10 are prohibited, but long list of exceptions provided. Includes all religious gatherings. However, events not specified in this order may allow indoor gatherings of more than 10 but no more than 25 pct capacity with a maximum of 100 people, and outdoor gatherings of more than 10 but no more than 50 pct of venue capacity with a maximum of 250 people. Allows for events like rodeos, farmers markets, fireworks shows, etc. of venue. Extended on 20210102 https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/19th-Continuation-Public-Health-Order-2.pdf. Extended on 20210126, but allows for (quote) events not specified in this order (quote) to have indoor gatherings up to 25 pct capacity with a maximum of 250 people, and outdoor gatherings up to 50 pct capacity with a maximum of 500 people. https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Order2_TwentiethContinuation_Jan212021.pdf.

Issues statewide mask mandate. All individuals shall wear a face covering when any person is inside, or in line to enter, any business or any goverment facility open to the general public, when any person is obtaining services at, or visiting healthcare operations, when any person is waiting for or riding on public transportation. Exceptions include children under 12, people with medical conditions, and people eating at a restaruant while seated. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel due to its broad applications indoors. Extended to 20210126 https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/First-Continuation-Public-Health-Order-4.pdf. Extended to 20210215: https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Order4_SecondContinuation_Jan212021.pdf. Extended to 20210301: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Ot446Cav1KXMkPIHT109Yt7SIZwHG_Nj/view. Extended to 20210316: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1XS5EBzuUwlsFdK9kvuFtn3FGLttBpWJ4/view

Expands restrictions on restaurants. The permitted number of persons at a table is now 6 persons (from 8). Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Restaurants are prohibited from operating from 10 pm to 5 am.

Curfew no longer applies to bars. The permitted number of persons at a table remains 6 persons. Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Curfew no longer applies to restaurants. The permitted number of persons at a table remains 6 persons. Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Ended on 20210316 https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Order1_23rdContinuation_March122021.pdf

Eases gatherings restrictions. Defines gatherings as 25 people in an indoor or outdoor space. Gatherings of more than 25 are prohibited, but long list of exceptions provided (including exemptions for all religious gatherings). However, events not specified in this order may allow indoor gatherings of more than 25 but no more than 25 pct capacity with a maximum of 500 people, and outdoor gatherings of more than 25 but no more than 50 pct of venue capacity with a maximum of 1000 people.

Eases gatherings restrictions. Defines gatherings as 50 people (from 25 people) in an indoor or outdoor space. Gatherings of more than 50 are prohibited, but long list of exceptions provided (including exemptions for all religious gatherings). However, events not specified in this order may allow indoor gatherings of more than 50 but no more than 25 pct venue capacity with a maximum of 1000 people (up from 500), and outdoor gatherings of more than 50 but no more than 50 pct of venue capacity with a maximum of 2000 people (up from 1000).

Eases gathering restrictions: (quote) This Order removes the personal gathering restriction but continues to apply restrictions/requirements to large indoor events of more than 500 people (quote). Indoor gatherings of more than 500 people are limited to 50 pct capacity. Includes mask protocols for large events. Restrictions and limitations on outdoor gatherings are removed. Includes long list of exceptions provided (including exemptions for all religious gatherings). The use of face masks is recommended in indoor public places and when physical distancing cannot be maintained among people who do not live in the same household.
Recommends use of face coverings indoors when six feet of distance cannot be maintained. Applies to teachers, students, school staff, and visitors.
